webTitle: Hick waits anxiously

fields.headline: Hick waits anxiously
fields.standfirst: 11 February England's build-up is going well but elsewhere in Sri Lanka preparations are behind schedule
fields.trailText: England's build-up is going well but elsewhere in Sri Lanka preparations are behind schedule
fields.body:
This England set-up can be appropriately ruthless. In Colombo, for example, there has been no cosy introduction to cricket on the senior tour for young Jason Brown. He's been ferrying the drinks since arrival and in all probability he will have to wait until 1 March - after the first Test - for a proper bowl. The selectors opted for Robert Croft as their spin partner for Ashley Giles, trusting in Croft's greater experience and his batting potential, and the Welshman has been given every chance to get his game in order. Brown can only look on and reserve paceman Matthew Hoggard must be equally patient.

In fact Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain have left themselves just one decision to make prior to the first Test: whether to pick Michael Vaughan or Graeme Hick for the final batting slot. Vaughan had nudged ahead in this contest by scoring 57 accomplished runs in the first innings of the match against the President's XI - until yesterday when Hick, no stranger to the last-chance saloon, cracked 75 from 112 balls. Meanwhile Vaughan, caught sweeping, failed to score.

Hick's innings restored England's control of the match, a dominance driven home by Darren Gough's evening burst of three for 15. England should win comfortably; the home side still require an improbable 306 runs for victory on the final day with seven wickets remaining. More importantly Hick's knock, coming after two failures on the Sri Lankan tour, may have prolonged his Test career.

The temptation to restore Vaughan to the Test team is obvious. It stems partly from Hick's mediocrity in Pakistan. By contrast, in between his injuries Vaughan's temperament has impressed with vital innings at crucial moments at Centurion, Lord's and Headingley, all of which contributed to victory. Moreover the long-term view demands that Vaughan should be battle-hardened soon. The Australians are just around the corner; it would help if Vaughan was properly established in the team by then. And he is a marginally better bowler than Hick even if he's still seeking his first Test wicket.

Yet my guess is that after yesterday Hick will prevail for several reasons. Firstly selectors by nature have a conservative streak; this may not be a bad fault. There is a place for loyalty provided it is not too misguided - they weren't too loyal in the case of Ian Salisbury, who was rightly jettisoned from the tour party. Moreover they know that Hick has the potential to dominate against spinners in a manner beyond Vaughan's capability. What is so infuriating is that this rarely happens at Test level, though Hick did hit a century against Murali and Co in England's last match against Sri Lanka at The Oval in 1998.

The selectors may also be aware that Hick can't really be recalled again. The next drop is likely to be the last one. And there is one other factor. Hick, the most mild mannered of men, has never the less provoked so much vitriol in parts of the press that a human response from the decision makers might well be 'We're not going to yield to this stuff'. So they may stick by him longer than they would, ordinarily, have done. It will be an interesting decision and for Hick, at least, a crucial one.

Otherwise England's batsmen appear to be acclimatising well to Sri Lanka. The cornerstone of the batting line-up in Pakistan, Mike Atherton and Graham Thorpe, have yet to reach 50 on the tour but no one will be too bothered about that. Yesterday both spent about two hours at the crease and were fluent enough.

In the first innings Hussain hit his highest score for more than a year and Craig White has sustained the approach that was so effective in Pakistan. Marcus Trescothick is now a 'banker' and was allowed to rest during this game. There may be concern about Alec Stewart's frailty against the spinners. He was stumped for the second time in the match against the left-arm spin of Hettiarachchi.

Meanwhile Gough, who delivered a few ill-chosen words to two of the Sri Lankan colts in the first match of the tour, wisely let his bowling do the talking in the final session. In a brisk five-over spell he disposed of three young Sri Lankans to set up victory for the tourists.

webTitle: Blood clot insurance offered to air travellers

fields.headline: Blood clot insurance offered to air travellers
fields.trailText: Air travellers can now insure themselves to cover the cost of taking legal action against an airline in the event of death or injury from deep vein thrombosis.
fields.body:
Air travellers can now insure themselves to cover the cost of taking legal action against an airline in the event of death or injury from deep vein thrombosis.

In the wake of recent publicity surrounding the link between DVT and air travel, insurer Club Direct has altered its standard travel policy to include a provision which pays legal costs of up to £25,000 for passengers or their relatives to make a claim against an airline. The vast majority of travel insurance policies which cover legal costs exclude lawsuits against airlines.

'You are more likely to die from flight-induced DVT than you are from an air crash but most airlines do nothing to warn passengers of the risk,' said Club Direct managing director Brent Escott. He claimed the cover would apply to legal action against any airline which does not provide advice on reducing the risk of developing DVT on its flights.

However, travel law specialist Ian Skuse warned that in practice an insurance company will only pay out where it believes the case has a reasonable chance of success.

webTitle: Escape guide to cricket-crazy Sri Lanka

fields.headline: Sticky wicket
fields.standfirst: The Tamil Tigers may be lurking in the outfield, but the English are flocking to this exotic island for the Test series.  Robert Friedlander  on the delights in store
fields.trailText: The Tamil Tigers may be lurking in the outfield, but the English are flocking to this exotic island for the Test series. Robert Friedlander on the delights in store.
fields.body:
In one corner of the botanical gardens at Peradeniya near Kandy stands a lily-choked ornamental lake in the teardrop shape of Sri Lanka. And at the tip of the teardrop the Jaffna peninsula, stronghold of the Tamil Tiger separatists, has been blocked off and drained.

Jaffna has been out of bounds to most Sri Lankans since 1983, but curiously, tourism flourishes despite civil war and the threat of terrorism. Indeed, the thousands of Britons who will arrive during the next few weeks to follow England's cricket tour are expected to lift visitor figures towards the half-million mark this year.

Sri Lanka's ethnic war has had little impact on tourists, despite having lasted two decades. Thousands of lives have been lost as the Hindu Tamils have struggled against the Buddhist Sinhalese majority to establish a homeland in the North and East of the country. Although the LTTE - the Tamil Tigers' umbrella body - declared a month-long truce at Christmas (since extended by another month), government forces continue to battle through Elephant Pass, the strategic bottleneck at the foot of the Jaffna peninsula. All the while, the Norwegian government is trying to broker a peace deal - which does seem closer than at any time since the violence erupted.

Give or take the odd roadblock you would not notice the strife - unless you used the buses. The Tigers' favoured strike method inside enemy territory involves suicide bombers and their usual targets are crowded buses and bus stands, the aim being to intimidate the masses.

Few foreigners consider using Sri Lankan buses in any event - they are overcrowded and unreliable. Fewer still drive themselves. The average Sri Lankan driver sees a six-lane highway where the tourist sees a two-lane road and overtaking that water tanker on a blind bend is a matter of national pride. The only thing to do is to hire a car and driver - at around $US20 a day - and look at the scenery.

Then there is the railway. Train trips along the coast or into the central highlands offer views no other mode of transport can - though booking ahead and first-class tickets are a must. Even second-class guarantees only standing room, no fun on the 12-hour Colombo to Badulla stopper.

This is the island which gave the word 'serendipity' to the world, but it's no happy accident that one religion brings the whole population together. Sri Lanka is cricket crazy and victory in the 1995 World Cup only confirmed that. The game is everywhere: on television (almost daily); all over the papers (twice daily) and on every open space in every city, town and village, every waking hour of every day.

If cricket is king, one man is king of kings and, perhaps, the best single hope of lasting religious tolerance. Muttiah Muralitharan, the off-spinner with the freakish wrist action, is a Tamil and the star performer in a team of Buddhists.

'I am a human being. The fact that I am a Tamil doesn't matter,' he once said. There are those who claim the man with the bent elbow is superhuman. He recently reached 300 Test wickets, faster than anyone apart from Dennis Lillee, and looks a sure bet to set a world record for Test victims. And his 19 million compatriots couldn't care less about his ethnic grouping.

'Murali' is Sri Lanka's best hope of beating England in the forthcoming Test series, and his every ball will be cheered, whistled and roared on by thousands. England's 'Barmy Army' of travelling supporters will need to be in full voice to make themselves heard.

The Tests straddle three and a half weeks - time enough to do justice to a country the size of Ireland but which has more micro-climates than Europe, more than 400 species of bird and a thousand different shades of green. Lush is the word and it has nothing to do with Sri Lanka's fiery palm toddy, arrack.

Galle, in the south-west corner of the island, stages the first Test. The seventeenth- century Dutch fort encloses much of the town and makes a daunting backdrop to the cricket stadium. Paint-peeled windows and sea-damp walls cannot conceal the splendour of the houses and Dutch churches. But the real gem is the New Oriental Hotel, which is neither new nor oriental. The dining room is watched over by portraits of the last two British monarchs, the bedrooms are ropey, but the gardens are a delight - though you wonder about a clientele which merits a sign forbidding spitting in the pool.

Galle is in the middle of 120 miles of beaches and bays, mostly backed by hotels, guest houses and bars. The occasional quiet spot does exist - though it is generally tagged on to a colonial treasure recycled as an Elle Deco theme hotel. You can buy into a tropical dream for as little as $US70 a night.

Heading north, past the Sinharaja rainforest and through the big sky country of Horton Plains, you hit tea country: the central highlands around Nuwara Eliya. Here it is all hill clubs and golf courses with a Scottish Highlands look and - in relative terms - a climate to match.

Kandy, venue of the second Test, is set around an ornamental lake. Home of the tooth relic sacred to Buddhists, it is a bustling grid of weird and wonderful shops and hotels. Kandy forms part of the 'Cultural Triangle' with the temple complexes of Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa. It is also in striking distance of the stunning rock fortress of Sigiriya, the cave temples at Dambulla and a clutch of national parks flush with wild elephants, leopards, deer and monkeys. And birds everywhere.

Colombo, site of the last Test, is the commercial pulse of the island; it is a busy city full of banks and grand buildings, chain hotels and smart bars.

It is also home to more than a million people, many of them desperate to see their heroes beat the touring side. So quiet it will not be. But then, if you want quiet and you want to avoid all that sunshine and high humidity, you can hang on until the county season starts in England. It is only a few weeks away, and there is sure to be plenty of space around the grounds.

Top tips for the Test

GALLE (First Test)

Top hotel
Small: The Sun House. Beautiful, intimate but airy town house, Colonial feel, tasteful décor and a swimming pool in a frangipani orchard. Tel: 00 94 9 22624
Large: The Lighthouse. Modern 57-room hotel on coast west of city; superbly designed, with any numbers of bars, restaurants, pools. Tel: 00 94 9 23744

Top restaurant
Closenburg Hotel, east of Galle city. Good food, beautiful views.
Top bar
Hundreds of them along beaches either side of city; Lion beer and a tube of mosquito repellent are all you need.

Top tip
Have a sundowner at the Rampart Hotel after walking round the walls of the old town. Don't pay what the three-wheeler taxi (tuk-tuk) drivers ask. Be prepared to haggle - though not too much.

KANDY (Second Test)

Top hotel
Small: Stone House Lodge. Granite-built spacious and graceful house with half a dozen rooms and a master bedroom overlooking a tranquil garden and the distant Knuckles mountain range; large library and marvellous food including the best breakfasts in Sri Lanka. Tel: 00 94 8 232769
Large: Hotel Suisse. Overlooking lake opposite town, 100 rooms, most with a/c, and good public spaces including snooker room; Lord Mountbatten's wartime HQ boasts good gardens and a fine pool. Tel: 00 94 8 233025

Top restaurant
Queens Hotel (opposite Temple of the Tooth) has good restaurant; for Chinese food try Flower Song (Kotugodella Vidiya) and, for home cooking, the splendidly named Sharon Inn (Saranankara Rd).

Unnamed pub next to Queens Hotel.

Top tip
Wear socks to visit the Temple of the Tooth. A honeymooning friend picked up a collection of verrucas which lasted longer than his marriage. A lot longer. Don't forget to pack a mac or buy a brolly. Those afternoon showers may bring relief, but they're torrential.

COLOMBO (Third Test)

Top hotel
Small: Mrs Padmini Nanayakkara's (a couple of rooms with entrance, attached bath, net and fan set in a lovely little garden near the hub of the city. Tel: 00 94 1 73095
Large: Plenty of big, plush numbers but the Galle Face Hotel has them licked. Full of history and character; huge rooms, good restaurants and great views from terraced bars across Indian Ocean and Galle Face Green. Tel: 00 94 1 541010

Top restaurant
The German Restaurant (Galle Face Court) for those who need a fix of pork and dumplings, draught beer and German wine.

Top bar
Colombo is full of great bars; all the leading hotels have bars and nightclubs, but the Cricket Club Café (Queens Rd) continues a theme, while architect Geoffrey Bawa's former office at the Gallery Café (Alfred House Road) is stunning, with food to match.

Satisfy your longing for a cappuccino or skinny latte at Odel (Lipton Circus) or Paradise Road (Dharmapala Mawatha) after you've scooped up armfuls of brilliant clothes and materials. Tyson Tours (01293 450600) has sold out for the first two Tests but has some places on a 17-day trip departing on 12 March to cover the Third Test and the one-day internationals. fields.bodyText: In one corner of the botanical gardens at Peradeniya near Kandy stands a lily-choked ornamental lake in the teardrop shape of Sri Lanka. And at the tip of the teardrop the Jaffna peninsula, stronghold of the Tamil Tiger separatists, has been blocked off and drained. Jaffna has been out of bounds to most Sri Lankans since 1983, but curiously, tourism flourishes despite civil war and the threat of terrorism. Indeed, the thousands of Britons who will arrive during the next few weeks to follow England's cricket tour are expected to lift visitor figures towards the half-million mark this year. Sri Lanka's ethnic war has had little impact on tourists, despite having lasted two decades. Thousands of lives have been lost as the Hindu Tamils have struggled against the Buddhist Sinhalese majority to establish a homeland in the North and East of the country. Although the LTTE - the Tamil Tigers' umbrella body - declared a month-long truce at Christmas (since extended by another month), government forces continue to battle through Elephant Pass, the strategic bottleneck at the foot of the Jaffna peninsula. All the while, the Norwegian government is trying to broker a peace deal - which does seem closer than at any time since the violence erupted. Give or take the odd roadblock you would not notice the strife - unless you used the buses. The Tigers' favoured strike method inside enemy territory involves suicide bombers and their usual targets are crowded buses and bus stands, the aim being to intimidate the masses. Few foreigners consider using Sri Lankan buses in any event - they are overcrowded and unreliable. Fewer still drive themselves. The average Sri Lankan driver sees a six-lane highway where the tourist sees a two-lane road and overtaking that water tanker on a blind bend is a matter of national pride. The only thing to do is to hire a car and driver - at around $US20 a day - and look at the scenery. Then there is the railway. Train trips along the coast or into the central highlands offer views no other mode of transport can - though booking ahead and first-class tickets are a must. Even second-class guarantees only standing room, no fun on the 12-hour Colombo to Badulla stopper. This is the island which gave the word 'serendipity' to the world, but it's no happy accident that one religion brings the whole population together. Sri Lanka is cricket crazy and victory in the 1995 World Cup only confirmed that. The game is everywhere: on television (almost daily); all over the papers (twice daily) and on every open space in every city, town and village, every waking hour of every day. If cricket is king, one man is king of kings and, perhaps, the best single hope of lasting religious tolerance. Muttiah Muralitharan, the off-spinner with the freakish wrist action, is a Tamil and the star performer in a team of Buddhists. 'I am a human being. The fact that I am a Tamil doesn't matter,' he once said. There are those who claim the man with the bent elbow is superhuman. He recently reached 300 Test wickets, faster than anyone apart from Dennis Lillee, and looks a sure bet to set a world record for Test victims. And his 19 million compatriots couldn't care less about his ethnic grouping. 'Murali' is Sri Lanka's best hope of beating England in the forthcoming Test series, and his every ball will be cheered, whistled and roared on by thousands. England's 'Barmy Army' of travelling supporters will need to be in full voice to make themselves heard. The Tests straddle three and a half weeks - time enough to do justice to a country the size of Ireland but which has more micro-climates than Europe, more than 400 species of bird and a thousand different shades of green. Lush is the word and it has nothing to do with Sri Lanka's fiery palm toddy, arrack. Galle, in the south-west corner of the island, stages the first Test. The seventeenth- century Dutch fort encloses much of the town and makes a daunting backdrop to the cricket stadium. Paint-peeled windows and sea-damp walls cannot conceal the splendour of the houses and Dutch churches. But the real gem is the New Oriental Hotel, which is neither new nor oriental. The dining room is watched over by portraits of the last two British monarchs, the bedrooms are ropey, but the gardens are a delight - though you wonder about a clientele which merits a sign forbidding spitting in the pool. Galle is in the middle of 120 miles of beaches and bays, mostly backed by hotels, guest houses and bars. The occasional quiet spot does exist - though it is generally tagged on to a colonial treasure recycled as an Elle Deco theme hotel. You can buy into a tropical dream for as little as $US70 a night. Heading north, past the Sinharaja rainforest and through the big sky country of Horton Plains, you hit tea country: the central highlands around Nuwara Eliya. Here it is all hill clubs and golf courses with a Scottish Highlands look and - in relative terms - a climate to match. Kandy, venue of the second Test, is set around an ornamental lake. Home of the tooth relic sacred to Buddhists, it is a bustling grid of weird and wonderful shops and hotels. Kandy forms part of the 'Cultural Triangle' with the temple complexes of Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa. It is also in striking distance of the stunning rock fortress of Sigiriya, the cave temples at Dambulla and a clutch of national parks flush with wild elephants, leopards, deer and monkeys. And birds everywhere. Colombo, site of the last Test, is the commercial pulse of the island; it is a busy city full of banks and grand buildings, chain hotels and smart bars. It is also home to more than a million people, many of them desperate to see their heroes beat the touring side. So quiet it will not be. But then, if you want quiet and you want to avoid all that sunshine and high humidity, you can hang on until the county season starts in England. It is only a few weeks away, and there is sure to be plenty of space around the grounds. Top tips for the Test GALLE (First Test) Top hotel Small: The Sun House. Beautiful, intimate but airy town house, Colonial feel, tasteful décor and a swimming pool in a frangipani orchard. Tel: 00 94 9 22624 Large: The Lighthouse. Modern 57-room hotel on coast west of city; superbly designed, with any numbers of bars, restaurants, pools. Tel: 00 94 9 23744 Top restaurant Closenburg Hotel, east of Galle city. Good food, beautiful views. Top bar Hundreds of them along beaches either side of city; Lion beer and a tube of mosquito repellent are all you need. Top tip Have a sundowner at the Rampart Hotel after walking round the walls of the old town. Don't pay what the three-wheeler taxi (tuk-tuk) drivers ask. Be prepared to haggle - though not too much. KANDY (Second Test) Top hotel Small: Stone House Lodge. Granite-built spacious and graceful house with half a dozen rooms and a master bedroom overlooking a tranquil garden and the distant Knuckles mountain range; large library and marvellous food including the best breakfasts in Sri Lanka. Tel: 00 94 8 232769 Large: Hotel Suisse. webTitle: Skiing on the Matterhorn

fields.headline: Champagne in the snow
fields.standfirst: A Victorian playground for high society has been refurbished as the ultimate in luxury. If only the sun would come out!
fields.trailText: A Victorian playground for high society has been refurbished as the ultimate in luxury. If only the sun would come out!
fields.body:
Ask anyone to name an Alpine mountain and the chances are they will say the Matterhorn. The Riffelalp Hotel stands smack in the middle of the Gornergrat ski area, with a view of the peak from almost every room. It was here, at 7,300ft, that the first Grand Hotel was built in 1884, quickly becoming the 'playground of European high society'. Gutted by fire in 1961, it had a decade as a three-star hostelry from 1988. Now the Riffelalp has been refurbished, expanded, indeed re-invented, to emerge as the five-star, 64-room Riffelalp Resort Hotel. This is as luxurious as it gets for mid-mountain accommodation.

As a 'Resort Hotel', rather than a mere hotel, it aims to cater for the visitor's every need. During our stay, which was dogged by poor visibility and high winds that limited skiing, this theory was well-tested. If the Riffelalp could keep us happy in these conditions, it would certainly satisfy us when the Matterhorn deigned to appear and the skiing opened up. They say the Matterhorn never shows itself to the first-time visitor or to those of a mendacious nature. As I had been to Zermatt before, only my veracity was at issue.

Facilities are sumptuous. Panoramic windows allow swimmers to survey the slopes from the wave-action pool or while relaxing after a sauna, 'wellness centre' treatment or session in the small gym. For white-out days, two tenpin bowling alleys are a surprising and amusing diversion. A nice touch is the provision of in-resort mobile phones for use around the slopes.

We stayed in the old 'Nostalgie' part of the hotel. Accessories in the luxurious en suite double room include a bedside console controlling lights, TV and curtains, but I searched in vain for the button which made the Matterhorn appear.

Bedrooms in the modern wing are chalet-style, with the main public rooms - the á la carte Alexandre restaurant and piano bar - being elegant, even lavish. Alternatives for dinner in the hotel are the cosy Walliser Keller for local specialities and Les Terrasses, with the feel of on-slope dining. Pre-dinner wine tastings are available in the cellar. The 'dine around' option offers guests 10 choices for dinner in Zermatt. After a drink in the arty Bar Kino we dined in style at the Mont Cervin.

The charms of Zermatt - its car-free streets, shopping and nightlife - are well known. Perhaps the only disadvantage - although some might say it is an advantage - is that the Riffelalp is 21 minutes above Zermatt on the Gornergrat railway. The last train back up the mountain is at 11.30pm, just when the village is beginning to hum. Up at the Riffelalp, evenings in the piano bar are restrained. 'A disco would spoil the feel,' said the manager. So if you crave Zermatt's après-ski, the Riffelalp may not be for you.

A Riffelalp shop is planned; but until it opens staff can arrange rapid deliveries - from toothpaste to specialist skis - from the village. This is perhaps less than ideal for avid shoppers. Even at the Riffelalp, it seems you can't have your cake and eat it; the seclusion defines the clientele.

Certainly it is perfectly placed for skiers. Zermatt's snow record is one of the best in Switzerland with 153 miles of piste on three linked ski areas, including the possibility of skiing over to Italian Cervinia. The hotel's ski hire shop has a small but reasonable selection of equipment.

On-mountain dining is excellent. We enjoyed the convivial atmosphere and superb cuisine of the Paradies chalet at Findeln. Champagne cooled in the snow while we waited for the Matterhorn to emerge from the stubborn clouds. But during our four-day stay it never did.

 The Swiss Travel Service (0870 727 5911) offers seven nights half-board at the Riffelalp from £1,386, including Swissair flights and the four-hour transfer with Swiss Rail. Booking direct with the Riffelalp costs from Sfr 480 (about £200) per double room per night. (www.lhw.com/riffelalp, tel 00 41 27 966-0555). A six-day ski-pass costs £123 and six-day ski hire is £56. Zermatt resort information

fields.trailText: Late bargains, chosen by Desmond Balmer.
fields.body:
Holidays

Istanbul

Internet bookers can grab four nights in Istanbul for £298 through cheapflights.com The offer, which is valid until 28 February, includes return British Airways flights, and four nights room-only at the four-star Mercure Hotel. Book online or phone 0870 010 7000.

At sea

Festival Cruises (020 7734 0005) has a one-off cruise departing on 4 May on the Mistral exploring the Caribbean before sailing across the Atlantic to Madeira and on to Genoa via Cadiz and Marseilles. Prices start at £945 - saving £550 - for an inside cabin (£1,395 for a mini-suite, a saving of £880). This includes flight to Guadeloupe and full board.

Benidorm

A week's full board at the three-star Orange Hotel costs £282 with Eclipse (08705 010203). Fly from Gatwick on 27 March.

Venice

Catch the carnival on a two-night break with Cresta (0870 161 0900) for £413. This includes flights from Gatwick on 23 February and two nights B&B at the four-star Colombina Hotel and flight from Gatwick.

Lisbon

Stay for two nights at the three-star Sana Classic Capitol for £199 with British Airways Holidays (0870 241 241 2). The price includes BA flights from Heathrow or Gatwick and breakfast. Valid until 31 March.

Bermuda

Save £72 on a week's self-catering at the Barnsdale apartments with Prestige (01425 480400). Price between 22 February and 24 March is £656 including flights from Gatwick and VIP transfers. Regional connecting flights from Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Manchester are available at £50 return.

Tunisia

Fly from Gatwick on 24 February for seven nights B&B at the four-star Hotel Jerba Palace on Djerba island for £289 with Advantage Travel Centres (0870 444 3493).

Flights

Sydney

Fly out on an Airtours charter and return on a scheduled airline for £399 with Austravel (0870 055 0223). This applies to Gatwick departures on selected dates in Feb, returning by the end of April.

Munich

Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 752 0066) offers flights with bmi British Midland from Manchester for £146 . Must stay on a Saturday night: valid until 28 February.

Buzz

The low-cost airline is holding a Valentine's Day seat sale on Wednesday for online bookers. Seats will cost £24 one way to cities such as Milan, Paris and Berlin for flights between 26 Feb and 31 March - Fridays and Sundays excluded. See www.buzzaway.com.

webTitle: Travelex Guide Book of the Year Competition shortlist

fields.headline: On guide patrol...
fields.standfirst: Toothbrush. Ticket. Travel guide. Most of us wouldn't leave home without one. But which is the best?
fields.trailText: Toothbrush. Ticket. Travel guide. Most of us wouldn't leave home without one. But which is the best?
fields.body:
The shortlist of five titles for the Travelex Guide Book of the Year competition, organised in association with The Observer and Books etc, has been named. The judges were looking for a book that would excite interest in a country while satisfying the need for practical information. The winner will be announced in Escape on 25 March.

The judges were Desmond Balmer, Travel Editor of The Observer; Gerry Conroy, Travelex's Group Director of Retail Operations; Jackie Crank, manager of the Broadgate branch of Books etc and Bing Taylor, managing director of Phoenix Press.

Cuba

Rough Guides, £10.99

As always from the series that won last year's award, this is the complete guide for the thinking traveller. The writing is enthusiastic and upbeat providing a fascinating cultural and political background. Everything is covered from music to sport. It will help find the hidden or alternative Cuba with no stone unturned ('take the left-hand fork at the petrol station'). This is especially helpful if you land in a small regional town where the state-run restaurants are poor. But this does make it the heaviest of the five guides shortlisted: 'I would read it before I travelled and take notes,' said Bing Taylor. A redesign gives a cleaner look but the small typeface is difficult to read.

Istanbul
Time Out, £10.99
A new edition from an established series. The writing is quirky but captivating. 'You can hear the author's voice,' said Jackie Crank. The maps are excellent (you wouldn't need to buy another one). The history of the city is told with a lightness of touch and a gentle humour in the sidebars: 'atta Turk!' about the founder of modern Turkey, 'at the drop of a hat' about the fez and 'Uefa yes, EU no' about the links with Europe. As you would expect from Time Out , the listings are comprehensive but never boring. This was also the best mix of photographs and text. The cover is dull but, worse, the guide contains some naff local adverts. Any fears about this influencing the verdicts are soon lifted, however. Take this from the description of the Ceylan Inter-Continental: 'The style is brash, the tone set by a horrendous golden staircase spiralling its way upwards from the lobby area.' The hotel's advert on the inside back cover features a picture of the guilty staircase.

Costa Rica
The National Geographic Traveler, £12.99
The photographs, as you would expect from the National Geographic library, are outstanding. These are matched by personable writing ('I felt the rapport you might have with a good tour guide,' said Gerry Conroy) and thoughtful presentation. The book excited interest in this haven for wildlife. There were useful sections devoted to specific subjects - the world of butterflies, volcanoes and the grano de oro (the coffee bean of gold). The maps were clear and the regional guides provided a sense of place equipping the reader to plan a visit. The range of the listings for hotels and restaurants seemed limited and there was no phrase book or food glossary. The high production values made this good value at £12.99.

Hiking in the USA
Lonely Planet, £14.99
An interesting move by Lonely Planet into new terrain, an enticing guide to the Great Outdoors, an often overlooked aspect of the American experience. 'This is something I wouldn't normally think about but it made it seem possible. By the end I thought, I'm going,' said Jackie Crank. The introduction sets up the history and geography of the westward expansion of the United States with good detail about the flora, fauna and wildlife. The layout and mapping have been thoughtfully assembled. The only drawback was the sheer volume of information required for day-by-day trekking. The project seemed too ambitious - who is it aimed at? It felt more like a reference book.

New York
AA Spiral Guide, £9.99
Sharp bite-sized information, ideal for the quick trip. The spiral format was enjoyed, thanks to the good paper quality. 'You can keep it in your pocket as you travel around,' said Gerry Conroy. Some of the detail was excellent, as were the walking map guides. Read this on the plane over and you could learn how to avoid the queues at the base of the Empire State Building or find the hidden Campbell apartment bar with its Tiffany stained-glass windows at Grand Central Station. Yet some of the judgments seemed uneven: 'They've recommended the worst restaurant in Brooklyn,' said New Yorker Bing Taylor. 'And do we need to know what a hot dog looks like?'

These are matched by personable writing ('I felt the rapport you might have with a good tour guide,' said Gerry Conroy) and thoughtful presentation. The book excited interest in this haven for wildlife. There were useful sections devoted to specific subjects - the world of butterflies, volcanoes and the grano de oro (the coffee bean of gold). The maps were clear and the regional guides provided a sense of place equipping the reader to plan a visit. The range of the listings for hotels and restaurants seemed limited and there was no phrase book or food glossary. The high production values made this good value at £12.99. Hiking in the USA Lonely Planet, £14.99 An interesting move by Lonely Planet into new terrain, an enticing guide to the Great Outdoors, an often overlooked aspect of the American experience. 'This is something I wouldn't normally think about but it made it seem possible. By the end I thought, I'm going,' said Jackie Crank. The introduction sets up the history and geography of the westward expansion of the United States with good detail about the flora, fauna and wildlife. The layout and mapping have been thoughtfully assembled. The only drawback was the sheer volume of information required for day-by-day trekking. The project seemed too ambitious - who is it aimed at? It felt more like a reference book. New York AA Spiral Guide, £9.99 Sharp bite-sized information, ideal for the quick trip. The spiral format was enjoyed, thanks to the good paper quality. 'You can keep it in your pocket as you travel around,' said Gerry Conroy. Some of the detail was excellent, as were the walking map guides. Read this on the plane over and you could learn how to avoid the queues at the base of the Empire State Building or find the hidden Campbell apartment bar with its Tiffany stained-glass windows at Grand Central Station. Yet some of the judgments seemed uneven: 'They've recommended the worst restaurant in Brooklyn,' said New Yorker Bing Taylor. 'And do we need to know what a hot dog looks like?'

webTitle: Labour on the road to the polls

fields.headline: Labour on the road to the polls
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: February
fields.body:
February

The Hammond inquiry: If Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz are found guilty of wrongdoing, rows over sleaze will quickly follow. If they are cleared, Labour faces embarrassment as Mandelson argues he was sacked for no reason.

March

Budget, 6 March: the key to the whole campaign. If there are enough sweeties to tempt the voters without looking like shameless bribery, it will be the launch pad for election victory.

 The Dome: If the sale is safely nailed down by the end of March, that's an embarrassment safely buried. If it drags on, public patience, already at a low ebb, will snap.

April

Hospital waiting lists: If the figures are down by 100,000 on the 1997 total, Labour will have met its election pledge and can pose as the patient's friend; if the queues have gone up too much over the winter, another promise bites the dust.

 Inflation: If it stays under control, interest rates can continue their downward course, a key part of the feelgood factor, and crucial for businesses, which need to keep borrowing costs down. It also means convergence with the Eurozone is more likely.

 The pound: Manufacturers have been pummelled by sterling's strength against the euro, which has undercut their competitiveness when exporting to Europe. If interest rates continue to fall, so could the pound. Good for workers in Labour's heartlands, and for their middle-class bosses too.

 One of Gordon Brown's proudest boasts has been cutting unemployment. The outlook is unclear. Some figures say it is on the way up. Some on the way down. Monthly figures up to the election will be crucial for the Treasury if Brown is to play this as a trump card.

webTitle: Comment: why is nothing going right for William Hague?

fields.headline: Not even cold comfort for the Tories
fields.standfirst:
When so much seems to be going wrong for Tony Blair, why is nothing going right for William Hague?

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: When so much seems to be going wrong for Tony Blair, why is nothing going right for William Hague?
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
Much as I try to avoid inflicting gratuitous pain on my readers, imagine yourself as one of the clever young men at Conservative Central Office who spin and toil to make a success of William Hague. Last summer, the leader summoned you to offer advice on how to escape his awful predicament. With less than a year remaining before the election, what miracle can save the Tories from a thumping defeat? His job - and yours - depend on it.

In an attempt to cheer up your depressed leader, you dream up a fantastical scenario composed of the worst possible things that could afflict the Government. Given the swelling resentment about petrol prices, you think it's possible that fuel protests will erupt with a swiftness that brings the country to a halt and raises searching questions about Tony Blair's ability to govern.

No Tory should ever forget their favourite cliché: 'Events, dear boy, events.' Getting even luckier, a terrible rail accident combining with severe winter floods will sweep Britain into further chaos. Mr Hague does not look fully convinced that even this will be enough to make him liked.

So you tell him, though you know this is going to sound ludicrously optimistic, that there could also be a major resignation at the very heart of the Government. It would be wonderful for the Conservatives if Peter Mandelson were to be forced to resign from the Cabinet for a second time. And it would be even more brilliant if the Prime Minister's closest trusty then turned so vengeful against his former friends that he became a fire-ship rampaging through the New Labour armada.

By gum! A delighted William Hague slaps his stout Yorkshire thigh. Then the voters would rumble New Labour. If that concertina of catastrophes were to occur, the opinion polls would surely change.

So here we are. The countdown to polling day is now deafening, and all your predictions have proved dazzlingly correct. You should be the toast of Smith Square. An avalanche of apocalypses has indeed descended on Tony Blair. And the opinion polls have shifted in the most amazing way: Labour has extended its lead over the Conservatives.

The beginning of the explanation is the economy. For most people, in most places, doing most jobs, of which there are more than ever, things have never been better. Not if you are a steelworker whom Corus has declared surplus to its global requirements. But the real, after-tax disposable incomes of the vast majority have risen considerably since May 1997.

In his big speech last week, Tony Blair gave a remarkably candid account of the narrative of New Labour. The first phase of government was 'essentially one of reassurance'. He had to exorcise the ghosts of his party's historic failures, notably economic incompetence. The timidity of New Labour may be regretted - it has been a consistent theme of this column - but it is entirely understandable.

By this point in the life of every previous Labour Cabinet, they had been shipwrecked by economic calamity and were drifting on to the rocks of electoral defeat. It is a tribute to the success of that part of the story, a success for which Gordon Brown takes the largest share of credit, that economic stability is now so taken for granted. Uniquely for a Labour Chancellor preparing a pre-election Budget, Mr Brown's biggest migraine is not disturbing the markets by spending too much money.

Compared with their own prosperity, the voters take the John Prescott view of the soap operas of politics. The Mandelsonian histrionics are compelling and entertaining. Ultimately, though, it 'doesn't mean a damn' to the well-being of them and their families. I guess that the most unbearable thing for Peter Mandelson is that, since his defenestration, the Government appears to have actually become more popular.

The only man for whom this is even bleaker news is William Hague. The opinion pollsters, and the newspapers who employ them in the hope of creating a headline, are becoming anxious to find fresh ways of telling the familiar story of Tory plight. For the Daily Telegraph, Gallup hit upon the novel wheeze of asking its sample whether they agreed that William Hague 'comes over as a bit of a wally'. Two thirds - a massive 66 per cent - agreed. Less than a third - 31 per cent - disagreed. And that may be because some of them regard the Tory leader as a lot of a wally. On the more conventional question - who would you vote for? - respondents to that poll gave New Labour a staggering 21 per cent lead. Even allowing for a massive margin for error, that puts Tony Blair back in Number 10 with a majority in excess of 100.

This is not just because the Tories look like losers. It is also because they sound like losers. An undersung achievement of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown is to have put the Conservatives into intellectual retreat since the last election, and the Tories are still falling back as we approach the next one.

Time after time, issue after issue, the Tories are being forced to fight on Labour ground. The Conservatives have embraced independence for the Bank of England, conceded to the minimum wage, and accepted the Scottish Parliament and Welsh Assembly. It is a rare Conservative policy that lasts more than three months before bowing to Labour. Having said, only a matter of weeks ago, that they would scrap free TV licences and the winter fuel allowance for pensioners, the Tories have now decided that they dare not do either.

New Labour's greatest victory over the Conservatives has been on that most critical battleground - taxation and spending. At the last election, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown felt obliged to stitch themselves into the eye-wateringly tight spending restraints inherited from the Major government. At this election, the Tories feel compelled to say they would match Labour's plans for a large expansion in spending, not just on education and health, but also on transport and policing. In their most significant surrender of ground, the Conservatives have given up promising to make direct cuts to income tax, an abandonment of the Thatcherite holy of holies, executed by Michael Portillo, the man who was once her most devoted altar boy.

Ironically, I wouldn't put it past the cunning Mr Brown to respond by using his pre-election Budget to make some form of cut to one or more of the headline rates. This is just my inspired hunch. It's particularly inspired by how actively the Treasury is spinning to persuade newspapers to carry stories that there is absolutely no chance of a cut to income tax. The Chancellor's crew is brilliant at playing the expectations game on the media. The more I read that he won't do it, the more suspicious I become that Gordon Brown will make an income tax cut to win some voter-pleasing headlines on the eve of the campaign and plunge the Tories into further disarray and despair.

Imagine - if you can bear the pain one more time - that you are one of the desperate young men who advise William Hague. With less than three months left before the election, the leader is again begging you for miracles to save the Tories from a crushing defeat. Well, you speculate, the Chancellor might be arrested blagging a bank, Tony Blair could be caught in bed with Robin Cook and a meteor might wipe out all life on planet Earth. On second thoughts, you ignore the summons from Mr Hague - and slit your wrists instead.

 In the Channel 4/House Magazine Political Awards 2001 broadcast last night, Andrew Rawnsley's Servants of The People: The Inside Story of New Labour (Hamish Hamilton, £17.99) was voted Political Book of the Year

webTitle: Ageing Greek ferries still sailing in wake of disaster

fields.headline: Ageing Greek ferries still sailing in wake of disaster
fields.trailText: The Greek government has failed to address some of the safety problems facing its fleet of ferries.
fields.body:
Four months after the sinking of the Greek ferry Express Samina which claimed 82 lives, the Greek government has failed to address some of the safety problems facing its fleet of ferries.

Frewin Poffley, author of the newly-revised Greek Island Hopping guide , which last year picked out the 'decrepit' 34-year-old Express Samina as one to be avoided, said there were still ships operating on some routes which would not be granted a licence anywhere else in Europe.

On 26 September the Express Samina hit a rocky outcrop off the island of Paros and sank, the first incident involving passenger fatalities in Greek waters for 35 years. In the immediate aftermath of the tragedy the Greek government withdrew the operating licences of 65 ferries - almost half the domestic fleet - for failing safety inspections. All but seven of those ships are now back in operation.

'The government wanted to be seen to be doing something but it was a political decision rather than a safety-related one. Most of those ships had their licences suspended because of fire safety issues, but the real issue is the age of the ships,' Poffley said.

Among the measures announced last October are plans to reduce the age limit on ships from the current 35 years to 30 by the year 2006 and to lift the restrictions that ban foreign vessels from operating passenger services in Greece two years earlier than planned, on 1 January, 2002. The decision will allow ferry companies from other EU member-states to compete on the lucrative Aegean tourist routes.

In anticipation of the new competition, the Greek ferry companies have begun updating their fleets -20 new ferries have come into service in the last 18 months - and standards are improving but, for the coming summer, island-hoppers might do well to take Poffley's advice and avoid the 'tired old' Lalyssos and the Agios Rafail offering an experience which he describes as 'a cross between travelling on the back of a floating lorry and a building site'.

webTitle: Japanese encephalitis outbreak in Bihar, India

fields.headline: Japanese encephalitis outbreak in Bihar, India
fields.trailText: An outbreak of Japanese encephalitis (JE) is causing concern in Nawadah, Bihar, India. Between September and the end of December 2000 there were 77 cases and 19 deaths. This is the first laboratory confirmed Japanese encephalitis outbreak in this area. Preventive and control measures are in progress.
fields.body:
An outbreak of Japanese encephalitis (JE) is causing concern in Nawadah, Bihar, India. Between September and the end of December 2000 there were 77 cases and 19 deaths. This is the first laboratory confirmed Japanese encephalitis outbreak in this area. Preventive and control measures are in progress.

JE is transmitted by the bite of an infected mosquito. This viral infection occurs throughout South East Asia and the Far East. Often JE infection goes unnoticed (only 1 in 200 infections are thought to give rise to symptoms). In those who do get symptoms however, there is a high death rate, and a high incidence of permanent brain damage (approximately 30 per cent).

The highest risk areas are rural where rice and pig farming coexist. During and just after the rainy season (which varies from country to country) the risk is increased.

Long stay and rural travellers to these areas should consider vaccination against JE. All travellers should take steps to avoid mosquito bites.

webTitle: Choices

fields.headline: Choices
fields.trailText: Operatic revolution | Get thee to a nunnery | Watch the whales
fields.body:
Operatic revolution
The Bastille in Paris has been a symbolic place of assembly since the Revolution and was chosen by President Mitterand in 1982 as an ideal site for a new 'opera house for the people' - a stunning, controversial building every bit as operatic as its repertoire. Paris Travel Service (0870 727 5912) offers breaks to this world-class venue, with prices for one night at the 3-star Pavillon Bastille hotel (opposite the opera house) from £156 per person until the end of March, based on two sharing and travelling by Eurostar. Two nights are from £203. Parsifal, Peter Grimes, Tales of Hoffman and The Damnation of Faust are among future productions now booking. Tickets are about £70.

Get thee to a nunnery
A collection of New Zealand's most distinctive bed and breakfast properties, lodges and boutique hotels are brought together in Bridge the World's new 'Little Gems' brochure (0870 444 7474). The properties, ranging from sheep stations to a converted nunnery, feature only a handful of guest rooms and many offer home-grown produce and wines. Prices start at £22 per person per night at On the Edge Homestay, a property on the Coromandel Peninsula where every room overlooks the Pacific Ocean.

Watch the whales
P&O Portsmouth is offering nature lovers the chance to see and learn about dolphins, whales and sea birds in the Bay of Biscay on a series of minicruises to Spain. The ferry operator has teamed up with Shetland-based The Company of Whales and the Biscay Dolphin Research Project to organise special whale and dolphin watching trips this summer on board Pride of Bilbao, which opened the first ferry-based dolphin observatory in January. Marine-life researchers will accompany the three-night cruises which depart on selected dates between June and October. Prices from£89 per person. Contact P&O (0870 2424 999) or the Company of Whales (01950 422483).

Jungle fever
Would-be Jungle Janes (and Tarzans) inspired by the recent TV series about surviving in the jungles of Borneo should contact Explore Worldwide (01252 760 000). The adventure holiday specialist is offering a choice of three trips to Borneo, including a 21-day adventure (from £1160 pp). Highlights will include a journey by boat into the Bako National Park to view probiscis monkeys and monitor lizards, a stay in a traditional longhouse, walking in the foothills of Mount Kinabalu and watching the orang utans in the jungle sanctuary at Sepilok.

webTitle: 'Billy Elliot' payout for poor pupils

fields.headline: 'Billy Elliot' payout for poor pupils
fields.trailText: Working-class children will be given piano lessons, ballet classes and other traditional perks of a middle-class childhood under a revolutionary £35 million government 'credit' to level the educational playing field.
fields.body:
Working-class children will be given piano lessons, ballet classes and other traditional perks of a middle-class childhood under a revolutionary £35 million government 'credit' to level the educational playing field.

Education Secretary David Blunkett wants the state to make it up to the pupils left standing at the school gate while their wealthier peers are whisked off for after-school treats and coaching.

The 'Billy Elliot' revolution' aims to bridge the gap with up to £360 per pupil at some inner city schools to pay for activities broadening children's horizons and nurturing artistic talent - such as theatre visits, drama classes or music lessons.

'These ideas are a crucial contribution to targeting cash at youngsters and schools who need it most, to do what better-off parents or leafy suburban communities are already able to afford,' said one senior source.

Blunkett will tomorrow publish his blueprint for the future of schools, expected to promise new targets for raising standards among 11- to 13-year-olds. Trainee teachers will also have their student debts paid off by the Government if they stay in subjects where there are serious shortages such as maths and science, in an incentive to recruitment.

And the Excellence in Cities programme - turning around failing inner city schools and tempting middle-class parents to send their children - is expected to be extended to a third of all schools. This follows evidence that pupils' GCSE results improve faster where the scheme is used.

The theme of the plan will be an equal chance for every child through to university and beyond.

For the first time it will focus not only on improving disadvantaged children's exam scores and basic skills, but on their wider lives through the pupil learning credit scheme for cultural extras. Blunkett will make clear the activities for 11- to 16-year-olds - which could be after school or during the day - will open their eyes to an educationally stimulating world.

'Anyone who has been anywhere near a school to collect their kids, off to a piano lesson or ballet class or whatever, will have noticed the children that don't get to go, don't get any stimulation like that, and it's not the parents' fault - they just can't afford it,' said one source.

The scheme is reminiscent of the film Billy Elliot in which a boy from a working- class background takes up ballet, to the mockery of his family and classmates, only to turn out to be a star.

The number of £2,000 bursaries helping disadvantaged teenagers go to university will also be more than doubled.

Pupil learning credits will target up to 65,000 children from disadvantaged backgrounds from September.

Schools must have more than 35 per cent of pupils claiming free school meals to qualify and will get grants starting from £240 per child, rising to £360 for the worst off. The cash will be used by schools to set up clubs or pay for trips.

Ministers believe the two-year pilot scheme can give poorer children a chance to tap into undiscovered talents. Blunkett also wants all primary school children at least to have the chance either to learn a new sport or a musical instrument.

Meanwhile, Trade Secretary Stephen Byers will unveil plans making it easier for the founders of small businesses to bounce back if their start-ups fail. Honest people who go bankrupt through no fault of their own could be free to return to business within 12 months rather than after the present three-year quarantine. But malicious bankrupts who behaved dishonestly or recklessly would be banned from being directors of limited companies and forced to notify anyone with whom they have business dealings for a 15-year period.

webTitle: Leader: Don't ditch the comprehensives

fields.headline: Don't ditch the comprehensives
fields.standfirst:
All children deserve special schools

Education site
fields.trailText: Education, education, education declaimed Tony Blair dramatically in 1997. In the event there has been some improvement in academic results and some reduction in class sizes for primary school pupils. But the hard core of Britain's underperforming schools remains formidably intact.
fields.body:
Education, education, education declaimed Tony Blair dramatically in 1997. In the event there has been some improvement in academic results and some reduction in class sizes for primary school pupils. But the hard core of Britain's underperforming schools remains formidably intact; retention of able teachers is at crisis levels; and the middle-class flight from the state system remains unabated.

The Government's analysis, although it does not openly say so, is that the failure of the educational system is the failure of the experiment in comprehensive schools. Both Mr Blair and Education Secretary David Blunkett inveigh against mixed ability teaching and a lack of respect for excellence. Their aim is noble; to establish a first-class education system for all, so that even children from underprivileged backgrounds can succeed. And both men have - refreshingly - educated their children at state schools. But the difficulty is neither their values nor their ends. It is the means.

Tomorrow, the Government sets out its vision of Britain's educational future. Essentially it wants to break up the comprehensive system by doubling the network of specialist schools while targeting money on enabling working-class children to move to the better universities. The Observer supports the build-up of new investment, and welcomes bursaries and incentives for good universities to increase their intake from state schools. Indeed, there are already signs that Oxbridge is more determinedly recruiting from the state sector, perhaps the most serious challenge for a generation to the pre-eminence of private schools and their attractiveness to middle-class parents.

But we have very serious reservations about an emerging educational environment in which four out of 10 secondary schools will not be comprehensive. All too frequently their problem is not liberal teaching methods but the desperate socio-economic conditions of their catchment areas. With even the Office for Standards in Education last week acknowledging that many 11- to 14-year-olds are bored at school, the need may be to radicalise teaching methods rather than insisting on the old-fashioned merits of 'talk and chalk' - and to accompany that radicalisation with a massive infusion of resources directed at the poorest.

New Labour may weaken the stranglehold of the privately educated middle class on the top dozen universities, but the real issue remains the education of the mass of children. The investment in diversity should be taking place within the comprehensive framework, not beside it. Otherwise, the Government risks the creation of a two-tier state education system with remaining comprehensives regarded as even more second class than at present. Mr Blair and Mr Blunkett must locate their new science, language and enterprise schools not outside the comprehensive system - but within it.

webTitle: Can schools survive commercial drive?

fields.headline: Can schools survive commercial drive?
fields.standfirst: Under Labour, corporations are moving inexorably into the classroom. It started with 'free' computers - now they're running buildings and teachers, reports  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Under Labour, corporations are moving inexorably into the classroom. It started with 'free' computers - now they're running buildings and teachers, reports Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
It was meant to have been a perfect example of Tony Blair's public private partnership idyll. When the Prime Minister's team arranged for him to make a speech in his Sedgefield constituency to mark the tenth anniversary of Tesco's Computers for Schools initiative they could not have known it would come at the end of a week in which he had sacked his adviser, Peter Mandelson, and that the media would be snapping at his heels.

The supermarket chain's scheme, which has cost £62.5 million so far, is the longest running and among the most generous corporate funding projects in state education. Since 1992 more than 42,200 PCs, mostly bearing the Tesco logo, have been delivered to Britain's 25,000 schools through its customer voucher scheme.

This was the 'triumph' that Blair wanted to publicise in County Durham. But the event didn't quite go to plan. The Sedgefield primary school chosen as the venue had burnt down the previous weekend. Tesco hurriedly rearranged it at the local parish hall. And when Blair did roll up, he was hounded by questions about Keith Vaz and Nissan.

Events may have dampened the anniversary party and distracted the press but there is no escaping the growing private sector involvement in the country's schools.

State education has to look to the private sector for extra resources. And the private sector loves it to do so. Whether it is books from the Sun newspaper, or computers through Tesco, big companies are using schools to embed their brands in the minds of children and parents.

Nike, for example, is establishing a football coaching scheme that it hopes will eventually encompass half a million children. What will that do to the pressure on parents to buy a particular brand of trainers?

'Schools are the centre of a community,' said Robert Halhead, the public affairs director implementing telecoms giant NTL's schools strategy. 'We get the reputation for being a good corporate citizen. But it's not an esoteric, holier-than-thou thing. We're in business.'

For NTL, that means contributing to education action zones, which give failing schools the right to raise private sector money and receive matching funding from government. NTL is pushing hard to wire up schools. So far, it has reached 5,200, rivalling BT. High street banks are investing millions in sending schools CD-roms and games-type machines that teach personal finance, a subject now on the National Curriculum.

Royal Bank of Scotland deploys 4,000 staff in its education department and has gone into half of all English secondary schools. Goody bags full of branded accessories from sportswear companies are now increasingly common. And recently, schools have been offered 'Jazzy Books' - free classroom exercise books that carry advertising from soft drink companies, pop bands and sportswear groups. 'I thought if they're free, we'll have them,' said Penny Greenhalt, a primary school head in Hackney, east London. But she found them too commercialised, and 'I ended up throwing them away'.

But the no-cost books, computers and gizmos are only one prong of the private-sector assault. Aside from the action zones, government schemes to lever private capital into education authorities have mushroomed in the past three years, heralding a revolution in education provision.

Private companies on multimillion pound contracts now work with heads and education authorities to set attainment targets.

Outsourcing specialists organise everything from recruiting teachers to organising payrolls, ordering stationery and IT supplies, and maintaining classrooms. And it is in these areas that companies are beginning to flex their muscles. Last month the Department for Education and Employment confirmed that 20 local education authorities had either contracted out their back-office functions or were doing so.

For the City, education 'support' is a growth sector. Investors Chronicle has twice in the past two months highlighted Nord Anglia, the Cheshire education services specialist, as a 'group cashing in as authorities seek to outsource work.' The paper expected the firm's profits to 'grow at more than 30 per cent over the next two years'. Nord Anglia's chairman, former teacher Kevin McNeany, last month sold £510,000 worth of shares to Merrill Lynch.

Capital Strategies, the finance house, believes this sector will grow from £1.6bn today to £5bn within five years. Its education team managing director, Stan Patey, said Education Secretary David Blunkett had gone in 'quite hard to reform stagnation'. Asked whether outsourcing had saved money and demonstrated value, Patey said the work was in its infancy: 'You have to look at what they're doing in the prison service to see what is possible.'

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: 'Many heads have been so browned off with the service they have been getting that they'll take anyone. But are they value for money? Will they raise standards? The jury is out.'

WS Atkins, the company that agreed last month to provide the south London borough of Southwark with virtually all its education services - including building maintenance, payroll, hiring teachers and purchasing - has been told by schools minister Estelle Morris that further reform is likely.

For companies such as Atkins and Nord Anglia, education is a low-margin business. Returns are typically 5 per cent, although contracts last an average of eight years. The only way for outsourcers to make more is through greater penetration of the market. They 'cluster' their activity, so if a neighbouring borough has already gone this way, expect yours to be targeted. Inevitably there are fears that centralised contractors do not have sufficient local knowledge to provide services.

In Haringey, north London, parents, governors and the council itself have rejected two bids from outsourcing specialists, despite intense ministerial pressure that this was the only way to rescue a failing authority.

The bidders were Cambridge Education Associates and a consortium known as Ensign, consisting of Group 4, the security firm, and Tribal, run by Henry Pitman, a descendant of the creator of shorthand. Their bids were, respectively, £6.5m and £2.7m above the amount Haringey now spends on providing the services involved.

A Haringey education authority source said: 'If we go down that route, money which should go into classrooms will get diverted.'

Consultants have helped the borough to prepare for a new scheme - racking up bills that must run into millions, according to a union source.

Nearly 20 per cent of the more than £9bn committed by the Government since 1997 to rebuild schools is earmarked for schemes under the private finance initiative. Under this, private consortiums build schools and then receive rent from the local education authority for up to 50 years. These index-linked contracts eventually cost much more than direct state investment.

In Pimlico, central London, a long-running battle against a £35m PFI school has just ended with governors throwing out the scheme for fear that it would be too costly and that to help finance it, play areas would be lost.

But it is rare for schemes to be overturned. The Government is moving towards increased private-sector involvement in schools. From goody bags to curriculum support, the corporate classroom is in its infancy.

Class distinctions

Nord Anglia: Founded in the Seventies, the floated education specialist has contracts with 15 LEAs and is shortlisted for another three. Criticised for failing to act quickly enough in Hackney. Shareprice tipped for high growth. Worth £32 million.

Cambridge Education Associates: Fined £23,000 last November for failing to reach performance targets in Islington. Risks losing half management fee if targets not reached this year. Islington contract worth more than £100m over seven years.

WS Atkins: Has just won Southwark outsourcing contract. Has £148m PFI contract to build and manage schools in Cornwall, and is preferred developer to do the same in Kent.

Ensign: A consortium backed by Group 4 and Tribal Group. Tribal wants to float on AIM. Last year bought Sfe, an online education provider specialising in teacher training over the internet.

Amey: Last month this £1bn company signalled its intent to break into school services. In two years, Amey has transformed itself from construction specialist to a support services outfit.

webTitle: Restaurants: Zaika, London SW3

fields.headline: Zaika, London SW3
fields.standfirst: Kathryn Flett joins the cashmere-clad residents of Chelsea in their local curry house - Vineet Bhatia's Michelin-starred Zaika - and discovers the crown jewel of Indian restaurants
fields.trailText: Kathryn Flett joins the cashmere-clad residents of Chelsea in their local curry house - Vineet Bhatia's Michelin-starred Zaika - and discovers the crown jewel of Indian restaurants.
fields.body:
Telephone: 020 7351 7823
Address: 257-259 Fulham Road, London SW3
Dinner for two, with wine and including service, £110.

On Friday nights, I quite often seek post-deadline sustenance in an Indian meal delivered to my door (thanks to Classic Tandoori, London NW6, free delivery within a five-mile radius, praised by Fay Maschler, lovely peshwari nan). Sometimes, however, I might even make it out of the house and on to Westbourne Grove, where west London's lovers of no-nonsense Indian food divide into two camps: Khan's devotees or habitués of the Standard. Not quite born but certainly raised there, I'm a Standard girl myself. Such is my fierce devotion, indeed, that I've never quite managed to set foot in (the much prettier) Khan's a few doors down.

But the point I labour to make is that with certain cuisines, variety is not always the spice of life - indeed, surely for most punters the unctuous predictability of an Indian meal is an important part of its appeal. You can move from high street to high street around the country and it will be a bit like playing the Generation Game 's conveyor belt: 'Ah, chicken tikka masala, vindaloo, cuddly toy, sag aloo...' You don't really want surprises in an Indian restaurant, you want fuel and beer. However, I have just experienced a new benchmark in culinary decadence - not just the eating of a non-takeaway Indian on a Monday night, but a slice of truly Ghetto-Fabulous (Chelsea division) decadence: eating an Indian meal on a Monday night at the freshly Michelin-starred Zaika, wherein chef Vineet Bhatia creates miracles.

Zaika is a sitar symphony of beiges and browns, creams and biscuits, with leathery banquettes and tasselly cushions, a blast of a purple wall and waiters in chocolate-coloured Nehru jackets. There are two big rooms in which the tables are spaced at respectful distances. It's a warm, stylish space and, on this January Monday, heaving with the Chelsea Settlers - a stylish though not very warm collection of soignée blondes in their early thirties boasting a variety of Euro-accents, a wardrobe of milky cashmeres and Labrador-coloured suedes accessorised by vast, blindingly Klieg-like rings worn on French-manicured hands that don't do dishes. Plus, of course, their wives. It's not just another country down here in SW3, it's several other countries. Interestingly, the clientele includes the highest proportion of smokers I've seen in any restaurant for yonks.

Crunching on mini-poppadums, the partner and I pore over the menu for a very long time: descriptions are intriguing and choices hard. Eventually I settle on the jhinga khichdi - an Indian risotto with red onion and coriander topped with crispy prawn - and the titar mussalam - pheasant with black lentils, punjabi spices and new potatoes in a black-lentil sauce with morels.

After discovering that the scallops are off this evening (quite right, too, on a Monday), the partner opts for the dhunga machli tikka - tandoori-smoked salmon with spices, mustard and dill - and veinchinna mamsun - a spicy lamb masala, dry-cooked with powdered bay leaf, peppercorn, cinnamon and tamarind rice. On the side, we overindulge in a selection of rice, raita, cauliflower florets and paratha. Somehow, beer doesn't hit the right note, so we select a white wine that promises not to fight the impending flavour-fest.

And now to the boring bit: the superlatives. Of course, one expects a Michelin-starred kitchen to avoid cliché - but to do so with a cuisine that has, on these shores at least, become its own cliché is even more of a feat. Everything we ate managed to exorcise the ghosts of a thousand Indian meals past and reveal them to be, if they were lucky, merely tragically bludgeoned and abased versions of this meal. In the words of the partner, who was not only slightly stressed on arrival, but is also, professionally, a visual person: 'The taste of everything you eat always comes through the spices.' I couldn't have put it better myself.

Most of us like to think we know the meaning of words like tikka and biryani, but if they're being bandied about by Vineet Bhatia, it is probably best to unlearn everything. For instance, such was the intense subtlety - not, I think, a contradiction in terms - of the tandoori-smoked salmon that, in my book at least, 'tandoori' need no longer describe something made stringy and florid in an industrial-strength oven - even though I'm usually quite happy with stringy and florid.

But despite having done so at length, it is almost pointless (if not insulting) to compare Zaika with your local Indian - at this level one should really only compare like with like. Except that in this case there is no 'like' because I haven't been to Tamarind, the only other London 'Indian' with a Michelin star, thus Zaika must go it alone, boldly, as a first-class restaurant by anybody's standard (let alone the Standard's standard). If the kitchen can sustain this level of cooking, it will be worthy of another star next year.

In short, this turned out to be one of the very best meals I have ever eaten in London. And if further proof were needed, how often have you been seriously tempted by an Indian dessert menu? Take it from me, Zaika's aaam ki kheer - a deliriously scented confection of mango and coconut rice - is an all-singing, all-dancing Bollywood blockbuster of a pud, and all done in the best possible taste.

· Jay Rayner returns next week.

You can move from high street to high street around the country and it will be a bit like playing the Generation Game 's conveyor belt: 'Ah, chicken tikka masala, vindaloo, cuddly toy, sag aloo...' You don't really want surprises in an Indian restaurant, you want fuel and beer. However, I have just experienced a new benchmark in culinary decadence - not just the eating of a non-takeaway Indian on a Monday night, but a slice of truly Ghetto-Fabulous (Chelsea division) decadence: eating an Indian meal on a Monday night at the freshly Michelin-starred Zaika, wherein chef Vineet Bhatia creates miracles. Zaika is a sitar symphony of beiges and browns, creams and biscuits, with leathery banquettes and tasselly cushions, a blast of a purple wall and waiters in chocolate-coloured Nehru jackets. There are two big rooms in which the tables are spaced at respectful distances. It's a warm, stylish space and, on this January Monday, heaving with the Chelsea Settlers - a stylish though not very warm collection of soignée blondes in their early thirties boasting a variety of Euro-accents, a wardrobe of milky cashmeres and Labrador-coloured suedes accessorised by vast, blindingly Klieg-like rings worn on French-manicured hands that don't do dishes. Plus, of course, their wives. It's not just another country down here in SW3, it's several other countries. Interestingly, the clientele includes the highest proportion of smokers I've seen in any restaurant for yonks. Crunching on mini-poppadums, the partner and I pore over the menu for a very long time: descriptions are intriguing and choices hard. Eventually I settle on the jhinga khichdi - an Indian risotto with red onion and coriander topped with crispy prawn - and the titar mussalam - pheasant with black lentils, punjabi spices and new potatoes in a black-lentil sauce with morels. After discovering that the scallops are off this evening (quite right, too, on a Monday), the partner opts for the dhunga machli tikka - tandoori-smoked salmon with spices, mustard and dill - and veinchinna mamsun - a spicy lamb masala, dry-cooked with powdered bay leaf, peppercorn, cinnamon and tamarind rice. On the side, we overindulge in a selection of rice, raita, cauliflower florets and paratha. Somehow, beer doesn't hit the right note, so we select a white wine that promises not to fight the impending flavour-fest. And now to the boring bit: the superlatives. Of course, one expects a Michelin-starred kitchen to avoid cliché - but to do so with a cuisine that has, on these shores at least, become its own cliché is even more of a feat. Everything we ate managed to exorcise the ghosts of a thousand Indian meals past and reveal them to be, if they were lucky, merely tragically bludgeoned and abased versions of this meal. In the words of the partner, who was not only slightly stressed on arrival, but is also, professionally, a visual person: 'The taste of everything you eat always comes through the spices.' I couldn't have put it better myself. Most of us like to think we know the meaning of words like tikka and biryani, but if they're being bandied about by Vineet Bhatia, it is probably best to unlearn everything. For instance, such was the intense subtlety - not, I think, a contradiction in terms - of the tandoori-smoked salmon that, in my book at least, 'tandoori' need no longer describe something made stringy and florid in an industrial-strength oven - even though I'm usually quite happy with stringy and florid. But despite having done so at length, it is almost pointless (if not insulting) to compare Zaika with your local Indian - at this level one should really only compare like with like. Except that in this case there is no 'like' because I haven't been to Tamarind, the only other London 'Indian' with a Michelin star, thus Zaika must go it alone, boldly, as a first-class restaurant by anybody's standard (let alone the Standard's standard). If the kitchen can sustain this level of cooking, it will be worthy of another star next year. In short, this turned out to be one of the very best meals I have ever eaten in London. And if further proof were needed, how often have you been seriously tempted by an Indian dessert menu? Take it from me, Zaika's aaam ki kheer - a deliriously scented confection of mango and coconut rice - is an all-singing, all-dancing Bollywood blockbuster of a pud, and all done in the best possible taste. · Jay Rayner returns next week.

webTitle: Letters: Trafficking flaws

fields.headline: Trafficking flaws
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Giuliano Amato's pledge to combat people trafficking and illegal immigration (Comment, last week) fails to recognise that these issues are not the same and cannot be tackled by the same response.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Giuliano Amato's pledge to combat people trafficking and illegal immigration (Comment, last week) fails to recognise that these issues are not the same and cannot be tackled by the same response.

Human trafficking involves deceiving or coercing someone to move and enslaving them. Smuggling is about assisting someone for a fee to cross a border illegally. What is required is better treatment and protection of trafficked persons, a measure that is lacking from Blair and Amato's statement of action.
Elaine Pearson
Trafficking Programme Officer
Anti-Slavery International
London SW9
