I spent at least four hours helming - it's an amazing feeling, like being pushed over the top of a hill on a brakeless bike. The kettle's on. Time to go. The paella should be rehydrated by now. Day 11 Most of her rivals eat the flying fish that wipe themselves out on the boats - but Ellen is concerned about them. I can't let them die flapping on the deck, I have to throw them back in. As there are dozens of them, it's quite time-consuming. Day 13 Feeling sore. I feel well, though my hands are covered in tiny, but incredibly sore little salt sores. The hotter weather is not helping. They need to stay dry and cool - impossible factors on a 60ft baking oven. Day 15 Doldrums takes a grip. Just seen the most astonishing thing - a satellite I guess - coming hurtling down to earth. But I can't think anyone has sailed more slowly than us in the past six hours. Day 16 Leader Parlier crossed the equator yesterday. I crossed the equator at 01:25 GMT - celebrated with a bottle of champagne, most of it went on the boat not me - on purpose. I thanked Neptune for letting us pass, and prayed that all the other boats passed safely in both directions. Day 20 Leading pack continue to charge south, 800 miles east of Rio. After 20 days at sea, I notice we have covered over one fifth of the course. It is a very fast pace. I believe this race will be won by the most reliable boat, the one that can push enough, just for long enough - but still keep things together. Day 21 Gymnastics up the mast. I went for the rig check, which involves climbing the mast, and checking over everything up there before we plunge into the Southern Ocean. It's not easy alone, as the boat never wants to sit still, and there's no one to winch you up, nor ease you down. That's the hardest part of the exercise. We have a jumar arrangement, like climbers, where as I climb it goes up with me so I'm always attached - then a separate one I ease down with me (not so easy!). On the first attempt I discovered a problem with the genoa stay, which meant I had to go back up - already bruised, I was bit annoyed. When I was up there the wind picked up as I was on my way down. I could have walked down the mainsail if it had been windier. Once on deck I furled the genoa, and unfurled the solent - and prepared my tools for the second ascent. All was well - the boat a bit more stable - till I realised when about to go down that I'd left the second jumar in the cuddy. Bugger. Oh well, like the old clipper crews I scaled down the mast, stopping to re-do the solent stay on the way down. Day 26 Drama as kite gives way. There are always down moments and this is one of them. First off I noticed some chafe, which I knew I had to sort sooner rather than later, so I set to reinforcing and protecting the problem area. I made 720 bradawl holes and 720 stitches by hand and sorted out the tack problem. It was six hours of hard work, and my hands were really sore afterwards, but it was a success. Then, when we were off and going well, suddenly the kite gave way and went under the boat and in the water. I had to stop and haul my biggest sail back in, untangle it from the bowsprit and everywhere else until I finally had a pile of wet cloth on the foredeck. Repair's fine - when I get a chance to dry the whole thing out, I'll be able to see what the problem was. Once I had the gennaker back up I went down and just collapsed on the chart table seat and had a bit of a cry - but it was only because I was so tired. Day 29 I went partying last night! A good night. The sea temperature is now down to three Celcius and when on deck you can really feel the cold coming off it. I am getting very layered up now with the fleeces and linings and I wear a hat at all times. I went partying last night with the Royal Ocean Racing Club at their Christmas dinner. I phoned up and it was so fantastic to hear the 350 sailors there whooping and cheering at me down the line as I scooted along at up to 25 knots and then made loads of noise when we said goodbye. It was great, this is great. I am where I want to be. This is my dream. Thanks everybody! Day 30 Icebergs - a close call for Kingfisher. I awoke with a start from a short nap. I looked out of the window in the cabin and there it was - an iceberg right by the boat. Within seconds I was on deck, and we passed within 15 to 20 metres of the berg, actually sailing through the white water next to it. All I could think of was what would have happened if we had hit it. The radar was alarmed, but as is sometimes the case, this berg was invisible to it, even when I was right next to it. Day 31 Champagne again. Kingfisher passes the longitude of Cape of Good Hope - a quick sip from a bottle of champagne to celebrate. PRB retakes second place from Sill. Kingfisher is fourth. Feeling a bit achy and tired this morning, not sure why. It's cold, but I've got used to it. If I'm chilly, I just get on deck and start trimming the mainsheet with the winch grinder. I get to warm up and the boat goes surfing faster - perfect. Day 32 All change. Michel Desjoyeaux and PRB take the lead, with Sill in company. Parlier (Aquitaine) is becalmed in his very southerly position. Kingfisher slips to sixth place. Dominique Wavre smashes the 24-hour record just days after it was set by Yves Parlier, recording just under 430 miles in 24 hours. A month ago losing a couple of places like that in the official list would have really stressed me. But now I have a much better perspective, and the Southern Ocean. I'm racing my race, definitely noting what is happening around me, but taking care of my boat and me before anything else. Waves coming from all directions. It's amazing, we just pick up a wave, accelerate, gets faster and faster and just keeps on going. Day 36 Company alongside. It's very strange when you're thousands of miles from anywhere to suddenly see another boat. Yesterday, at first light, there was Toma Coville (Sodebo) alongside. He's been there all day, and I have to admit I'd rather be physically alone. It's different when it's the albatrosses. Feeling stressed. Day 38 Ellen cries herself to sleep. I really screwed up yesterday, I misread my notes and waited too long for the pressure to drop before gybing. Stupid fool - I was so p***** off I cried myself to sleep in my bunk, for the first time. So angry during night that I put up the genoa in 35 knots. Fast if nothing else... now blowing 40... time to roll it up! Day 39 The closest to death I have come. As I sit here now I feel worse than I have ever felt in my life. Physically I am totally exhausted, and mentally - not so far off. My whole body aches. My mind feels like it's been frozen. Yesterday was the hardest challenge of my life, though this morning feels 10 times worse. It started when the tack of the staysail blew off. I dropped the halyard immediately and went on to the foredeck to sort out the mess, not easy in 45 knots. It was then that she started to go - to gybe, and before I could make it back to the cockpit her deck was vertical, and we were lying helplessly on our side. A fairly bad situation to be in - but what was to come was far worse. I realised that I couldn't get the mainsail down to fix a problem with one of the battens, which had broken. Neither love, money nor the best will in the world was going to let me lower that sail without going up there to remove the batten. Going up the rig in 40 knots plus just doesn't bear thinking about. It was bitterly cold, the biting wind cutting into the bare skin on my hands and face. The first part, to the first spreader, was OK because I still had energy - but to the second spreader was 10 times harder with each inch I climbed. I was beginning to tire, as each wave we surfed on (about 10 meters high) was trying to throw me off. The last 2ft to the second spreader were the hardest 2ft of my life. I struggled to inch my way up, and hung there a while banging away at the mast trying to recover. I found the energy from I don't know where, and made it on to the spreader. You'd think getting down was the easy bit - but it took me closer to the edge than I wished to go. Each few inches I descended I had to take my weight with my hands, or legs, which proved exhausting. I arrived at one point with all my weight on my right wrist in one of the webbing loops on the sail. I hung there, banging into the mast, trying desperately, and unsuccessfully, to get my foot through the gap between the sail and the mast. I started to hurt badly. It took over an hour to get down - just 15 metres. I barely had the energy to put the sail back up again, then collapsed in the cockpit. As I dashed about working, my vision went funny - I was seeing stars permanently, as if I was about to black out. This morning was worse. I saw a rip in the genoa, along the foot. I tried to fix it. It was impossible. Even with the sail sheeted hard behind the main it flapped and flicked in my face, and ripped out the stitching I was trying to put in. After trying to fix that sail I was at my lowest point in the race. I cried out loud to the heavens. I am losing miles because of a stupid tear in a sail. So frustrating. I can't sleep, or switch off. Day 40 The world's a better place. Ached a lot when I woke this morning, but life is considerably better than 24 hours ago. I had to slow down for three hours to repair the genoa, but it's done - getting it fixed, at least for now, has done great things for my morale. Day 42 Kingfisher lies third after the dismasting, a day earlier, of Yves Parlier. He is OK does not need assistance from Ellen - who is finding life hard. I'm constantly on edge: I think the big winds are still 24 hours away. The guys farther back in the fleet have been experiencing 60-plus knots, so I know it's going to be a rough Christmas this year. Day 46 Damaged, exhausted new limits. I extended my limit. I'm battered, bruised and exhausted. A lost sail, a broken halyard, four hours at top of a mast to fix it. My forearms are shaking. Why? Why now? Why do this to me? The mainsail has to come down, then it's back up with it, with the last reserves of energy. Unfurl the genoa. Grind and grind on the pedestal to get it trimmed - 150sqm of sail powering up the boat again. Drag the remnants of the lost sail, soaked in freezing water, down the fore-hatch - to the sail graveyard. But it's not over The same halyard that holds the Code 5 sail up is used for the only other downwind sail she has left - the gennaker. What's left of the broken halyard is at the top of the mast and on the deck - with nothing in between. The only solution is to free climb the 25-metre mast, to twice the height of the same death-defying climb of a week ago, and make the repairs, then a painful descent. Day 47 - Christmas Day! Team office closed, Ellen and boat still open for business. She had more than 70 different people ring her to wish her well during a conference call. Day 50 Third-placed Ellen sails into the immense Pacific - albeit the Southern Ocean part, one of the world's most isolated regions. Next land that the skippers will hope to see will be Cape Horn. I've never seen squalls quite so violent ... in just over 24 hours' time we shall be on the same longitude as Auckland [where she was built]. I think Kingfisher is feeling she's close to home. Day 53 PRB had a 112-mile lead from Sill with Kingfisher, third, forced off to the south. I feel quite low now this is the hardest part for me - putting us in the right place. The worry, the constant fretting - the hours staring at a computer screen analysing and reanalysing till you are blue in the face. Guess this is what I lack - the experience. The experience of standing by a decision, and understanding it in a way different to I do now. Day 54 Tears on New Year's Day. Not the best of New Years. I've never cried so much in my life. I'm really not sure why I've been feeling so low. I'm very tired, and maybe I've not realised how much the past 50 days have taken out of me. This morning I lay in the cockpit and just cried for two hours. I've never done that in my life before, not like this... I don't seem to be able to sleep, and that of course is making it worse. I certainly miss my family and friends but I don't feel lonely. Day 56 Ellen's most testing time. Ten icebergs in one day. Never in my life before have I experienced such beauty, and fear at the same time - 10 icebergs so far today. They have ranged from 200ft in length, to about half a mile. The first was not a surprise, the second neither really - but when the third, fourth, fifth and sixth all appeared in a line with just a mile between them I was bewildered at their frequency. I wanted to gybe north, but ended up hand steering to pass three of the bergs to windward. I gybed between the fifth and sixth only to see the next two - the seventh being the most enormous of all... I was forced to hand steer to pass the seventh. It was enormous, and for a while I didn't think we'd make it to windward as the wind rose to 30 knots. We made it and I was then faced with the most beautiful iceberg I could imagine. Wide, blue, high-arched caves, and a height that must have been similar to the white cliffs of Dover. So quiet, apart from the waves breaking about its base. High faces of pure white harshly disfigured by deep blue cracks roughly cut from above. Every 10 minutes I stick my head out and look. Every time I dodge the flying freezing spray - squinting at the horizon till my eyes sting with the cold. I'd just made a cup of tea to try to thaw out when I thought I 'd have a last check. Of course there was a berg - stayed up there for half an hour... freezing cold, but eyes glued to the water for growlers (small pieces of ice that break off the main berg). Several times, despite trying to duck, the visor of my jacket is pounded by the waves. Frozen eyelids again. Day 58 Kingfisher moves into second place. Sailed yesterday under-canvassed. I should have had the reef out, but I know it was time to rest more than I have been doing. I have to build up my reserves. As a result of Sill's problems with the broken gennaker halyard, Kingfisher has managed to move into second place. Day 62 Big trouble for Kingfisher with PRB 500 miles ahead when the gennaker halyard breaks for the second time. I couldn't believe it suddenly the boat slowed and I just knew what had happened - once again my body feels like it has been dislocated in a dozen places. I had to work out the best plan to save the sail - at least when we were stopped we bought some time. As I stumbled across Kingfisher's rolling deck, seeing her sails down, I could not help but feel she resembled a wounded bird. I felt for her. I fought for an hour and a half to get it back on deck - on further hauling huge rips were present... My heart sank... again up the mast, and a repair that I'm not even sure is possible. Day 66 After a time going slow without the halyard, Kingfisher is back on track and Ellen finally passes the Cape two days and 17 hours inside Christophe Auguin's record pace from the 1996 event - and just over two days behind the race leader Michel Desjoyeaux. I feel overwhelmed. The stress and difficulties of the last few days seem to be melting into emotion as I approach the Horn. The second time for Kingfisher and me together. It's a great symbol for the two of us personally, as the very first time I was ever alone on her, was just a few miles from this famous rock. I cannot help but feel moved deep inside. The thoughts of the past storms and struggles are far off at this point. This race has been hard, but when I think of those here hundreds of years ago I feel very humble sitting here in my hi-tech wet-weather kit. For them, the corner was literally life or death. My heart goes out to all those who have struggled, survived and died on this piece of water. It's been a long haul since the launch in NZ, and the most incredible adventure of my life. It's far more than just the story of a girl alone at sea. For me it's a story of teamwork, friendship and love. The story of so many people working towards a goal, and if not working, willing us on... I feel there are so many others with me on board. I've never been lonely - far from it. Day 72 A low-pressure area forming between two highs, will bring back the South American cold front - who will gain most? If I run the routing software for all the [leading] boats it suggests we'll all be at a similar latitude in a few days... I've been having amazing dreams for much of the race. Yesterday I dreamt Richard Branson was on board, but I've no idea why. If someone could find out whether he likes milk in his coffee, and how much, that would be great - I'd love to know if my dream was factually correct or not! Day 75 Ellen closing in on PRB. The pressure is rising, in more ways than one... Kingfisher this morning is positioned just 50 miles to the south of PRB and still 200 miles to the west. Behind Ellen, Active Wear has closed to less than 200 miles. This morning feels like a new start. It's incredible... we've had little wind - and now, thank goodness, it seems in 36 hours we might be able to tack [signalling entry to the SE trade winds, to the north of the St Helena high-pressure system - the 'hole' that has been blocking the route of PRB for days now]. It's a constant job of looking at tacking, trimming, keeping going. Frustrating - we need new winds. Day 79 Kingfisher and PRB head for Doldrums. The mast-climbing is back. During the night Ellen's wind instruments failed (they work from a 'wand' at the top of the mast). A two-hour climb to top of the mast, drill and sandpaper in hand, and the DIY Queen of the Seas had it fixed. A day of varied winds and many sail changes. The temperature has increased further, and sleeping, especially during the day, is difficult. Despite exhaustion it is well worthwhile as Kingfisher is once again crossing the waves at her full potential... a great feeling. Day 80 Tough in the Atlantic, less than 300 miles from the Equator... almost too late to choose another position to cross. I've been hand-steering all night, the replacement wind instrument wand wasn't working properly... I've been preparing mentally for another climb. I'm tired, but now it's light I have to go and sort it out [which she then does]. I'm totally exhausted, my leg is black from the bruises, I've got scratches and holes all over me. It was brutal. Once I got to the top a rain squall came over, the boat half-gybed on its own seven times. The wind was all over the place. The only way I could get her back the final time was to try to flick the top of the mainsail over with my body so the wind would fill on the right side again... I just want to cry. Day 81 Back in the Northern Hemisphere - and just 26 miles behind PRB! Ellen's third crossing of the equator in 10 months. My body still aches quite badly and I definitely need to get more sleep. Mich not surprisingly took a few miles on me yesterday during the day, but while I was sleeping immediately after coming down from the mast, I was heading further east than before as I just left the genoa up, and so we've closed on longitude [east/west separation], which I didn't actually want to do. He has, of course, not left me much room for manoeuvre. As he hit the calms I was still going great but I know that whoever gets away first is going to stack the miles on. Day 82 Kingfisher ranked first! Ellen sailed to the top of the ranking during the night. The 03:00 positions put her three miles ahead, although nine miles to the south and further east than PRB - in the battle to exit the Doldrums. Mich and I are suffering here, we've done just 65 miles in 24 hours, it's desperate. I am very, very tired, having entered the Doldrums quite exhausted after climbing the mast... that wasn't the best way to start this battle with the calms. I guess I had no choice. Mich and I are very stuck. This is exhausting. Day 83 PRB touched the Trade Winds about 10 hours before Ellen and managed to get away to the north and west - now holding a 46-mile lead. Once I lost my westerly position I never had the opportunity to get back there. I'm still kicking myself for my mistake three days ago when I fell asleep after climbing the mast, and let the boat head farther east. I always wanted to be west, but that moment of fatigue lost me that advantage... I can't help thinking where I would be if I'd held that more westerly position going in to the calms. Day 84/85 The long route north. PRB, Kingfisher, Sill and Active Wear are possibly - for the first time in a month - all sailing in basically the same conditions. Then disaster (or something) strikes Kingfisher is damaged when she sails in to a solid object, suspected to be a semi-submerged container. She's left 79 miles behind PRB; 2,438 miles to go to finish for Ellen. All of a sudden there was the most almighty crunching sound and the boat felt like she had hit land. As I glanced behind to see what I had hit I saw part of the rudder and the daggerboard floating away. It was a gut-wrenching moment. I immediately ran through the boat, checking in all the watertight compartments that there was no water in there. There was obviously a big risk of having ripped the bottom of the boat open. The hull was fine, and it appeared that it was just the appendages [daggerboard, rudder] that were damaged... I will just try to do the best that I can. I promised that... could I still catch PRB? Big question. Anything can happen, absolutely anything can happen. Day 87 PRB slows as 'pressure' rises again. After four days of relatively steady sailing upwind in the Trades, PRB has started to feel the effects of the high-pressure system that blocks the route of the leaders. Ellen is 90 miles to his south and 40 miles east. This next 48 hours are going to be decisive. It's the last chance for anyone to pass I think. We seem to have been keeping our distance on third-placed Bilou I'm sailing a bit closer to the wind and accepting some speed loss, so at least I'm not just following Mich's tracks. Day 89 PRB extends lead as storm approaches. Where are they? They are now to the west of Madeira, heading towards Cape Finisterre, the final landmark before the finish at Les Sables d'Olonne. Annoying to see how far Mich has got away... I have a cargo ship near me, but I haven't been able to see it at all, so I have to keep a constant lookout for it. I know he's there from the Active Echo radar detector, but I don't know where exactly. Not very relaxing. Day 91 It's 7 February. Rough but Kingfisher is holding position. After one of the toughest 24 hours for Ellen, she is mentally exhausted. Sill is still trapped by lighter winds and is now at 400 miles from Kingfisher, and Activewear is even farther back at 900 from PRB. I'm on a new chart - even better, I'm nearly a third of the way up the chart towards Les Sables. Got to go - looks like my lashing on the radar, broken during the daggerboard removal exercise has come loose the radar is hanging down - got to try to save it. Day 93 Near disaster on the final lap - the genoa forestay main rigging holding the mast foreward fails. Ellen breaks a 36-hour silence on mishap. I didn't want to give Mich a reason to ease off, he could equally suffer gear failure if he pushes... and I didn't want to give Bilou a reason to attack harder. My heading and speed have dropped away compared with Mich, I decided it was time to share this bad news. I now have to focus on finishing in the top three - it's been a difficult 10 days. I'm ready to finish. Day 94 Patched Kingfisher second - end in sight. The wind has switched more south-west so although I'm sailing at a good speed of 13 to 15 knots, I'm making only 11 towards the finish. I look at the repair of the gennaker and pray - I'm surprised that it has lasted this long. Had the weirdest dream last night: we were all doing the Vendée Globe on bicycles! Don't ask me what I'm doing next after this race... congratulations to Mich.  Adapted from material provided by Mark Turner of Offshore Challenges. Related stories She won everything, except the race Le Professeur teaches the world to sail along Useful links Ellen MacArthur's site Kingfisher Challenges

webTitle: Grand Prix hits the pits

fields.headline: Grand Prix hits the pits
fields.standfirst: Bernie Ecclestone's latest smoke and mirrors manoeuvres on the global Formula One circuit reveal the tycoon's gritty determination to stay in pole position.  Paul Farrelly  reports
fields.trailText: Bernie Ecclestone's latest smoke and mirrors manoeuvres on the global Formula One circuit reveal the tycoon's gritty determination to stay in pole position. Paul Farrelly reports
fields.body:
Have the two men who have ruled the Grand Prix world of Formula One for the best part of three decades finally fallen out? Certainly, motor racing fans turning to the financial pages last week might think their sport convulsed by a yet another spectacular bust-up at the top.

To date, most of the squabbling has been over money between the top Grand Prix teams - the likes of Williams and McLaren - and Bernie Ecclestone, the diminutive tycoon who controls Formula One with a vice-like grip.

The teams have also engaged in periodic bouts of blood-letting over rules and regulations with the sport's governing body - the Geneva-based Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA) - and its president Max Mosley, son of the infamous British wartime fascist, Sir Oswald Mosley. A controversial investigation by the European Commission into Ecclestone's cosy links with the FIA has also cast a long shadow over the sport for the last three years.

Last week, however, it seemed that the streetwise billionaire and his long-standing friend, Mosley, were at each other's throats. Ecclestone has failed to come up with a $60 million deposit for lucrative television and merchandising rights for the Grand Prix circuit. Struck last June, it was the latest in a long line of extraordinary, eyebrow-raising deals that have turned Ecclestone into one of Britain's richest men over the last 25 years. For $360m, the tycoon would extend his exclusive rights to sell the sport to its 5 billion viewers wordwide for a further 100 years until 2110. The price was a snip compared with the fortunes changing hands for Premier League and American football for a fraction of the duration.

Mosley seemed up in arms over the $60m deposit. Drastic measures were threatened if the cash did not appear by the time the FIA's 150 members next assembled on 22 March. Ecclestone, it appeared, might be frozen out by an alternative deal with the sport's major carmakers, Fiat, Ford, BMW, Daimler-Chrysler and Renault, who have been eager for a further piece of the action.

What you see in Formula One, however, is often the result of smoke and mirrors. For seasoned observers, and City cynics, the 'clash' between the erstwhile bosom buddies appeared too conveniently timed, when a 50 per stake in the sport itself now finds itself up for grabs. 'This row really looks complete fiction,' one Formula One insider said. 'Bernie is doing what he does best, wheeling, dealing and manoeuvring.'

Peer through the burning rubber for a moment, therefore, and cast your eyes at Germany. Not at the infamous Nürburgring, which claimed the lives of Britain's Peter Collins and John Taylor and, in 1976, nearly killed Nikki Lauda. Look instead towards Munich and a troubled television company, which owns the Muppets, sells Bugs Bunny merchandise to German kids and last March bought 50 per cent of SLEC Holdings, Formula One's controlling company, for a cool $1.6bn.

Under Ecclestone's guiding hand, the glamour of Formula One has never failed to mesmerise. Lately, noone has been more bewitched than Thomas Haffa, the charismatic founder of Germany's EM.TV. After breakneck expansion, however, including the $680m purchase of the Jim Henson Company a year ago, Haffa's ambition overreached itself. Just before Christmas, Germany's rising star - then worth more than the mighty Lufthansa - stunned the market with a profits warning and the revelation of accounting discrepancies. With £700m of debt, EM.TV is now being circled by vultures eager to pluck the Formula One jewel from its tarnished crown. And Ecclestone, as ever, is no mere spectator.

EM.TV's stake already has a chequered history. The tycoon first parted with a 12.5 per cent share in Formula One in October 1999 for $325m to Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, a venture capital house owned by Germany's Deutsche Bank. The testosterone-charged deal was feted by bankers: after many false starts it was the first time the City had got its claws into Ecclestone's empire.

The tycoon loathes bankers. In 1997, he dumped advisers Salomon Brothers after the failure of much-trumpeted plans to float Formula One. Since then, the 70-year-old has cashed in by other means. Eighteen months ago, he raised $1.4bn for his family trusts through a difficult bond issue. Morgan Stanley, one of the biggest Wall Street banks, found itself publicly ridiculed by Ecclestone after taking seven months to complete the deal, which had already been scaled back from $2bn. And even then, Morgan needed help from German bank WestLB, the tycoon's latest favourite, which - eager to muscle in on future deals - took half the issue itself.

The love-in with the venture capitalists at Morgan Grenfell was short-lived. After failing to bring in Italy's Benetton and other high profile investors, Morgan Grenfell decided against taking up an option on another 37.5 per cent of the shares for $975m. Instead, Ecclestone sold the stake to San Francisco-based Hellman & Friedman for a knockdown $700m, another band of US financiers who fell for Formula One's charms. When EM.TV came calling, the bankers took a quick profit. The trouble is that they took most of it in EM.TV's highly rated paper, whose price has since collapsed, leaving Morgan Grenfell red-faced with a loss of over $250m.

'Ecclestone is laughing. He's the best deal-doer I've ever met,' said one City banker. 'So far, he's cashed in to the tune of $2.5bn and he still controls Formula One.'

The tycoon's next card may be his smartest ace yet. As part of the EM.TV deal, Ecclestone agreed to give the Germans an option over another 25 per cent, ceding control for another $1bn. EM.TV, of course, is now in no position to buy anything. Ecclestone, however, also has a right to force EM.TV to take the shares: a 'put option' that can be exercised until May, which now hangs like a sword of Damocles over the Germans.

'If Bernie exercises the option, EM.TV will go to the wall. He's in a very advantageous position and is making best use of it,' one former adviser said. 'Someone will have to pay him not to do it. But it is a doubled-edged sword: the Formula One shares are also pledged as security to EM.TV's banks.'

So far, so good. What Ecclestone is unhappy with, motor racing insiders say, is the prospect of Germany's Kirch Group, Europe's biggest pay-TV operator, getting hold of EM.TV and control of Formula One. Kirch, run by Germany's media hardman Dieter Hahn, is currently in exclusive talks to rescue EM.TV, though Haffa faces opposition from his board.

What better way, cynics say, to scupper the talks than by questioning the value of Formula One itself. Ecclestone, too, hopes to take a slice of the shares back as a pay-off for letting his option lapse. Doubts over Grand Prix's future, therefore, just knock down the price. This weekend, silence from the Formula One camp simply added grist to the cynics' mill. 'This is where the "row" is all too well-timed. Bernie and FIA haven't legally completed their deal. But they will and the $60m, too, is already sitting in an escrow account,' one source said.

'The fact that Bernie hasn't yet concluded the deal creates uncertainty just as the poker starts over the Formula One shares. Bernie would love to get some of those shares back so he can sell them on again.'

After 10 years in the driving seat, FIA members are due to vote on renewal of Mosley's presidency for another five-year term later this year. By then, the FIA will have little clout. Rights to Formula One will have been sold to Ecclestone and, under a deal with the European Commission, the FIA will just be a regulatory body.

Despite his age, however, Ecclestone has no intention of leaving the stage. The tycoon is currently in talks with the carmakers, who are being advised by Goldman Sachs, over a stake of up to a third in Formula One. fields.bodyText: Have the two men who have ruled the Grand Prix world of Formula One for the best part of three decades finally fallen out? Certainly, motor racing fans turning to the financial pages last week might think their sport convulsed by a yet another spectacular bust-up at the top. To date, most of the squabbling has been over money between the top Grand Prix teams - the likes of Williams and McLaren - and Bernie Ecclestone, the diminutive tycoon who controls Formula One with a vice-like grip. The teams have also engaged in periodic bouts of blood-letting over rules and regulations with the sport's governing body - the Geneva-based Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA) - and its president Max Mosley, son of the infamous British wartime fascist, Sir Oswald Mosley. A controversial investigation by the European Commission into Ecclestone's cosy links with the FIA has also cast a long shadow over the sport for the last three years. Last week, however, it seemed that the streetwise billionaire and his long-standing friend, Mosley, were at each other's throats. Ecclestone has failed to come up with a $60 million deposit for lucrative television and merchandising rights for the Grand Prix circuit. Struck last June, it was the latest in a long line of extraordinary, eyebrow-raising deals that have turned Ecclestone into one of Britain's richest men over the last 25 years. For $360m, the tycoon would extend his exclusive rights to sell the sport to its 5 billion viewers wordwide for a further 100 years until 2110. The price was a snip compared with the fortunes changing hands for Premier League and American football for a fraction of the duration. Mosley seemed up in arms over the $60m deposit. Drastic measures were threatened if the cash did not appear by the time the FIA's 150 members next assembled on 22 March. Ecclestone, it appeared, might be frozen out by an alternative deal with the sport's major carmakers, Fiat, Ford, BMW, Daimler-Chrysler and Renault, who have been eager for a further piece of the action. What you see in Formula One, however, is often the result of smoke and mirrors. For seasoned observers, and City cynics, the 'clash' between the erstwhile bosom buddies appeared too conveniently timed, when a 50 per stake in the sport itself now finds itself up for grabs. 'This row really looks complete fiction,' one Formula One insider said. 'Bernie is doing what he does best, wheeling, dealing and manoeuvring.' Peer through the burning rubber for a moment, therefore, and cast your eyes at Germany. Not at the infamous Nürburgring, which claimed the lives of Britain's Peter Collins and John Taylor and, in 1976, nearly killed Nikki Lauda. Look instead towards Munich and a troubled television company, which owns the Muppets, sells Bugs Bunny merchandise to German kids and last March bought 50 per cent of SLEC Holdings, Formula One's controlling company, for a cool $1.6bn. Under Ecclestone's guiding hand, the glamour of Formula One has never failed to mesmerise. Lately, noone has been more bewitched than Thomas Haffa, the charismatic founder of Germany's EM.TV. After breakneck expansion, however, including the $680m purchase of the Jim Henson Company a year ago, Haffa's ambition overreached itself. Just before Christmas, Germany's rising star - then worth more than the mighty Lufthansa - stunned the market with a profits warning and the revelation of accounting discrepancies. With £700m of debt, EM.TV is now being circled by vultures eager to pluck the Formula One jewel from its tarnished crown. And Ecclestone, as ever, is no mere spectator. EM.TV's stake already has a chequered history. The tycoon first parted with a 12.5 per cent share in Formula One in October 1999 for $325m to Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, a venture capital house owned by Germany's Deutsche Bank. The testosterone-charged deal was feted by bankers: after many false starts it was the first time the City had got its claws into Ecclestone's empire. The tycoon loathes bankers. In 1997, he dumped advisers Salomon Brothers after the failure of much-trumpeted plans to float Formula One. Since then, the 70-year-old has cashed in by other means. Eighteen months ago, he raised $1.4bn for his family trusts through a difficult bond issue. Morgan Stanley, one of the biggest Wall Street banks, found itself publicly ridiculed by Ecclestone after taking seven months to complete the deal, which had already been scaled back from $2bn. And even then, Morgan needed help from German bank WestLB, the tycoon's latest favourite, which - eager to muscle in on future deals - took half the issue itself. The love-in with the venture capitalists at Morgan Grenfell was short-lived. After failing to bring in Italy's Benetton and other high profile investors, Morgan Grenfell decided against taking up an option on another 37.5 per cent of the shares for $975m. Instead, Ecclestone sold the stake to San Francisco-based Hellman & Friedman for a knockdown $700m, another band of US financiers who fell for Formula One's charms. When EM.TV came calling, the bankers took a quick profit. The trouble is that they took most of it in EM.TV's highly rated paper, whose price has since collapsed, leaving Morgan Grenfell red-faced with a loss of over $250m. 'Ecclestone is laughing. He's the best deal-doer I've ever met,' said one City banker. 'So far, he's cashed in to the tune of $2.5bn and he still controls Formula One.' The tycoon's next card may be his smartest ace yet. As part of the EM.TV deal, Ecclestone agreed to give the Germans an option over another 25 per cent, ceding control for another $1bn. EM.TV, of course, is now in no position to buy anything. Ecclestone, however, also has a right to force EM.TV to take the shares: a 'put option' that can be exercised until May, which now hangs like a sword of Damocles over the Germans. 'If Bernie exercises the option, EM.TV will go to the wall. He's in a very advantageous position and is making best use of it,' one former adviser said. 'Someone will have to pay him not to do it. But it is a doubled-edged sword: the Formula One shares are also pledged as security to EM.TV's banks.' So far, so good. What Ecclestone is unhappy with, motor racing insiders say, is the prospect of Germany's Kirch Group, Europe's biggest pay-TV operator, getting hold of EM.TV and control of Formula One. Kirch, run by Germany's media hardman Dieter Hahn, is currently in exclusive talks to rescue EM.TV, though Haffa faces opposition from his board. What better way, cynics say, to scupper the talks than by questioning the value of Formula One itself. Ecclestone, too, hopes to take a slice of the shares back as a pay-off for letting his option lapse. Doubts over Grand Prix's future, therefore, just knock down the price. This weekend, silence from the Formula One camp simply added grist to the cynics' mill. 'This is where the "row" is all too well-timed. Bernie and FIA haven't legally completed their deal. But they will and the $60m, too, is already sitting in an escrow account,' one source said. 'The fact that Bernie hasn't yet concluded the deal creates uncertainty just as the poker starts over the Formula One shares. Bernie would love to get some of those shares back so he can sell them on again.' After 10 years in the driving seat, FIA members are due to vote on renewal of Mosley's presidency for another five-year term later this year. By then, the FIA will have little clout. Rights to Formula One will have been sold to Ecclestone and, under a deal with the European Commission, the FIA will just be a regulatory body. Despite his age, however, Ecclestone has no intention of leaving the stage. The tycoon is currently in talks with the carmakers, who are being advised by Goldman Sachs, over a stake of up to a third in Formula One. They are also a favoured destination for the EM.TV shares, as are Hellman & Friedman, Morgan Grenfell and as many other investors as possible. 'The more widely spread the shares are, the more clout Bernie will have. He likes to divide and rule,' one City source said. 'The best solution for everyone now is for Bernie not to exercise his option. But whatever happens, he'll go to his grave before he quits Formula One.'

webTitle: United in Euro 'fix' claim

fields.headline: United in Euro 'fix' claim
fields.trailText: One of Valencia's top internationals has claimed that a Champions League match against Manchester United last season was 'fixed'.
fields.body:
One of Valencia's top internationals has claimed that a Champions League match against Manchester United last season was 'fixed'.

The United manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, was baffled by the claim. 'I don't know anything about it,' he said after yesterday's 1-1 draw against Chelsea. 'It didn't come from me. I have no comment.'

Valencia needed a point to go through and United had already qualified before the teams met in the final Group B qualifier. The game finished 0-0, ensuring the Spanish team a place in the quarter-finals. They went on to reach the final, losing 3-0 to Real Madrid in Paris.

Midfielder Miguel-Angel Angulo said: 'I just hope this match won't be like the last one when we "agreed" to draw before the game. I guess this time will be different because there's a lot to fight for. It was to our mutual benefit to go easy last time.'

The clubs meet again at the same stadium in Valencia on Wednesday. This time, he says, there will be no collusion. 'It won't be the same because there's a side like Panathanaikos breathing down our necks,' he said.

When last season's game started, United had already guaranteed a place in the last eight. Valencia were second, where they eventually finished, but could have been overtaken by Fiorentina. The Italians needed to win their final game, at home to Bordeaux, while hoping for a United win in Spain. They only drew - but will be intrigued by Angulo's comments and Fiorentina directors will discuss the claims this week.

webTitle: Le Manoir Aux Quat' Saisons, Great Milton, Oxfordshire

fields.headline: Le Manoir Aux Quat' Saisons, Great Milton, Oxfordshire
fields.trailText: The restaurant is the beating heart of Le Manoir, but Monsieur Blanc has created a hotel of character around his remarkable kitchen.
fields.body:
Is that Raymond Blanc's salle?
Try rooms. The restaurant is the beating heart of Le Manoir, but Monsieur Blanc has created a hotel of character around his remarkable kitchen.

An English country house hotel?
The village of Great Milton is as English as steak-and-kidney pudding but the estate is a corner of Oxfordshire that will be forever France. It's not just the two-star Michelin table or the predominance of French-speaking staff. That singular French sense of style pervades the public rooms of the main house and the individually designed bedrooms, sometimes strikingly contemporary, sometimes more traditional. We stayed in the Dovecote, a love nest with white drapes billowing to the roof and a bath big enough for two on the ground floor. The gardens are more international with a Japanese tea garden, ornamental herb and flower features, and an enormous organic vegetable patch.

Fresh produce from the garden to the table. I knew you would get round to the food.
The leek that dresses your pan-fried scallops will have been plucked from the ground the same day. As in France, the restaurant is the focal point of a visit. What better way to celebrate an anniversary than with the seven-course menu gourmand?

That sounds like an assault on the stomach?
You won't feel bloated but your senses will be stretched. Blanc creates a delicate balance of tastes and textures. Those scallops were mouthwatering and the monkfish medallions with citrus dressing were lightness itself. Even the robust venison - served with bitter chocolate - did not swamp the braised celery heart and truffled chicory. And just when you thought that the croustade pastry with caramelised apple served with honey and ginger ice cream looked on the large size, you discovered that the pastry melted in the mouth.

Why does Le Manoir have only two Michelin stars?
Those of us who are not foodies retire from the table wondering what on earth chefs have to do to earn a third star.

· Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons, Church Road, Great Milton, Oxford OX44 7PD (01844 278881, fax 278847. Rooms cost from £230 per night (standard) to £550 (superior suite) for one or two guests, including French breakfast, fresh fruit and flowers and a newspaper. The menu gourmand costs £84 per person.

webTitle: Henry rises to the rescue

fields.headline: Henry rises to the rescue
fields.trailText: There is no logical reason to stick a late bet on Arsenal to win the Premiership when some of the shrewdest bookmakers have already paid out on Manchester United. But when have football and logic ever got on?
fields.body:
There is no logical reason to stick a late bet on Arsenal to win the Premiership when some of the shrewdest bookmakers have already paid out on Manchester United. But when have football and logic ever got on?

While the fat ladies of Manchester have every right to continue singing confirmation of United's impending success, perhaps they should also be mindful that Arsenal will move to within 10 points of the top if they win their next Premiership game - at Old Trafford.

Arsenal have difficult European and FA Cup ties to play before that showdown so their season could be all but over by then. Today, however, it is very much alive.

'I said there were three big games for us this week, but this was the important one,' said Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger. 'I sensed we were finding our form a few weeks ago and the players have proved me right. Now we need to show this consistency for the rest of the season.'

Arsenal, who have now not conceded a goal in the last six games of a seven-match unbeaten run, fully deserved this win. But it was never obvious they would pull it off because Ipswich seemed impregnable before Thierry Henry stopped nursing an ankle injury on the substitutes' bench to come on to the pitch and score.

One player does not make a team, but Henry is a proven match winner and others can make the difference between survival and humiliation if he is a goalkeeper in the form of Richard Wright.

Ipswich manager George Burley pointed out four world-class saves in the first half and claimed there will not be a goalkeeping performance to match it all season. Whether England manager Sven-Göran Eriksson's right-hand man Tord Grip agrees will be revealed when they name their first squad on Friday. But he was here to see it.

First to curse the man who has his eyes on David Seaman's England place was Dennis Bergkamp, who struck a curling sixth-minute shot which seemed destined for the top corner before Wright made a last-gasp lunge to tip the ball around a post.

Ten minutes later he denied Sylvain Wiltord's 20-yard goal-bound drive with another agile flick to push the ball over the bar. Moments later came a point-blank stop of a well-struck Lauren volley to keep Ipswich alive. Arsenal were on a roll, but so was Wright and he made a full-stretch save to keep out a crisp, low shot from Ashley Cole in the 23rd minute.

A couple of bewildered Arsenal players approached Wright and seemed to ask him what he was up to - or on - as they waited for the latest in a series of corners. Wright's show of invincibility eventually had a positive effect on his team-mates as they began to shake off their early caution and negative tactics to probe Seaman's goal.

Arsenal kept their grip on the game, but Ipswich began to play with belief rather than hope. Wenger sensed it and his response was to send on Henry for midfielder Lauren 13 minutes after the restart.

If Ipswich were worried they did not show it as they created their best chance before Henry touched the ball. Martijn Reuser tossed an overhead kick to the far post and an unmarked Marcus Stewart failed to show how he had come into the game as the Premiership's leading scorer by getting the ball stuck under his feet with only Seaman to beat.

But Wenger's feeling that Henry had been the missing link was confirmed when the French international scored in the 67th minute with his first sight of goal. Bergkamp ended a quick series of passes by springing Ipswich's offside trap to send Henry clear and this time Wright was helpless as a low right-foot shot zipped into the net to settle the game.

webTitle: Rebrov strikes, crowd sleeps

fields.headline: Rebrov strikes, crowd sleeps
fields.trailText: Who need Mogadon when you can watch Tottenham Hotspur? George Graham's tired side bored their opponents into submission at Maine Road, allowing Sergei Rebrov to grab a late winner for their first away win since last April.
fields.body:
Who need Mogadon when you can watch Tottenham Hotspur? George Graham's tired side bored their opponents into submission at Maine Road, allowing Sergei Rebrov to grab a late winner for their first away win since last April.

And, while he paid lip service to the thrilling 4-2 midweek FA Cup win against Charlton at The Valley, there was little doubt which result meant more to the pragmatic Spurs manager. 'There are times when you have to dig and get what you can,' Graham said. 'It was a quality move and a quality finish. We are unbeaten in eight games and I see no reason why we can't move up the table when we have all our players fit once more.'

But while Graham was celebrating, the result was far from deserved. Lacking in inspiration and reliant on route-one football Spurs spent much of the first half hoofing the ball towards the muscular Gary Docherty and then deciding, despite their lack of success using this tactic, to repeat the manoeuvre throughout the second half, this time aiming for the ineffective Andy Booth.

Not that City, stuck in the bottom three and desperate for points with tough games against Manchester United and Arsenal to come, were much better.

The mood was set from the start with City's attacks tending to break down in the midfield and Tottenham seemingly content to hang on for their fifth consecutive goalless draw in the league.

With such a tactic it was unsurprising that City gradually began to get the measure of their opponents over the half. Having done so they showed little inclination to capitalise on that advantage. Neil Sullivan saved comfortably from Gerard Wiekens, Shaun Goater missed when clean through, while new boy Andrei Kanchelskis caused the occasional flutter on the right without actually threatening to do anything with the available space.

With Spurs creating precisely nothing and City unable to work out what to do with their superior possession, the game drifted towards the dire.

City's best player, the impressive Darren Huckerby, broke the tedium minutes into the second half, capitalising on a sleepy Spurs defence to put the ball in the back of the net, only to see it ruled out in dubious circumstances.

City manager Joe Royle admitted he was at a loss to explain why the goal had not been allowed. 'The referee said it was a push by Shaun Goater on their goalkeeper, someone else said it was a push by Howey, I thought it was a push by Campbell,' he said.

'It's the second perfectly good goal we've had ruled out recently but sometimes you just don't get the breaks.'

The referee's decision seemed to break City's already fragile spirit and, while they continued to breach the Spurs midfield, their shots grew increasingly wild and the idea of a goal increasingly unlikely.

That a goal should then fall to the opposition when, with one minute to go, the alert Oyvind Leonhardsen slipped a pass through to Rebrov who finished clinically, only increased Royle's sense of injustice. 'I thought they had a pretty good ratio,' Royle sniffed. 'They had one shot and scored one goal.'

webTitle: United in a different ball park

fields.headline: United in a different ball park
fields.trailText: That's the draw out of the way, now the New York Mancees need seven wins from their remaining 11 games to be sure of yet another pennant - assuming Arsenal win all their games, that is, including one at Old Trafford. Held they may have been yesterday, but Manchester United remain in a different ball park.
fields.body:
That's the draw out of the way, now the New York Mancees need seven wins from their remaining 11 games to be sure of yet another pennant - assuming Arsenal win all their games, that is, including one at Old Trafford. Held they may have been yesterday, but Manchester United remain in a different ball park.

The Chelsea White Sox gave them a home run for their money, taking a first-half lead with Jimmy Floyd Haisselbank's sixteenth goal of the season. But Andy Cole's twelfth in a second period they dominated gave United a deserved share of the points. As the Chelsea manager, Claudio Ranieri, might say: ' Una partida a due facce .'

There could and should have been more goals, with the Premiership's leading two scorers producing an exciting, energised contest to illuminate a dank west London afternoon. And proof, too, that good technique can thrive on even a threadbare surface.

If United were going to stumble on their title run-in, Stamford Bridge was going to be the place where it was most likely to happen, given Chelsea's formidable home record. United, though, looked determined to avoid last season's 5-0 thrashing here and - reprieved when Hasselbaink spurned a chance to make it 2-0 early in the second half - they finally realised that attack was their best form of defence. All this with quiet performances from David Beckham and Ryan Giggs.

'I sensed the edge in my players,' said the United manager Sir Alex Ferguson. 'It was our best performance for quite a few weeks. What pleased me most was our perseverance in keeping control by passing and moving. Chelsea are a good side but we ran them ragged in the second half.'

Not in the first, though. From the outset, Dennis Wise was at Roy Keane's ankles while alongside him Sam Dalla Bona provided the guile, moving the ball swiftly and slickly. Indeed, United struggled to cope with Chelsea's 3-4-3 formation, in which Jesper Gronkjaer caused them serious problems wide on the left. They were troubled, too, by Chelsea's shoot-on-sight policy to test Raimond van der Gouw, deputising in goal - or should that be as catcher - for Fabien Barthez, who is expected to be fit for Wednesday's Champions League game in Valencia after a slight hamstring strain. The Dutchman had to be sharp to turn aside Dalla Bona's low drive then could only watch anxiously as Gianfranco Zola's similar attempt from 20 yards went wide of his right post in the early onslaught.

Jaap Stam's untimely challenge on Zola might well have yielded a penalty, though Chelsea soon proved they had no need of one to take the lead. Gronkjaer crossed and Stam had to be strong to beat Hasselbaink to the ball, but Paul Scholes rashly attempted to head the clearance back to Van der Gouw to find Hasselbaink lurking, and he glanced in a header from six yards.

At least and at last it sparked United, with Keane looking especially determined to avoid the half-time ear-bashing from Sir Alex that accompanies a deficit. It may explain why he did so a minute into the second half after a penetrating run. webTitle: Video releases

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Those Who Love Me Can Take the train | My Dog Skip | Braveheart | What's Up Tiger Lily?
fields.trailText: Those Who Love Me Can Take the train | My Dog Skip | Braveheart | What's Up Tiger Lily?
fields.body:
Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train
(1999, 12, Artificial Eye, EHV Retail/Rental)

Superior example of the horrific family reunion picture, a universal genre in which dysfunctional families gather for weddings, birthdays or funerals and indulge in literal and figurative blood-letting. In this film by Patrice Chéreau, a minor bisexual painter (Jean-Louis Trintignant) insists his body be taken from Paris to the world's largest cemetery in Limoges, where his estranged twin (also Trintignant) puts his battling friends and relations at ill-ease. The film is packed with quirky detail and appalling behaviour, and is performed by a starry cast that includes Pascal Greggory, Charles Bering and Dominique Blanc. The final aerial shot is stunning.

My Dog Skip
(2000, Warner, U, VHS/Rental)
Fictionalised memoir by the late Willie Morris (author of the marvellous premature autobiography North Toward Home ) recalling his schooldays during World War II in a strictly segregated Mississippi town and his adventures with a beloved terrier. There are borrowings from Tom Sawyer and much sentimentality, but it's an attractive affair with strong performances from Kevin Bacon and Diane Ladd.

Braveheart
(1995, 15, Warner, DVD Retail/Rental)
Actor-director Mel Gibson's three-hour epic celebrates medieval Scottish hero William Wallace in the boozy patriotic spirit of a Burns Night recitation of 'Scots wha hae wi Wallace bled'. A grand entertainment, extremely hostile to the English foes: Gibson might well have called it 'What Scotsmen Want'. The DVD contains a voiceover commentary by the director and a 'making-of' documentary.

What's Up Tiger Lily?
(1966, PG, VHS, DVD, Rental/Retail)
For his first venture in filmmaking (the title echoes What's New Pussycat? which he wrote the previous year), Woody Allen acquired the rights to a terrible Japanese Bond-style extravaganza, re-edited it and provided an incongruous soundtrack full of New York Jewish gags. The joke wears thin, but there are good laughs along the way. Allen's then-wife Louise Lasser and friend Mickey Knox help out.

webTitle: Litmanen's lucky break

fields.headline: Litmanen's lucky break
fields.trailText: Steady on with talk of a Liverpool revival, at least until Thursday's Uefa Cup encounter with Roma.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at The Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Steady on with talk of a Liverpool revival, at least until Thursday's Uefa Cup encounter with Roma.

Gérard Houllier's team were decidedly fortunate to escape from Sunderland with a point, and might well have lost on Wearside for the first time in 43 years without the dodgiest of penalties awarded 12 minutes from the end.

It was not that Stanislav Varga did not trip Gary McAllister, or that the Scot's tumble to earth in instalments was an attempt to con the referee, just that the Slovakian captain's none-too-discreet ankle-tap took place a good yard outside the area.

Graham Barber checked with his linesman before confirming his decision, and Jari Litmanen equalised joyfully from the spot, which was fair enough since he and Michael Owen had originated the move which McAllister was attempting to finish. What was less just was Barber's strange decision to book Kevin Phillips for protesting, rather than Varga for what could only be interpreted as a professional foul by the last defender. Perhaps, knowing Varga had been cautioned 18 minutes earlier, the referee simply wanted to escape the North-East without a police escort.

He must have been mightily relieved to see an offside flag rule out what looked like a winning goal from Robbie Fowler five minutes from time, for defeat would have been cruel on a battling Sunderland side who led for most of the second half through a goal from former Liverpool player Don Hutchison.

'The players feel hard done by. There's no doubt the penalty changed the game,' Peter Reid said. 'We slightly lost our discipline after that.'

This is debatable. Sunderland were bristlier than ever after two successive Premiership defeats, and there was niggle all through the game. Niall Quinn complained about holding, Michael Gray was booked for a crunching tackle on Gregory Vignal, and Reid remonstrated on the touchline with Barber - and that was just the first five minutes.

Hutchison was lucky to get away with a succession of rash lunges, while Varga also went unpunished for standing on Emile Heskey's ankle, causing him to limp off after 27 minutes to be replaced by Litmanen.

Hutchison got the booking he was asking for just before half-time for one of his more innocuous challenges on Vignal, who responded by retaliating and picking up a card of his own. In between the argy-bargy there were few occurrences of football until the game came to life after half-time.

Vignal is a promising player, but his inexperience cost Liverpool dearly when Sunderland took the lead. Neat interplay between Julio Arca and Phillips had sent the latter into the Liverpool penalty area where he was abruptly stopped by Stephane Henchoz, but as Sunderland appealed vainly for a penalty Vignal had plenty of time to clear. Instead, he looked up to assess his options and was caught in possession, Arca's block giving Hutchison all the time and space he needed to place a shot low past Sander Westerveld.

The home side were busily in pursuit of a second when Liverpool broke away for McAllister to win his penalty and prevent Sunderland leapfrogging their opponents into third place. The home crowd, even without the benefit of video replays, were deeply unimpressed. Reid did not join in the gigantic boo at the end, even though he probably felt like it, but he did have a pop when he heard that the referee intended to report three of his players (Hutchison, McCann and Arca) for over-zealous goal celebrations.

'If I'd scored a goal against Liverpool I'd have been in the crowd with them,' Reid said. 'Football's about passion, and that was a smashing game, tackles flying in and everything. What do you want from a football match? I find this sort of thing staggering, petty and small-minded.'

webTitle: New economy tycoons who flew too close to the sun

fields.headline: New economy tycoons who flew too close to the sun
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: If there was one company that typified the mania of the dotcom boom and bust of the past 12 months, it was online urban sportswear company boo.com.
fields.body:
Boo

If there was one company that typified the mania of the dotcom boom and bust of the past 12 months, it was online urban sportswear company boo.com. Founded by three Swedes - one of them, Ernst Malmsten, is a former poet, another, Kajsa Leander, was a model - Boo became a textbook example of how not to run an e-tailer.

First there was the technology. Boo thought it had hit on a masterstroke when its website allowed shoppers to view products from different angles. But the pages took ages to download - and shoppers turned away in their droves.

Then there was the company's rampant hubris. It launched in more than 20 countries simultaneously and spent vast sums buying leases on properties. The parties were wild but expensive. And they did little to attract the punters. The company failed to sign up enough big-name clothing manufacturers to draw enough visitors to its site.

Its grip on its finances was relaxed, to say the least. The founders were notorious for flying everywhere first class at the drop of a hat. Staff would regularly take deliveries of sumptuous loads of fruit and cake from local delis, all paid for by the company.

Having raised more than £100 million from the likes of the Benetton family and luxury goods firm LVMH in 1999, Boo collapsed in May 2000. Its technology platform was sold off for $250,000 and the Boo name for a similar amount. Leander and Malmsten are writing a book on their experience.

Oxygen

There was dotcom mania and then there was Oxygen Holdings, the internet incubator which saw its share price rise by a jaw-dropping 2,775 per cent when it came to market last February.

At its peak Oxygen was valued at £240 million. Co-founded by 26-year-old Emma Edelson with the backing of her father, Manchester United director Michael Edelson, the incubator was supposed to help nurture university start-ups. Much of the hype surrounding the firm came from the fact that Oxygen, like many other dotcoms, knew the publicity value high-profile directors brought to the company. Thus it was that PR guru Matthew Freud and media heiress Elisabeth Murdoch were appointed to the company's board. It was also well publicised that former Manchester United chief executive Martin Edwards was backing the company.

But Oxygen, like the scores of other incubators that launched around the same time, found the going much tougher than anticipated. The company provided little expertise or support to the few firms it managed to identify as suitable investment vehicles.

Problems became apparent practically the day after Oxygen had launched, and shortly after Emma Edelson presciently stated: 'There is a certain window of time for these entrepreneurs to make their mark. The capital valuations are crazy and I'm pretty sure the bubble will burst.' She wasn't wrong. The day after Oxygen floated, Edelson, a former Cambridge University student, saw her £11m paper stake slashed to a paltry £500,000 as the company's share price crashed by an unprecedented 95 per cent. Once its shares were worth nearly 60p a pop; today Oxygen's share price stands at just over 2p.

Virtual Internet

Spare a thought for Jason Drummond, founder of Virtual Internet, the company that specialises in helping boring old firms develop a web presence.

In March last year Drummond, then 30, took a call from a friend who told him this newspaper had just ranked him as Britain's wealthiest young entrepreneur. The company was worth around £200 million, giving Drummond, who has a 64 per cent stake, a paper fortune of nearly £125m.

Its future looked assured. It had nearly 50,000 clients and more than half of FTSE 100 companies were customers, paying it to advise them on issues such as domain name registration, branding in cyberspace and protecting trademarks. The company operated in five countries and had plans to launch new products and enter a raft of new markets. Even though there were question marks over other dotcom models, Virtual Internet looked assured because it had a business-to-business model rather than the business-to-consumer version. 'We're the pick and shovel providers at the mucky end of the gold rush,' he said.

Today the firm is worth just £30m. Last month it unveiled figures for the year to 31 October which showed that losses had widened from £1.3m to £4.3m. Blame was laid firmly on the fact that a much-promised array of new products had failed to materialise.

Drummond's stake is now worth just £15m.

First Tuesday

Julie Meyer, undisputed queen of European dotcom fever, was one of four founders of First Tuesday.

A meeting of friends in a Soho bar on the first Tuesday of October 1998 grew into a global networking organisation and became a symbol for the new economy. The meetings brought together venture capitalists and aspiring entrepreneurs.

Meyer was brought up in California, but describes herself as European and is passionate about taking 'Europe.com' to the next stage. Though First Tuesday was part of the 'overall internet euphoria', she says: 'We've helped peel back the onion of European entrepreneurialism by promoting the individual rather than states or companies as an agent of change. I'm proud of the contribution I made.'

The slump was inevitable, Meyer says. 'It's a return to reality. But people who have the right business model, the right investors and team are frankly feeling pretty confident now.'

Investors who attended First Tuesday meetings were referred to as 'vulture capitalists' because they took stakes purely for financial reasons.

Relations between the founders are believed to have become frosty following the network's sale to Yazam, an Israeli firm that later folded.

Firstmark

The former One 2 One supremo Tim Samples moved on after Deutsche Telecom bought out the mobile phone company. He became chief executive of Firstmark Europe, the broadband telecoms company that received Europe's largest-ever private equity round - $1 billion - last June.

Samples claims he sold the first mobile phone in the world, but it couldn't help him sell Firstmark to the markets at the end of last year.

The original plan was to serve small and medium enterprises in 18 European countries with 'end-to-end' broadband networks. But almost as soon as the company began trading it became bogged down in the negative sentiment after expensive licence auctions. An expected flotation was pulled last year as it became clear funding options were running out. Firstmark changed its strategy. It turned towards its profitable German fibre-optic operations, and developments in France and Spain, but closed London operations. Samples left Firstmark last month.

fields.standfirst:
Only a year ago internet shares were still riding high on froth whipped up by entrepreneurial greed, analysts and the media. Faisal Islam on a bubble that had to burst

More net news
fields.trailText: Only a year ago internet shares were still riding high on froth whipped up by entrepreneurial greed, analysts and the media. Faisal Islam on a bubble that had to burst
fields.body:
In retrospect World of Fruit was never really going to set the world on fire. But last January the prospect of Fyffe's providing '24-hour secure online trading for the global fresh fruit and vegetable market' was sufficient to fuel a bananamania that added £370 million to the fruit importer's value.

Perhaps the banana industry was well ahead of the curve. Fyffe's share price was already on the way down at this time last year. In less tendentious areas such as telecoms, technology and media, the dotcom speculative orgy was reaching a crescendo.

Oxygen Holdings, which invests in entrepreneurial students, had just jumped 2,775 per cent on its first day on the stock market. Martha Lane Fox was planning her tour of newspaper offices and TV studios to promote the eagerly awaited flotation of Lastminute.com. Manchester United's £30 million sponsorship deal with Vodafone was lauded as a foretaste of a new world of watching football on your wap phone. Tony Blair was launching his first weekly webcast to the nation.

The media giants were getting stuck in, too. BSkyB's share price surged by a fifth on news that it was to invest £250m in internet ventures. Rupert Murdoch was busy proclaiming his reluctance to become a snack for a dotcom in the wake of AOL's merger with Time Warner. Overseas, his efforts to help Singapore Telecom take control of Hong Kong Telecom were scuppered by an unknown upstart new media company called Pacific Century Cyberworks. And an Indian software magnate briefly became the second richest man on the planet, after the 1,000lb gorilla of the international capital markets decided that Indian IT workers were the gold-dust of the New Economy.

'This time next year we'll be millionaires,' was the cry of a raft of individuals breaking out of their corporate shackles and starting a website. And if they didn't have their own dotcom idea, they could simply steal other people's, and then claim to be running an 'incubator'.

'Far too many people thought that they had the skills to become an entrepreneur. And every Tom, Dick and Harry was getting funding,' says Julie Meyer, founder of First Tuesday, and queen of the internet revolution in Europe.

Dotcom types will tell you that one year by the Julian calendar is four years 'in internet time'. But February 2000 must feel like decades ago to the bruised egos and wallets of the net entrepreneurs. A number of theories have been put forward to explain dotcom fever - ranging from millennial madness to a serious dose of equity market psychosis. But as John Naughton argues in his column this week (Big blue meanies and cyberspace monsters...), it's a phenomenon that's been seen before.

What distinguishes dotcom fever is the element of mass participation, the role of the media and the extent of the inflation of the biggest bubble ever. Economist Robert Shiller's analysis, which was going to the presses this time last year, seems extremely prescient now. For him, the stock market bubble was the result of an irrational exuberance born out of herds, hype and triumphalism. Periods of wild overvaluation of equities were nothing new, and had historically coincided with 'new era' sentiment. In other words, every so often a new technology comes along that will clearly make some people a lot of money at some point in the future - and may even revolutionise the way we do business.

This confidence in a sure-fire bet on the future obscures such pithy matters as who will win out, the size of their bounty, and when it will be secured. Add in the fact that in the short term the market rewards those who anticipate what everyone else will do, and you have a recipe for froth.

But the degree of frothiness can be exploited as cover for incompetence and mismanagement, and can be directly or tacitly whipped up by interested parties. Enter the media and the famed equity analysts.

The sports-style coverage of business issues in the mass media, particularly in the US, has given rise to superstar analysts such as Henry Blodget of Merrill Lynch and Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley. Though the quality of their research is not in doubt, their objectivity is questionable. Banks are unlikely to issue 'sell' advice in a high-growth business when they, too are also touting for lucrative contracts. Additionally, if analysts' words can move markets, it's easy to see how a conflict of interest arises.

Blodget is now the subject of a bitter internet-based campaign suggesting he talked up Amazon.com shares, to the eventual detriment of day traders who followed his advice. Meeker took time out to introduce Lastminute's Brent and Martha to institutional investors in the US. Morgan Stanley would eventually increase the price of Lastminute's float at a late stage from 190p to 380p. They now stand at 69.5p.

For Shiller the equity analysts are too often a branch of the bank's sales team. But maybe the media are the real villains

At the heart of the hype was the contention that the internet and related information industries were a revolution in the way companies and sectors organise themselves. It was more than just the emergence of a sexy new 'standalone' industry; it was a 'disruptive technology' that would cut costs and fatten profits across the economy.

The technology would prove to be the glue binding together formerly discrete industries such as telecoms and media. Companies could join forces to seek out the cheapest supplies around the world, be it a tonne of cheese for a supermarket chain or a jumbo jet wing for an airline.

At the same time, the US was experiencing a seemingly unending boom. The high growth rate and years of investment in IT were seen to be connected. But as any statistician knows, correlation is no proof of causation.

Much of the net's value was thought to be enmeshed within existing corporations, specifically in the telecommunications and media sectors. Share valuations soared, and the companies borrowed and did deals on the back of those soaring valuations.

Go back a couple of years and there were very few so-called 'pure-play' internet firms, but demand for their shares was high. It is this imbalance between supply and demand that pushed prices so high, attracting ever more interest in companies with little or no financial record. And this speculative froth was whipped up even more by marketing, publicity and hyperactive PR. Those companies that did come to market restricted the supply of stock and managed the release, guaranteeing a stel lar first-day performance, and yet more attention.

Privately, bankers were scornful of market research of the type that claimed that e-commerce in the artichoke industry would be worth £5bn by 2010. But the demand stoked by such reports offered early investors their profitable exit strategies. Suddenly a rush was on to push these companies to take advantage of the buoyant demand, speeding up the conveyor belt to flotation.

At the same time venture capitalists and bankers were funding half-baked business plans and incapable managements. There was too much capital chasing too few ideas.

Eventually a sufficient number of pure internet firms came to market for buyers to become discerning and, predictably, share prices slumped. For a while buyers looked to other sectors. Enthusiasm for 'optoelectronics', for example, propelled the share price of Bookham Technology, which rallied from March to July after the dotcoms had slumped. But it didn't last, particularly when stalwarts of the IT sector such as Apple and Microsoft issued profits warnings late last year.

The conveyor belt juddered to a halt. Venture capitalists pulled the plug on investment funding in, for example, Boo.com. Collateral damage was felt in related industries. Companies from News Corp to Disney reined in their investments and slashed jobs.

Telecoms companies were hit with an unexpected bill of billions for 3G (third-generation) licenses, the high watermark of irrational exuberance, and their credit ratings were downgraded. Like the Asian tigers in 1998, they found that with confidence undermined, capital markets are reticent when they are most needed.

For the cheerleaders, a truly new economy had been created by IT investment, and the proof was an increase in the trend growth rate of productivity. But figures released last week showed that this trend had not been sustained in the early stages of the US slowdown.

And even on Friday afternoon news was filtering through of another dotcom collapse, this time in the online travel sector.

But is it all over? Well, there are clearly still some peaches among all the lemons. Perhaps selecting them is a job for World of Fruit's 10 remaining staff in Dublin.
