webTitle: Profile: Nicole Kidman

fields.headline: Out of Cruise control
fields.standfirst: Mission accomplished. Now separated from Hollywood's top gun, the time may be right for this talented Australian (born in Hawaii) to establish herself as a superstar
fields.trailText: Mission accomplished. Now separated from Hollywood's top gun, the time may be right for this talented Australian (born in Hawaii) to establish herself as a superstar.
fields.body:
Kidman: 'Why haven't you ever been jealous about me?'

Cruise: 'I don't know. Maybe because you're my wife...' ( Eyes Wide Shut )

Stanley Kubrick's ponderous, largely-plotless and highly-pretentious study of sexual obsession, Eyes Wide Shut, has made for more interesting viewing this week than when it came out. Some even claim that the film did for the marriage of its stars, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman - that their relationship 'never quite recovered' from the strain of exploring the subject of marital infidelity under the eye of their notorious obsessive-compulsive-perfectionist director, day-after-day, week-after-week, month-after-tortuous month.

It's a nice theory and suitably dramatic, but given that the couple have cited 'divergent careers' as a reason for the split, the making of Eyes Wide Shut probably constitutes their marital Good Old Days: neatly convergent careers working together in London while renting that lovely Nash house in Regent's Park, not getting papped every time they took the kids to school and enjoying weekends hiking in the Lake District.

After the film wrapped, the couple hung around long enough for Kidman to work with Iain Glenn in David Hare's acclaimed The Blue Room at the Donmar Warehouse - the incandescently-reviewed production in which, interestingly, Kidman's powerfully sensual presence was exploited by director Sam Mendes in directly inverse proportion to the manner in which it had been neglected by Kubrick.

But I don't think we can blame Kubrick for the end of the Cruise's matrimonial journey. Instead, I suspect that Nicole just woke up after a 11 years of marriage and decided she wanted to be more of a Kidman than she did a Cruise.

Born in Hawaii in 1967 - where her father, a biochemist, was studying, and her mother was a nursing teacher and a feminist: 'I'd hand out pamphlets on the street with her and be scoffed at,' Nicole has recalled - the Kidman family moved back home to Sydney when Nicole was three. Her stage debut - wearing a car seat cover to play a sheep in her school nativity play - wasn't quite 'theatrical Viagra', while her father had nicknamed her 'storky' because she was already 5ft 10in by the time she started at North Sydney High School, convinced she was 'the ugliest person on earth'.

The beanpole adolescent sought sanctuary in Saturday morning drama classes: her first kiss was a stage kiss and her professional debut was yelling 'Beat me! Harder! Harder! Harder!' in a Sydney production of Wedekind's Spring Awakening. She has, it is fair to say, never fought shy of theatrical challenges. She's even been described as 'the heavyweight theatrical actress who married a lightweight movie star'.

By 17, Kidman had won an Australian best actress award for a TV mini-series, Vietnam, and 'knew I wasn't going to go to college. I wanted to cut loose. I was a nightmare to my parents. I lied to them. There was a time when my mother said: "I can't live in the same house with her".' Which sounds like fairly normal teenage foot-stamping, even for an award-winning thespian. Kidman then made the traditional Aussie rite-of-passage - travelling to Europe - and returned, sort-of grown-up, kind-of worldly.

By 20, having made an impression at home and abroad in the teen romance Flirting and the thriller Dead Calm, with Sam Neill and Billy Zane, she went to Hollywood and pitched up to audition for a Tom Cruise vehicle (literally - it was about stock car racing) called Days Of Thunder. 'Tom stood up to shake my hand and there I was looking down on him,' Kidman says. But despite having three inches on her boss, it was apparently 'instant lust'. They married in Telluride, Colorado, on Christmas Eve 1990, when Kidman was 23 and Cruise 28, with one divorce (from Mimi Rogers, who famously described him as 'like a monk') already under his belt.

But, lust aside, marrying Hollywood's biggest young star also meant marrying into his world: she became a Scientologist, though she says little on the subject (Tom deals publicly with Scientology, I don't...'); she fitted her career around his, conscious that she might be seen as the professional passenger in the relationship; she embraced his love of macho high-adrenaline pursuits ('I'm a fanatical sports freak. I love being able to do things like skydiving and aerobatics on the wing of Tom's biplane...'); she deftly juggled the demands of international celebrity homemaking ('a house in Sydney, a ranch with horses in Colorado and a place in Los Angeles, which is our albatross...'); and she remained necessarily tight-lipped on the subject of her own and her husband's fertility (though their two children, Isabella and Conor, are adopted, Kidman has dismissed reports of fertility treatment as 'complete bull').

And she has always colluded with Cruise's perceived control-freakiness: the hired help were alleged to have signed lengthy contracts banning them from revealing anything about the couple's domestic arrangements, while Cruise himself is famously litigious.

Somehow, she also found time for acting, but it has been an odd sort of career, possibly hindered rather than helped by her husband. Certainly not an A-list actress (she auditioned for, but failed to win the leads in Ghost, Thelma and Louise, Sleepless in Seattle, The Silence of the Lambs, Mary Reilly and The Hudsucker Proxy, and only landed her big breakthrough role, as the murderously ambitious TV weathergirl in the deliciously dark To Die For, when Meg Ryan turned it down), Kidman's dazzling talent has never been in question, even when she has resorted to absurd 'clever-totty' roles in brainless blockbusters. (A neurosurgeon in Days of Thunder, a psychiatrist in Batman Forever and a nuclear physicist in The Peacemaker . Perhaps having a biochemist for a father explains the love of white coats.)

But when she hasn't been simply clocking-on, she's made a bunch of highly eclectic professional choices, too. Though it bombed, one can understand Kidman's desire to work on Portrait of A Lady for Jane Campion (Campion was an early admirer of Kidman), but Practical Magic with Sandra Bullock? Then there is the upcoming Moulin Rouge and an intriguing-sounding adaptation of Michael Cunningham's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, The Hours, alongside Meryl Streep (something of a Kidman role model) and the screen's other smart and luminously lovely, porcelain-skinned, titian-haired actress, Julianne Moore. Last week, too, it was revealed that negotiations have been underway to bring her back to the London stage, this time at the National Theatre.

Even to seasoned celebrity-watchers, the announcement of the couple's split came as a bit of a surprise, if only because there hadn't been any new rumours (old ones, including the durable 'Is he or isn't he gay?', were still in circulation) so in Hollywood terms, where successful marriages are measured in dog years, theirs appeared to be extraordinarily solid. But with the benefit of hindsight, it's easy to rewrite the Cruise-Kidman script. Twenty three is, after all, quite young to get married. She probably just grew up.

'We intend to return to Britain as soon as possible,' said Kidman at the end of her run in The Blue Room , as the couple prepared to decamp to Sydney while Tom made Mission:Impossible 2. Now it looks as though they'll be booking separate flights. In the long-term, I hope she avoids a nasty custody battle, escapes the clutches of Scientology, moves back to Sydney (she misses it, apparently, and hates LA) and that her career flourishes as it deserves to. Tom, meanwhile, will probably carry on with his predictable blockbusting high-adrenaline displacement activities - Mission:Impossible 3, 4 - and eventually find himself another, more malleable, Mrs Cruise.

Kidman to Cruise 'Forever? Let's not use that word. It frightens me...' (Eyes Wide Shut)

Upcoming films: Moulin Rouge, The Hours

webTitle: Killer's trial exposes Bollywood gangsters

fields.headline: Killer's trial exposes Bollywood gangsters
fields.standfirst: Bombay's film industry lives on escapism, but is stalked now by death. Burhan Wazir reports
fields.trailText: Bombay's film industry lives on escapism, but is stalked now by death. Burhan Wazir reports.
fields.body:
With its peeling wallpaper and uneven chairs, the Bombay courtroom looks like a set from a Bollywood movie. But tomorrow, a self-confessed killer will stand trial here for murder.

The case of Abdul Daud Rauf Merchant attracts a particularly zealous media circus. His testimony threatens to unveil the Bollywood-underworld nexus that stretches over continents to fund the country's largest export.

In 1997, Bollywood music baron Gulshan Kumar was assassinated by a hit squad in Bombay (now renamed Mumbai) city centre. Last Tuesday, Merchant, an assassin employed by India's most feared gangland boss, Chotta Shakeel, was remanded in police custody. He has now confessed to receiving 100,000 rupees (almost £1,500) from Shakeel as the first instalment for the murder of the music baron.

His confession taints a film industry respected the world over for promoting family values. In the past 20 years, Bombay has expanded into the world's leading provider of cinematic escapism: a £14 billion behemoth, churning out nearly 900 films a year and easily outpunching Hollywood.

India alone has 13,000 cinemas, with a daily audience of more than 10 million. And the films form the staple diet of expatriates in Europe, South East Asia, the Middle East and the United States.

Publicly, Bollywood stars and their associates - directors, producers and music writers - display a persuasive commitment to morality. Only last week, an array of actors made personal appearances throughout the city to raise funds for victims of the earthquake in Gujarat.

Yet in recent weeks, Bombay has been rocked by a police investigation of underworld links. On 9 January police arrested film financier Bharat Shah, a big wheel in the diamond trade, for suspected links with Shakeel. Industry watchdogs claim he has sunk more than $43 million into Bollywood ventures.

Earlier, police arrested Shah's producer, Nadeem Rizvi, and his assistant Abdul Khan, accused of acting as a conduit between the financier and the gang boss. Police claim to possess taped conversations between Rizvi and Shakeel in which the two discussed the progress of Shah's latest film, Chori Chori, Chupke Chupke ( Quietly Quietly, Softly Softly ). Shakeel subsequently fled to Karachi.

India's leading film star, Salman Khan, was interrogated for five hours. His co-star in Chori Chori , Preity Zinta, was also questioned. The film's negatives have been seized, although bootlegged copies are available in Britain.

With the branding of Bolly wood as a global leader in the early Nineties, a new breed of gangsters has cut a lucrative share of the fortunes. The Dubai-Karachi-Bombay trafficking of bootlegged films and soundtracks nets the underworld 400 billion rupees (about £6bn) each year.

The film-underworld connection has claimed lives. In 1997, film producer Mukesh Duggal was shot dead in Bombay; He was reputed to have borrowed money from another gang boss, Chotta Rajan, to finance his features. Police believe this led to his murder at the hands of Shakeel, in a revenge killing.

In the same year, director Rajiv Rai survived a murder attempt, and last February, producer Rakesh Roshan was shot and injured after he refused to pay protection money to racketeers.

The relationship between crime and filmmakers has forced out a veteran generation of thespian talent. As India's most prominent screen hero during the Fifties and Sixties, Dilip Kumar's reputation outgrew the didactic craft of Bollywood musicals. His movies - left- wing, politically motivated dramas - are national treasures that make him the local equivalent to Marlon Brando.

Kumar, 78, went into semi-retirement in the Eighties and turned to directing. His thoughtful style would be replaced at the box office by the inflammatory hysterics of Amitabh Bachchan, India's self-styled 'angry young man'. Kumar remembers: 'As the films became more successful, the formulaic style of Bollywood became apparent. Crime was sexy - the heroes were almost interchangeable with the bad guys. The movies dealt less with the injustices in Indian society.'

Film industry cognoscenti speak of a witch-hunt by the city's police department. Salman Khan turned down several requests for interviews with The Observer .

'How can a person in the film industry get a fair trial? The police have created this media storm,' says Mahesh Bhatt, the director of Daddy and Aag (Fire). His films cater to a niche, literate audience. He has controversially tackled themes as diverse as racism, divorce and the role of women in Indian society.

'I wouldn't go as far as to draw a parallel between what is happening here and the McCarthy hearings. Not yet anyway,' says Bhatt, who has questioned Shah's detention.

'But are the police naive enough to think they can smash organised crime by investigating the film industry? These criminals are like corporations: they account for 2 per cent of the global economy. There's a rot in Indian society: and it stretches all the way to the judiciary and politics.'

But Bombay's police force, itself beset by accusations of corruption, seeks out the invisible hands controlling Bollywood as a possible vindication of its war against crime. 'This is no witch-hunt,' says D. Sivananhan, the Joint Commissioner of Police.

'The police are determined to start cleaning up these gangs,' he says. 'And in order to do that, some influential people will have to face some tough questions.'

Despite the controversy stirred by the Bharat Shah case, the tabloids are crammed with studio announcements for pending releases. Pahlaj Nihalani, president of the Film Producers' Association of India, says: 'The last year was particularly bad financially: not many films turned over a profit. So filmmakers are increasing their productivity. Most actors are committed to as many as six films a year.

'Remember that Bollywood holds a mirror to Indian society. If you find something rotten at the heart of the film world here, it's an indication of a wider malaise.'

webTitle: Euan Ferguson meets... Ken Russell

fields.headline: The Peter Pan of shock
fields.standfirst: He tested the boundaries of taste in the Sixties, then died professionally. Now the rebel is reborn, shooting a movie with a camcorder and a budget of less than £20,000
fields.trailText: He tested the boundaries of taste in the Sixties, then died professionally. Now Ken Russell is reborn, shooting a movie with a camcorder and a budget of less than £20,000.
fields.body:
'I identify a great deal with J.M. Barrie: he never grew up, never lost his innocence or sense of wonder, and that is something to be cherished'

'You're just in time to watch the orgy. Have a glass of champagne.'

This is a phrase, it's quite clear, that Ken Russell has hardly shied from in his many years; a phrase he would like to hear on his first minute in heaven. I'm quietly impressed at the supreme confidence with which he can still tilt his glass just-so and utter the words, given the bathos of our surroundings.

We are not in some ritzy private LA screening room watching Glenda frolic naked in Women in Love, waiting to spend our millions on the town that night quaffing and joshing with Ollie Reed. We are sitting at the top of exhausting stairs in a tiny Soho studio watching a blow-up sex doll and a blow-up Godzilla having simulated sex, filmed on a camcorder, while Britain's one-time most famous director attempts to dub in orgasm noises lifted from a porn movie. The film was shot on his camcorder, cost under £20,000 to make and has no buyer. He might, tragically, try to release it on the internet. He's having a lot of fun.

He is doing what he does best, matching sound to music. The film itself might stink (it's too early to say, of course, but I know where the smart money would go), as did a number of his high-profile efforts of the Seventies and early Eighties, but he remains a consummate master of split-second dubbing, and the care he brings to knitting together the screams of orgasm and the final footage of Godzilla's busy tail is the same infinitely subtle care with which he famously meshed tragic and uplifting moments from the lives of Elgar, or Debussy, or Liszt, or Tchaikovsky, to their music, which he still loves so much (Elgar's his favourite overall, since you ask; probably Falstaff ). This can never be taken away from him. The rest of the movies, and their infamy at the time - the devils, or Reed and Alan Bates wrestling naked, or Strauss and Nazi nuns - can; in fact they were. He cannot remember the last time he was asked to make a film; which is why, at 73, he's decided to do it himself with what little money he has left; he wants, again, to have fun. But despite his obvious glee, it's still an absurd come-down. What on earth happened to Ken Russell?

'Most people think I'm dead,' he says, matter-of-factly. 'I don't really know what happened. Mistakes. And, whoever you are you need an agent, and mine... well, my last agent got me one job in 20 years and my present agent hasn't got me a job at all.'

He sighs. 'You should remember that in the Seventies the Americans were all here. United Artists, Columbia, Paramount, they all had huge offices here, and weren't afraid to spend money on British ideas, and take risks. Great times. Then the tax deals got less attractive, and they also got less interested in European-style films, with irony, which were not totally commercial. If anything was happening here in England, it didn't seem to involve me. I wasn't frozen out exactly, but at one point I was offered two films: Valentino, or The Rose, about Janis Joplin, and I foolishly chose Valentino. Even more foolishly I chose Nureyev to portray him, which was a disaster. I couldn't get a performance out of him, the accent was hopeless, and he slapped his co-stars and lost the respect of the crew. It was awful, he hated everyone.

'Then I got offered sci-fi and horror movies, and foolishly turned these down. Yes, mistakes. And nothing seemed to happen. I sent scripts off to British Screen, and they were returned. I can't even remember what happened in the Nineties. Did anything happen? It's a total gap. I wrote a novel, I suppose, which didn't do well.

'So about a year ago, I had a rebirth. I got tired of waiting for the phone to ring and decided two things. One, that by hook or by crook I would make my own movies and, two, that I was tired of living alone and that I would look for company. I advertised for a soul mate.' None of his three ex-wives, unsurprisingly, responded, but a younger American fan, Elise, did, and they now look extremely happy. After he 'decided to get off my arse', life again became 'tremendous fun'.

But this, I say, can't have been what he thought he would be doing at 73?

'No.' He grows slightly grumpy. 'Not at all. I suppose I thought I would be going on being a success. I suppose I wish I had a bit more money. But this kind of film-making is why I started, to have fun with images and sound. And I'm beholden to no one.'

Did he wonder whether his fascination with modern Gothic, with shocking images and kitsch humour, had made him too much of a stereotype? 'Please don't forget I made a lot of films with no horrible images at all: The Rainbow and the BBC films on composers. Song of Summer , about Delius, is probably my best. But I don't resent the others. They made an impact.' Which was - you guessed it - 'fun'.

'The Sixties were a great time for pushing back the boundaries; we could do it, so we did. I think, paradoxically, Britain is now much less tolerant; the culture is narrowing rather than broadening...' He went to the Evening Standard film awards, 'where I sat next to Twiggy, and I suddenly realised the Sixties were like the Twenties. It was an age of invention, of fun, of exuberance. Things happened. I could make Women in Love and the Music Makers. I could make documentaries on composers nobody had ever heard of, and show them to a mass audience. That's now gone, completely, and it's sad; we're left with the Daily Mail mentality, where everything's safe and yet prurient.'

He thinks, and sighs again. 'Perhaps I should have moved to America. If I had I'm sure I would have done better. If you're on the end of a telephone to them it's as if you're on Mars; if you're there beside them, they believe in you. But I wanted to keep living here. I love the New Forest. It's steeped in folk memory. You never feel lonely.'

He doesn't know, exactly, from where his fascination with the modern Gothic stems and doesn't want to to have 'said' anything about it. But he does talk, probably tellingly, about one project: 'I was asked to do a script on Peter Pan for an American company, and it seemed to write itself. It's called Never land , and the script's been accepted with no changes, which is astonishing, and I believe it could happen.

'I found myself identifying a great deal with J.M. Barrie: he never grew up, never lost his innocence or his sense of wonder, and that is something to be cherished. I've still a lot of that inside me.' His smile is cherubic.

One suspects that in the fast-moving cultural times of the Seventies and Eighties, in the fastest-moving medium, he just didn't grow up enough. Even now, with the camcorder movie, the preoccupations seem terribly dated; and not even Sixties, but Eighties; goths and punk and rock stars and sex dolls and lubricious outrage, there to shock for shock's sake rather than make a wider point, at a time when it's all been done.

His amanuenses now are two girls from the 'Underground Movement'; one is called Emma Millions, the other Tulip Junkie. It seems tired, and slightly sad; growing up is not always a bad thing. But there is something exuberantly life-affirming in his refusals either to go quietly, or to have an attack of taste. Glass of champagne? Thank you, Ken. Cheers.

webTitle: Tim Atkin: Seal of approval

fields.headline: Seal of approval
fields.standfirst: £92 for a bottle of wine with a screwcap? Does the Clare Valley campaign mark the end of the cork?
fields.trailText: £92 for a bottle of wine with a screwcap? Does the Clare Valley campaign mark the end of the cork?
fields.body:
The Clare Valley is an unlikely setting for a revolution. This unhurried, gently bucolic spot, an hour-and-a-half's drive to the northwest of Adelaide, has a reputation for producing some of Australia's finest Rieslings, but it's not exactly a hotbed of radicalism and sedition. The thought of local wine producers manning the vinous barricades is faintly absurd. Or was, until the 2000 vintage.

Just over a year ago, 14 Clare Valley wineries decided to bottle some or all of their Rieslings with screwcaps (or Stelvin closures, as they're known Down Under). Screwcaps don't have a particularly good image in Australia, despite the fact that they are arguably the best closure for wine.

They don't have a very good image here, either. Screwcaps are generally associated with Lambrusco, cheap Spanish Muscat and the park-bench set. I once saw a less-than-sober customer in a branch of Kwik Save tearing the top off a bottle of Moscatel de Valencia before he'd got to the checkout. When Penfolds did a consumer trial with their Bin 2 Shiraz/Mourvèdre in the UK, they met with considerable resistance from consumers. Natural corks, however unreliable, were their closure of choice.

The remarkable thing about the Clare Valley initiative (apart from the fact that it happened at all) is that the producers concerned include some of the best in the country, such as Mount Horrocks, Jim Barry and Jeffrey Grosset. These are not cheap, low-end operations. The Clare Valley group has started an important trend. It is surely no coincidence that, in the Napa Valley, PlumpJack recently released its 1997 Reserve Cabernet with a screwcap at $135 (£92) a bottle. In my view, it will be the first of many.

So far, the Australian public has been enthusiastic about screwcaps. There have been one or two (possibly apocryphal) reports of consumers taking bottles back to off-licences with corkscrews stuck in the cap, but most people have been happy to 'twist, not screw' as the Jim Barry marketing campaign would have it.

Stephanie Toole, the feisty owner of Mount Horrocks, says that the reaction has been very positive Down Under. 'People have told me that, "We're sick of bloody cork,"' she says. 'There's nothing better than opening a bottle and pouring it without having to worry.' She thinks that unwooded Semillon and early-drinking red-wine producers could follow the Clare Valley's lead over the next few years. 'We have to educate the consumer, but it's only a matter of time.'

Toole says that the cork industry has 'upped the ante' in Australia, with comments in newsletters and sniping from the various wine consultants it employs. 'They invited me to a dinner last year, but I didn't go, I thought the idea was dreadful,' says Toole. Worryingly for the cork industry, the Clare Valley screwcap brigade is growing in number. Several companies that were reluctant to do the twist in 2000 have ordered the required bottles and closures for the 2001 vintage. The revolution continues.

Best cellars Four millennial Rieslings to savour

2000 Jim Barry Watervale Riesling (£5.99, Tanners, 01743 234 500; General Wine Company, 01428 722 201). Jim Barry bottled part of its production with corks in 2000, including, sadly, the stuff that has been shipped to the UK. But this is still a good introduction to Clare Riesling, with ripe, full-flavoured lime and citrus-peel fruit and a softish, dry finish.

2000 Grosset Watervale Riesling (£11.99, Milton Sandford, 01628 829 449). The more approachable of Jeff Grosset's two Clare Rieslings, this Watervale bottling shows flavours of lime, pineapple and apple with the structure and intensity that are so typical of his style. I vastly preferred this to the same wine bottled with cork.

2000 Mount Horrocks Watervale Riesling (£11.95, Bennetts, 01386 840392; Connolly's, 0121 236 9269; Harrods, 020 7730 1234; Vin du Van, 01233 758 727). Made in the same cellar as Jeffrey Grosset's wines (Toole and Grosset are partners), this has, nonetheless, a totally distinct style. It's a juicy, beautifully defined Riesling with notes of lime and honeysuckle, underpinned by taut acidity.

2000 Grosset Polish Hill Riesling (£14, Milton Sandford). The best Riesling in the Clare Valley and, even in a difficult vintage like 2000, the best Riesling in Australia. If the Watervale bottling is open and loose-limbed, this is a much tighter, more restrained white. A minerally, stony Riesling with the potential to age for a decade or more.

It is surely no coincidence that, in the Napa Valley, PlumpJack recently released its 1997 Reserve Cabernet with a screwcap at $135 (£92) a bottle. In my view, it will be the first of many. So far, the Australian public has been enthusiastic about screwcaps. There have been one or two (possibly apocryphal) reports of consumers taking bottles back to off-licences with corkscrews stuck in the cap, but most people have been happy to 'twist, not screw' as the Jim Barry marketing campaign would have it. Stephanie Toole, the feisty owner of Mount Horrocks, says that the reaction has been very positive Down Under. 'People have told me that, "We're sick of bloody cork,"' she says. 'There's nothing better than opening a bottle and pouring it without having to worry.' She thinks that unwooded Semillon and early-drinking red-wine producers could follow the Clare Valley's lead over the next few years. 'We have to educate the consumer, but it's only a matter of time.' Toole says that the cork industry has 'upped the ante' in Australia, with comments in newsletters and sniping from the various wine consultants it employs. 'They invited me to a dinner last year, but I didn't go, I thought the idea was dreadful,' says Toole. Worryingly for the cork industry, the Clare Valley screwcap brigade is growing in number. Several companies that were reluctant to do the twist in 2000 have ordered the required bottles and closures for the 2001 vintage. The revolution continues. Best cellars Four millennial Rieslings to savour 2000 Jim Barry Watervale Riesling (£5.99, Tanners, 01743 234 500; General Wine Company, 01428 722 201). Jim Barry bottled part of its production with corks in 2000, including, sadly, the stuff that has been shipped to the UK. But this is still a good introduction to Clare Riesling, with ripe, full-flavoured lime and citrus-peel fruit and a softish, dry finish. 2000 Grosset Watervale Riesling (£11.99, Milton Sandford, 01628 829 449). The more approachable of Jeff Grosset's two Clare Rieslings, this Watervale bottling shows flavours of lime, pineapple and apple with the structure and intensity that are so typical of his style. I vastly preferred this to the same wine bottled with cork. 2000 Mount Horrocks Watervale Riesling (£11.95, Bennetts, 01386 840392; Connolly's, 0121 236 9269; Harrods, 020 7730 1234; Vin du Van, 01233 758 727). Made in the same cellar as Jeffrey Grosset's wines (Toole and Grosset are partners), this has, nonetheless, a totally distinct style. It's a juicy, beautifully defined Riesling with notes of lime and honeysuckle, underpinned by taut acidity. 2000 Grosset Polish Hill Riesling (£14, Milton Sandford). The best Riesling in the Clare Valley and, even in a difficult vintage like 2000, the best Riesling in Australia. If the Watervale bottling is open and loose-limbed, this is a much tighter, more restrained white. A minerally, stony Riesling with the potential to age for a decade or more.

webTitle: Nigel Slater: King of cabbages

fields.headline: King of cabbages
fields.standfirst: It's crunchy, flavoursome and regal in its magenta coat, so why is the red cabbage always last off the rack?
fields.trailText: It's crunchy, flavoursome and regal in its magenta coat, so why is the red cabbage always last off the rack?
fields.body:
There has been a red cabbage in the bottom of the fridge for longer than I care to say. It has been quietly watching me, probably wondering when it was going to get its 15 minutes of fame. Once the purple pride of my shopping bag, it now sits and haunts me as surely as an unposted thank-you letter.

You cannot wait to get certain vegetables into the pot - bunches of spinach, those frilly hearts of kale as beautiful as any Valentine bouquet and, for me especially, the spoon-leafed Chinese veggies such as pak choi and their juicy stems. They have an urgency that invites you to cook them the minute you get them home. Others just sit there quietly nagging, continually passed by for something fresher and more short-lived, until their wizened presence embarrasses us enough to put them out of their misery.

It is always the same with winter vegetables. The last two celeriac I bought ended up on the compost heap - shame on me - but I promise never to let it happen again. I picked them up in a fit of enthusiasm for their creamy ivory skin and lush plume of emerald green. Those leaves dried to a crisp, their skin withered and turned grey - in short, they rotted. Deep down I knew they were there, waiting patiently as I roasted pumpkins, steamed mustard greens and blitzed beetroot into juice. Every time I put a Savoy cabbage, a bunch of fat carrots, a football-sized red cabbage into my bag, I could hear them screaming: 'Use us, use us.' After a fortnight or so, their pleas had become a barely audible whimper. After three weeks in the vegetable rack, my heads of celeriac resembled nothing more than Norman Bates's mother in her rocking chair.

My red cabbage on the other hand is beginning to feel like an old friend. We renew our friendship once a week when I clean out the salad drawer, rekindling my enthusiasm by peeling off another layer of blackening leaves, once as crisp as chicken bones, to reveal a fresh purple gloss. This week, I promise.

The initial excitement was for its deep magenta leaves with their dusty bloom of mauve. As you turn the hard head of leaves over in your hand, you cannot but help picture the brilliant, jewel-like colours you will get when your shredded red cabbage meets the sting of wine vinegar. Yet I rarely get round to using a red cabbage till its outer skin is black and its once-tempting crunch has softened to a dull thud. This vegetable's keeping-qualities are its downfall. Put it into the same use-me-quick category as spinach or sorrel and it would be the star of any table.

When it finally gets to the stove, the red cabbage is almost certain to meet its knee-jerk fate of being cooked with apples and vinegar. And I don't see why not - the pairing works. Cabbage of any colour likes meeting up with juniper berries, garlic, onions, apples, vinegar and pork. Such flavours flatter. But there are others, too. I made a crisp salad this week with shredded cabbage lightly fried in oil then drained and tossed with lumps of fried smoked bacon, crumbled pecan nuts, rough shards of Cheshire cheese and a mustard, oil and white-wine vinegar dressing. It was a little gem of a winter salad.

Bacon has crept into many of the season's vegetable dishes. The smoky saltiness is perhaps the answer to accompany the roast parsnips, to tip over the mashed swedes and to sneak into the cabbage stir-fries that make up much winter fodder. It will turn up with the new head of celeriac I have just bought, too. I will coarsely grate it while the vegetable is still firm and pale and toss it in the hot bacon fat with some toasted walnuts and some roughly chopped fennel fronds. This week, I promise.

Boiled gammon and red cabbage with juniper sauce

Cabbage has a well-known affinity with ham, as does apple, and all three work beautifully with juniper. It seemed only natural to bring them all together for a winter's Saturday lunch. I have used some of the ham's cooking liquor in the juniper sauce and just a very little cream, but given it some edge with a squeeze of lemon. Five of us ate this for a Saturday lunch with baked sweet potatoes. The fluffy, vivid orange potatoes took about 50 minutes at 200 C/gas mark 6 and made sense what with the slight bitterness of the cabbage and juniper and the fact that the hob is already full with ham, sauce and cabbage pots and the oven empty. We had a bit of Stilton and the rest of the celery afterwards. Serves 5-6.

1.5kg piece of smoked gammon
1 bottle of apple juice
2 large carrots
2 sticks of celery
2 leeks
1 small onion
2 or 3 bay leaves
8 juniper berries

for the cabbage

a little peanut oil
2 cloves of garlic, peeled and finely chopped
1 small red cabbage or half a larger one, finely shredded

for the sauce

3 ladlefuls of the gammon cooking liquor
6 or 7 juniper berries, crushed in a pestle and mortar
1-2 tsp Dijon mustard
3-4 tbsp double cream
a squeeze of lemon juice

Put a large pot on the stove, sit the gammon in it, and pour in the apple juice and enough water to lap at the top of the meat. Bring to the boil, then skim off the froth that comes to the surface. Turn the heat down so that the liquid is just bubbling, then slide in the carrots and celery, nicely scrubbed, the washed leeks, the onion, bay leaves, the juniper berries and 4 or 5 whole black peppercorns. Let the meat simmer gently for about an hour, maybe a little longer, until it is cooked right through to the middle. If you are doing the baked sweet potatoes, and I hope you are, then put them in when the ham has been on for about 20 minutes.

Once the ham is cooked, get a frying pan hot with a little peanut oil in it. Add the garlic, then the shredded cabbage, tossing it around for a minute or two over high heat until the cabbage is bright and garlicky.

Remove three or four ladlefuls of the stock into another, smaller pan, add the juniper berries and let it boil until it has reduced by half. This will only take a few minutes at a good boil. Now stir or whisk in the mustard and the cream and grind in a little black pepper. Taste for salt - I find it doesn't need it, but much will depend on your ham.

Carve the ham, laying it in a warm dish or plate with some of the cooking liquor spooned over to keep it moist and hot. Take it to the table with the sauce (give it a last-minute bubble to get it really hot), squeezing in the lemon at the last minute. Serve the ham, the cabbage and the potatoes, spooning a little of the juniper sauce over the ham as you do so.

Red cabbage with juniper and dill

You could, of course, eat this sweet-sour cabbage with pork or bacon. I ate it with store-bought rollmops, and some big, fat boiled potatoes. Lots of chopped dill, and a glass of beer turned it into a pleasant enough supper. The rollmops were sharp and cold, and the potatoes hot and floury, and the cabbage hot and sweet and sour. I had found some dark rye bread, too. Lively tastes for a winter's day.

There is nothing new about adding sweet and sharp flavours simultaneously to red cabbage. You could substitute sultanas or raisins for my apricots if you wish (I used them because of their sweet-tartness), and you might prefer white-wine vinegar to my red. The point is simply to soften the cabbage's 'cabbaginess' with a mixture of sweet and sharp flavours. The juniper berries bring a bitter herbal note, too. Serves 4 as a side dish.

half a small cabbage, or a quarter of a larger one

1 onion

a little olive oil

1 fat clove of garlic

the juice of 1 orange

6 juniper berries

6 dried apricots

3 tbsp red-wine vinegar

a few bushy springs of dill

Peel the onion and cut it into thin slices. Put it into a heavy-based pan with a little olive oil and set it over a low to moderate heat. Shred the cabbage finely, cutting away and discarding the hard core. Rinse thoroughly, then drain and add to the onion with the garlic, peeled and sliced, and a good grinding of salt. Turn the cabbage in the oil, raising the heat if nothing much is happening, till the colour is bright - a matter of a minute or two.

Halve the orange and squeeze it. Squash the juniper berries roughly, maybe with the flat of a heavy knife blade or a pestle. You don't want them so much to be a powder, more simply well bruised. (The smell will be not dissimilar from that of a gin and tonic.) Slice the apricots. Pour the juice and stir the berries and apricots into the cabbage, cover with a tight lid, and leave to steam for 15 minutes or so. You want the cabbage to be soft and vivid purple.

Pour the vinegar into the cabbage and leave for a minute till most of it has evaporated, then chop the dill and toss it in.

webTitle: Monty Don: Prim and proper

fields.headline: Prim and proper
fields.standfirst: Harbinger of spring, the modest primrose stands out among its more gaudy neighbours
fields.trailText: Harbinger of spring, the modest primrose stands out among its more gaudy neighbours.
fields.body:
There is a sense in which journalists should not write about things they really care for, lest either that affection is displayed for what it is - a flimsy, irrational, delicate thing - or else they somehow exhaust the emotion in the articulation. I feel like that about primroses. I know that I love them but I am not really sure why or how. But they hit the spot with devastating accuracy every time. Perhaps flowers are like a perfume, tugging at memory and response as you pass, irresistibly cutting a swathe through the densest protection.

By primrose I do not mean the whole range of primulas (400-odd species and, according to The RHS A-Z Encyclopedia of Garden Plants (£50, Dorling Kindersley) - now in two volumes so using it is less like balancing a palmful of bricks - 'Primula is a complex genus divided into many botanical sections'). I mean Primula vulgaris , the prime rose, the first flower that grows best in hazel coppices and deciduous woodland with clearings around oak standards, but which also grows on the mossy banks of lanes and tracks across this country from January through to Easter. This unimproved, unhybridised, straightforward, exquisite flower has the magic.

This morning I picked a little bunch - not many, because they are not yet prolific in the garden and will not be so for another week or two - made terribly fragile by the ice that encrusted them, although in fact they are tough and able to take almost any weather that Britain can conjure. Half of them were almost transparent with cold but slowly absorbed their familiar colour as the warmth crept into them. One of the reasons that I cannot be doing with the hybrids is simply the power of the colour association with the word 'primrose'.

These few petals in the tiny vase by my keyboard, growing sodden as the frost in their veins thaws, are their own colour. This actually ranges quite loosely from the palest yellow to quite an orangey lemon, but a primrose cannot be violet or apricot or magenta - or worse - and retain any sense of self. That type of breeding from natural species is like some crazy branding exercise by a group of shiny-arsed management consultants, as though inventing names is on par with creating something. I would strongly argue that the wild primrose is literally perfect and that any attempt to 'improve' it is a profound misuse of time and energy.

The hummocks of leaf and flower at this time of year are tight and tangled, but they grow out from this as the weeks go by until they make a natural posy, the flowers arched artfully from the surrounding splay of leaves.

Many years ago, when I was a child, it was an annual ritual to collect baskets of primroses to decorate the church and graveyard at Easter. We would set off up to the woods and coppices and plunder them for their flowers. These would be tied into posies of varying generosity, depending on how good a year it was - and I seem to remember that it varied a lot from year to year - but whatever the size of the bunch, they were always tied with coloured wool and always included three or four leaves. These would be carried up to the church on Easter Saturday in a container of water, before going round with a dibber to each grave and planting each bunch into the ground. Quite a few graves in that tiny churchyard were unmarked grassy mounds and I liked the way the little bunch of pale yellow flowers made instant headstone and garland. There's a new TV twist for you - graveyard makeovers.

Although we would carelessly strip all open flowers from a patch of primroses, I don't recall it affecting the subsequent year's harvest, and I see that Richard Mabey, in his Flora Britannica (£35, Sinclair Stevenson) says there is no evidence that picking does any harm. I suppose it slows the spread from seed, but it is not as if the plant was systematically deflowered. Plenty came before and after our Good Friday picking that produced seed enough.

Lest I romanticise this too much, I must admit that I regarded it as a chore and would always try to escape the duty. They looked fine as they were and each stem seemed so tiny and the basket so big_ I'd snatch at them, or try to pick two at once, and invariably the flowers would break off. I am proud to say that I felt a touch of guilt about this. But, with hindsight, the good thing was that it taught me to look at a flower very closely, to recognise instantly its lovely scent, to know how it grew and shaped itself and to see where it was most easy and prolific. How many children get the chance to do that today?

For a gardener, it drums home the obvious but vital importance of giving each plant conditions as close to its natural environment as possible. The logic for me is to grow plants that either originate locally or in conditions similar to those of this garden, rather than trying to create an 'unnatural' microclimate. So all our primroses are planted in the tiny coppice that we have been nurturing for the past five years. They like wet soil best, with summer shade. The drier the local climate, the more they need shade and heavy soil that will hold moisture.

So, if you are planting primroses and you do not live in the wet west, add plenty of organic material to help conserve moisture for the roots. If you are putting them into a bank, plant them near the top as they will tend to spread down, and plant at least two clumps so they can cross-pollinate. They will spread steadily, especially if exposed to light every few years, so if they are in a border make sure they are underplanting shrubs that can be pruned hard every now and then, such as cornus, hazel or willows. The primrose's natural companions are violets, bluebells, and - if you are lucky and the wood is very old - wood anemone.

Some people lump primroses and cowslips ( Primula veris ) together, but in fact they like very different conditions, with cowslips coming from free-draining chalky downland. I grow ours along the verge of a grass path, letting the grass grow up tall until the cowslips have seeded, and then mow them in with the grass (by now very long) in July. Primroses would resent this kind of treatment and don't do well in grass unless the ground is very wet. They can more or less be left alone, although they do not seem to mind being moved and can be split easily enough. The best time to do that is in early summer, when they have completely finished flowering. Primroses and cowslips have apparently always crossed, and it was from this union that the polyanthus was bred. I cannot love this offspring a fraction as much as I care for both parents. I know they have a gaiety and freshness when massed - as in the nuttery at Sissinghurst - but it is that pink again. I have a lot of trouble with pink.

Actually, the polyanthus is chiefly bred from the false oxslip, itself a natural and common cross between cowslip and primrose (so why the ox? Why not cowrose or primslip?). It is recognisable from the true oxslip because it holds its flowers upright and primrose-like at the top of a cowslip-like stalk.

The true oxlip, Primula elatior , has its flowers hanging modestly to one side and is a species in its own right, and very rare. Where it does occur - mainly in a small patch on the Essex/Suffolk border - it grows profusely and, locally, can seem terribly common. It is primrose-like in that it likes plenty of moisture and will grow happily in woods as well as damp meadows - which the cowslip will not do. To be honest, looking at its picture while writing this makes me wonder why we do not grow the true oxlip here. We will.

My roots

I spent the whole of last week in London. This had its odd moments - as in Cherie Blair looking me in the eye and saying, 'Who the hell is Monty Don?' and somehow I don't think she was coming over all metaphysical - but two places struck me most. The first was Chelsea Physic Garden, which I know of old. This time I got a guided tour around its glasshouses, potting shed and seed-packing room, which was a great treat.

The thing that struck me most - other than the quiet air of modest expertise that hung over the place - was how their resources were no greater than many a private garden I have been to. I still expect gardens of the great and good to have a secret - some system or kit that explains things. There never is. It is just people doing something carefully and well. So visit the Physic Garden and give it some money - they will spend it wisely.

I also went to a city farm - Mudchute, on the Isle of Dogs. No garden, of course, and more an animal sanctuary than a farm, but in its own way impressive and entirely laudable. Whereas the Physic Garden is tucked away, the Mudchute City Farm is open to the landscape, overlooked by the towers of Canary Wharf. But seeing both together made it clear to me that although I love farming and grew up with it, in the end tending animals is not enough. I have to grow things.

This is the longest that I have been away from the garden for six months, so at first light on Saturday I did a proprietorial sneak round, checking changes with that mixture of excitement and dread that any gardener is familiar with.

In fact, a week of flooding and frost meant that not much had grown. But the daffodils are rising green-fused from the blackened tatters of their pre-Christmas leaves. The big frost between Christmas and New Year did for that early growth, but obviously not for the bulbs. I have a nasty suspicion that it also did for the Clematis balearica 'Freckles', which flowered for the first time last year and was budding up well. The snowdrops are in their prime and the hellebores are nakedly appearing, heads down and leafless.

But the best thing in the garden happened before I got up. At 6.45am the light began to open up and a robin and then a wren sang modestly for 15 minutes and then were quiet. Not much. Hardly a dawn chorus. But I got the message. Gently, quietly, stepping over rain and ice, springtime is coming in.

This actually ranges quite loosely from the palest yellow to quite an orangey lemon, but a primrose cannot be violet or apricot or magenta - or worse - and retain any sense of self. That type of breeding from natural species is like some crazy branding exercise by a group of shiny-arsed management consultants, as though inventing names is on par with creating something. I would strongly argue that the wild primrose is literally perfect and that any attempt to 'improve' it is a profound misuse of time and energy. The hummocks of leaf and flower at this time of year are tight and tangled, but they grow out from this as the weeks go by until they make a natural posy, the flowers arched artfully from the surrounding splay of leaves. Many years ago, when I was a child, it was an annual ritual to collect baskets of primroses to decorate the church and graveyard at Easter. We would set off up to the woods and coppices and plunder them for their flowers. These would be tied into posies of varying generosity, depending on how good a year it was - and I seem to remember that it varied a lot from year to year - but whatever the size of the bunch, they were always tied with coloured wool and always included three or four leaves. These would be carried up to the church on Easter Saturday in a container of water, before going round with a dibber to each grave and planting each bunch into the ground. Quite a few graves in that tiny churchyard were unmarked grassy mounds and I liked the way the little bunch of pale yellow flowers made instant headstone and garland. There's a new TV twist for you - graveyard makeovers. Although we would carelessly strip all open flowers from a patch of primroses, I don't recall it affecting the subsequent year's harvest, and I see that Richard Mabey, in his Flora Britannica (£35, Sinclair Stevenson) says there is no evidence that picking does any harm. I suppose it slows the spread from seed, but it is not as if the plant was systematically deflowered. Plenty came before and after our Good Friday picking that produced seed enough. Lest I romanticise this too much, I must admit that I regarded it as a chore and would always try to escape the duty. They looked fine as they were and each stem seemed so tiny and the basket so big_ I'd snatch at them, or try to pick two at once, and invariably the flowers would break off. I am proud to say that I felt a touch of guilt about this. But, with hindsight, the good thing was that it taught me to look at a flower very closely, to recognise instantly its lovely scent, to know how it grew and shaped itself and to see where it was most easy and prolific. How many children get the chance to do that today? For a gardener, it drums home the obvious but vital importance of giving each plant conditions as close to its natural environment as possible. The logic for me is to grow plants that either originate locally or in conditions similar to those of this garden, rather than trying to create an 'unnatural' microclimate. So all our primroses are planted in the tiny coppice that we have been nurturing for the past five years. They like wet soil best, with summer shade. The drier the local climate, the more they need shade and heavy soil that will hold moisture. So, if you are planting primroses and you do not live in the wet west, add plenty of organic material to help conserve moisture for the roots. If you are putting them into a bank, plant them near the top as they will tend to spread down, and plant at least two clumps so they can cross-pollinate. They will spread steadily, especially if exposed to light every few years, so if they are in a border make sure they are underplanting shrubs that can be pruned hard every now and then, such as cornus, hazel or willows. The primrose's natural companions are violets, bluebells, and - if you are lucky and the wood is very old - wood anemone. Some people lump primroses and cowslips ( Primula veris ) together, but in fact they like very different conditions, with cowslips coming from free-draining chalky downland. I grow ours along the verge of a grass path, letting the grass grow up tall until the cowslips have seeded, and then mow them in with the grass (by now very long) in July. Primroses would resent this kind of treatment and don't do well in grass unless the ground is very wet. They can more or less be left alone, although they do not seem to mind being moved and can be split easily enough. The best time to do that is in early summer, when they have completely finished flowering. Primroses and cowslips have apparently always crossed, and it was from this union that the polyanthus was bred. I cannot love this offspring a fraction as much as I care for both parents. I know they have a gaiety and freshness when massed - as in the nuttery at Sissinghurst - but it is that pink again. I have a lot of trouble with pink. Actually, the polyanthus is chiefly bred from the false oxslip, itself a natural and common cross between cowslip and primrose (so why the ox? Why not cowrose or primslip?). It is recognisable from the true oxslip because it holds its flowers upright and primrose-like at the top of a cowslip-like stalk. The true oxlip, Primula elatior , has its flowers hanging modestly to one side and is a species in its own right, and very rare. Where it does occur - mainly in a small patch on the Essex/Suffolk border - it grows profusely and, locally, can seem terribly common. It is primrose-like in that it likes plenty of moisture and will grow happily in woods as well as damp meadows - which the cowslip will not do. To be honest, looking at its picture while writing this makes me wonder why we do not grow the true oxlip here. We will. My roots I spent the whole of last week in London. This had its odd moments - as in Cherie Blair looking me in the eye and saying, 'Who the hell is Monty Don?' and somehow I don't think she was coming over all metaphysical - but two places struck me most. The first was Chelsea Physic Garden, which I know of old. This time I got a guided tour around its glasshouses, potting shed and seed-packing room, which was a great treat. The thing that struck me most - other than the quiet air of modest expertise that hung over the place - was how their resources were no greater than many a private garden I have been to. I still expect gardens of the great and good to have a secret - some system or kit that explains things. There never is. It is just people doing something carefully and well. So visit the Physic Garden and give it some money - they will spend it wisely. I also went to a city farm - Mudchute, on the Isle of Dogs. No garden, of course, and more an animal sanctuary than a farm, but in its own way impressive and entirely laudable. Whereas the Physic Garden is tucked away, the Mudchute City Farm is open to the landscape, overlooked by the towers of Canary Wharf. But seeing both together made it clear to me that although I love farming and grew up with it, in the end tending animals is not enough. I have to grow things. This is the longest that I have been away from the garden for six months, so at first light on Saturday I did a proprietorial sneak round, checking changes with that mixture of excitement and dread that any gardener is familiar with. In fact, a week of flooding and frost meant that not much had grown. But the daffodils are rising green-fused from the blackened tatters of their pre-Christmas leaves. The big frost between Christmas and New Year did for that early growth, but obviously not for the bulbs. I have a nasty suspicion that it also did for the Clematis balearica 'Freckles', which flowered for the first time last year and was budding up well. The snowdrops are in their prime and the hellebores are nakedly appearing, heads down and leafless. But the best thing in the garden happened before I got up. At 6.45am the light began to open up and a robin and then a wren sang modestly for 15 minutes and then were quiet. Not much. Hardly a dawn chorus. But I got the message. Gently, quietly, stepping over rain and ice, springtime is coming in.

webTitle: Pukka tucker

fields.headline: Pukka tucker
fields.standfirst: Four more surprising Michelin stars  by Sue Webster
fields.trailText: Four more surprising Michelin stars  by Sue Webster
fields.body:
Despite his jolly image as a rotund chap in, er, bandages, Michelin has always been perceived in this country as a ferocious guardian of classical cuisine. So is he going soft? After all, a Michelin star has just been awarded for the first time to a (very nice) pub, The Stagg Inn, Titley, Herefordshire (01544 230 221). Here are three more starred restaurants that might surprise you.

Harry's Place Great Gonerby, Grantham (01476 561 780). What regular diners really value at Britain's tiniest Michelin-starred restaurant - the 10-seater Harry's Place - is that Harry Hallam always cooks for you, single-handedly, and his wife is front of house. Said house is their own Georgian village abode, and would-be diners often go on a waiting list in the hope of getting one of the three tables. It's an unpressured affair, with just two dishes to choose from at each course - Lincolnshire woodcock roasted with bacon and sage or fillet of monkfish, say.

Tamarind 20 Queen Street, London W1 (020 7629 3561). This is the other posh Indian place in the capital to be awarded a star for the first time this year. It has elegant service, a serious wine list, and a cool setting, complete with sari fabric under glass created by Emily Todhunter. Chef Atul Kochhar is an Indian-trained chef who was talent-spotted at The Oberoi in Delhi and enticed to London to cook real Indian food. He specialises in complex North-Western dishes, prepared in the peek-a-boo tandoor, which also turns out fantastic traditional breads.

Ockendon Manor Cuckfield, West Sussex (01444 416 1111) It's a surprising year for chef Martin Hadden, former wonder boy who slaved at The Halcyon in London for six years in an effort to win a star, then quit for lack of budgetary support from the hotel management. Now he's in this rural backwater, the Michelin inspectors have finally seen fit to crown his inventive French cooking with a star for Ockendon, a beautiful country house hotel. Diners can enjoy an eight-course feast featuring the likes of crispy salmon teriyaki and grilled boudin blanc with caramelised apple and new potatoes for £55. The only irony is that Hadden had been despairing of winning a star, and three days before exchanged contracts on the 30-seat Priory House Restaurant, Stoke-sub-Hamdon, Somerset (01935 822 826), where he thought he'd be in a better position to achieve his dream. He opens on 16 February, so the starry quest starts all over again.

webTitle: Shortfall in NHS GPs as thousands retire early

fields.headline: Shortfall in NHS GPs as thousands retire early
fields.trailText: Patients face a drastic shortfall of thousands of family doctors undermining the government's plans to speed up treatment, a new analysis of NHS shortages claims.
fields.body:
Patients face a drastic shortfall of thousands of family doctors undermining the government's plans to speed up treatment, a new analysis of NHS shortages claims.

Up to 4,700 doctors are expected to retire in the next eight years, many of them part of a wave of Indian doctors recruited in the 1960s and now reaching pensionable age, according to figures collected by the Liberal Democrats.

And doctors' leaders accused Labour of denting hopes of future recruitment and retention by "politicising" shocking cases such as the Harold Shipman murders, using them as a stick with which to beat other GPs.

Ministers are now considering increasing their promise to train 2,000 doctors amid blunt warnings from the profession that it is nowhere near enough.

"I am fed up with people saying there is no problem in the medical workforce when frankly there is," said Dr Lawrence Buckman, of the BMA's general practitioners committee.

The Lib Dems calculate that the sudden rush of retirements - coupled with new responsibilities under the 10-year NHS plan, which the BMA estimates would require up to 10,000 more doctors - could eventually create a shortfall of up to 15,000 doctors. Family doctors can in theory work until they are 70, but on average retire 10 years earlier.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said ministers were working with the BMA to solve the problem.

webTitle: Confident kids likely to try drugs

fields.headline: Confident kids likely to try drugs
fields.trailText: Young people with high self-esteem are more likely to take illicit drugs than those whose self-confidence is low, new research has revealed.
fields.body:
Young people with high self-esteem are more likely to take illicit drugs than those whose self-confidence is low, new research has revealed.

The findings contradict the conventional wisdom that drug-taking is most prevalent among anxious or insecure youth looking for an escape from poor conditions or a way to feel better about themselves.

Instead, up to 27 per cent of young people with high self-esteem had used illicit substances compared with only 20 per cent of their less self-confident peers. Experts say the new research means an overhaul of drug education programmes is necessary.

The survey of 15,000 children aged 14 and 15 was conducted by the respected Schools Health Education Unit (SHEU) in Exeter.

On most occasions the drug tried was cannabis, though solvents and amphetamines also featured in responses, said David Regis, who led the research team.

'Unfortunately the results blow a hole in the simple moral fable that young people are led into the paths of righteousness by high self-esteem,' he said.

Two factors are thought to explain the results. More confident children are more likely to be sociable, have more money and thus have more opportunity to experiment with drugs. And they are also often more willing to indulge in 'risk-taking' activities, ranging from extreme sports to class-A drugs.

Research reveals that though youngsters who describe themselves as 'experimental' cigarette smokers often have low self-esteem, those who call themselves 'committed' smokers have self-esteem levels as high or higher than average.

Heather Ashton, a professor of pharmacology at Newcastle University who has studied patterns of drug-taking among students, said last week that the results of the SHEU survey did not surprise her: 'Students all report they take drugs for pleasure and that it has nothing to do with anxiety or stress. Years ago young people who did [drugs] were seen as psychotic or low or risk-takers. Now that is not the case.'

Ashton's research shows that one in five university students says he or she uses cannabis at least once a week. It also shows that a typical cannabis joint in the Sixties contained only 10mg of a potent chemical known as THC which affects the brain. The typical joint now, with more sophisticated cultivation and plant breeding, contains more than 150mg and has a far more potent effect.

The report detailed the damage long-term use of cannabis can do to cognitive ability, memory, coordination and the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.

webTitle: 'Asylum debate is a shameful example of political and journalistic lying'

fields.headline: 'Asylum debate is a shameful example of political and journalistic lying'
fields.standfirst: Forget about principles, asylum seekers are only welcome if they guarantee our future prosperity
fields.trailText: Forget about principles, asylum seekers are only welcome if they guarantee our future prosperity.
fields.body:
I lay myself open to two charges when I say that the asylum 'debate' is the most shameful example of political and journalistic lying I have heard in 20 years as a reporter. The first, that I sound like a sententious saloon-bar berk, is unduckable and must be taken on the chin. The second is encapsulated by the rejoinder: what about the competition? It's ferocious, I grant you. But the merits of rival claimants cannot trump the pretence that we treat refugees decently. Since the early Nineties, grateful New Labour and Conservative politicians have been allowed to - encouraged to, in fact - get away with transparent falsehoods by media inspired by hatred of strangers (the far-Right press) and a credulous trust in authority (the BBC and ITN).

Last Sunday, Tony Blair and Giuliano Amato wrote in these pages of their detestation of 'the horrors illegal immigrants endure at the hands of the people traffickers' and promised, 'in all that we do, we will honour our obligation to provide protection to those fleeing persecution'.

It was an old, big lie, which was polished by Jack Straw at the European Union justice ministers conference in Stockholm on Thursday when he posed as a tough yet tender statesperson who wanted to be 'generous toward genuine refugees' while taking a 'tougher line' against economic migrants.

In a Westminster world where words have been yanked from their moorings to meaning, comprehension comes when you grasp that the truth is invariably the exact opposite of what is said. The leaders of the European Union have created people-trafficking gangs as surely as prohibition created bootleggers. Blair and Straw are doing everything they can to stop 'genuine refugees' finding sanctuary. As for economic migrants, we love them for their labour and taxes.

The 1951 United Nations Convention on Refugees allows the victims of political oppression to claim shelter in safe countries. Britain has been subverting its enlightened principles for years. Whenever conflicts begin, the Home Office imposes visa restrictions on the suffering countries. The persecuted who are running from Saddam Hussein or the Taliban cannot travel to Britain legally unless they have a visa.

But, and here is where the Home Office shows its slyness, we don't give visas to those who say they want asylum or are suspected by embassies of thinking of claiming asylum. As a result, authentic refugees can be slandered as 'illegal immigrants' when they arrive at Dover.

To make sure they get the message, Britain and her European allies fine the owners of planes, trains, ships, cars and lorries if they carry passengers who don't have visas. Last week the last breach in the walls was plugged when France agreed to allow British immigration officers on to the Eurostar. The various News at Tens reported the restrictions as a blow against illegal immigrants without explaining why the aliens were illegal or noting that genuine victims of persecution were among their number. I suppose I've no right to be shocked after all these years.

Desperate people take desperate measures. For want of legal means of travel, refugees have turned to smugglers and visa forgers whose businesses have been boosted by Blair and his colleagues. Not everything is going the gangsters' way. Britain now receives the greatest number of asylum applications in Europe because the far greater flow of millions from the former Yugoslavia, most of whom went to Germany, has been stemmed by the Kosovo campaign (for which the PM can take credit) and the fall of Milosevic.

The keepers of Fortress Europe remain frustrated, however, and plan to get rougher still. The French are proposing that carriers who allow undocumented refugees to travel should be fined and then made to return them to the point of embarkation. Straw, meanwhile, is demanding mass expulsions.

His hope that refugees seeking a home in Europe could be forced to live in camps in the Third World, while interior ministries decide whether they would accept them, puzzled observers. Why on earth would dirt-poor countries, which already have to look after the majority of the world's refugees, cooperate?

The short answer is that they will be bullied and bribed into compliance. Last year the European Union signed a new Lomé convention with the nations of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. They were compelled to accept the repatriation of people 'illegally present' in Europe - as asylum seekers tend to be - or lose £8.5 billion in aid and trade. The victims of the world's greatest crimes will either be sent back to face their local police chiefs or confined behind wire in neighbouring states. (The EU has told the Turks that it will finance the building of internment camps for refugees who come into their territory and promised the persecutors of the Kurds that the jails would not be troubled by UN inspectors.)

Straw will soon be free to engage in gesture politics. If a celebrity reporter finds a wounded girl with a cute face in the next Sarajevo, I'm sure she will be rushed to Great Ormond Street Hospital. If the cameras aren't there, I suspect compassion will evaporate. When you put their cruelties to the political class, you are often treated to a bluff lecture on pragmatism. We agree with much of what you say, you're told, but live in the real world, son. There's only so much immigration society can take. We're civilised people, but you should see our swinish voters. If we aren't mean, there will be a racist backlash.

The force of this argument is blunted by the generally tolerant welcome asylum seekers receive in British cities - despite the hard work of the Daily Mail, there's been nothing to compare with the fire-bombings of hostels in Germany. It is refuted by the desire of European Union governments to allow mass immigration.

The baby-boomers who are now in power have, somewhat carelessly, failed to produce enough sprogs to generate the wealth which might pay for their pensions. As this is a generation unused to privation, something must be done. Barbara Roche, the immigration Minister, who rants at gypsy mothers and presides over a system of relief which has brought asylum seekers to the edge of starvation, is therefore singing the positive virtues of economic migration.

With an ageing and declining population, Britain requires doctors, computer programmers and engineers as well as skivvies and navvies to do the dirty work. A Home Office report released last month said that about 150,000 immigrants from outside the EU will be needed every year for 20 years if the economic show is to be kept on the road. Roche was not reviled by the press. Even the Mail praised her. Prejudice must never threaten profits.

Everyone in power can empathise with people who move to make money. What they find intolerable and incomprehensible are those who run for their lives because they have made a stand on -- of all things! - political principle.
