Barbara Roche, the immigration Minister, who rants at gypsy mothers and presides over a system of relief which has brought asylum seekers to the edge of starvation, is therefore singing the positive virtues of economic migration. With an ageing and declining population, Britain requires doctors, computer programmers and engineers as well as skivvies and navvies to do the dirty work. A Home Office report released last month said that about 150,000 immigrants from outside the EU will be needed every year for 20 years if the economic show is to be kept on the road. Roche was not reviled by the press. Even the Mail praised her. Prejudice must never threaten profits. Everyone in power can empathise with people who move to make money. What they find intolerable and incomprehensible are those who run for their lives because they have made a stand on -- of all things! - political principle.

webTitle: Reorganisation brings power back to the regions

fields.headline: Reorganisation brings power back to the regions
fields.standfirst: A very English revolution is taking place as a stealthy reorganisation brings power back to the traditional regions of the country
fields.trailText: A very English revolution is taking place as a stealthy reorganisation brings power back to the traditional regions of the country.
fields.body:
So here's the deal. New Labour has lost interest in a new politics in which a progressive coalition with the Lib Dems is created by proportional representation; the battle to include a manifesto commitment to a referendum on PR in the next parliament has been lost. It had no champions and powerful enemies.

But there is an important potential quid pro quo. There promises to be a compensating commitment to establish elected assemblies for the English regions if supported by regional referendums, with a voting system modelled on London's, where a form of PR is used to top up the assembly's numbers. The new politics will be piloted in the new regional capitals, cities such as Leeds, Newcastle, Birmingham, Bristol, Manchester and Norwich.

Regionalism is not where you would first look for votes or even policy innovation, or so most London-based commentators instinctively feel. You either need a big idea or some eyecatching national policy - selling council houses or slashing taxes - if you want to cut a political dash. Wrong.

Britain and England have been subtly changing for more than 15 years, and there are the first signs of a new self-confidence in our regions and regional cities, together with an appetite for tackling their problems locally. Labour, with its powerful political base in precisely these areas, has been quick and astute enough to identity the change. This is a party and government that moves cautiously - behind public opinion if it can - so if it recognises a new support for regional politics, be sure its antennae have detected something stirring.

In the 1980s, I spent five years as economic correspondent for Newsnight or, rather, as it sometimes seemed, the economic chronicler of Britain's regional woes under Thatcherism. There seemed no city outside London which did not in one way or another tell the same tale of de-industrialisation, economic decay and social disintegration, with a local political and social élite desperately concerned but unable to do anything as power was increasingly concentrated in Westminster and Whitehall. You couldn't make the same reports today; the economic, social and cultural depression is no longer so ubiquitous.

There remain areas of apparently endemic and irredeemable blight, but there is nowhere which does not have a hot spot of vigorous economic activity with living standards and attitudes that match those of London. Indeed, London itself is desperately polarised with incredible wealth and poverty coexisting in the same boroughs, especially in the north-east and south-east.

What Labour has grasped, partly as a matter of intellectual conviction and partly as a recognition of political reality, is that while national policies of redistribution, reinforcement of public services and encouragement of enterprise go so far they need to be customised to the needs of individual regions. And that the only effective agencies are the people whose fates and loyalties lie with particular cities and regions and who are now beginning to agitate against their political powerlessness.

Economic and social problems vary hugely, even within England. One pressing problem is to establish proper east-west rail links between the North-West and North-East. In the Midlands, where 60 per cent of Britain's internationally traded goods are manufactured, the issue is how to grow and sustain a smart manufacturing base to replace ageing and uncompetitive plant. In Yorkshire, Leeds has emerged as a national and regional growth pole; it needs to be supported rather than undermined by the ambitions of its rivals, while Yorkshire itself needs to raise its level of business start-ups and hi-tech presence.

In the South-East, the question is how to balance London's potential destiny as the pre-eminent global city with the needs of the rest of the region. In the South-West and East Anglia, the dominant issue is how to deal with stunning levels of illiteracy and innumeracy. All require regional initiatives where the priorities are importantly different.

This has long been the view of Richard Caborn at the Department of Trade and Industry and Hilary Armstrong at the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. Il capo of English regionalism, John Prescott, has made the case consistently, generally to deaf ears. But for the past three months, the argument has taken off, the most important convert being Gordon Brown. Two weeks ago, he called for a 'Britain of regions and nations with a new dynamism', continuing: 'We are moving from the old Britain of subjects, where people had to look upwards to a Whitehall bureaucracy for their solutions, to a Britain of citizens where, region to region... we are ourselves in charge.'

Brown has come to this view not least because of the economic arguments, set out last week in a paper edited by Ed Balls, chief economic adviser to the Treasury, and John Healy MP, Brown's parliamentary private secretary. Six out of eight English regions have per capita incomes below the European average, writes Balls. National solutions go so far, but real engagement with regional failings must come from the bottom up. If that were successful, then Britain would have more balanced growth and close the productivity gap with its rivals.

Balls wants to build on the eight English Regional Development Agencies already established by Labour, giving them more cash and more flexibility to prioritise what they choose. He accepts they need to be accountable, but the system he, along with the Chancellor, proposes is to use the existing network of regional chambers - a collection of regional notables and local councillors - alongside a new regional committee in the House of Commons. They need to go further and my suspicion is that they already have. By 2004, the RDAs will be spending £1.7 billion between them, a scale of publicly-led investment not seen since the days of the Industrial Reorganisation Corporation in the 1960s and the National Enterprise Board in the 1970s; indeed, RDAs are emerging as New Labour's interventionist arm.

But if accountability and bottom-up engagement are to mean anything, RDAs need to be held to account by their local communities, in other words, elected regional assemblies.

Here, Labour enters a witch's brew of internecine rivalries as powerful regional cities campaign to be the regional capital - Sheffield against Leeds, Manchester against Liverpool, Newcastle versus Sunderland - with the open question being whether there are really any regional loyalties that might underpin the legitimacy of the new assemblies. My view is that Labour has little choice. It wants vigorous RDAs and the demand for accountability and regional political direction is following in their wake. The regional chambers are powerless talking shops. Necessarily they must become elected, reinventing the English regions of the Saxon era - and the manifesto is about to accept that ineluctable logic.

Proportional representation was meant to reinvent British politics, which it would have done, but the march of regionalism is no less significant. New Labour conceives of the assemblies as toothless tigers, but already we know better, as London, Scotland and Wales have proved. We are watching, instead, the quiet and long overdue reinvention of the British state.

webTitle: It takes just four minutes to log into paedophile web

fields.headline: It takes just four minutes to log into paedophile web
fields.trailText: The computer was already switched on in a quiet corner of The Observer's London offices. I picked a search engine at random. So far so simple. Typing in the most innocuous term which sprang to mind, 'pre-teen', I expected to have a long, complicated trawl through the world wide web ahead.
fields.body:
The computer was already switched on in a quiet corner of The Observer's London offices. I picked a search engine at random. So far so simple. Typing in the most innocuous term which sprang to mind, 'pre-teen', I expected to have a long, complicated trawl through the world wide web ahead.

But it took four minutes. Without being asked for payment or identification or a credit card number, the computer screen showed a series of the most disturbing photographs I have ever seen - graphic pornographic images of little children.

I had asked an IT expert to help me discover just how accessible child porn really was on the internet. I thought we might find a suggestion of it. But these were not dirty pictures: this was child abuse of the most horrific kind. Some images were of naked little girls who had been encouraged to strike adult porn star poses. A click on the mouse took us straight to another website, again with a strip of photographs across the middle of the screen.

'Very littli (sic) girls 3-9 year old,' ran a banner headline. 'Free photos from Russian Undegraund (sic) Server.' The face of a child aged no older than seven was pictured pushed against the genitalia of an adult male. Next to her came a picture of a tiny child whose body was being violated by the man holding the camera.

The experiment was over, I could not stomach any more but shutting down the web page was so difficult; endless pop-up adverts directed the user to an endless array of other sites where children had been abused in horrific circumstances.

One such child was Donna, aged 10, whose photograph was put on the internet by the father of her best friend. No one who knew her had any idea she was being abused until the man was arrested after a complaint by another child. Donna's horrified mother was told her daughter had not only been raped but that rape had been filmed and put on the internet.

The Observer also visited chatrooms where sexual fantasies were discussed and liaisons arranged. It took longer, perhaps up to an hour, before a paedophile, anonymous behind his electronic protection, cruised through one of the chatrooms looking for 'young boys'.

A spokesman for the National Crime Squad said last night that the speed at which we had found such images was no surprise. 'Availability of paedophilic material is a massive problem,' he said. 'The availability of these sites is increasing and we are working on ways of preventing this happening.'

webTitle: Members of international paedophile ring to be sentenced

fields.headline: Members of international paedophile ring to be sentenced
fields.trailText: It seemed like an ordinary club, with a chairman, a treasurer and a board of long-serving and respected members.
fields.body:
It seemed like an ordinary club, with a chairman, a treasurer and a board of long-serving and respected members.

Everyone had a nickname and there were the usual petty rows: grumbles that too many members were being allowed in without going through the official channels or being approved by the hierarchy.

But it was the sinister entry fee that exposed the fact that this was no ordinary club: each new member had to supply 10,000 pornographic images of children.

This was the Wonderland Club, an international online paedophile ring which ran for four years before finally being smashed by the biggest international police operation ever undertaken.

Tomorrow, seven British members of the ring will be sentenced at Kingston Crown Court for 'conspiring with others to distribute indecent images of children'. The legal jargon masks a terrible reality: Wonderland was an international network of paedophiles involving the rape of boys and girls live on camera and the traffic in images of the torture of children as young as two months.

The international investigation to crack the ring was the biggest in policing history, taking in 13 countries and 180 men. Led by British officers, on 2 September 1998 police forces simultaneously kicked in the doors of 107 homes and made 104 arrests.

The suspects included the usual collection of outsiders: unemployed loners in UK bedsits, a father and son in a US trailer-park. But they also numbered a computer consultant in an Italian penthouse apartment, a German professor and a Canadian medical student who had trained on a children's hospital ward. The more senior members of the club earned their status by providing photographs and videos of themselves performing sex acts with children. In a perverse paedophile version of Hollywood, certain children became 'stars'.

One prolific abuser, Gary Salt, invited other members to visit his Stockport home to pose with children in front of the webcam as if they were meeting a screen hero. Thesheer weight of the physical evidence illustrates the enormity of Operation Cathedral - 750,000 individual images of children and 1,800 computerised videos depicted children being sexually abused.

The images were so appalling that National Crime Squad officers who had to sift through the mountain of material had compulsory therapy sessions to help them deal with what they saw.

'These really are quite horrific images,' said Alex Wood, deputy chief inspector of the NCS. 'These are kids being subjected to the most serious, serious, abuse.'

The ring began to unravel after the arrest of Ronald Riva in Greenfield, California. Officers discovered that Riva had raped his daughter's 10-year-old friend in front of a camera which relayed the live image onto the internet. The child, who had been invited to a slumber party by Riva's daughter, is one of only two of the 1,236 Wonderland victims to have been traced. The other, a Portugese boy, has disappeared and police fear he may have been murdered.

Among six men who had typed messages of encouragement to Riva was Ian Baldock, a 31-year-old computer consultant from St Leonards, East Sussex. The FBI informed the UK police, who soon realised the scale of the enterprise they had stumbled on. Operation Cathedral was born.

'At first there was not enough police knowledge or power,' said Wood.

'We had to bring in computer experts who worked with us for 14 months. Once we had traced actual computers we then had to establish who was using that computer at a particular time and with many of them in libraries and universities it wasn't easy.'

Round-the-clock surveillance on suspects had to be introduced to ensure none had access to children while the investigation was ongoing. At one point, the operation almost collapsed when one British man, Gavin Seagers, was discovered working with Sea Cadets. The police knew that if they arrested him they risked tipping off the whole network. Tracing the victims of the Wonderland Club is now a priority. New technology is being tested out by Interpol based in Lyons, France, to enable photographs sent in by social services and families to be 'matched' by computer against the victims' photographs. Already 900 children have had their photographs 'sanitised' and stored and police forces across the world will be able to access them.

The British Government introduced legislation last month to increase maximum sentences for the possession of child porn from six months to five years. Those caught producing or distributing the images will now receive sentences of 10 years rather than the present maximum of three. But the new sentences will not apply to the Wonderland Club.

Next month the internet Crime Forum at the Home Office will publish a report on chatrooms where child abusers discuss their fantasies. Police have become concerned that these forums are being used to 'groom' children and lure them to meetings with paedophiles. The report is likely to make depressing reading. A Home Office spokesman told The Observer : 'We have a very co-operative relationship with internet service providers, but it is technologically impossible for them to stop this stuff.'

In April, a new cyber-crime unit will start work involving 80 officers from the police, Customs and the National Criminal Intelligence Service.

According to the National Association of Probation Officers most internet offenders do not see themselves as criminals and few receive treatment. Spokesman Harry Fletcher said: 'We are only beginning to understand the scale of this crime. It is a major problem that their offending behaviour is not being challenged.'

webTitle: Patient killed in hospital after injection blunder

fields.headline: Patient killed in hospital after injection blunder
fields.trailText: A hospital has apologised after a patient died as a result of being wrongly injected with local anaesthetic into a vein rather than the spine. The patient died yesterday following what should have been a routine procedure to relieve pain.
fields.body:
A hospital has apologised after a patient died as a result of being wrongly injected with local anaesthetic into a vein rather than the spine. The patient died yesterday following what should have been a routine procedure to relieve pain.

Stuart Welling, chief executive of Royal Sussex County Hospital in Brighton, said: 'I apologise unreservedly to the family for this error and offer them my deepest sympathy.'

The patient underwent major surgery three days ago for an aortic aneurysm, a weakness in a blood vessel. Afterwards the patient was given the painkiller Bupivicaine, but it was injected by mistake into the vein by a senior consultant, who has been suspended.

Two separate inquiries have been initiated by the hospital and the Royal College of Anaesthetists. No details of the patient have been released at the request of the person's family.

Spinal pain relief is routinely given after many operations. One in three women in labour receive epidurals, and complications are extremely rare. It involves inserting a needle into the spine and passing a tiny catheter into the epidural space in the back, through which local anaesthetic can be administered.

The fatal blunder came a week after the death of Wayne Jowett, aged 18, who had an anti-cancer drug accidentally injected into his spine instead of a vein at the Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham. Two junior doctors have been suspended.

Last year the chief medical officer published a report admitting one in 10 patients going into NHS hospitals suffer some sort of harm, a total of 850,000 patients a year. It costs the NHS about £2 billion a year to provide the extra treatment needed as a result of non-fatal mistakes.

One study suggests medical accidents result in about 33,000 deaths a year in Britain - about 12 per cent of all deaths in hospital.

webTitle: 'Billy Elliot' payout for poor pupils

fields.headline: 'Billy Elliot' payout for poor pupils
fields.trailText: Working-class children will be given piano lessons, ballet classes and other traditional perks of a middle-class childhood under a revolutionary £35 million government 'credit' to level the educational playing field.
fields.body:
Working-class children will be given piano lessons, ballet classes and other traditional perks of a middle-class childhood under a revolutionary £35 million government 'credit' to level the educational playing field.

Education Secretary David Blunkett wants the state to make it up to the pupils left standing at the school gate while their wealthier peers are whisked off for after-school treats and coaching.

The 'Billy Elliot' revolution' aims to bridge the gap with up to £360 per pupil at some inner city schools to pay for activities broadening children's horizons and nurturing artistic talent - such as theatre visits, drama classes or music lessons.

'These ideas are a crucial contribution to targeting cash at youngsters and schools who need it most, to do what better-off parents or leafy suburban communities are already able to afford,' said one senior source.

Blunkett will tomorrow publish his blueprint for the future of schools, expected to promise new targets for raising standards among 11- to 13-year-olds. Trainee teachers will also have their student debts paid off by the Government if they stay in subjects where there are serious shortages such as maths and science, in an incentive to recruitment.

And the Excellence in Cities programme - turning around failing inner city schools and tempting middle-class parents to send their children - is expected to be extended to a third of all schools. This follows evidence that pupils' GCSE results improve faster where the scheme is used.

The theme of the plan will be an equal chance for every child through to university and beyond.

For the first time it will focus not only on improving disadvantaged children's exam scores and basic skills, but on their wider lives through the pupil learning credit scheme for cultural extras. Blunkett will make clear the activities for 11- to 16-year-olds - which could be after school or during the day - will open their eyes to an educationally stimulating world.

'Anyone who has been anywhere near a school to collect their kids, off to a piano lesson or ballet class or whatever, will have noticed the children that don't get to go, don't get any stimulation like that, and it's not the parents' fault - they just can't afford it,' said one source.

The scheme is reminiscent of the film Billy Elliot in which a boy from a working- class background takes up ballet, to the mockery of his family and classmates, only to turn out to be a star.

The number of £2,000 bursaries helping disadvantaged teenagers go to university will also be more than doubled.

Pupil learning credits will target up to 65,000 children from disadvantaged backgrounds from September.

Schools must have more than 35 per cent of pupils claiming free school meals to qualify and will get grants starting from £240 per child, rising to £360 for the worst off. The cash will be used by schools to set up clubs or pay for trips.

Ministers believe the two-year pilot scheme can give poorer children a chance to tap into undiscovered talents. Blunkett also wants all primary school children at least to have the chance either to learn a new sport or a musical instrument.

Meanwhile, Trade Secretary Stephen Byers will unveil plans making it easier for the founders of small businesses to bounce back if their start-ups fail. Honest people who go bankrupt through no fault of their own could be free to return to business within 12 months rather than after the present three-year quarantine. But malicious bankrupts who behaved dishonestly or recklessly would be banned from being directors of limited companies and forced to notify anyone with whom they have business dealings for a 15-year period.

webTitle: Why House of Mouse is haunted by failures

fields.headline: Why House of Mouse is haunted by failures
fields.standfirst: Internet collapse and falling TV audiences mar Disney's success, writes  Edward Helmore
fields.trailText: Internet collapse and falling TV audiences mar Disney's success, writes Edward Helmore
fields.body:
There was hardly a cloud in the sky last week when Disney chief executive Michael Eisner proudly opened the California Adventure, the company's latest theme park. It was a picture-perfect Disney moment, all gaiety and happy endings.

The same cannot be said for Disney itself. The entertainment colossus has been experiencing heavy weather. Although it narrowly beat analysts' downgraded financial expectations for the last quarter of 2000, its overall performance is far less impressive than the 22 per cent rise in headline earnings suggests.

The 'House of Mouse' has been enjoying strong performances at the box office and reliable attendance at its theme parks, but rising costs and the slowing US economy, combined with the collapse of its internet ambitions and weakness in its holdings in ABC television and cable channel holdings, could soon spell real problems.

Ten days ago, Disney reported improved sales and earnings for the whole of its last financial year. Revenue increased by 9 per cent to $25 billion, compared with $23bn in 1999. But in the last quarter net income fell by 82 per cent to $63 million. 'The year ended better than we had expected but not better than what we knew was possible, given our company's wealth of assets,' Eisner said.

The company attributes its successful year to ABC's hit television quiz show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? and record operating results for its theme parks and resorts in the US, Asia and Europe. Yet Disney shares fell by 15 per cent amid concern about future earnings.

One of Disney's biggest problems is what to do with ABC. Like its main rivals NBC and CBS, the network is struggling for ratings. A year ago, ABC was riding towards prime-time supremacy and record profits on the unexpected success of Millionaire. One year later, the game show has plunged back to earth, and for ABC it has suddenly become a life raft.

Mired in a deep creative slump, marked by only one genuine sitcom hit in four years, ABC depends on the four-times weekly show more than ever. Analysts say Millionaire, which has more episodes in a year than most shows produce in a lifetime, is both a wonder drug and a dangerous addiction for ABC. Although its editions are all still among the top 10 popular programmes, its ratings are down this season by an average of about 26 per cent - a decline that helps to expose a lack of new hits, or even of serviceable new shows.

'Our biggest concern is what happens if it fades more,' a top ABC executive said.

Once the master of family-orientated, middle-American-style comedies such as Home Improvement, ABC slashed its programme budgets by as much as half, lulled by the vast profits its aspirational gameshow was making. So while other networks made 30 or more pilot shows last season, ABC made only 12.

'Nobody's that smart,' says one TV producer. 'You have to take more shots than that. It's just the nature of this business to make a lot of pilots, because you don't know which will work.'

Perhaps even more worrying for ABC is that its Millionaire addiction has raised the median age of its audience from 41 to 46, while it has failed to launch new, 'younger' shows. This is serious, because ABC, like rivals NBC and Fox, bases all its success on how well it fares with viewers aged between 18 and 49, the group most sought by advertisers.

'Millionaire was the ultimate Band-aid,' says Sandy Grushow, Fox's chairman of entertainment. 'The question is whether it covered a scab or a tumour. Millionaire bought them one year. We thought it would be at least two.'

Disney's troubles, however, reach beyond ABC. The failure of its internet business is a significant blow. It is in good company - all the other media outlets and networks - from CNN to the New York Times - are scaling back their web investments and cutting staff, but Disney's ambitions were always much grander.

Its offering, Go.com, was supposed to become a fully-fledged portal, but that business had long since been sewn up by America Online and Yahoo! At its inception in January 1999, the company predicted it would have more than 8 million registered users and an audience share of 36 per cent.

But the visitors never came and Disney abandoned its struggling operation, laying off 400 staff, putting its search engine up for sale and refashioning its stalled internet strategy last month. It withdrew its internet tracking stock from trading - it was the first big company to do this - and said it would take more than $800m in charges against its earnings.

But Disney has not ruled out buying what it has been unable to create for itself. Last week, Eisner told Wall Street analysts he would 'pounce and pounce well' when he saw an opportunity.

He may be willing to pursue Yahoo! as a means of competing with the merged entertainment behemoth AOL Time Warner - if the price was right. 'Yahoo is a great company,' he said. 'The problem is it's just over-valued - and way too expensive at $50bn or even $25bn.'

But he responded to criticism that Disney has been too timid in seeking acquisitions by saying: 'We are not going to make one to give journalists headlines, to make bankers wealthy, or for our egos.'

The company maintains that an internet enterprise remains central to its strategy. Disney president Robert Iger said the decision to close Go.com was made in order to focus on the company's branded sites, such as Espn.com and Disney.com, while formulating a broadband strategy that could soon deliver pay-per-view movies directly to homes and bypass traditional video distribution.

Tom Staggs, Disney's chief financial officer, said: 'We're going to focus on those businesses where we think we can create value.'

Meanwhile, Disney's consumer products arm, which sells merchandise based on its screen heroes, continues to suffer, with operating income down nearly 14 per cent to $177m, while revenue fell 6 per cent to $828m. About 100 of its 700 retail stores will now be closed.

But Disney has found suc cess in its theme parks - including Disneyland Paris, which reported a 64 per cent increase in net income for the year. Once dismissed as little more than a long-term property investment, these are now being praised for extracting more revenue from customers.

A knotty succession problem has been settled with Iger's appointment, and questions over Eisner's famously controlling management - arising after his ill-advised court battle with former lieutenant Jeffrey Katzenberg - seem to have receded. Nevertheless, more than a dozen top managers have left in the past two years, and of the four men he started with in 1984, Eisner is the only one left.

So can Disney regain its lustre on Wall Street? It expects double-digit growth this year, but economic uncertainty and the success Disney finds with summer blockbuster films such as Pearl Harbor are likely to dictate the answer.

webTitle: Private lives pulped as PCC earns praise

fields.headline: Private lives pulped as PCC earns praise
fields.trailText: There was a triumphalist tone to the trumpet Lord Wakeham was blowing this week as chairman of the Press Complaints Commission. His smart bash at Somerset House to celebrate the PCC's tenth birthday was a huge public relations success.
fields.body:
There was a triumphalist tone to the trumpet Lord Wakeham was blowing this week as chairman of the Press Complaints Commission. His smart bash at Somerset House to celebrate the PCC's tenth birthday was a huge public relations success.

Even though the coverage of the event was less about the PCC and press self-regulation and more about the soap opera involving Prince Charles, Prince William and Camilla Parker Bowles, that one glamourous event must have done more to raise public awareness of the PCC than its entire promotion budget for the past decade.

Wakeham, it has to be said, has a lot to be triumphant about. The old Press Council, from which the PCC sprang in 1991, had lost all credibility with politicians and the public. It had been destroyed by the press itself. When the old Press Council reprimanded John Junor, then editor of the Sunday Express, for a racial slur in his personal column, he repeated the offending words in print and called the Council 'po-faced, pompous, humourless twits'. Margaret Thatcher knighted him two years later for his services to journalism.

When the old Press Council investigated the orgy of chequebook journalism that built up around Sonia Sutcliffe, wife of the Yorkshire Ripper, it found that David English, then editor of the Daily Mail, and others of Fleet Street's finest evaded, lied and failed to cooperate. English refused to attend an oral hearing. When he and his paper were found guilty of gross misconduct, Sir David (for he had been knighted by Thatcher while the inquiry was in progress) wrote an article in which he described the findings as 'short-term, short-sighted and smug', proving 'yet again that the Press Council still does not understand the concept of a free press'.

Looking back over the PCC's first decade, Wakeham deserves congratulation for rescuing it from a shaky start. Sir David Calcutt's 1993 review of its first two years concluded that it had failed and should be replaced by a statutory body. Also that year, a Commons Select Committee came out in favour of privacy legislation, and the erratic behaviour of its first chairman, Lord McGregor, over a case involving clandestine photographs of Princess Diana in a leotard, caused the Mirror Group to pull out of the PCC for several days.

So to arrive at glittering Somerset House from the dark days of 1993 has been a real achievement. With the Prime Minister, Culture Secretary Chris Smith and Tory leader William Hague all declaring that freedom of the press is central to democracy and the PCC its handmaiden, Wakeham can say: 'There are no serious commentators now who believe that statutory controls are either desirable or practical.' Indeed, compared with the self-regulated complaints machinery operated by lawyers or doctors or bankers, the PCC is now pretty good.

Wakeham's next claim, though, goes too far. He asserts: 'The PCC - with the absolute commitment of editors themselves and their publishers - has changed the entire culture of British newspapers.'

The wily old ex-chief whip has successfully fixed the politics of self-regulation for the time being. The close personal relationship between the PCC's director, Guy Black, and his predecessor, Mark Bolland, who is now private secretary to Prince Charles, effectively covers the exposed royal family flank.

But he deludes himself if he thinks he has led a cultural revolution. For the PCC is in the business of broking between individuals with a complaint and the publications that ran their stories.

It is not in the business of ethics. Unlike its counterpart, the Broadcasting Standards Commission, it does not research public attitudes to media issues, and it declines to take complaints from 'third parties'.

So, if a person who feels abused by the press does not personally complain, the PCC system remains silent.

If you put all this together with falling newspaper circulations and today's much greater media focus on personalities and private lives, my guess is that there is more invasion of privacy by the press than there was 10 years ago.

What is more, broadsheet editors have realised that their readers are every bit as interested as tabloid readers are in the private lives of the well-known.

A reporter from a broadsheet, not a tabloid, was clearly mystified a month ago when I said that I would not confirm gossip about someone I know on the grounds that it was an entirely private matter.

Of course, the PCC's code has a 'public interest' clause. It is the duty of the press to expose crime, malpractice and hypocrisy in high places. But, as evidence that there has been no change in the past decade in the culture of British newspapers over the right of the individual to be let alone, I offer at random the following (half from broadsheets, half from tabloids):

 Details of the private life of banker Amschel Rothschild, who committed suicide in Paris in 1996.

 The revelation the same year that Joan Bakewell and Harold Pinter had been lovers.

 Details of Glenn Hoddle's marriage breakdown in 1997.

 Disclosures about the sex life of Anthea Turner in 1998.

 The revelation the same year that Des Lynam had an affair while covering the World Cup.

 The disclosure, also in 1998, that the retired and widowed Admiral Sir James Eberle had had a relationship with a prostitute.

All of these stories will have interested the public, but which of them actually involved 'the public interest'? Answers on a postcard to the PCC, please.

Hugh Stephenson is Professor of Journalism at City University, London.

Peter Preston is away.

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText:
Unreal Mandy?
Peter Mandelson denied reports in the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph that he is angling for a European Commissioner's post, despite being seen at both papers' offices over the past few days. In a move which will further raise concerns about his mental state: Mandy says: 'I wish they would fill the papers with things that are real.' So what about the Financial Times' sympathetic feature on Thursday charting his downfall? After all, it appeared just two days after Mandelson had a long meeting with FT editor Richard Lambert.
fields.body:
Unreal Mandy?
Peter Mandelson denied reports in the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph that he is angling for a European Commissioner's post, despite being seen at both papers' offices over the past few days. In a move which will further raise concerns about his mental state: Mandy says: 'I wish they would fill the papers with things that are real.' So what about the Financial Times' sympathetic feature on Thursday charting his downfall? After all, it appeared just two days after Mandelson had a long meeting with FT editor Richard Lambert.

The half Monty
What news of our favourite joker David Montgomery? Has everyone's favourite Ulsterman been overtaken by a fit of bashfulness? Diary was disappointed to find he had declined to show up for the latest results from African Lakes, the internet company he chairs. Perhaps Monty, whose other ventures included a failed bid for the Express and a magnificently inspired effort to put internet kiosks in pubs, no longer enjoys the limelight. It was left to Richard Wilkinson, executive deputy chairman, to mouth the courageous spiel about 'connecting Africa'. Monty, we understand, has decided that given the shabby treatment he receives from some critics in the press, it is better to leave the PR stuff to others.

On the Ball
BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball seemed on top form at the press conference for his half-year results. But a Sky insider spoiled his apparently spontaneous witticisms by informing Diary: 'He used exactly the same lines at the analysts' meeting.'

fields.headline: Mental health laws are rigging the scales of justice
fields.standfirst: But the real scandal is the dearth of psychiatrists and of hospital beds for the mentally ill.
fields.trailText: But the real scandal is the dearth of psychiatrists and of hospital beds for the mentally ill.
fields.body:
A crowd of 200 had gathered to watch the prisoner arrive. Mothers and fathers with pushchairs and small children in tow, screamed 'Scum', and 'Die' and 'Kill the bastard'. A man built like a Charolais and dressed in sweatshirt and trainers hurled himself at the silver police people-carrier bearing Roy Whiting, a 42-year-old mechanic, to Chichester Magistrates Court, where he was remanded in custody last Wednesday, charged with the kidnap and murder of Sarah Payne.

The fury of the mob had been stoked at first by horror at the killing of an eight-year-old and by the News Of The World 's subsequent name-and-shame campaign. More recently the police, if not whipping up hysteria, have, seemingly, done little to tamp it down. A week ago, detectives helpfully tipped off the press that they planned to charge Whiting, who had been arrested and questioned twice previously, within three days. It was believed, though not confirmed, that their breakthrough hinged on an appeal by the BBC's Crimewatch programme.

As a 'senior police source' told the Daily Mail: 'The incident room has not stopped working since the day little Sarah disappeared. The man is due to be arrested... and the mood among many officers is buoyant.' If true, this revelation of police hubris is a disgraceful affront to justice.

Roy Whiting is innocent in the eyes of the law. He has entered no plea and faced no jury. Once a quaint old protocol decreed that, at the whiff of an arrest, a veil of secrecy descended. Now, it seems, practically anything goes in high-profile murder cases, where tragedy elides with show business and the public clamours for results.

Can Whiting get a fair trial, given the weight and type of publicity surrounding Sarah's murder? Among other examples of goldfish-bowl defendants, the next in line is Barry George, a prime focus of the media spotlight, who goes on trial for Jill Dando's murder in a fortnight.

One can see why three Appeal Court judges resisted the argument that Michael Stone should not have his case tested again in court because, as his barrister claimed, 'the wealth of prejudicial material... would make such a retrial unfair'. Perhaps, given the tonnage of pre-publicity surrounding criminal cases, the best to be hoped for is an amnesiac jury.

Later this week, the judges will give their reasons for ordering a retrial following their decision to quash Stone's conviction for the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter, Megan, and the attempted murder of Josie Russell, after a key witness had been shown to be unreliable.

The Russells will have to revisit their tragedy. Kent police may, in due course, have some tough questions to answer as to why justice miscarried. For now, the best that can be said of the whole debacle is that the appellate process has been shown to work. Whether Stone is found guilty or innocent, his case was treated with a swiftness denied to others.

Last week Stephen Downing finally walked free, after serving 27 years for the murder of Wendy Howell, a crime he almost certainly did not commit. Disgracefully, he was held in prison long after he would normally have been released, because parole boards refuse to free those who do not admit their guilt.

Last week too, the case of a man hanged for the murder of a cinema manager in 1950 went to appeal after the solicitor for George Kelly's family argued that 'the police and courts believed it was more important to secure a conviction to reassure the public than to properly investigate a crime'.

So what's changed? A quarter of a century after Kelly went to the gallows, the notorious West Midlands Serious Crimes Squad began its regime of torture, bogus confessions and creative note-taking, resulting in a litany of miscarriages of justice. The Birmingham Six were wrongly convicted, and Ann Whelan spent 17 years fighting for the release of her son, Michael Hickey, and watching his life unravel in prison before it finally emerged that he and the two other living members of the Bridgewater Four had been framed by the Squad. How long ago it seems since the wrongful conviction of Judith Ward, Stefan Kiszko, the Maguire Seven, the Guildford Four. How far we have come since then.

But not, perhaps, quite far enough. The Criminal Cases Review Commission is over-loaded with petitioners claiming to have been wrongly sentenced, and the Crown Prosecution Service remains unaccountable, prone to arbitrary decisions and strapped for cash. While science should make convictions watertight, the perception - or the reality - can be quite the opposite. The pattern of invisible blood spots that clinched the case of Sion Jenkins, the teacher found guilty of murdering his step-daughter, Billie-Jo, did not impress a number of powerful advocates who argue that he should never have been convicted. That unease, and the worries raised by the Michael Stone case, don't, of course, denote a return to the corrupt ways of the Seventies.

There are, however, new considerations in an age when locking people up is becoming so simple. Not long ago, Tony Blair announced plans to take DNA samples from everyone arrested in Britain. Fine, except that genes are already being interpreted not only as evi dence of a crime committed but as indicative of one that might be. If genetic profiling becomes part of police investigation, then the presumption of innocence dies. The Law Commission is expected soon, in the light of DNA advances and Sir William Macpherson's recommendations, to relax the 'double jeopardy' principle, under which an acquitted suspect cannot be retried for the same offence. Fine, unless the police and CPS produce slovenly prosecution cases, knowing they can always have another bash.

But the really iniquitous development is the promise by Government of post-election legislation indefinitely to detain people with untreatable personality disorders. Though the real scandal is the dearth of psychiatrists and of hospital beds for the mentally ill, Jack Straw has for years preferred to dream of incarcerating those who have committed no offence but who might. His success, framed in a recent White Paper, may delight those who choose not to recognise that schizophrenics commit 10 murders a year, or about 2 per cent of all killings. We are 20 times more likely to be killed by a sane person than an insane one, but such statistics carry little weight in a hot climate of fear in which we are encouraged to believe that a child-molesting monster lurks at every corner.

In fact, British children are the second safest in the world, according to a new survey by Unicef. But even if they were not, there would be no justification for such a gross affront to human rights. When the weight of the criminal justice system offers no guarantee that we are locking up the right suspects, incarcerating people while skipping the optional extras of a crime and a trial is hardly likely to produce good outcomes. And besides, for those failed by the courts, there is still the prospect of finding justice, even if, in Stephen Downing's case, the quest took most of his life. Jack Straw's and Alan Milburn's detainees, unconvicted but 'untreatable', may have no such luxury.

webTitle: Interview: Toby Litt

fields.headline: 'It's a boy book'
fields.standfirst: Toby Litt was born in 1968. He is the author of  Beatniks,  Adventures in Capitalism and  Corpsing, which is being made into a film
fields.trailText: Toby Litt was born in 1968. He is the author of Beatniks, Adventures in Capitalism and Corpsing, which is being made into a film
fields.body:
Observer: What is deadkidsongs about?

T. Litt: It's a boy book. I came across this book in the library on the campus at UEA [University of East Anglia]. I was looking through the American literature section and there was this book which caught my eye: The Boy Book. I didn't have a chance to read it, but it was about the death of the Boy Book. I thought, damn, I've just written a dead book, but that was probably inevitable, given the title. But it's within that tradition.

Obs: Can you pinpoint the moment you decided to write it?

TL: I have known I was going to write a book about childhood for at least 10 years. The first idea I had was called The Childhood Novel. It started with some boys hanging upside down in a tree and the alternative title was Descriptions of the English Countryside. It was going to be to do not just with the boys themselves but with everything around them. The countryside. Where they were. The time they were growing up in.

Obs: I found the novel's antecedents in the 'boyhood' stories of Graham Greene, William Golding, and even Ian McEwan. Much further back, there's Kipling and the late Victorians. Was your intention to explore that genre?

TL: Yes - or to explode it. I haven't re-read Lord of the Flies since I was the age of the boys in it. For a long while I was scared of reading it because the cover had a film still from the Peter Brook film where the boy is holding the conch. I thought the shell was a fly's egg that was going to hatch and that it was going to be a horror story where they'd all get eaten by monster flies. That's just because I was watching too much Doctor Who.

It was partly not to write about them the whole way through in a childish way. They are trying to live adult lives and the boys' power struggles are like those in a court of a king or with sycophants surrounding a dictator. They're to do with jockeying for position within a hierarchy. They don't just play at being military, they are military.

Obs: But it's also about their relationships to their families, isn't it ?

TL: Yes, two of their fathers particularly. The mothers are sidelined by the boys and the fathers are judged by the boys as to whether they are adequate.

Obs: What do you think women will make of the book?

TL: I'm not sure. I wrote it to be honest about a certain kind of violence and that is likely to be upsetting. I couldn't write the equivalent girl book. It would be a different kind of violence, I think.

Obs: Did you always want to be a novelist?

TL: Well, I had the usual sort of fumbling-around ambitions.

Obs: Which were?

TL: Dinosaur hunter. Vet. Architect, and then painter and eventually ended up writing poetry, then writing short stories, then writing novels. But I knew it was words from, oh I don't know, 11 or 14 or 23.

Obs: And how useful to you was the UEA writing course?

TL: I found it useful in giving me confidence to trust the times I am living in rather than feeling that I needed to go for a subject that seemed to me 'literary' in advance. So with the short stories and Adventures in Capitalism I concentrated on writing about the year of the course. If people were wearing clothes then that they wouldn't be wearing next year, that was part of it. I wasn't worried about a sell-by date on the writing. I think that's the most important thing I learnt.

Obs : What did you read as a child?

TL: I mostly watched television, to be honest. I started reading later on. The first big book that felt like a real achievement to finish was Lord of the Rings, because it is so big. The fact it was in three volumes was quite important. After I finished that, I thought, oh, I can read anything now. Also, I was read to by my parents and then I lost interest. I started almost everything, but I got bored very quickly.

So I've read the first three pages of hundreds of things I haven't finished. I found reasons for not reading things. Like being scared of Lord of the Flies because of the cover. I had a similar thing with Dracula and I didn't read Brighton Rock for a long time because we had a disgusting school's edition which I thought would be horrible to carry around. It sort of had diarrhoea-coloured stripes on the cover. So I was very judgmental.

But films started to get me into books and then once I started I read odd things, like the Glass Bead Game. I was very much into science fiction. Dune and things like that. Consciously I went back and read the things I should have read earlier, like Treasure Island, when I was about 25.

Obs: Who are the writers that you admire now?

TL: My favourite writers are generally dead. Henry James, for instance. I'm editing a Penguin Modern Classic of a Henry James book that hasn't been reprinted since he died, The Outcry. It's the last novel he completed and he adapted it from a play of his that didn't get produced. It's about the scandal of someone, a brash American coming over to buy a piece of English heritage, a painting. It's his international theme coming back for the last time. I'm quite excited about the idea of writing a preface for a Henry James book. I also like Jane Austen and James Joyce. Very solid, straightforward writers.

Obs: In the novel, you've got these free translations of the Kindertotenlieder. At what point did they come into the mix?

TL: I didn't realise until I'd chosen them that it was quite a large genre of poetry. The Kindertotenlieder were a version of childhood that was very different. They are incredibly sentimentalised. But the songs almost don't allow the children an existence independently. They have idiosyncrasies. All they do is stand in doorways looking beatific. But the children, the boys, in my book are the agents of everything that happens.

Obs: Are they your translations?

TL: Yes. They're quite distorted.

Obs: Are you familiar with German?

TL: Er, indirectly. I can read it when I have a parallel translation. It gave an overall structure that paralleled what went on in the book - the structure of the Mahler song cycle. But in a way if someone's not familiar with that they'll take the title as something that might lead them to think of hard- boiled fiction.

Obs: What are you working on now?

TL: I'm doing a book of short stories which will probably be called Exhibitionism, and I'm writing the next novel. I've written short stories ever since completing Adventures in Capitalism, so that's about four years of short stories. So I have almost enough for a collection now and the novel's taking up most of my time.

Obs: And what would you do if you weren't writing fiction?

TL: Before I managed to go full time I was doing subtitles for television programmes, so I might still be doing that, but if I was pursuing another career a lot of my family are doctors and I'm quite fascinated with bodies, with corpsing, so to speak.

webTitle: Observer review: deadkidsongs by Toby Litt

fields.headline: Behind the rhododendrons, crazy kids
fields.standfirst: Toby Litt enters the murky world of childhood with deadkidsongs
fields.trailText: Toby Litt enters the murky world of childhood with deadkidsongs
fields.body:
deadkidsongs
Toby Litt
Hamish Hamilton £9.99, pp452
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There's no getting away from it, kids are scary. Their unpatrolled kidscape world is a frightening place in which most of the confusions come from the posturing hypocrisy of the grown-ups.

Add a rogue adult, one whose frustration with his own world has so retarded him that he seems to have crept back to the comforting violence of childhood, and you have a cauldron bubbling with good and evil, whose Manichean complexities are resolved only with the burgeoning of guilt.

William Golding went into this turbulent world with his first novel Lord of the Flies. Now, nearly half a century later, Toby Litt has ruthlessly clawed aside the camouflage of the hideaway rhododendrons and taken us all back into the secret and brutal lair of childhood.

deadkidsongs is set some time in the 1970s, when exactly is ambivalent, to say the least. The clues are at best contradictory. Let's say some time between 1973 and the Queen's Silver Jubilee, or just afterwards. We are in a provincial country town some way north of London, which has a junior school, and a middle school where Andrew, Matthew, Peter and Paul go when it is not the summer holidays, as it is now.

Gang - not the gang - but Gang, as our four intrepid commandos call themselves, waits and trains for the inevitable Cold War encounter with the Russkis, establishing base camps, lines of fire for the English resistance and routes of escape. They have code names and ranks, and each has special skills. Then Matthew dies, suddenly, of meningitis.

His comrades can think of no other explanation for their sudden loss than the failure of Matthew's grandparents, with whom he lived following the death of his mother and father in a car crash, to spot the seriousness of his illness in time. These grandparents, the Dinosaurs, are the enemy, or collaborators, who are as good as, anyway.

Gang resolves to have its revenge by killing the grandparents, slowly and subtly and, above all, without suspicion falling on its members, just as their proto-Maquis training has taught them. But now the cracks start to appear, cracks whose methodological arguments mask an increasingly insidious moral whisper, less heard of course by one than another.

Litt takes us spinning through this crazy kids' world at a cracking page-flipping pace, sustaining the tension by reiterating incidents from the different, but not so different, points of view of Gang members. Continuity suffers sometimes, perhaps more than can be explained by differing perceptions of character. And sometimes the facts within the fiction appear wildly wrong - a Morris Traveller does not have four passenger doors so an entire sequence simply could not have happened; a second lieutenant is senior to a sergeant, something the boys would have known instinctively, while a sub-lieutenant being a naval rank is off the scale.

But these, among other solecisms, are quibbles with what is an immensely spirited work, whose moral melodies linger long after the last page is turned. Is it really about childhood? Or is it about parenthood? Whatever the reader decides, it is wickedly, wittily scary.

And sometimes the facts within the fiction appear wildly wrong - a Morris Traveller does not have four passenger doors so an entire sequence simply could not have happened; a second lieutenant is senior to a sergeant, something the boys would have known instinctively, while a sub-lieutenant being a naval rank is off the scale. But these, among other solecisms, are quibbles with what is an immensely spirited work, whose moral melodies linger long after the last page is turned. Is it really about childhood? Or is it about parenthood? Whatever the reader decides, it is wickedly, wittily scary.

webTitle: Focus: Blair begins long and bloody marathon, Feb 2001

fields.headline: Blair fires starting pistol for  single currency marathon
fields.standfirst:
Both sides are keeping their powder dry for now but the battle that will follow the election is set to be a long and bloody one, reports Gaby Hinsliff

The Euro debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: Both sides are keeping their powder dry for now but the battle that will follow the election is set to be a long and bloody one, reports Gaby Hinsliff
fields.body:
When the phone call between the Prime Minister and the man they nicknamed Carlos the Jackal was placed before Christmas, it was meant to be a well-kept secret.

Lines between London and Tokyo had hummed for weeks as Ministers tried to persuade the Japanese car giant Nissan not to pull the plug on thousands of jobs in the north-east. But the question the firm's chief executive Carlos Ghosn kept asking was one nobody but Blair could answer: did he still want to take Britain into the single currency?

'Put it this way, last week certainly answered a question about what Blair promised Carlos,' said one source close to the negotiations. For last Wednesday Blair finally confirmed, in eight words tossed over the dispatch box to William Hague, that he would take the first irrevocable steps to joining the single currency before May 2003. The battle for the euro has finally begun.

So why did Blair poke his head above the parapet only weeks before a general election, when the message is supposed to be about schools, hospitals and crime?

And with the polls still uniformly against him, why on earth does he think this battle could ever be won?

The seeds of Downing Street's confidence were actually sown three months ago on the French Riviera, when Blair first realised that the eurosceptic press was only mortal after all.

Faced with tabloid uproar over the Nice summit to negotiate a new EU treaty, Blair and the Foreign Secretary Robin Cook confronted their critics head-on, accusing them of hysteria.

The gamble worked: opinion polls at the end of the summit showed the British public had largely ignored scare stories about a common European army or the end of British sovereignty.

'Nice can be seen as the turning point - that and the change in economic terms for the euro,' said one Foreign Office source.

The second key was the Nissan crisis, providing concrete proof that Labour's backpedalling on the euro was alarming inward investors. Nor was Ghosn alone: Nick Schiele of Ford Europe, close to the Trade Secretary Stephen Byers, was also privately reassured by Ministers.

Insiders say it has been clear since before Christmas that Labour could not get away with promising vaguely to decide on entry 'early in the next parliament'. This week William Hague simply gave Blair a golden chance to clear up any confusion.

'There was a danger in an election scenario of Ministers at different ends of the country giving different interpretations of "early". 'Blair was just providing an official definition,' said one Whitehall source.

And despite the delight of europhiles who once feared a referendum might never happen, Blair's timetable is actually deeply cautious: he did not promise a referendum within two years, only an assessment of the position. The real ripples he caused this week were among eurosceptics.

The gold cardboard medallions issued as invites might have been tacky, but the giggly girls and pounding disco music spilling out of the Rock nightclub in central London a few weeks ago were striving unmistakably after cool.

The 'no to the euro' campaign knows it has an image problem and hopes parties like this will change it. 'If they think euroscepticism means Bill Cash then we're in trouble,' as one campaigner put it.

Enter Piers Adam, friend of Madonna's husband Guy Ritchie and owner of Rock, the man they hope will add a little celebrity stardust. While men like Sir Stanley Kalms, the 69-year-old Dixons chairman, may actually be filling Business for Sterling's coffers, its website showcases video clips from younger supporters like Adam, or the Belgo restaurant tycoon Luke Johnson.

It even persuaded Countdown queen Carol Vorderman to come out against the euro.

And it regards Blair's new two-year deadline as a gift. 'It's a lot easier for us in terms of fundraising,' says BFS chairman Dominic Cummings. 'Last year people were saying "Blair can never win, what's the point, we've already seen off a referendum".'

BFS plans to blow its war chest early, starting its campaign at the end of May, aiming to whip up such feeling that Blair will never dare call a referendum. 'Blair's not going to have one unless he thinks he's going to win it. And that argues for an early strike,' Cummings said.

Their tactic will be to baffle ordinary voters with so many conflicting claims about the euro that they stick with the status quo. 'If people go into a referendum thinking "I haven't got a clue about the economics" then we have won because they will go on their visceral instincts,' he added.

If the eurosceptics' problem is a dearth of cool, the pro-Europeans need a dose of old-fashioned patriotism. Mingling with diplomats at Europe Minister Keith Vaz's New Year drinks party last month were two unusual guests: the Olympic gold medallist Sally Gunnell and the jump jockey Richard Dunwoody. Both are seen as ideal potential recruits.

Meanwhile the Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott, widely seen as cautious on the euro, will make his debut for pressure group Britain in Europe at their fringe meeting in Glasgow next weekend. Insiders say he is just the kind of no-nonsense figure they need.

But anyone expecting the pro-European campaign to begin immediately after an election will be disappointed. Its orders are to lie low until the autumn: for over the summer, Labour strategists are hoping to watch the Tories tear themselves apart.

The 'save the pound' stickers handed out in shopping precincts across Britain yesterday, as William Hague proclaimed his love for sterling from a rally in Richmond, illustrate the Tories' conviction that Europe is still their trump card. Their line is hardening: Hague's manifesto will pledge not only to save sterling but to rip up the Nice treaty. However, senior Tories are privately warning that too much naked euroscepticism could backfire. For the party line is far from solid..

Candidates have been quietly told they can depart from Hague's line on Europe in their election addresses if they wish - either to rule out the euro forever, or to back a single currency.

The former Tory Minister Ian Taylor, who will make a speech tomorrow urging Blair to go further faster, says his party could shoot themselves in the foot by making Europe their main issue.

'My own view is the Nice treaty should not be renegotiated and I shall make that clear in my literature,' he said. 'The Conservative Party will be well advised to leave the real battle over Europe to a referendum and get on with trying to do as well as it can on issues like public services.'

Labour, which gleefully exploited Tory rifts over Europe during the 1997 election, is rubbing its hands at the prospect of doing the same again. But with two-thirds of voters hostile to the euro, will troublemaking among the Tories really be enough to turn the tide?

Blair's best hope is the private polling showing that given a choice between joining the euro and leaving the EU altogether, half of voters back the single currency. Even BFS admits opposition is 'not as firm as the Tories think': Labour will do everything it can to confuse the anti-single currency campaign with the anti-EU fringe. But Cummings warns that the phoney battle over Nice should lull no-one into a false sense of security.

'The Tories messed that one up enormously,' he says. 'This time, we'll get it right.'

webTitle: How E-Day will be the costliest show on earth

fields.headline: How E-Day will be the costliest show on earth
fields.standfirst:
The logistics of introducing 300 million people to new notes and coins are staggering

The Euro debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: Nothing highlights the sheer ambition of the euro project better than the plans to roll out an entirely new set of notes and coins across a continent
fields.body:
Nothing highlights the sheer ambition of the euro project better than the plans to roll out an entirely new set of notes and coins across a continent in just a few weeks. The contents of the pockets of more than 300 million people and the tills of hundreds of thousands of banks and shops, stretching from Portugal to Finland, from Ireland to Greece, will have to be switched at the start of next year.

It is by far the greatest currency changeover ever seen, a bigger logistical exercise, affecting a larger population, than if America decided to bring in a new currency to all 50 states overnight.

The 12 countries joining the euro need 14.5 billion new banknotes, worth about £400bn. They need about 50bn new coins, using 350,000 tonnes of metal. National mints - only geared up to replacing small numbers of old coins - started minting the euros four years before their introduction.

Each country, with the exception of Luxembourg, is producing its own euros. The seven notes - with harmonised pictures of Europe's architectural styles from Greek to modern - are identical in every country.

The eight coins - from one euro-cent to two euros - have one identical face across Euroland, and the other face set aside for a national symbol. France has chosen a tree and a woman sowing crops, Germany an eagle and the Brandenburg gate, and Ireland the Celtic harp.

The national mints have only a fraction of the storage space needed to hold the coins, and too few trucks to transport them. Banks and security companies declared themselves unable to cope, and have demanded the army's help.

So vast is the amount of metal being used that it swung the world's metal markets. The new ones won't contain nickel because of fears among Scandinavians that it causes skin reactions. As a result, when the old coins are recycled, there will be a 100,000-tonne surplus of nickel. The price of nickel fell more than 10 per cent on the news.

After the euro was officially launched on 1 January 1999, the financial markets and electronic transactions in Euroland were immediately converted to the single currency. Shops and restaurants have to show prices in both old and new currencies.

The beginning of the end of the old currencies starts on 1 September this year, when the euro notes and coins will start being transferred from secure storage to banks. A few months later they will be taken to shops and restaurants. Customers will be able to buy little starter packs from banks, with each one of the eight coins.

But E-day, as it has been dubbed, is 1 January 2002. After that, all the cash machines and banks in Euroland will issue only euros. In preparation, the banks have had to replace their cash machines to make sure they are compatible with the new notes.

Vending machines and payphones will have to be changed to accept the new coins, and loaded up beforehand so that they have the correct change.

Shops must immediately give all change in euros. Old national currencies can be used by customers but will rapidly be withdrawn. From 28 February 2002, across all 12 countries only the euro will be legal tender.

From that date on, we will no longer see drachma, francs, lire, pesetas or deutschmarks when we cross the Channel. It is the psychological effect of that which Tony Blair hopes will win over the British.

 'The Euro - Should Britain Join: Yes or No?' by Anthony Browne, published on 26 February, price £3.99

webTitle: Mandela - In his own words

fields.headline: Mandela - In his own words
fields.standfirst: Quotations from Nelson Mandela's best-known speeches and statements
fields.trailText: Quotations from Nelson Mandela's best-known speeches and statements
fields.body:
"We plan to make government impossible. I have chosen this latter course which is more difficult and entails more risk and hardship than sitting in jail. I have had to separate myself from my dear wife and children, from my mother and sisters, to live as an outlaw in my own land. I have had to close my business, to abandon my profession, and live in poverty and misery". ANC press statement made from hiding, 26 June 1961

"During my lifetime I have dedicated myself to this struggle of the African people. I have fought against white domination and I have fought against black domination. I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. It is an ideal which I hope to live for and to see realised. But if needs be, my lord, it is an ideal for which I am ready to die." At the Rivonia trial, 20 April 1964

"I stand here before you not as a prophet but as a humble servant of you, the people. Your tireless and heroic sacrifices have made it possible for me to be here today. I therefore place my life in your hands." On his release from prison, 11 February 1990

"The achievement of democracy was the defining challenge - the long walk continues." Farewell speech to Parliament, 29 March 1999

"Apartheid was experienced as such a basic onslaught against human dignity that it demeaned all of us - one has an appreciation for the support received from people all over the world, irrespective of their party political affiliation." Speech to the British Labour Party conference, 29 September 2000

"Today, all of us do, by our presence here, and by our celebrations in other parts of our country and the world, confer glory and hope to newborn liberty. Out of the experience of an extraordinary human disaster that lasted too long, must be born a society of which all humanity will be proud.

Our daily deeds as ordinary South Africans must produce an actual South African reality that will reinforce humanity's belief in justice, strengthen its confidence in the nobility of the human soul and sustain all our hopes for a glorious life for all - never, never and never again shall it be that this beautiful land will again experience the oppression of one by another, and suffer the indignity of being the skunk of the world."

From Mandela's inaugural address as President of South Africa

"We dedicate this day to all the heroes and heroines in this country and the rest of the world who sacrificed in many ways and surrendered their lives so that we could be free.

Their dreams have become reality. Freedom is their reward.

We are both humbled and elevated by the honor and privilege that you, the people of South Africa, have bestowed on us, as the first President of a united, democratic, non-racial and non-sexist South Africa, to lead our country out of the valley of darkness.

We understand it still that there is no easy road to freedom.

We know it well that none of us acting alone can achieve success.

We must therefore act together as a united people, for national reconciliation, for nation building, for the birth of a new world.

Let there be justice for all.

Let there be peace for all.

Let there be work, bread, water and salt for all.

Let each know that for each the body, the mind and the soul have been freed to fulfill themselves.

Never, never and never again shall it be that this beautiful land will again experience the oppression of one by another and suffer the indignity of being the skunk of the world.

Let freedom reign".

Extracts from Inaugural Address as President of South Africa, 10 May 1994

webTitle: Men and women behaving badly? Don't blame DNA

fields.headline: Men and women behaving badly? Don't blame DNA
fields.standfirst:
Discovering we're more than the sum of our genes affects understanding of free will, reports Robin McKie

Revealed: the secret of human behaviour
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Discovering we're more than the sum of our genes affects understanding of free will, reports Robin McKie
fields.body:
There is a delicious story told by Craig Venter, the controversial scientist whose company Celera has been one of the pioneers of the unraveling of the human genome.

A few years ago, he and his colleagues published a revision of the number of genes they believed a human being possessed. Previously, it was thought there were about 120,000 to 150,000 genes, single pieces of DNA that controlled the manufacture of proteins, the building blocks of our cells. Then Venter and his team of researchers, having studied preliminary results of sequencing data, decided to downgrade the number to around 80,000.

'The day after we published I got this call from the head of a leading biotechnology company,' says Venter. 'He was cursing and swearing and using all sorts of obscenities about my company and about myself.'

Venter calmed him down and asked the company chief's problem. 'You've just announced there are only 80,000 human genes, and I've just done a deal with SmithKline Beecham. I've already agreed to sell them 100,000 genes - where I am supposed to get the rest, you bastard.'

The biotech chief has since died, which may be fortunate - for the news that the researchers have now reduced that number even further to around 30,000 would have probably turned him to violence.

And so could the rest of the biotechnology, we might suppose. Their industry is based on isolating genes that go wrong in our bodies, so they create drugs to tackle the problem. In one blow, genetics have cut their output by a third, it would seem.

In fact, most companies remain sanguine. The discovery that humans possess a limited genome means they simply have a more manageable set of targets. 'Let's face it, 30,000 potential new drugs is not a bad potential,' said one pharmaceutical chief.

In any case, the really critical implication of the discovery still lies with the door that geneticists have opened on the environmental influences of our behaviour, our personalities and our health, and for the critical blow it strikes the idea of biological determinism.

For the past decade, the public has witnessed a rising epidemic of tales of discoveries of genes that dispose humanity to homosexuality, to alcoholism, to political persuasion, to running ability, and to artistic taste.

The 'discovery' of the gay gene is good example. Allegedly isolated by Dean Hamer and colleagues on the human X-chromosome, this DNA slice is supposedly inherited from mothers and passed on so that some of their sons prefer Kylie Minogue and Judy Garland.

But even before yesterday's revelations by Venter, scientists had stopped believing in the gay gene. Yet belief in its existence still persists among the public. The assault on biological determinism that geneticists have now triggered will be timely, if nothing else, in showing the notion of inherited homosexuality was a myth, and that human nature is a lot more complex and intriguing than determinists have given it credit for.

Even more importantly, the discovery has critical implications for our understanding of idea of free will.

It has become increasingly fashionable for individuals - particularly in the United States - to blame actions and crimes on the influence of their genes. Consider the following story. A young American woman, Glenda Sue Caldwell, was convicted of killing her child and was jailed for life.

Only later did she begin to display the symptoms of Huntington's Disease, an inherited brain disorder that produces horrific delusions and uncontrolled movements. Claiming she was a victim of her genes, the woman was cleared on appeal.

Since then, several other US defendants accused of violent crimes have argued that they too were innocent victims of their genes. They were not responsible for their actions. Their genes were. None of these people has yet succeeded in persuading courts of their innocence and their genes' guilt. Most lawyers felt such an outcome was nevertheless inevitable.

In other words, genetic predestination could soon have been used to excuse murder or robbery - if it had not been for this discovery that we lack the genes to thus dispose us!

The complex relationship between genes and the environment was also illustrated by conference delegate Kevin Davies, author of The Sequence , the story of the human genome race which is to be published this week by Weidenfeld & Nicolson.

'There has been a recent study on perfect pitch, the ability to know the absolute pitch of a musical note, that strongly suggests that is acquired through the inheritance of a single gene.

'That may sound like a clear-cut piece of biological determinism. However, there is a crucial corollary - you have to be exposed to early musical training for the ability to materialise. In other words, even in seemingly simple inherited abilities, nurture has a role to play.'

And then there is the case quoted by Venter. 'Everyone talks about a gene for this and that. But it is not like that. Take the example of colon cancer.
