A few years ago, he and his colleagues published a revision of the number of genes they believed a human being possessed. Previously, it was thought there were about 120,000 to 150,000 genes, single pieces of DNA that controlled the manufacture of proteins, the building blocks of our cells. Then Venter and his team of researchers, having studied preliminary results of sequencing data, decided to downgrade the number to around 80,000. 'The day after we published I got this call from the head of a leading biotechnology company,' says Venter. 'He was cursing and swearing and using all sorts of obscenities about my company and about myself.' Venter calmed him down and asked the company chief's problem. 'You've just announced there are only 80,000 human genes, and I've just done a deal with SmithKline Beecham. I've already agreed to sell them 100,000 genes - where I am supposed to get the rest, you bastard.' The biotech chief has since died, which may be fortunate - for the news that the researchers have now reduced that number even further to around 30,000 would have probably turned him to violence. And so could the rest of the biotechnology, we might suppose. Their industry is based on isolating genes that go wrong in our bodies, so they create drugs to tackle the problem. In one blow, genetics have cut their output by a third, it would seem. In fact, most companies remain sanguine. The discovery that humans possess a limited genome means they simply have a more manageable set of targets. 'Let's face it, 30,000 potential new drugs is not a bad potential,' said one pharmaceutical chief. In any case, the really critical implication of the discovery still lies with the door that geneticists have opened on the environmental influences of our behaviour, our personalities and our health, and for the critical blow it strikes the idea of biological determinism. For the past decade, the public has witnessed a rising epidemic of tales of discoveries of genes that dispose humanity to homosexuality, to alcoholism, to political persuasion, to running ability, and to artistic taste. The 'discovery' of the gay gene is good example. Allegedly isolated by Dean Hamer and colleagues on the human X-chromosome, this DNA slice is supposedly inherited from mothers and passed on so that some of their sons prefer Kylie Minogue and Judy Garland. But even before yesterday's revelations by Venter, scientists had stopped believing in the gay gene. Yet belief in its existence still persists among the public. The assault on biological determinism that geneticists have now triggered will be timely, if nothing else, in showing the notion of inherited homosexuality was a myth, and that human nature is a lot more complex and intriguing than determinists have given it credit for. Even more importantly, the discovery has critical implications for our understanding of idea of free will. It has become increasingly fashionable for individuals - particularly in the United States - to blame actions and crimes on the influence of their genes. Consider the following story. A young American woman, Glenda Sue Caldwell, was convicted of killing her child and was jailed for life. Only later did she begin to display the symptoms of Huntington's Disease, an inherited brain disorder that produces horrific delusions and uncontrolled movements. Claiming she was a victim of her genes, the woman was cleared on appeal. Since then, several other US defendants accused of violent crimes have argued that they too were innocent victims of their genes. They were not responsible for their actions. Their genes were. None of these people has yet succeeded in persuading courts of their innocence and their genes' guilt. Most lawyers felt such an outcome was nevertheless inevitable. webTitle: Mandelson 'could make a comeback'

fields.headline: Mandelson 'could make a comeback'
fields.standfirst:
Former Labour chief hints at rehabilitation
Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson could make a comeback to an important role but only if he cleans up his act fast, a former Labour Party general secretary said last night.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson could make a comeback to an important role but only if he cleans up his act fast, a former Labour Party general secretary said last night.

As anonymous aides to Tony Blair finally turned on Mandelson, dismissing him as 'flakey' and 'emotionally incontinent', Lord Sawyer admitted that the former Cabinet Minister had badly jeopardised his chances in the last two days.

But Sawyer, a powerful figure who ran the party machine during the last general election, said the former spin doctor still had talents that could be used in future if he now devoted himself to his Hartlepool constituency. The intervention will be seen as an attempt to keep him quiet for the party's sake.

Last night Mandelson went to ground after two days of increasingly erratic behaviour. Unnamed cabinet ministers lined up to brief against him, resulting in articles appearing in many of today's newspapers posing the question: has Mandelson gone mad?

But Sawyer told The Observer all need not be lost for Mandelson if he stopped the war of words now. 'I don't think a man's political career is necessarily over just by not being in Cabinet,' he added.

'The events of the last 48 hours do seem to have changed things a bit if one is to believe the accounts by the media. He has made things worse for himself. I thought he ought to keep his head down, see if Hammond does a decent job for him and at least doesn't accuse him of being a liar, and then there is still room in politics for his brain and his ideas.

'He has obviously got a lot of enemies but I am not one of them. I think he is very talented and a big loss to the Labour party. If he wants to play a role in politics - which I think for the foreseeable future must be outside the Cabinet - well I think you can never say never.'

Mandelson should dedicate himself to Hartlepool and stop briefings to the media, Sawyer added.

'He is a big political figure and he will be listened to provided he has got something to say and providing he cleans up his act.'

Two junior ministerial aides today tell BBC1's On the Record programme that Mandelson should be brought back if the Hammond inquiry, to which he gives evidence this week, clears him. Lorna Fitzsimons, parliamentary private secretary to Foreign Office Minister Brian Wilson, says Mandelson should be 'as eligible as anybody for promotion' if found innocent.

Phil Woolas, PPS to Transport Minister Lord McDonald, said the inquiry could exonerate Mandelson. 'If that is the case, I can't see any reason why after the general election, some time in the future, that he couldn't play a role in government,' he added.

But Mandelson's former aide Derek Draper last night accused his old boss of having 'lost the plot' and got his problems way out of perspective.

'He is like the neglected child who misbehaves just to get noticed, because getting a smack is better than being ignored,' Draper wrote in the Sunday Mirror .

Amid the media scrum in Hartlepool, Mandelson had given away Labour's worst- kept secret by referring to a likely election in May. He had also denied stories, planted apparently on his behalf, that he wanted to be a European Commissioner.

Mandelson is due to give evidence to the Hammond inquiry this week.

webTitle: Clintons swept up in tide of scandal

fields.headline: Clintons swept up in tide of scandal
fields.standfirst:
Ed Vulliamy in New York reports on revelations over the ex-President's links to a fugitive financier and his socialite wife

The Clintons: what they took
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Ed Vulliamy in New York reports on revelations over the ex-President's links to a fugitive financier and his socialite wife.
fields.body:
Denise Rich, wife of fugitive but now pardoned billionaire Marc Rich, will throw a lavish party in Manhattan tomorrow night. It may or may not feature ice skaters covered in gold body paint that twirled into one recent event, or cupids in red hot pants that parachuted into her last Valentine's celebration - but it will be scintillating enough.

The purpose is to welcome 'home' Andrew Cuomo, ex-President Bill Clinton's Housing Secretary who is to fight to become governor of New York State.

Cuomo's likely opponent: New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, who - back in 1983, as a young US attorney - signed the first indictment against Marc Rich, pardoned by Clinton in the final hours of his presidency, thereby detonating what is fast supplanting the Lewinsky affair as the defining scandal of the epoch.

The most quietly powerful body on Capitol Hill, the Senate Judiciary Committee, will this week open an investigation into the circumstances of the pardon.

The potential damage to the Clinton legacy was compounded on Friday night by another twist in the saga of gifts and furniture taken by the Clintons from the White House and other government buildings. It turns out that the First Couple had begun removing furniture more than a year ago when they moved to their $1.7 million house in New York and were humiliatingly forced to return them.

It also emerged on Friday night that Denise Rich launched her campaign to secure his pardon as early as 1998, with a donation of $450,000 to the Clinton library in Arkansas - in addition to a torrent of campaign contributions - according to documents reviewed by an investigating committee in the lower House of Representatives.

The documents are the first fruit of a series of orders by the House committee, chaired by Clinton foe Representative Dan Burton, anxious to establish connections between the pardon and contributions to President and Hillary Clinton's campaigns.

The committee has demanded full disclosure of all donors to the library fund.

Clinton lawyer David Kendal has sworn to defy the request and Denise Rich has refused to testify to or cooperate with the House investigation. As a counterblow on Friday, the Burton committee said it would offer her immunity from prosecution in exchange for her bank records.

Husband Marc is preparing to sell his business interests - based in Switzerland and London - to a division of the Russian Alfa Group and is planning to return to the US after 28 years on the run, fugitive from 63 counts of tax fraud and others of trading with an enemy, Iran.

The Observer has learnt this week from Russian and US officials that most of the fortune he harvested came from the ravaging of Russia after the collapse of the USSR. His profits supported a plenteous lifestyle which included soirées at which Placido Domingo entertained guests.

The Energy Minister at the time, Vladimir Lopukhin, calls Russia 'a Klondike for Mr Rich'. He adds: 'Can I call what he did illegal? He was always walking the fault line between legal and breaking the law.'

Apart from donations to the Clintons, inquiries by The Observer uncover another possible motive for the politically disastrous pardon - a 'raison d'état'.

One US intelligence source entertains the likelihood that Rich 'may have had very close ties with the Israeli security services'. Another official says that there could have been a 'Middle East quid pro quo' behind the pardon.

Rich has kept his Israeli citizenship; his pardon was sought by former Prime Minister Ehud Barak, whose aide Michal Herzog works for Rich. Rich's financial point man in the Middle East - who manages the Rich Foundation, Ayner Azulai - was a Mossad agent for 30 years.

Marc David Reich was born in Antwerp in 1934, his family fleeing the Nazis eight years later; he grew up a Jewish refugee in Kansas. Rich joined Philipp Brothers, the biggest raw materials company in the world. He was sent to Havana during Batista's final years and slipped Philipp's financial assets out of Cuba just before Castro's revolution.

He blended wafer-thin morals with a financial genius to - in effect - invent the spot market in oil, tapping countries which like him had more raw material than scruples, to undercut cartel-set world prices.

But Rich was too good in a market that alarmed the establishment firm, and was ironically forced to leave the company after brilliant speculation before the Opec price increase of 1973.

Iran and Iraq had been lucrative friends on the spot market, and Rich continued trading with Iran through the hostages crisis of 1979. The ensuing embargo was an opportunity too good for him to pass up; he exported and laundered hundreds of millions of dollars of Iranian oil, subverting price controls and evading taxes.

Rich attracted the attention of US law and he left for Switzerland, where he was safe from extradition agreements governing financial offences. Giuliani's indictment came in September.

On the run, Rich - who has denied criminal wrongdoing - has lived in the opulence of his mansion in Zug, with a fellowship at Oxford endowed in his name and millions distributed to worthy causes.

He continued to build his empire on mineral mines, sugar, coal, oil, aluminium and soya shipped around the world. Platt's Oilgram in New York lists Rich among the shippers of oil to Serbia during the embargo. But, above all, it was built on Russia.

With the collapse of the USSR - from which Rich had traded oil to embargoed South Africa - Russia was ravaged, as syndicates of criminals and former KGB and communist officials stripped the nation of natural resources, principally oil and gold. Rich was at the hub of the wheel. Officials say that in the tumult of the years 1991-3, he was able to buy Russian oil at 1 per cent of the world price and export it.

In 1966, Rich had married Denise Eisenstein, an heiress from New England, also from a wealthy Holocaust refugee family, as effervescent as he was introverted.

As her husband grew richer, she became one of New York's most prominent socialites, better known for writing pop songs for Sister Sledge and Celine Dion; for the gold-painted skaters and the 300 helium balloons that fell on Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones (on the night he proposed) than she is for her fugitive husband.

But Denise's most important guests were the former First Couple. She gave more than $1.5 million to the party, $70,000 to Hillary Clinton's Senate campaign and $10,000 to the Clintons' legal fund. She gave the Clintons $7,375 of furniture, a saxophone to Bill and provided an introduction to Michael Jackson.

webTitle: Revealed: the secret of human behaviour

fields.headline: Revealed: the secret of human behaviour
fields.standfirst:
Environment, not genes, key to our acts

Men and women behaving badly? Don't blame DNA
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: In a breakthrough that revolutionises our understanding of human behaviour, scientists have found that we possess far fewer genes than previously thought.
fields.body:
Scientists have made a radical breakthrough in our understanding of human behaviour with the discovery that we possess far fewer genes than previously thought.

The discovery of our meagre gene numbers - by two major groups of international scientists - reveals that environmental influences are vastly more powerful in shaping the way humans act.

Their analysis of the first human genetic map - known as the genome - shows that we have as few as 30,000 genes, the blueprints for brain and body cells. This is a far lower total than expected, and dramatically undermines claims that human beings are prisoners of their genes.

Some biologists claim that there are individual genes shaping behaviour patterns, ranging from sexual preferences to criminality, and even including political preference. But one of the scientists behind this weekend's revelations said yesterday that the new evidence demolished such claims.

'We simply do not have enough genes for this idea of biological determinism to be right,' said Dr Craig Venter, the US scientist whose company Celera was a major player in the sequencing project. 'The wonderful diversity of the human species is not hard-wired in our genetic code. Our environments are critical.'

Venter was speaking yesterday on the eve of the publication of the first analysis of the human genome sequence in science journals this week. Nature magazine is scheduled to outline the discoveries made by the publicly-funded venture that was spearheaded by the US government and the UK Wellcome Trust's Sanger Centre.

The Observer has found that both teams' analysis of the first draft of the genome - completed to considerable public fanfare last June - has uncovered the same sensa tional, unexpected picture. It was anticipated the genome project would show that humans possess 100,000 to 150,000 genes. Both teams have now found the true figure is probably less than a quarter of this number.

In the case of the public US-UK project, scientists have found a range of between 30,000 and 40,000 genes. Celera scientists have found 26,000 to 38,000 genes. 'It is good to have a rough agreement between the two sides. Certainly, it shows that there are far fewer genes than anyone imagined,' said Venter.

The crucial point about the low figure is that it raises serious problems for scientists trying to explain the complexity of the human species.

'When we sequenced the first genome of a living crea ture - the fruit fly - we found it had about 13,000 genes, and we all thought, well we are much bigger and more complicated and so we must have a lot more genes. Now we find that we only have about twice what they have. It makes it a bit difficult to explain the human constitution.'

This problem is further exacerbated by studies of individual genes that have been carried out by the two teams. These analyses reveal there has been a startling degree of gene conservation over the past 600 million years of evolution on Earth.

'In many cases, we have found that humans have exactly the same genes as rats, mice, cats, dogs and even fruit flies,' said Venter. 'Take the gene PAX-6. We have found that when it is damaged, eyes will not form. You can take a human gene, insert it in fruit flies and the vision of their offspring will be restored.'

It is only when scientists looked at the way these genes are switched on and made to manufacture proteins that they could see a significant difference between various mammalian species. The key difference lies in the manner in which human genes are regulated in response to environmental stimulation compared with other animals.

As to differences between humans, the Celera team calculates that of the three billion DNA letters that make up our genes, only 10,000 of them account for the differences between any two individuals. 'Really we are just identical twins,' Venter said. 'But like all twins and brothers and sisters, we are all really different in the way we respond to the environment.'

webTitle: Legacy secures major Dome backer

fields.headline: Legacy secures major Dome backer
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The sale of the Dome moved a step nearer last night after it emerged that controversial bidder Legacy is close to securing the support of a major backer.
fields.body:
The sale of the Dome moved a step nearer last night after it emerged that controversial bidder Legacy is close to securing the support of a major backer.

Legacy, headed by Labour donor Robert Bourne, is nearing agreement with Quintain Estates, a quoted property company, to take a stake in its consortium, which now includes the contractor Sir Robert McAlpine, Treasury Holdings and the Bank of Scotland.

The Duke of Westminister - Britain's second richest man - is also believed to ready to take a stake through his private company, Grosvenor Estates.

The move will bolster Legacy's credentials among senior Ministers and ease the fears that its bid is unviable. But a decision on whether Legacy will be allowed to buy the Dome, expected this week, will now be delayed for another month.

Ministers meet on Thursday to decide the next step. A source close to the negotiations said: 'Either both parties will be deemed miles apart and the deal will be pulled or there'll be an announcement saying there is recognition that legal paperwork is not ready for exchange but everything else is in order.'

webTitle: Jail us or leave us alone, say cannabis users

fields.headline: Jail us or leave us alone, say cannabis users
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Cannabis activists are asking to be prosecuted for possession of the drug in an extraordinary bid to break down the laws on prohibition.
fields.body:
Cannabis activists are asking to be prosecuted for possession of the drug in an extraordinary bid to break down the laws on prohibition.

The move follows a wave of optimism in the cannabis legalisation movement, which supporters see as akin to the civil rights campaigns that led to the legalisation of homosexuality and women's right to vote.

For the first time in Britain, cannabis campaigners will stand in a general election, fielding up to 100 candidates.

The police and Crown Prosecution Service have become increasingly unwilling to prosecute for possession of cannabis. Juries now routinely acquit users who plead innocent on the grounds of medical necessity. Rather than take people to court, police are issuing cautions, which last week the Government announced would no longer mean carrying a criminal record for life.

However, activists are demanding to be prosecuted so that they can plead innocent under the new Human Rights Act, which prevents the Government from unduly interfering in the private life of an individual. There are at least half a dozen cases going through the courts where activists have refused cautions and deliberately admitted to using cannabis in order to test the Act. They are confident of victory.

Neil Morgan, a cannabis user in south Wales, is being prosecuted for possession after resisting an attempt by police to drop the case. He said: 'Going to court is a golden opportunity - it's the only way we'll change anything. We've waited a long time for this.'

The civil rights group Liberty is supporting the case of Jerry Ham, the founder of a homeless charity who is facing prosecution for possession of 3g of the drug. When he was caught by police, Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Minister in charge of drug enforcement, who knew him through his work, phoned him to offer condolences.

Lawyers believe defeat for the Crown Prosecution Service under the Human Rights Act would unravel the drug prohibition laws. The number of CPS prosecutions for possession of cannabis has dropped dramatically, prompting campaigners to accuse it of trying to avoid defeat.

Roger Warren-Evans, a barrister on the council of Liberty, said: 'The Crown Prosecution Service know that, for any simple case, it could provoke a human rights defence. They're backpedalling so they don't get caught with a sucker punch on possession. It would unravel all the rest of the prohibition laws.'

Daniel Westlake, a 21-year-old building labourer, is thought to be the most likely to bring a change in the law. When caught with a small amount of cannabis, he refused to accept a caution and pleaded not guilty under the Human Rights Act. His case is soon to come before the Court of Appeal, which has the power to declare the Misuse of Drugs Act incompatible with the Human Rights Act.

Many police forces have effectively given up enforcing the laws on cannabis possession. Two chief constables, one acting and one retired, have called for its legalisation. A Police Federation report last year called for its decriminalisation, although the Government last week announced it would ignore its recommendations.

As a result, campaigners are becoming increasingly open about using and growing the drug. Colin Davies, founder of the Medical Marijuana Co-operative is growing plants in Manchester to supply - illegally - more than 100 people with medical conditions. He has been prosecuted three times, and the jury has acquitted him on each occasion. He is now thinking of importing the drug from mainland Europe. 'I think the juries will be just as sympathetic,' he said.

Even social users are openly challenging the police. Mark Gibson, a prospective parliamentary candidate for the Legalise Cannabis Alliance in Cumbria, and a regular user, said: 'There are many more people standing up and being counted. If the police want to arrest me they can, but they don't pay any attention to me any more.'

A cannabis rally is being organised in London in May, in full cooperation with the police. A separate march on Downing Street is being planned.

Attitudes have changed dramatically both in the UK and abroad. Last year, a third of the Shadow Cabinet admitted to having tried cannabis. Last month, Belgium legalised the drug, following a similar move by Switzerland last year. Portugal, Spain and Italy have all decriminalised possession of cannabis. Holland has officially tolerated the drug for years.

Warren-Evans says the Human Rights Act would force Britain to follow Europe: 'The cool neutrality of the courts will get the politicians off the hook. That will happen before the end of the year. The whole apparatus of prohibition will fall.'

webTitle: BSE rules threaten bullfight fiestas

fields.headline: BSE rules threaten bullfight fiestas
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The famous Iberian fighting bull is threatened by mad cow disease, although no case has ever been found among these privileged animals, which spend their first four years running wild and feeding on grass, hay and vegetable proteins.
fields.body:
The famous Iberian fighting bull is threatened by mad cow disease, although no case has ever been found among these privileged animals, which spend their first four years running wild and feeding on grass, hay and vegetable proteins.

EU regulations to control the disease require the testing of all cattle aged above 30 months before their meat can be sold. Breeders say that because the compensation scheme is too slow and cumbersome, carcasses of bulls which perish in the 'moment of truth' will have to be destroyed.

They fear the loss of income from the sale of the carcasses - the meat is a prized ingredient in local stews - will be destabilising. More than 40,000 fighting bulls are killed every year, yielding meat worth about £7 million.

It is feared 80 per cent of Spain's bull-fighting fairs, which take place in small towns and villages in places such as Ajalvir, a village north-east of Madrid, could disappear this year.

'We cannot continue things as they are,' said Jaime Sebastian de Erice, secretary-general of the Union of Breeders of Fighting Bulls. He said the compensation scheme, to be funded by Spain's 17 autonomous communities, has been accepted in principle only by two.

Antonio Fernandez, who sits on Ajalvir's fiesta committee, fears that without paying a hefty subsidy the village will no longer be able to mount its traditional bullfight fair. Its impresario, Lazaro Carmona, said: 'Bull meat is very safe, very organic. But today the bulls will be incinerated because we simply cannot apply the BSE tests. There is nowhere to store the animals while we wait five days for the results.'

Pablo Mayoral, a breeder, said: 'It's a shame, because these animals are raised running wild, with very little feed.

'There is anxiety about how this will affect us - but not because we are afraid of testing positive for BSE, the probability of that is minimal.'

webTitle: Sharon woos veteran Peres

fields.headline: Sharon woos veteran Peres
fields.standfirst:
Peace process 'shows flickers of life' as hardliner puts aside rhetoric

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Peace process 'shows flickers of life' as hardliner puts aside rhetoric.
fields.byline: Virginia Quirke in Jerusalem, Ed Vulliamy in New York and Jason Burke
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon, the new Israeli Prime Minister, moved yesterday to unify a divided Israel and mollify world opinion by making a dramatic bid to woo senior left-wing figures into his government.

Sharon has made it known that he wants Shimon Peres, the veteran statesman and Nobel Peace Prize winner, as Foreign Minister. Though he has not formally offered Peres the job, there have been contacts through intermediaries, say senior aides close to the hawkish former general.

Sharon has already invited Ehud Barak, the man he defeated in last week's elections, to be Defence Minister in a government of national unity with representatives of Sharon's right-wing Likud Party and Barak's centre-left Labour Party in his Cabinet.

Appointing Peres would send a clear message that the new leader is genuinely interested in concluding some kind of peace deal with the Palestinians, despite his consistently hardline rhetoric.

Yesterday fierce gun bat tles in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip continued. An 18-year-old Palestinian wounded in a clash with Israeli soldiers near Bethlehem was critically ill. The four- month-old uprising has now killed nearly 400 people, the vast majority of them Palestinian.

Peres was one of the architects of the 1993 Oslo agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO). Sharon has previously declared that the peace process started then by Peres 'is dead'. But one Western diplomat said yesterday: 'The offer - and any appointment - would indicate there is some flicker of life in it yet.'

Peres, a former prime minister who many thought might have beaten Sharon if he had stood for office, has hinted he might accept a job from the right-winger. 'I am convinced Sharon wants peace,' he told Israeli television.

Sharon's moves are politically acute. If he is to form a functioning government he needs allies in the Knesset, the Israeli parliament. Without them he may not last more than a few months in power. An alliance with the centre-Left would prevent him having to rely on unstable right-wing and religious parties.

Sharon telephoned Yasser Arafat, President of the Palestinian Authority, on Friday and is reported to have expressed a desire to seek peace and to ease the economic plight of the Palestinian population. However, he insisted the Palestinians must curb their violent demonstrations against Israeli rule and rein in militants before any talks could take place.

A Sharon aide, however, yesterday denied reports that the former general had arranged a meeting with Arafat. 'He is sticking to his position that Israel should not negotiate under fire,' the aide said.

Barak, who suffered one of the heaviest defeats in Israeli political history, has not yet rejected his former opponent's offer, though he announced afterwards that he was leaving politics.

Observers have welcomed Sharon's apparent willingness to deal with the Israeli Left. Arab leaders are deeply concerned about the election of a man they instantly associate with the massacres in the Palestinian refugee camps of Sabra and Chatila in Lebanon in 1982 and the development of Jewish settlements in the Palestinian territories. To them, any sign of moderation is significant.

'We are watching his attitude and actions very carefully,' Esmat Abdel-Meguid, secretary-general of the Arab League, said yesterday. 'If he follows the same attitude we know, we are heading for a disaster. Israel will not be spared and will suffer as the area will suffer.'

The stance of the new American administration will be critical. General Colin Powell, the Secretary of State, has announced that his first overseas trip will be a tour of the Middle East. The choice shows the importance of the region to Washington. However, his itinerary, which includes Israel, Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, shows a change in emphasis. The hands-on diplomacy favoured by Bill Clinton is to be replaced by a broader regional approach and a tougher enforcement of security policy.

President George W. Bush has been warned by intelligence chiefs that Osama bin Laden, the alleged terrorist mastermind, is mobilising for new campaigns against American targets.

There are also reports of new links between the Afghan-based Saudi dissident and militants from the Palestinian Hamas and the Lebanese Hizbollah groups.

Another key US priority is dealing with Saddam Hus sein, whose grip on power in Iraq appears as strong as ever. The dictator's prestige in the Arab world has been hugely boosted by his belligerent support for the Palestinian intifada. His popular threats to wage war on Israel have undermined more moderate leaders.

Though Bush has made it clear he expects Israel and the Palestinians to make pro-gress without any continuous US involvement, Sharon's victory will push him to formulate Middle East policy faster than he had desired.

webTitle: Confident kids likely to try drugs

fields.headline: Confident kids likely to try drugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Young people with high self-esteem are more likely to take illicit drugs than those whose self-confidence is low, new research has revealed.
fields.body:
Young people with high self-esteem are more likely to take illicit drugs than those whose self-confidence is low, new research has revealed.

The findings contradict the conventional wisdom that drug-taking is most prevalent among anxious or insecure youth looking for an escape from poor conditions or a way to feel better about themselves.

Instead, up to 27 per cent of young people with high self-esteem had used illicit substances compared with only 20 per cent of their less self-confident peers. Experts say the new research means an overhaul of drug education programmes is necessary.

The survey of 15,000 children aged 14 and 15 was conducted by the respected Schools Health Education Unit (SHEU) in Exeter.

On most occasions the drug tried was cannabis, though solvents and amphetamines also featured in responses, said David Regis, who led the research team.

'Unfortunately the results blow a hole in the simple moral fable that young people are led into the paths of righteousness by high self-esteem,' he said.

Two factors are thought to explain the results. More confident children are more likely to be sociable, have more money and thus have more opportunity to experiment with drugs. And they are also often more willing to indulge in 'risk-taking' activities, ranging from extreme sports to class-A drugs.

Research reveals that though youngsters who describe themselves as 'experimental' cigarette smokers often have low self-esteem, those who call themselves 'committed' smokers have self-esteem levels as high or higher than average.

Heather Ashton, a professor of pharmacology at Newcastle University who has studied patterns of drug-taking among students, said last week that the results of the SHEU survey did not surprise her: 'Students all report they take drugs for pleasure and that it has nothing to do with anxiety or stress. The typical joint now, with more sophisticated cultivation and plant breeding, contains more than 150mg and has a far more potent effect.

The report detailed the damage long-term use of cannabis can do to cognitive ability, memory, coordination and the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.

webTitle: Comment: rigging the scales of justice

fields.headline: Rigging the scales of justice
fields.standfirst:
There will be no redress for the mentally ill, locked up without having committed any crime

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: There will be no redress for the mentally ill, locked up without having committed any crime
fields.body:
A crowd of 200 had gathered to watch the prisoner arrive. Mothers and fathers with pushchairs and small children in tow, screamed 'Scum', and 'Die' and 'Kill the bastard'. A man built like a Charolais and dressed in sweatshirt and trainers hurled himself at the silver police people-carrier bearing Roy Whiting, a 42-year-old mechanic, to Chichester Magistrates Court, where he was remanded in custody last Wednesday, charged with the kidnap and murder of Sarah Payne.

The fury of the mob had been stoked at first by horror at the killing of an eight-year-old and by the News Of The World 's subsequent name-and-shame campaign. More recently the police, if not whipping up hysteria, have, seemingly, done little to tamp it down. A week ago, detectives helpfully tipped off the press that they planned to charge Whiting, who had been arrested and questioned twice previously, within three days. It was believed, though not confirmed, that their breakthrough hinged on an appeal by the BBC's Crimewatch programme.

As a 'senior police source' told the Daily Mail: 'The incident room has not stopped working since the day little Sarah disappeared. The man is due to be arrested... and the mood among many officers is buoyant.' If true, this revelation of police hubris is a disgraceful affront to justice.

Roy Whiting is innocent in the eyes of the law. He has entered no plea and faced no jury. Once a quaint old protocol decreed that, at the whiff of an arrest, a veil of secrecy descended. Now, it seems, practically anything goes in high-profile murder cases, where tragedy elides with show business and the public clamours for results.

Can Whiting get a fair trial, given the weight and type of publicity surrounding Sarah's murder? Among other examples of goldfish-bowl defendants, the next in line is Barry George, a prime focus of the media spotlight, who goes on trial for Jill Dando's murder in a fortnight.

One can see why three Appeal Court judges resisted the argument that Michael Stone should not have his case tested again in court because, as his barrister claimed, 'the wealth of prejudicial material... would make such a retrial unfair'. Perhaps, given the tonnage of pre-publicity surrounding criminal cases, the best to be hoped for is an amnesiac jury.

Later this week, the judges will give their reasons for ordering a retrial following their decision to quash Stone's conviction for the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter, Megan, and the attempted murder of Josie Russell, after a key witness had been shown to be unreliable.

The Russells will have to revisit their tragedy. Kent police may, in due course, have some tough questions to answer as to why justice miscarried. For now, the best that can be said of the whole debacle is that the appellate process has been shown to work. Whether Stone is found guilty or innocent, his case was treated with a swiftness denied to others.

Last week Stephen Downing finally walked free, after serving 27 years for the murder of Wendy Howell, a crime he almost certainly did not commit. Disgracefully, he was held in prison long after he would normally have been released, because parole boards refuse to free those who do not admit their guilt.

Last week too, the case of a man hanged for the murder of a cinema manager in 1950 went to appeal after the solicitor for George Kelly's family argued that 'the police and courts believed it was more important to secure a conviction to reassure the public than to properly investigate a crime'.

So what's changed? A quarter of a century after Kelly went to the gallows, the notorious West Midlands Serious Crimes Squad began its regime of torture, bogus confessions and creative note-taking, resulting in a litany of miscarriages of justice. The Birmingham Six were wrongly convicted, and Ann Whelan spent 17 years fighting for the release of her son, Michael Hickey, and watching his life unravel in prison before it finally emerged that he and the two other living members of the Bridgewater Four had been framed by the Squad. How long ago it seems since the wrongful conviction of Judith Ward, Stefan Kiszko, the Maguire Seven, the Guildford Four. How far we have come since then.

But not, perhaps, quite far enough. The Criminal Cases Review Commission is over-loaded with petitioners claiming to have been wrongly sentenced, and the Crown Prosecution Service remains unaccountable, prone to arbitrary decisions and strapped for cash. While science should make convictions watertight, the perception - or the reality - can be quite the opposite. The pattern of invisible blood spots that clinched the case of Sion Jenkins, the teacher found guilty of murdering his step-daughter, Billie-Jo, did not impress a number of powerful advocates who argue that he should never have been convicted. That unease, and the worries raised by the Michael Stone case, don't, of course, denote a return to the corrupt ways of the Seventies.

There are, however, new considerations in an age when locking people up is becoming so simple. Not long ago, Tony Blair announced plans to take DNA samples from everyone arrested in Britain. Fine, except that genes are already being interpreted not only as evi dence of a crime committed but as indicative of one that might be. If genetic profiling becomes part of police investigation, then the presumption of innocence dies. The Law Commission is expected soon, in the light of DNA advances and Sir William Macpherson's recommendations, to relax the 'double jeopardy' principle, under which an acquitted suspect cannot be retried for the same offence. Fine, unless the police and CPS produce slovenly prosecution cases, knowing they can always have another bash.

But the really iniquitous development is the promise by Government of post-election legislation indefinitely to detain people with untreatable personality disorders. Though the real scandal is the dearth of psychiatrists and of hospital beds for the mentally ill, Jack Straw has for years preferred to dream of incarcerating those who have committed no offence but who might. His success, framed in a recent White Paper, may delight those who choose not to recognise that schizophrenics commit 10 murders a year, or about 2 per cent of all killings. We are 20 times more likely to be killed by a sane person than an insane one, but such statistics carry little weight in a hot climate of fear in which we are encouraged to believe that a child-molesting monster lurks at every corner.

In fact, British children are the second safest in the world, according to a new survey by Unicef. But even if they were not, there would be no justification for such a gross affront to human rights. When the weight of the criminal justice system offers no guarantee that we are locking up the right suspects, incarcerating people while skipping the optional extras of a crime and a trial is hardly likely to produce good outcomes. And besides, for those failed by the courts, there is still the prospect of finding justice, even if, in Stephen Downing's case, the quest took most of his life. Jack Straw's and Alan Milburn's detainees, unconvicted but 'untreatable', may have no such luxury.

webTitle: Comment: Ghosts in the dust of Gujarat

fields.headline: Ghosts in the dust of Gujarat
fields.standfirst:
India is still trying to dig itself free from the legacy of the British Raj

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: India is still trying to dig itself free from the legacy of the British Raj.
fields.body:
In India, as in El Salvador, Turkey and Armenia previously, grief turns to anger as survivors confront the 'unnatural' dimensions of earthquake disaster. Thousands have perished less as a result of plate tectonics than of poorly, even criminally constructed homes, schools and factories. Hundreds of people who might have been saved have died in the rubble for want of rescue equipment. The core issue is not seismicity but vulnerability to extreme but inevitable natural events.

The facile explanations are 'poverty' and 'underdevelopment', yet there is another, more ghostly, culprit: the enduring disaster of the Raj.

A hundred years ago, the residents of Ahmedabad were also burning their dead on huge, makeshift funeral pyres. The death toll in 1901, however, was a full order of magnitude greater than today's. Drought, famine and cholera in tandem scythed down one in six of Gandhi's fellow Gujaratis. Among outcast or tribal people, the mortality was closer to 30 per cent.

As in the latest tragedy, the proximate cause was environmental: an epic monsoon failure, probably arising from the global El Niño event of 1899-1900 that turned Gujarat's 'once green as a park' countryside (according to an American missionary) into 'a blasted waste of barren stumps and burned fields'. A correspondent of the Times of India was unnerved by the vast dome of blue, cloudless sky over a slowly dying landscape: 'I do do not think I ever hated blue before, but I do now.'

The drought, which afflicted most of north-central India, was counterbalanced by bumper harvests in Bengal and Burma. As the official famine report would later emphasise: 'Owing to the excellent system of communications which now brings every portion of the [Bombay] presidency into close connection with the great market, the supplies of food were at all times sufficient.'

Traditional Indian polities like the Moguls and the Marathas had zealously policed the grain trade in the public interest, distributing free food, fixing prices and embargoing exports. As one horrified British writer discovered, these 'oriental despots' sometimes punished traders who short-changed peasants during famines by amputating equivalent weights of merchant flesh.

The British worshipped a savage god known as the 'Invisible Hand' that forbade state interference in the grain trade. Like previous viceroys (Lytton in 1877 and Elgin in 1897), Lord Curzon allowed food surpluses to be exported to England or hoarded by speculators in heavily guarded depots. Curzon, whose appetite for viceregal pomp and circumstance was legendary, lectured starving villagers that 'any government which imperilled the financial position of India in the interests of prodigal philanthropy would be open to serious criticism; but any government which by indiscriminate alms-giving weakened the fibre and demoralised the self-reliance of the population, would be guilty of a public crime'.

Vaughan Nash of the Manchester Guardian and Louis Klopsch of the New York Christian Herald were appalled by Curzon's 'penal minimum' ration (15 ounces of rice for a day's hard labour) as well as the shocking conditions tolerated in the squalid relief camps, where tens of thousands perished from cholera.

'Millions of flies,' wrote Klopsch, 'were permitted undisturbed to pester the unhappy victims. One young woman who had lost every one dear to her, and had turned stark mad, sat at the door vacantly staring at the awful scenes around her.'

Despite Kiplingesque myths of heroic benevolence, official attitudes were nonchalant. British officials rated Indian ethnicities like cattle, and vented contempt against them even when they were dying in their multitudes. Asked to explain why mortality in Gujarat was so high, a district officer told the famine commission: 'The Gujarati is a soft man... accustomed to earn his good food easily. In the hot weather, he seldom worked at all and at no time did he form the habit of continuous labour. Very many even among the poorest had never taken a tool in hand in their lives. They lived by watching cattle and crops, by sitting in the fields to weed, by picking cotton, grain and fruit, and by... pilfering.'

Gujaratis are famously industrious and probably enjoyed a higher average level of nutrition and well-being than their English contemporaries before the arrival of the East India Company.

In 1901, before the famine had run its course, the Lancet suggested that a conservative estimate of 'excess mortality' in India from starvation and hunger-related disease during the previous decade was 19 million.

As the great Indian political economist Romesh Chunder Dutt pointed out in one of his Open Letters to Lord Curzon , British Progress was India's Ruin. The railroads, ports and canals which enthused Karl Marx in the 1850s were for resource extraction, not indigenous development. The taxes that financed the railroads and the Indian army pauperised the peasantry.

Even in the macabre denouement of the Gujarat famine, the Government announced that 'the revenue must at all costs be gathered in', an act which Vaughan Nash denounced as 'picking the bones of the people'. When patidar farmers, ruined by the drought, combined to refuse a 24 per cent increase in their taxes, the collectors simply confiscated their land.

On the expenditure side, a colonial budget largely financed by taxes on farm and land returned less than 2 per cent to agriculture and education. While a progressive and independent Asian nation like Siam was annually investing two shillings per capita on education and public health, the Raj expended barely one penny per person as 'human capital'.

Not surprisingly, there was no increase in India's per capita income during the whole period of British overlordship from 1757 to 1947. Celebrated cash-crop booms went hand in hand with declining agrarian productivity and food security. Moreover, two decades of demographic growth (in the 1870s and 1890s) were entirely wiped out in avoidable famines, while throughout that 'glorious imperial half century' from 1871 to 1921 immortalised by Kipling, the life expectancy of ordinary Indians fell by a staggering 20 per cent.

This is the catastrophic past from which Indians are still trying to dig themselves free.

• Mike Davis's latest book, Late Victorian Holocausts , is reviewed on page 16 of the Review section

webTitle: Russia turns its back on young Aids generation

fields.headline: Russia turns its back on young Aids generation
fields.standfirst:
Prostitution and drugs are fuelling a huge rise in HIV infections - but officials and victims are still in denial, reports Amelia Gentleman from St Petersburg

Special report: Russia
Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Prostitution and drugs are fuelling a huge rise in HIV infections - but officials and victims are still in denial, reports Amelia Gentleman from St Petersburg.
fields.body:
The bones of dead Aids victims have been ground to powder and mixed with heroin by Chechen drug dealers to spread the virus through Russia and debilitate the nation, Sasha, a young HIV-sufferer in St Petersburg, insisted.

This is the reason for the dramatic explosion of HIV infections in the city, he said, and very possibly how he contracted the disease. Either that or by using a needle borrowed from a friend. 'Most of them are already infected. I know about 40 people who've tested positive in the last few months. There's no way of escaping it now,' he said.

His doctor assessed his prospects with less optimism. 'In a few years, when he contracts Aids, neither he nor the government will be able to afford the necessary drugs and he will die,' she said.

Russia's northern capital is in the grip of a severe epidemic - progressing faster than in any other city throughout the federation. Over the next year the disease will be passed from drug users, prostitutes and the gay community and begin to spread through the rest of the community, pushing the number up further. 'It's only then that the local authorities will start paying attention. But of course by then it will be too late,' commented Vladimir Musatov, a doctor with Médécins du Monde, one of the independent organisations trying to combat the outbreak.

The bus has clean needles, facilities for testing and photocopied information on the transmission of the disease. Sveta, 24, broke off from her five-hour shift by the roadside, for which she earns about 400 roubles (£9.75), to pick up new needles. 'I'm very frightened about the disease,' she said, looking old and tired beneath her cheerful make-up. 'A few years ago we hardly knew what Aids was, and now we all know someone who's infected.'

St Petersburg has a heroin problem. About four years ago, it stopped being just a transit point on the drug route between Central Asia and West Europe and became an important market in its own right. Large quantities of very cheap heroin appeared, costing around 70 roubles (£1.70) a hit, and drug consumption soared tenfold among the young population.

About 98 per cent of those infected by HIV are intravenous drug users. But the 70 people who turn up every night at the bus are but a fraction of the 100,000 intravenous drug users in the city. 'The government needs to implement a series of campaigns, targeting prostitutes, drug users, schoolchildren and the general public on the risks,' Musatov said. 'Do I expect them to do this? No.'

Ingrained distaste for drug addiction among the Soviet generation has allowed many officials to suggest that those infected have only themselves to blame. 'We need to see real political desire to combat the epidemic, but the government is much better at hiding problems than at resolving them,' Alexander Tskhanovitch, director of the Médécins du Monde programme, said.

The head of the government-run centre for the fight against Aids, Vadim Pokrovsky, said: 'Many officials still don't believe we have an Aids problem.' This belief is fed by the much-quoted statistic that there are currently only 125 people in Russia suffering from the disease, with only 780 deaths registered.

Across the country some 86,000 people have been registered with HIV, which officials believe to be only 20 per cent of the real figure. Pokrovsky believes that by the end of the year, the actual number of HIV-infected Russians will rise to about a million, increasing to four million by 2005. Set against Russia's shrinking population of 145 million, the figure is disturbing.

Pokrovsky wants the government to set up a single anti-Aids co-ordinating body, headed by members of Russia's powerful Security Council, to oversee the battle against the disease. He too is doubtful about the likelihood of this happening. 'Last year the government gave us less than $2 million (£1.4m) to buy medicines, to pay for information campaigns and for testing, and this year the same amount has been allocated. To work effectively, we need no less than $100 million,' he said.

Doctors at Russia's only HIV maternity ward, on the edge of St Petersburg, treat pregnant HIV mothers to reduce the risk of passing the disease on to their unborn babies. In a clean ward upstairs, abandoned HIV-positive babies lie in neat rows of cots. Until 1997 only 20 babies had been born in Russia with the infection; since then 1,147 more have arrived - most of them the children of drug-using mothers. The future for these babies is not bright.

With the most effective Western drug treatment priced at around $800 (£544) a month per patient - and no Russian equivalent on the horizon - the doctors know that they will be unable to treat the children when they become ill.

webTitle: BT faces Oftel internet order

fields.headline: BT faces Oftel internet order
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The battle to turn Britain into Europe's top place to do e-business has taken a dramatic turn this weekend as telecoms watchdog Oftel looks at ordering BT to widen rivals' access to its network.
fields.body:
The battle to turn Britain into Europe's top place to do e-business has taken a dramatic turn this weekend as telecoms watchdog Oftel looks at ordering BT to widen rivals' access to its network.

The UK's two largest internet service providers, AOL Europe and Freeserve, who between them have nearly three million subscribers, are furious at what they say are discriminatory tactics by BT in the spread of high speed DSL internet services. The two ISPs argue that the former monopoly is giving its own Openworld ISP far more DSL capacity on its network than they are being offered. Last week the two competitors threatened legal action unless the situation was remedied immediately.

Oftel was due to respond to the ISPs' concerns last Thursday but The Observer has learnt that the regulator is now taking more time to consider a more radical option. If it finds that BT has been discriminating it will hit the company with an 'immediate determination' order, forcing it to resolve the problem within an agreed timeframe.

Freeserve, which has signed up a raft of content providers to offer interactive services based around the DSL technology, says its partners are going bankrupt as a result of the problem. Like AOL, under the current arrangement with BT, Freeserve is able to sign up just 100 new DSL customers a week. BT Openworld, by contrast, is signing up 2,000.

Oftel has been monitoring the row since both the rival ISPs formally complained about their difficulties last December. Last Thursday AOL and Freeserve turned up the heat when they threatened to take legal action, and this prompted Oftel to look further into their allegations.

On Friday an Oftel spokesman said: 'We are extending the completion timetable because of the representation AOL raised yesterday. We're still getting hold of the information.'

A BT spokesman played down the possibility that Oftel would find that it had employed discriminatory practices against its competitors: 'There is absolutely no way BT can favour one part of its company.'

The spokesman added that Oftel was simply following a procedure. 'When somebody formally complains, Oftel has to formally investigate.'

Other ISPs have expressed surprise at AOL and Freeserve's allegations. Several, which were contacted by The Observer, said they did not feel BT was discriminating against them in favour of its own ISP.

webTitle: Gene cures 'will not help Third World'

fields.headline: Gene cures 'will not help Third World'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: It was a stunning year for medicine; 21 new drugs - an unparalleled number - were marketed by US pharmaceutical companies in 2000.
fields.body:
It was a stunning year for medicine; 21 new drugs - an unparalleled number - were marketed by US pharmaceutical companies in 2000.

This record number of treatments - for heart disease, multiple sclerosis, hepatitis, Alzheimer's, epilepsy and cancers - poured out of the biotechnology giants of America. There has never been a better time to be ill - if you are American. For the world's richest people, things can only get better.

But for the rest of the planet, fears are growing that others may have to pay the price for this meteoric rise in medical knowledge. The concerns of the US biotechnology industry are sweeping aside everything in their path.

This point was starkly underlined at the BioVision 2001 life science forum in Lyons last week. International health officials, drug company chiefs and doctors all expressed alarm that the US genetics juggernaut has become so powerful it threatens to force its products on the world, whether it likes it or not. At best the consequences will be wasteful; at worst, it will be dangerous to health.

In most African countries new heart drugs are useless in towns and villages where most people die before middle age. In Europe drug regulatory problems and political opposition have led its biotech industry to the brink of extinction at American hands.

As Dr Tikki Pang, of the World Health Organisation, put it: 'There is a simple question to consider: will current advances in genomics help the developing world, and the answer is that they will not.'

The world needed mosquito nets, cheap re-hydrating drugs, and condoms to combat its three main killers - malaria, diarrhoeal illnesses and Aids - not hi-tech drugs to alleviate the symptoms of old age, he added. Pang warned that the health of Africans and Asians could worsen, thanks to the rise of the US genetics industry.

The example of malaria, which kills more than a million people a year, most of them children, was illustrative, he said. 'It is attractive to think that sequencing its genes will lead to new drugs and insecticides. It is more likely, however, that any such discoveries will be patented and only developed at prices unaffordable to those who need them most.'

Other controversial bio-technology forays include Syngenta's 'golden rice', normal rice that has been genetically modified to make vitamin A. This, it is claimed, could save thousands of Third World lives. Some scientists even claim that a month's delay in marketing golden rice could cause more than 50,000 children to go blind through vitamin A deficiency. But Greenpeace research suggests a person would have to eat more than 20lbs of rice a day to get a sight-saving dose of the vitamin.

Even within the West, a dangerous split has emerged. Conference delegates heard that 506,794 gene patents have now been made by scientists, and of these more than 9,500 cover patents for the human body, the richest vein for medical researchers. In addition, tens of thousands more patents are likely to follow, and from these the medicines of tomorrow will emerge: better targeted vaccines, drugs, and improved diagnostic tools. As Dr Dan Detmer, of Cambridge University, put it: 'There is a biological land rush going on now and everyone is trying to stake a genetic claim.' Crucially, the vast majority of these gene patents are being taken out by US companies.

Even in the US industry, this causes concern. 'We don't actually ask what people want from us,' said Dr Goran Ando, head of the Pharmacia Corporation. 'We tend to do what we can do, not what people want.'

Ando pointed to recent cancer drugs. 'These keep people alive for longer, which sounds great. But does it actually make lives better? There is no use in extending life if you don't extend its quality.

As one delegate put it: 'We are getting what is scientifically and financially feasible. Not what is needed.'

webTitle: Leader: Having fewer genes is good for you

fields.headline: Against nature
fields.standfirst:
Having fewer genes is good for you

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: We are more free, it seems, than we had realised. The discovery that humans have far fewer genes than previously thought - a mere 40,000 or so rather than 150,000 - has led scientists to reignite a debate that has split philosophers, educationalists and social reformers for millennia.
fields.body:
We are more free, it seems, than we had realised. The discovery that humans have far fewer genes than previously thought - a mere 40,000 or so rather than 150,000 - has led scientists to reignite a debate that has split philosophers, educationalists and social reformers for millennia.

There simply aren't enough genes, researchers now suggest, to have one each for all the characteristics that have been associated with them, from alcoholism to criminality to intelligence. The finding is a setback for those who believe we are largely pre-programmed, and a fillip to those who insist we are formed by our experiences. Nurture, the scientists now suggest, is far more important than nature.

The new research provides backing for those who believe in the beautiful adaptability and potential of humans, for those who believe that no child can be written off because of their genes. It offers a vote of confidence in those who believe in the importance of education and helping the young. It supports those who believe in redemption, who refuse to give up hope for criminals because 'they were born like that'. Politically, it offers comfort for the Left, with its belief in the potential of all, however deprived their background. But it is damning for the Right, with its fondness for ruling classes and original sin.

If the scientists really have found we are simpler than they thought, the lesson is clear - there is hope for us all. Let's just pray they are right - and keep reading the self-improvement manuals.

webTitle: EU allows in new flood of GM food

fields.headline: EU allows in new flood of GM food
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: European laws to be introduced this week will open Britain to a fresh wave of controversial genetically modified crops and foods.
fields.body:
European laws to be introduced this week will open Britain to a fresh wave of controversial genetically modified crops and foods.

A new directive, which has been backed by the Government, will end a three-year de facto moratorium on granting licences for the commercial development of GM foods. The standstill was imposed by major European nations following concerns about the impact of the new crops on health and the environment.

'The moratorium is dead,' said David Bowe, the British MEP who liaises between the European Parliament and the Commission on GM issues. He welcomed the new legislation last week.

'This is a significant step in terms of habituating people to GM products. There will soon be more GM foods in our shops but they will be safe. There is nothing here that will kill the world.'

But anti-GM campaigners have grave concerns.

'The [new directive] is not enough to protect the environment, consumers and farmers from GM crops,' said Adrian Bebb of Friends of the Earth.

'The British government is ignoring the wishes of the vast bulk of British consumers. The public have made it very clear that they are unhappy about eating GM foods and about GM crops growing in the countryside.'

Fourteen applications from biotech companies for licences to plant GM products for commercial use have been on hold during the moratorium. Dozens of requests to develop GM organisms are now expected from major multinational firms in the wake of the new legislation. The testing of GM crops for environmental impact has been allowed - there will be 96 such trials in the UK this year - but no planting for commercial use has been permitted. This will be changed by the new laws.

All fresh applications will be subject to approval by a majority vote in a committee made up of representatives of EU member states. They will have to pass the requirements of the directive.

'The regulations are so strict that some natural foods wouldn't pass them,' said Bowe.

However from this week it will be illegal under EU law for Britain to ban or stop the commercial planting of a crop cleared at a European level unless serious and justified concerns over environmental or economic impact can be demonstrated. Because of the time needed for trials, and the 'implementation period' allowed, the effect of the new laws is not likely to be felt for up to two years.

GM products which have commercial licences pending include tomatoes with extra-thick skins that make them less likely to bruise during transport and harvesting. Pressure from the public has previously forced supermarkets to withdraw paste made from the modified tomatoes.

The long-term effects of GM foods are not yet known. Campaigners now fear that supermarkets will be encouraged to 'have another go' at accustoming the British consumer to GM food. The Government has supported the new laws.

A spokesman for the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, which is responsible for the current UK non-commercial GM crop trials, said the reform 'put in place new safeguards rather than opening any floodgates.'

However there are clear signs that British consumer is not yet happy to accept the new foods. Last month supermarket chains Tesco and Asda announced they would no longer sell the meat or milk of any animal fed with genetically modified soya or maize.

The two companies, which between them control 42 per cent of the grocery market, said they will switch their imports from North America to Brazil where commercial GM plantings are illegal. Iceland, Marks & Spencer, McDonald's and Burger King have already acted to remove GM in animal products.

Tony Blair appeared to be an early supporter of GM foods, hoping that Britain could be a world leader in biotechnology if 'the tyranny of pressure groups' was resisted. However, recently he was more cautious: 'There's no doubt that there is potential for harm both in terms of human safety and in the diversity of our environment from GM foods or crops.'

The new laws face strong opposition from other European nations and could lead to a major row. The French have said that they will try to block all new licences for commercial growing of GM crops. They say that the question of the legal liability of biotech companies for any damage done by the new crops has not been satisfactorily resolved and are concerned about 'traceability' - provisions to ensure that consumers know what they are eating. Italy, Greece and Luxembourg are likely to back the French position.

Last month supermarket chains Tesco and Asda announced they would no longer sell the meat or milk of any animal fed with genetically modified soya or maize. The two companies, which between them control 42 per cent of the grocery market, said they will switch their imports from North America to Brazil where commercial GM plantings are illegal. Iceland, Marks & Spencer, McDonald's and Burger King have already acted to remove GM in animal products. Tony Blair appeared to be an early supporter of GM foods, hoping that Britain could be a world leader in biotechnology if 'the tyranny of pressure groups' was resisted. However, recently he was more cautious: 'There's no doubt that there is potential for harm both in terms of human safety and in the diversity of our environment from GM foods or crops.' The new laws face strong opposition from other European nations and could lead to a major row. The French have said that they will try to block all new licences for commercial growing of GM crops. They say that the question of the legal liability of biotech companies for any damage done by the new crops has not been satisfactorily resolved and are concerned about 'traceability' - provisions to ensure that consumers know what they are eating. Italy, Greece and Luxembourg are likely to back the French position.

webTitle: Leader:  Stagecoach's Mr Eccles takes the cake

fields.headline: He's off the rails
fields.standfirst: Stagecoach's Mr Eccles takes the cake
fields.trailText: The new rail director of Stagecoach, Graham Eccles, says he considers it acceptable for commuters to stand for up to 30 minutes in the rush hour on a crowded train.
fields.body:
The new rail director of Stagecoach, Graham Eccles, says he considers it acceptable for commuters to stand for up to 30 minutes in the rush hour on a crowded train. No doubt Mr Eccles, in the words famously coined by that other celebrated light entertainer, Liberace, is laughing all the way to the bank as he enriches himself on the misery of 'customers' paying through the nose in order to stand on his trains for five hours a week.

But given the pitiful track record of Stagecoach, which operates South West Trains and also owns 49 per cent of the laughable Virgin train operation, his comments do not come as a surprise. It is Mr Eccles's chairman, Brian Souter, who has boasted of telling complainants that he feels like writing to their bosses and saying: 'Do you know this guy spends two hours a week writing to a train company?' Beleaguered commuters need not spend two hours putting their complaints in writing, of course. They can simply call Mr Souter instead. On 01738-442111. It's good to talk.

webTitle: Cut workers' hours, not jobs, unions urge Corus

fields.headline: Cut workers' hours, not jobs, unions urge Corus
fields.trailText: Steel unions are urging Corus to save thousands of jobs in plants faced with closure by cutting the hours of threatened employees.
fields.body:
Steel unions are urging Corus to save thousands of jobs in plants faced with closure by cutting the hours of threatened employees.

As part of this plan, unions are pushing the Government to contribute funds for retraining affected workers. Officials at the ISTC steel union received strong support for the package from Prime Minister Tony Blair.

ISTC general secretary Michael Leahy travelled to Brussels on Friday after his meeting with Blair to ask European officials whether the proposals would pass European regulations on state aid in the steel industry.

ISTC sources claim some support from government may be acceptable under EU rules. It is likely that the ISTC, one of the country's wealthiest unions, would meet some of the costs itself.

On 1 February Corus announced 6,050 job cuts across its UK operations, with 3,000 falling on workers at plants in Wales and the North East. Ebbw Vale in Wales is to shut completely, while Llanwern, Shotton and Bryngwyn will all see partial shutdowns, along with Teesside in the North East.

After meetings with angry union officials, Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffat agreed to a two-week pause before the statutory period of union consultation over the job cuts. That pause ends on Wednesday. Leahy would not confirm details of the package. However he said: 'We are more hopeful today than we have been so far that we can put a package together that makes sense to the Government and to the company.'

The Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union has proposed talking to several companies about training and employing steelworkers should they be made redundant.

 Hundreds of jobs are on the line at Motorola's hi-tech manufacturing facilities in Scotland. On Friday the US electronics giant announced the loss of 4,000 jobs worldwide from its semiconductor business. Involuntary lay-offs are expected. Motorola employs 2,000 at its East Kilbride plant. A further 500 work at South Queensferry. If the global cuts were spread equally, around 300 jobs would be lost in Scotland.

webTitle: Stringfellow hopes Paris will lap up clubs

fields.headline: Stringfellow hopes Paris will lap up clubs
fields.trailText: Peter Stringfellow is about to make another conquest, and for once it won't be a pneumatic blonde a third of his age.
fields.body:
Peter Stringfellow is about to make another conquest, and for once it won't be a pneumatic blonde a third of his age.

After months of negotiations Stringfellow is poised to open his second table dancing club, in the home city of the Moulin Rouge and the Folies-Bergères. Opening a Paris club is the first step in Stringfellow's plan to build a chain of Cabaret of Angels clubs.

The 60-year-old Yorkshireman, who made table dancing famous here when he opened his first Angels club in London in 1995, said: 'I'm in the final stages of negotiating with a leisure group in Paris. I expect the negotiations to be concluded by 15 February.' He declined to name the leisure group.

Stringfellow, a prominent supporter of the Conservative party who first made a living organising gigs for the Beatles, has had his fingers burnt before from running clubs abroad. In the early Nineties the US recession forced him to close clubs in Los Angeles and Miami.

However, he now believes the time is right to expand abroad: 'This has been in negotiations for nine months. It's coming to fruition. I'm very excited about it. I'm also looking to open in Birmingham and Manchester.'

Stringfellow, whose club in Covent Garden makes more than £1 million profit a year, repeated his hopes for taking his company public. 'The City has got to take notice of this business, and I believe the plc way is the way forward.'

The flamboyant party-goer, recently linked with an attempt to acquire the Oldie magazine, has tried to float his business on the stock market on several occasions.

Stringfellow's overseas adventure comes as the UK table dancing industry faces a new threat from US operators with years of experience. US group Spearmint Rhino has already opened two clubs, one near Heathrow airport and the other in London's Tottenham Court Road, and plans a further 20 openings in the next few years.

Other US and Canadian operators are also poised to move in on Stringfellow's patch in the near future.

webTitle: Race for Formula One takes off

fields.headline: Race for Formula One takes off
fields.trailText: Europe's big carmakers aim to gain more clout in motor racing in what is becoming a four-way tussle for control of Formula One, writes Paul Farrelly .
fields.body:
Europe's big carmakers aim to gain more clout in motor racing in what is becoming a four-way tussle for control of Formula One, writes Paul Farrelly .

A consortium of Ford, BMW, Fiat, Renault and Daimler Chrysler is talking to the grand prix supremo Bernie Ecclestone about taking a 25 per cent plus stake valued at over $1 billion, City and motor sport sources say.

Ecclestone, who still owns half the company that controls Formula One, is meanwhile having an embarrassing row with the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA), the sport's governing body, over a $360 million deal to extend the term of his rights over the grand prix circus.

This weekend, he is understood to be opposing attempts by German media giant Kirch, Europe's biggest pay-TV operator, to take control of the sport. Kirch is negotiating to rescue its troubled Munich rival EM.TV, which bought the other half of Formula One last year.

The carmakers, who may be joined by Japanese firms Honda and Toyota, are keen to secure a return on their investment of $100m apiece in their grand prix teams.

Jaguar - owned by Ford - bought ex-world champion Jackie Stewart's team 18 months ago, while Mercedes - part of DaimlerChrysler - has taken over McLaren as part of a new phase of its Formula One involvement.

The carmakers have also been in talks with the FIA, which has threatened to reconsider its deal with Ecclestone if he does not conclude his commercial deal and pay $60m deposit within six weeks.

Last week, FIA president Max Mosley, a lawyer, and long Ecclestone's staunch ally, welcomed the manufacturers' interest, but deflected their calls for more power.

This weekend, however, senior motor industry sources warned of their determination. 'As always Max Mosley QC is choosing his words care fully,' one said. 'We wouldn't have invested if we didn't think the basics were right. But we need to protect our investment and want to improve our influence.'

If the carmakers were frozen out, one option would be to renegotiate the way revenue from showing the races on TV is shared between Ecclestone, the FIA and the teams, industry sources said.

Seasoned Ecclestone observers suggested his brinkmanship with the FIA was part of a wider game to unsettle Kirch's plans. The tycoon declined to comment.
