webTitle: Mrs Mops clean up for Unilever

fields.headline: Mrs Mops clean up for Unilever
fields.trailText: It charges £42 a week for a one-bedroom flat and was dismissed at its launch as a diversification too far, but Unilever has won enough customers for its home cleaning service to expand it across London.
fields.body:
It charges £42 a week for a one-bedroom flat and was dismissed at its launch as a diversification too far, but Unilever has won enough customers for its home cleaning service to expand it across London.

Myhome was tried out in a small area of west London 15 months ago and now has 1,500 customers. Following an evaluation of that pilot scheme, the service is to be sold across London - Docklands is likely to be the next lucky recipient - for a further year before the group decides whether to take it national.

'Demand so far has exceeded supply,' said Niall FitzGerald, Unilever's joint chairman. 'And that is one of the issues we will be looking at. The question is, have we put together a business model we can run with?'

A spokeswoman for Lever Brothers, the Unilever division running the trials, said the focus for the next phase would be on building customer loyalty - so that it can use the cleaning to promote other services, such as laundry or gardening.

Myhome is seen as a way both of promoting the use of Unilever cleaning products such as Cif, the new name for Jif, and of capitalising on the fact that Britons are becoming a 'cash-rich, time-poor' nation. We are, Unilever believes, keen to have sparkling homes, but less and less willing to do the work for ourselves.

That attitude is behind another initiative being tested by the group: Rocket ready-to-cook food. It has installed a kiosk at the City office of investment bank UBS Warburg, where staff can pick up the ingredients for a gourmet meal prepared and ready to be served in just 10 minutes. Thai-style coconut and lemongrass chicken with fresh lime and basmati rice is just one dish.

The results of that trial are still being evaluated. A decision on whether to extend it will be taken in the second half of the year. Unlike Myhome, however, Rocket is not a way of promoting Unilever products; the ready meals are likely to be a little more sophisticated than a jar of the company's Chicken Tonight.

webTitle: Manufacturing must make it

fields.headline: Manufacturing must make it
fields.trailText: At a superficial level the Government and the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) have conducted a superb economic policy. Inflation has remained low; full employment has come within sight; and the public sector's finances are in better shape than any previous Labour government ever dreamed of.
fields.body:
At a superficial level the Government and the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) have conducted a superb economic policy. Inflation has remained low; full employment has come within sight; and the public sector's finances are in better shape than any previous Labour government ever dreamed of.

Below the surface, however, things do not look quite so good. There are disturbing parallels with the way the first Thatcher government squandered its first four years, and presided over a dangerous decline in manufacturing industry.

The debit side of the public finances record is that public spending has grown by even less under Labour than it did under the Major government, with the problems of years of neglect apparent for all to see. As the distinguished German journalist Thomas Kielinger wrote last week: 'In Germany, such imperfections of public services as have become the hallmark over here would find the populace in open revolt.'

Daily life, in private and public, is a continuum. But, in a most un-Keynesian way, the present Government decided it had to save before it could spend, and allowed an already debilitated public sector to deteriorate further. The results are there for all to see, but as John Kenneth Galbraith once said about the British and monetarism, the phlegmatic British will put up with anything. The phlegmatic British are almost certain to re-elect this government, just as they re-elected Thatcher - not least because the 'alternative' is even worse. Yet much of what the Prime Minister and his colleagues promise now sounds much as if they were campaigning to be elected for the first time.

The other macro-economic failing of this Government has been, I believe, its insouciant attitude towards the exchange rate, and the damage an overvalued pound has done to industry. The extent of the problem is illustrated by the fact that, even though the pound has come down a lot against the Deutschmark, it is still above the levels that were considered intolerable at the time of Black Wednesday, in 1992, when we left the Exchange Rate Mechanism.

So far the Government has had the good fortune to ride on the back of a world boom manufactured in the US. But all that is changing, and the perception of the threat to the rest of the world from the dramatic US slowdown was a major factor behind last week's interest rate cut. Such has been the belated groundswell of opinion that the UK and Europe may well catch a cold from the US economic virus that the hawks on the MPC had an excuse to get out of the corner they painted themselves into last month. Then, they were worrying that a cut might be interpreted as panic. But if everybody else has talked themselves into expecting a cut, it's not considered panic.

To a certain extent the MPC has worried about the overvalued pound, and sometimes cited it as a reason for action or inaction. But its principal, indeed overriding, brief has been the achievement of the inflation target. This contrasts with other European countries in the period leading up to entry to the single currency. France spent years achieving a sensible exchange rate vis-à-vis the Deutschmark - in the end gaining something of a competitive advantage against Germany, which is commonly perceived as having entered at an overvalued rate.

Now that the Prime Minister has done a rare thing - clarifying policy in the Commons rather than via selective leaks to the media - we know that a decision will have to be taken on whether the pound is fit to be subsumed into the euro within two years of the expected May election.

This would suggest that it may be time to alter the MPC's brief, and gear economic policy towards achieving a sustainable exchange rate before entry to the euro. In any case, whatever the people decide in a referendum, we need a sustainable exchange rate.

When I was in Tokyo just before Christmas, the President of Nissan, Carlos Ghosn, told me his decision on whether to expand production in the UK (now taken, and favourably for this country) would be made after he had assessed whether Blair was serious about joining the euro - but also after assessing the prospects for the exchange rate.

When British Ministers welcome 'the recovery of the euro' this is code for the love that dare not speak its name: their welcome for the necessary devaluation of the pound. Nissan, with a highly efficient plant in Sunderland, has been finding it difficult to make profits at recent exchange rates. And the rationalisation emerging from Whitehall - that the crisis at Corus is part of an inevitable historical trend and has nothing to do with the strong pound - just beggars belief.

Between 1989 and 1999 (the last year for which full figures are available) industrial production rose by about a third in the US, by a quarter in the so-called 'sclerotic' European Union, and by about a tenth in the dynamic, Anglo-Saxon, Thatcherised and Blairised UK. Recently it was reported that the number of listed companies in the Midlands had fallen from 190 in 1995 to 127 in 2000, and that that great name Glynwed had essentially turned itself into a small business - not exactly, I think, what the Government's encouragement of small businesses is meant to be about.

If, as has been reported, 'the Government's industrial strategy is based on the notion that the traditional industries of Britain - steel, cars, textiles, metal-bashing in all its forms - are on the way out', perhaps the Government ought to make an excuse and leave too. Two-thirds of our export earnings come from manufacturing. The main reason for the relatively low share of total employment accounted for by manufacturing is that productivity gains are much greater in manufacturing than in services - as economists say, manufacturing is less 'labour intensive'.

But the Vodafones of this world are a supplement to traditional employment - they cannot take its place. Just look at how many manufactured objects you encounter and need in the course of a day - even when dealing with so called 'service industries'. The whole of the developing world, too, will be crying out for manufactured products in future years. Britain needs to stay in manufacturing if it is not to decline into some kind of European theme park - a park this Government would be none too good at running anyway.

As I pointed out recently, it is a myth that manufacturing was in decline in the decades up to the Seventies - indeed it was the fastest-growing sector. It is also a myth that depreciation of the currency got us nowhere - such depreciation reflected the fact that our inflation was higher, and our productivity lower, than in other countries.

Gordon Brown hopes to achieve the double of lasting improvements in our inflation and our productivity performance - improvements which, if achieved, would make the British economy's life easier under a single currency, when there would be no opportunity to devalue against other eurozone members.

Manufacturing has suffered three periods of severe currency overvaluation in 20 years. It is absolutely crucial to the run-up to possible euro entry that the exchange rate point is taken seriously.

Oh, and by the way: the Prime Minister's 'clarification' of the euro timetable has been interpreted largely in terms of domestic politics. But perhaps the cabinet - not all of whose members believe history began on 1 May 1997 - remember the name Charles de Gaulle.

Our friends across the water want us in at the moment, but if there is too much shilly-shallying, there may come a time when a new de Gaulle says 'non' - or even 'nein'.

Britain needs to stay in manufacturing if it is not to decline into some kind of European theme park - a park this Government would be none too good at running anyway. As I pointed out recently, it is a myth that manufacturing was in decline in the decades up to the Seventies - indeed it was the fastest-growing sector. It is also a myth that depreciation of the currency got us nowhere - such depreciation reflected the fact that our inflation was higher, and our productivity lower, than in other countries. Gordon Brown hopes to achieve the double of lasting improvements in our inflation and our productivity performance - improvements which, if achieved, would make the British economy's life easier under a single currency, when there would be no opportunity to devalue against other eurozone members. Manufacturing has suffered three periods of severe currency overvaluation in 20 years. It is absolutely crucial to the run-up to possible euro entry that the exchange rate point is taken seriously. Oh, and by the way: the Prime Minister's 'clarification' of the euro timetable has been interpreted largely in terms of domestic politics. But perhaps the cabinet - not all of whose members believe history began on 1 May 1997 - remember the name Charles de Gaulle. Our friends across the water want us in at the moment, but if there is too much shilly-shallying, there may come a time when a new de Gaulle says 'non' - or even 'nein'.

webTitle: My money: Accountant Graham Ward

fields.headline: Accountants dull? We're like Formula One racers
fields.standfirst: Pre-schoolers need pensions, an expert tells Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Pre-schoolers need pensions, an expert tells Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Graham Ward is thinking of starting a pension for his son when the new 'stakeholder' schemes begin in April.

'Inculcating some sound financial principles in four-year-old Alexander is a good idea,' the president of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales says with a smile.

Ward, now 48, founded PricewaterhouseCoopers' pensions advisory service 15 years ago, before retirement funds acquired their high profile. So he is well aware of the fact that parents will be able to get basic-rate tax relief on stakeholder pension contributions they make on behalf of their children from 6 April.

By that time, Ward will be near the end of his year as president of the accountants' body. He plans to be near to completing a huge reform programme intended to show the public that chartered accountants are not just a large vested interest. He is setting up a structure to review, supervise and discipline the 118,000 institute members.

What is different about this structure is that several of its committees will be dominated by lay people. (Perhaps the lawyers will learn a lesson from this.) It is no longer good enough, he says, for accountants to say to clients and the broader public: 'Trust us, we're professionals. It's OK.'

This might not sound wildly exciting but it is important in the financial world. Every time a Barings Bank collapses, a Robert Maxwell plunders his employees' pensions or an Equitable Life becomes immersed in crisis, there are cries about why the auditors did not spot the problems. A commonly-voiced concern is whether the auditors were too close to the company.

So people such as Ward are playing a crucial role in the background of our lives. Why, then, does this Oxford chemistry graduate and boxing blue think accountants are seen as dull?

'This myth is supposed to come from the Monty Python sketch. If you look at what people value about chartered accountants, as well as their business skills, it is integrity and reliability. But that doesn't mean you have to be boring. Being a Formula One racing driver means you have to be reliable.'

After his term of office finishes on 6 June, Ward will return to spending most of his 80-hour weeks in his PricewaterhouseCoopers role of 'senior partner of the global energy and utilities group'. Being a partner has a direct effect on his own investment strategy: he cannot buy shares in companies that are clients of the firm so he buys unit and investment trusts instead. But he also has to be careful not to buy into funds which are managed by clients.

'You can't have the president breaking his own rules,' he says.

He describes himself as a cautious investor: 'I tend to be quite conservative. I'm looking for solid and steady growth, not trendy go-go stuff. I make sure I have as much invested in pensions as I can. And then I make maximum use of Peps, Isas and Tessas to sweep up.'

He knows blunders with money would not help his image as an accountant and adviser to the utility companies of the world. 'I get someone in the firm to do my tax return for me. And, yes, I did get it in on time.'

webTitle: EDS set to join Sema chase

fields.headline: EDS set to join Sema chase
fields.standfirst: US computing giant considers £3bn bid  Troubled Anglo-French software firm eyes break-up
fields.trailText: EDS, the world's biggest computer services company, is understood to be considering a bid of more than £3 billion for Sema, the troubled Anglo-French software firm.
fields.body:
EDS, the world's biggest computer services company, is understood to be considering a bid of more than £3 billion for Sema, the troubled Anglo-French software firm.

The US giant's interest comes as Sema is locked in advanced takeover talks with Schlumberger, the US oilfield services-to-smartcard technology group.

Sema, one of the UK's biggest software and computer outsourcing companies, appointed investment bank advisers a fortnight ago following an approach from Schlumberger, and said last week that it was talking to a number of unnamed suitors.

Insiders say Sema is also considering a possible break-up to maximise shareholder value.

The group has been vulnerable since its shares collapsed: they lost more than half their value following two profits warnings at the end of last year. The market was stunned by poor performance from LHS, a German software house for which Sema paid £1.9bn only last June.

EDS was founded in 1962 by maverick entrepreneur Ross Perot and has controversially snapped up the lion's share of UK government outsourcing contracts. In 1984 it was bought by General Motors, but was spun off in 1996 and - with sales of $19bn last year - is now listed on the New York and London stock exchanges.

This weekend, EDS declined to elaborate on its interest. 'We do not comment on rumours or speculation of this sort, but we thank you for taking the time to give us a call,' spokesman Isch Haley said from the US giant's headquarters in Plano, Texas.

Industry sources, however, said the firm - now headed by former Cable & Wireless chief Dick Brown - was a far more logical buyer than Schlumberger. Since taking over 18 months ago, Brown has cut 15,000 jobs and taken EDS into higher-growth areas.

One senior industry source said: 'EDS understands the outsourcing business better and would give Sema real US clout. Sema would also take EDS into attractive, high-growth telecoms software.'

This weekend Sema, which is being advised by CSFB and Rothschild, also declined to comment, as did Schlumberger. Among other parties, Siemens of Germany and Computer Sciences Corporation of the US are understood to have run the slide rule over the group.

Britain's Logica has ruled itself out. France's Cap Gemini, which is merging with Ernst & Young's computer consultancy operation, is thought unlikely to bid.

Sema's board met last Friday to consider the takeover approaches and a possible break-up, involving a spin-off of its outsourcing, telecoms and other software operations. The group is due to announce annual results on 20 February. Schlumberger had hoped to conclude a deal by then.

Schlumberger, whose sales totalled $9.6bn last year, is also keen to tie up France Télécom's 17 per cent holding in Sema, which is for sale, and a key stake held by the French bank BNP-Paribas.

It has recently agreed to take over French computer group Bull's smartcard operations for $325m.

EDS's Brown also has good Gallic links. In December, he joined the board of French entertainment giant Vivendi Universal after its merger with Canada's Seagram.

webTitle: International Power plots California move

fields.headline: International Power plots California move
fields.trailText: British generator International Power is planning to cash in on the Californian energy crisis by building power stations there and reaping rewards from high prices.
fields.body:
British generator International Power is planning to cash in on the Californian energy crisis by building power stations there and reaping rewards from high prices.

The international arm of former UK generator National Power sees a long-term opportunity in California because the state does not have enough generating capacity to meet soaring internet-fuelled demand for electricity.

Wholesale electricity prices in California have leapt from an average $30 to hundreds of dollars per megawatt hour, threatening to ruin utilities in the state, which cannot pass on the increased costs fully to consumers.

International Power chief executive Peter Giller told The Observer last week that he had sent a team to California to seek possible sites and prepare the ground for future contracts in the hope of building up to 3,000 MW of generating capacity there. This is more than IP currently has in its existing American plants in Texas, Georgia, Massachusetts and New Jersey. It has four further plants under construction in the US, along with stations in Europe, Asian and Australia.

Giller said: ' There is something like 60,000-70,000 MW of plant there, so I would look at about 3,000, which would give us about a 5 per cent market share.' He said he would fund construction costs by signing forward contracts with energy users. Contracts totalling between $10 million and $15m would make construction viable, he said.

He added that stringent environmental and planning laws in California - blamed as a key reason for the lack of new plant being built in the state - could make the process difficult.

But last Friday state governor Gray Davis introduced a fast-track approvals process for new power stations as part of a plan to increase the state's output by 5,000MW.

Giller also made it clear that he saw Europe as a growth area. The blocking of a £9.7 billion merger between Spanish giants Endesa and Iberdrola, which would have put some 5,000MW up for sale, meant that IP would focus more on Italy than Spain in the future.

webTitle: Money writes: Sad saga ends with £800 joy

fields.headline: Sad saga ends with £800 joy
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I have not been paid in full by Ema Financial Insurance Services for a claim I made when I had to cancel a Saga holiday because of my wife's illness.

I booked this Mediterranean cruise in November 1999 and bought an annual travel policy in May 2000.

The cruise started in October 2000 but on 19 September my wife visited the doctor, who said she was well enough to travel. This was confirmed by a specialist she saw on 22 September. Her condition deteriorated five days later and I contacted the insurer on 27 September.

They say I should have told them the day she first saw the doctor, but we had no reason then to think the holiday would be cancelled. Allowing for a £100 excess, they should have paid £2,544 but I had only £1,662, a shortfall of £882.
HP, Basingstoke

You alerted the insurer more promptly than most people would in the circumstances. Ema says its policy clearly states that you should inform them when awaiting the results of tests. But nowhere are the words 'on the day you first feel ill' or even 'immediately' used, so I do not see how they can penalise you.

The insurer says you could have followed its complaints procedure if you had been unhappy with the payment, but it now accepts you acted reasonably and in good faith. Contact the broker again and your claim will be paid fully.

Missing pension: Woolwich woes

On the advice of the Woolwich, I swapped to an accountwith extra interest. I was told everything would be the same. A month later, my pension was not been paid into my new account.

I am now getting my pension but when the DSS sent my £100 winter fuel payment to the account, the Woolwich sent it back. The bank gave me £10 for my trouble and phone calls, but I would rather have given £20 to someone who could clear up this mess.

It has caused me a lot of distress and anxiety. My husband blames me so we quarrel over it.
ZC, Maidstone

The Woolwich has now written to you accepting full responsibility for this muddle. it blames a breakdown in communication.

It is profusely sorry and is sending you a cheque for £100 with unreserved apologies. It says you should contact the DSS again to make sure they have your new bank details for the fuel payment.

Intrusive queries: Firm backs off

I responded to an advertisement sent out by St James's Place to attend a seminar on inheritance tax planning. They asked me to complete a questionnaire, which was reasonable in the circumstances apart from three peculiar questions: They wanted the numbers of my driving licence, passport and national insurance.

I could not see their relevance to estate planning so queried it. The salesman insisted the details were a 'statutory requirement'. Very odd indeed.
GM, London

St James's Place first told me they wanted the information to make sure you are who you say, and said you must provide identification for 'anti-money laundering purposes'. That is true if you open a bank account - but not to sit in on a seminar.

On a closer look, St James's realised that the financial adviser who sent the questionnaire had been trying to short-circuit his paperwork.

He sent you a 'factfind' which is the document clients complete if, after a seminar, they want financial advice. Factfinds do not normally include money laundering questions, but St James's has rolled two forms into one to save effort.

It admits the salesman's aim for efficiency backfired and it is telling him in future to rewrite his covering letter to make it clear that completing the questionnaire is not a prerequisite of attending the course.

Tessa trouble: Paper lost

I wrote to my Alliance & Leicester branch in January about the difference in rates paid on its Tessa and Isa, and asked for a maturity certificate to be made available on the Tessa's maturity date. The letter was passed to head office.

Four days after that date I had still not received the certificate. The branch said no certificate was available; none had been ordered nor could they find a copy of my letter.

Head office said it was company policy not to send out certificates until after the maturity date but, until I receive the certificate, I cannot open a Tessa Isa with another provider.
GT, Llandysul

The Inland Revenue does not allow Tessa providers to issue maturity certificates until the due date but institutions vary in the way they send them out. Some make them available in branches on the day.

Alliance & Leicester posts them by first class mail the day after, but cannot trace why your certificate took so long to arrive. It will pay interest from the date of maturity to the time you received it and make a goodwill payment of £25.

Missing cheque: Lost Week

Last November I bought a subscription to The Week for my son in California. A month later, I was told that my cheque had not arrived. I gave my debit card details over the phone on the understanding that, should my original cheque turn up, I would be refunded the excess.

In December, the cheque cleared but my efforts to recover the £52 have been fruitless. On one occasion, I was told that a cheque had been sent to me on 26 December. Who would be in the office on that day?
DT, Bishop Auckland

The week says there was a skeleton staff working at Christmas, and records show that a cheque was sent out. It cannot explain why you did not receive it. It has now sent a cheque for £52 by recorded delivery and added four issues to your son's subscription in compensation.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Property: The shock of the new

fields.headline: Moving in - and the shock of the new
fields.standfirst: Graham Norwood  on the pitfalls of just-built homes
fields.trailText: Graham Norwood on the pitfalls of just-built homes.
fields.body:
Most of us go for the easy life when it comes to buying a house. A poll of home buyers by upmarket estate agent Strutt and Parker recently revealed that younger buyers wanted new houses with lower running costs: this allowed them to devote more of their income to the largest possible mortgage.

The thatched country cottage and the Jacobean townhouse do look lovely, but most of us prefer new homes because they cost less to maintain. Don't they?

Don't expect agreement from Mr and Mrs A of Sussex, who want to remain anonymous because of legal action taking place over their grievances with a small developer. Last May they moved into a new four-bedroom chalet bungalow on a small development constructed and marketed by a private building company.

Since then they say they have had problems including sewage from a blockage next door emerging through the floor of their house and a cracked bathroom floor - plus a host of minor com plaints such as poorly fitting doors.

They are also in dispute over whether the house has the appropriate cavity-wall insulation, and now want the National House Building Council (NHBC) to consider action against the developer.

'We moved into a new house and expected snagging and some problems,' says Mrs A, 'but nothing of this scale. We've been in constant dialogue with the builder since we moved in, and haven't ruled out legal action at some stage.

'We've had to keep a record of everything we've gone through, including the money we've spent on some work we would say was really the responsibility of the builder. We put everything away over Christmas to try to have a normal holiday, but now we're considering possible legal action.'

That family's experience is more severe than most, but a recent survey by the NHBC showed that 81 per cent of people moving into a new house suffered some snags - but that most of them expected the problems, too.

There is no guarantee that even the best-built new house will come without a fault, but one way of minimising the risk is to ensure that a new property conforms to standards set out by the National House Building Council.

The NHBC is a non-profit body listing some 20,000 builders and developers who agree to construct houses to a standard set out by the council and with a code of practice for rectifying prob lems. The NHBC 'Buildmark' scheme applies to new flats, maisonettes, bungalows and houses, offering three key provisions:

 If the builder goes bankrupt before the house is complete, the NHBC will refund the buyer's lost deposit or pay the cost of completion up to a maximum of 10 per cent of the market value or £10,000, whichever is the greater.

 During the first two-year 'initial warranty period' after completion, any defect that results from non-compliance with NHBC standards must be put right by the builder at no cost to the buyer.

 During the following eight-year 'structural warranty period' insurance cover is provided against any major damage caused by a failure to stick to NHBC regulations

The NHBC monitors participating builders - 41 were struck off in the year ending April 2000 - and the worst offenders are named in press releases. The council also offers advice on independent arbitrators who, at a cost, can judge where responsibility for remedying problems should lie.

Nonetheless, payments by the NHBC to remedy poor workmanship increased to £28 million in 1999/2000, a 33 per cent rise on the previous year and more than twice the amount paid only five years earlier.

Customer expectations are growing, and so is their willingness to complain in order to get things done. Some developers, conscious of these growing customer aspirations, are voluntarily improving their performance and image.

One of Britain's biggest builders, Berkeley Homes, surveys every new buyer some six weeks after they move in to assess problems and the company's performance. During 2001 the firm is introducing customer managers to liaise with buyers right from when they first reserve a house until they complete, and to give advance notice of any delays on completion dates or other news about their local development.

Then warranty managers will handle any complaints for two years from the day they move in. The front-line repairs team consists of Berkeley staff: they may have to call in sub-contractors, but will aim to complete the work themselves if possible.

'We need to do this to keep our customers happy and to encourage repeat business - which keeps us happy, too' says a spokesman.

Buyers will hope the system works as well as it sounds.

Don't expect agreement from Mr and Mrs A of Sussex, who want to remain anonymous because of legal action taking place over their grievances with a small developer. Last May they moved into a new four-bedroom chalet bungalow on a small development constructed and marketed by a private building company. Since then they say they have had problems including sewage from a blockage next door emerging through the floor of their house and a cracked bathroom floor - plus a host of minor com plaints such as poorly fitting doors. They are also in dispute over whether the house has the appropriate cavity-wall insulation, and now want the National House Building Council (NHBC) to consider action against the developer. 'We moved into a new house and expected snagging and some problems,' says Mrs A, 'but nothing of this scale. We've been in constant dialogue with the builder since we moved in, and haven't ruled out legal action at some stage. 'We've had to keep a record of everything we've gone through, including the money we've spent on some work we would say was really the responsibility of the builder. We put everything away over Christmas to try to have a normal holiday, but now we're considering possible legal action.' That family's experience is more severe than most, but a recent survey by the NHBC showed that 81 per cent of people moving into a new house suffered some snags - but that most of them expected the problems, too. There is no guarantee that even the best-built new house will come without a fault, but one way of minimising the risk is to ensure that a new property conforms to standards set out by the National House Building Council. The NHBC is a non-profit body listing some 20,000 builders and developers who agree to construct houses to a standard set out by the council and with a code of practice for rectifying prob lems. The NHBC 'Buildmark' scheme applies to new flats, maisonettes, bungalows and houses, offering three key provisions:  If the builder goes bankrupt before the house is complete, the NHBC will refund the buyer's lost deposit or pay the cost of completion up to a maximum of 10 per cent of the market value or £10,000, whichever is the greater.  During the first two-year 'initial warranty period' after completion, any defect that results from non-compliance with NHBC standards must be put right by the builder at no cost to the buyer.  During the following eight-year 'structural warranty period' insurance cover is provided against any major damage caused by a failure to stick to NHBC regulations The NHBC monitors participating builders - 41 were struck off in the year ending April 2000 - and the worst offenders are named in press releases. The council also offers advice on independent arbitrators who, at a cost, can judge where responsibility for remedying problems should lie. Nonetheless, payments by the NHBC to remedy poor workmanship increased to £28 million in 1999/2000, a 33 per cent rise on the previous year and more than twice the amount paid only five years earlier. Customer expectations are growing, and so is their willingness to complain in order to get things done. Some developers, conscious of these growing customer aspirations, are voluntarily improving their performance and image. One of Britain's biggest builders, Berkeley Homes, surveys every new buyer some six weeks after they move in to assess problems and the company's performance. During 2001 the firm is introducing customer managers to liaise with buyers right from when they first reserve a house until they complete, and to give advance notice of any delays on completion dates or other news about their local development. Then warranty managers will handle any complaints for two years from the day they move in. The front-line repairs team consists of Berkeley staff: they may have to call in sub-contractors, but will aim to complete the work themselves if possible. 'We need to do this to keep our customers happy and to encourage repeat business - which keeps us happy, too' says a spokesman. Buyers will hope the system works as well as it sounds.

webTitle: Bruised by the pensions bungling

fields.headline: Bruised by the pensions bungling
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott talks to Dinah Austin, an Equitable investor who has become an old hand at savings scrapes
fields.trailText: Maria Scott talks to Dinah Austin, an Equitable investor who has become an old hand at savings scrapes.
fields.body:
The crisis at Equitable Life has shocked its many investors, but for Dinah Austin, the experience has been particularly bruising. This is the second time she has found herself at loggerheads with the pensions industry over her retirement savings.

Austin, 53, a former manager with computer giant IBM, was advised during the Nineties to transfer a company pension into a personal pension contract that had to be unwound.

Having extricated herself from that, she was advised last year by an Equitable salesman - only weeks before the insurer closed to new business in December - to put a fund of £71,000 into an income drawdown pension scheme.

Last week, Equitable agreed to cancel that contract after she complained about the insurer's handling of her investment.

Mrs Austin's two experiences with the pensions business have left her deeply unimpressed. The disputes have required 'a lot of persistence' to sort out, she says. 'It is disgraceful that the average working person has to face this morass.'

Mrs Austin's was first advised by independent adviser William Mercer to transfer her main IBM pension fund to a personal pension contract. She believed it would be three times the IBM pension, and it was half. She was eventually reinstated to the IBM scheme by Mercer, though the firm did not admit liability or failure to comply with selling regulations.

After leaving IBM Mrs Austin worked freelance for several years before retiring in 2000. Meanwhile, she continued to contribute to a fund with Equitable Life, started originally as an Additional Voluntary Contribution Scheme when she was with IBM. Her troubles with Equitable began last year when she retired and sought advice from an Equitable salesman about what to do with the £71,000 fund.

Her main grievance was over the administration of income payments from the plan. Mrs Austin is an expatriate who lives on a boat for part of the year: she wanted the pension paid abroad and for Equitable to communicate by email. She believed this was going to be possible, but Equitable has been unable to comply with her wishes.

Although this was her main complaint she has subsequently consulted two independent advisers, who questioned whether the product Equitable sold was suitable for her.

They felt that her fund was too small for a drawdown plan, which involves stock market risk. These plans are an alternative to low-paying annuities, and keep the investor's funds in the stock market in the hope that capital will increase to provide a higher income than an annuity. But there is a view in the investment industry that they are only suitable for funds of at least £100,000, because of the market risk involved. And administration charges can deplete smaller funds.

Some advisers, such as the Income Drawdown Advisory Bureau (IDAB), one of the independent firms Mrs Austin sought help from, generally avoid selling them to anyone with funds of less than £250,000. Ian Padmore, an adviser with the Bureau, was concerned that Mrs Austin's money was invested entirely in a with-profits fund. 'This is putting eggs in one basket and isn't the way we would advise income drawdown to be set up.'

He says the IDAB has been contacted by a number of Equitable customers with drawdown schemes bought with small funds - as low as £16,000. He believes these investors should ask the insurer to justify its recommendations.

Equitable spokesman Alistair Dunbar defended the contract, even for small funds, on the basis that costs were low and with-profits was a relatively low-risk form of stock market investment. Equitable Life said it agreed to unwind Mrs Austin's plan because of her concerns over administration and payment abroad, not because it had been mis-sold.

webTitle: Renewed interest in home loans

fields.headline: Renewed interest in home loans
fields.standfirst: The rate cut helps, but there are cheaper mortgages out there anyway. Jill Insley scouts the market
fields.trailText: The rate cut helps, but there are cheaper mortgages out there anyway. Jill Insley scouts the market
fields.body:
Homeowners around the country are no doubt relishing the fact that the roofs over their heads are costing them less this weekend, thanks to last week's 0.25 per cent cut in interest rates.

Several lenders had already reduced their standard variable rate. Nationwide building society started the trend last December by cutting its SVR from 7.29 per cent to 7.09 per cent; it was followed by several others, including the Portman, Yorkshire and, most recently, Standard Life Bank. Others, including the Halifax and HSBC, cut their SVR immediately after the Bank of England's announ-cement on Thursday.

Economists expect another small cut soon. But mortgage brokers say borrowers who really want to save money should take advantage of the ultra-low discounted, tracker and fixed-rate loans available.

David Hollingworth of Bath mortgage broker London & Country favours tracker mortgages, where the interest is set at a certain level above or below the Bank of England base rate. He prefers them to discounted loans because any change in the base rate is reflected by an immediate change in the tracker's interest rate. In contrast, discounts are linked to the lender's SVR, and as some lenders can be tardy in cutting their SVR following a base rate fall, cost savings can be delayed. And unlike discounted mortgages, tracker loans rarely have early redemption penalties.

Hollingworth recommends a Halifax base rate tracker, which is set at 0.45 per cent below the base rate until the end of 2002, giving a current rate of 5.3 per cent. The loan has no redemption penalties and borrowers can apply for up to 75 per cent of their property's value for purchase or remortgage. Remortgagers get a free valuation and legal fees.

However, Ray Boulger of London mortgage broker Charcol says borrowers should consider discounted loans if their rates are sub stantially lower than those of trackers. Charcol, for example, has negotiated special terms with the Woolwich on its Open Plan flexible mortgage, providing a discount of 3 per cent in the first year and 1.8 per cent in the second. Borrowers can repay up to 25 per cent of the loan in each of the first two years, and interest is calculated daily.

Fixed-rate mortgages are ideal for people on a tight budget who cannot afford fluctuations in their monthly mortgage payments. People in this situation may be tempted to wait for the next base rate cut before applying for a loan, assuming that cheaper fixed rates will become available.

But this is not necessarily the case, says Boulger. He explains that fixed rates are arranged on the money markets, where prices are based on future base rates, not the present one. 'This means fixed-rate mortgages tend to bottom out before the base rate. If you wait until the base rate reaches bottom, you could find fixed rates are on the increase,' he says.

Most borrowers have been interested in short fixed terms of two or three years. Hollingworth likes a Yorkshire Building Society loan fixed at 4.99 per cent for two years for buyers only. Loans worth up to 75 per cent of the property's value are available for a fee of £295, with a 5 per cent redemption penalty in the first two years.

Bank of Ireland has loans fixed at 5.49 per cent for five years on loans of £100,000 or more (5.69 per cent on smaller loans), available for purchases or remortgages. Interest is calculated on a monthly basis. There is a £280 arrangement fee, and redemption penalties in the first five years. No mortgage indemnity insurance is required for loans worth up to 85 per cent of the property's value.

And for those who want to know they can afford their mortgage for the next decade, Boulger suggests a Newcastle building society mortgage fixed at 5.99 per cent for 10 years. Although the loan normally has redemption penalties of six months' interest during the fixed period, borrowers can repay part or all of the loan without penalty provided they inform the society of their intention in March of the year they want to do it, and follow through within three months.

The Newcastle loan has a completion fee equivalent to 0.35 per cent of the amount borrowed, which can be added to the loan, plus £100 if you don't buy one of the society's buildings, contents or payment protection insurance policies.

webTitle: Crisis at the Equitable: But will they wear the cap?

fields.headline: But will they wear the cap?
fields.standfirst: Calmer waters ahead if holders of guarantees accept the Halifax offer, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Calmer waters ahead if holders of guarantees accept the Halifax offer, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Prospects for members of the Equitable Life with-profits fund are looking better this week after the insurer agreed a deal with the Halifax bank. Although financial advisers are still saying that some members would be best off taking their money out, some think that returns from the fund should now improve.

The Halifax will be injecting £500 million into the fund on 1 March to pay for its purchase of Equitable Life assets, including the sales force and administration sys tems. A further £250m will be payable in 2004 if the sales force reaches certain targets.

Another £250m will be due if Equitable Life members vote to approve proposals to cap liabilities to one group of members: the 90,000 people with Guaranteed Annuity Rate (GAR) policies, whose open-ended contracts plunged the insurer into crisis last year.

'Advising on this is like advising on shifting sand,' says Amanda Davidson of independent financial adviser Holden Meehan. 'So much now depends on the GAR annuitants. Are they going to accept an end?'

Various groups of members will be entitled to vote. Those most likely to vote against - and therefore to scupper this part of the deal - would be the GAR holders if they felt the deal on offer was not good enough. Equitable is in consultation with interested parties to discuss the outline of the proposals.

There has been speculation that the Halifax offer might be contested by American financial services group GE Capital. However, Equitable says that the Halifax deal is now 'signed and sealed'. Equitable also suggests that GE Capital has been lurking in the wings for six months and has never made itself a serious bidder.

The point of offering a deal to the GAR holders is not merely to get the £250m from the Halifax but to end the uncertainty hanging over the with-profits fund. Under the terms of the GAR policies, those members become entitled on retirement to fixed-rate annuities of, in many cases, 12 per cent or more. With interest rates going down, it becomes more and more expensive for the Equitable to pay.

GAR holders can also increase the potential cost to Equitable by topping up their plans. This potential black hole in the fund could become catastrophic for personal pension plan and other members who would have to bail out the GAR liabilities before being able to receive investment returns from the fund themselves.

So the most crucial part of last week's developments was, arguably, not so much the Halifax's offer but the response of the GAR holders.

Stuart Bayliss, co-ordinator of the Equitable Life Action Group, is a prime mover in discussions and is communicating with 9,000 GAR holders. Is a deal likely?

'Quite likely,' he says. 'If you consider the position of GAR holders and non-GAR holders, they both need a compromise.' The deal he suggests would see a one-off payment of between 19 and 24 per cent to most GAR holders in return for a cap on their future claims. The cost would be about £1.5 billion - the sum Equitable saved last year by not paying a bonus for the seven months from January to July.

A major problem now seems to be tactics. Equitable Life has proved to be a very poor communicator with its own members and an unskilled negotiator. It is gearing up to hold the vote 'in the middle of this year'. But such a timetable could increase the anxiety on all sides and see more non-GAR holders leaving the fund and more GAR-holders triggering their policies if they are over 50.

'You need momentum,' says Bayliss, who believes a vote could take place in April. 'If you don't have momentum, the more extreme views gather some level of authority.'

For a deal to be accepted by members, it will need approval from 75 per cent of policyholders by value and 50 per cent by number. Trustees of company pension and AVC (additional voluntary contribution) schemes will be included in the ballot, but they can vote as they think best without consulting their members. If members give it the go-ahead, the scheme would need approval from the High Court.

If all of this happens, the outlook would certainly be far better. But that is because the potential black hole has disappeared. The ability of the fund to perform well is a subject of debate.

Raj Mody of actuary Bacon & Woodrow is a relative optimist: 'The long-term prospects look set to be back on comparable terms with any other with-profits funds - at least in the medium term.'

Edinburgh-based actuary Ronnie Sloan is worried whether a fund which has closed itself to new business, which the Equitable with-profits fund has done, can ever perform well: 'Closed funds don't work. When you reach the end you find that there is only you and me left.'

In theory, the last people in the fund could find that they have a handsome surplus to share - but Equitable is an insurer with a shortage of reserves. Anyone thinking this way would be taking a big gamble. A more likely scenario would be that the investment strategy becomes very conservative in the longer run to ensure that there is at least some money left to meet liabilities.

Halifax subsidiary Clerical Medical has agreed to take over the investment management of the fund and will charge low fees. The best outcome - from an investment performance point of view - would be if another insurer agreed to take on the fund and merge it with a fund of its own so that it could take in new members once more.

Donna Bradshaw of independent financial adviser Fiona Price & Partners is another who is sceptical about the fund even if the full deal goes ahead: 'The cash injections would still only be adding 3 to 4 per cent to the fund. It's still not going to be particularly strong. It's still a closed fund. And Equitable's with-profits performance is not particularly great anyway.'

She is advising GAR-holders to sit tight - but believes that for younger investors who have perhaps been in a personal pension plan for less than five years 'it may be best to leave'.

For people who are thinking of leaving, a crucial time is approaching. The Equitable has confirmed that it is likely to make its bonus declaration in early March. Rather than using the 9 per cent provisional bonus rate which it has used since bonuses were restored on 1 August, it will give a definite figure - which Sloan believes is likely to be less.

So people who have definitely decided to bail out may make Sloan's calculation and go now. It has been taking about two weeks for applications to transfer out of the fund to be processed.

 New rules on pensions due to come into force on 6 April could affect the decision that high earners make about whether to transfer funds away from Equitable Life. These rules will change the amount that can be transferred between a company pension (including an AVC scheme) and a personal pension, and in some cases could reduce the amount by 30 per cent. The rules will affect anyone who has been a controlling director in a company over the past 10 years or whose salary has breached the 'earnings cap', which restricts tax relief on pension contributions to salaries that are below £91,800.

People with larger pension funds who want to transfer into an income drawdown scheme, to avoid locking into low annuity rates, must do so by transferring first into a personal pension, but the new regulations could limit the amount of money that can be moved. Specialist adviser the Income Drawdown Advisory Bureau says Equitable investors thinking about a drawdown scheme may need to consider their position before 6 April.

webTitle: Here comes the bride's £14,000 bill

fields.headline: Here comes the bride's £14,000 bill
fields.standfirst: You could land yourself in debt for years to pay for that big day, says  Virginia Wallis
fields.trailText: You could land yourself in debt for years to pay for that big day, says Virginia Wallis.
fields.body:
At the risk of putting anyone off, if you were thinking of using Valentine's Day as an excuse to pop the question, don't you think you should consider the financial implications before you flex that knee joint?

If selling the photos to Hello! isn't an option, what's supposed to be the best day of your life could also turn out to be the most expensive. Since the beginning of this year, changes to the fees for civil ceremonies mean that even a no-frills registry office do - excluding drinks in the pub afterwards - will set you back a total of £97.50. That's made up of £30 each to give notice of marriage, which is now compulsory for both partners, £34 for the registrar to turn up on the day plus £3.50 for a copy of the marriage certificate. But couples who have set their hearts on a traditional wedding with all the trimmings could easily part with more than a hundred times that figure. In 2000, the average - and not particularly lavish - white wedding cost just over £11,500, according to research by insurer Weddingplan.

This looks at how much you would pay for the same wedding held on a Saturday in 12 different UK regions and covers wedding stationery, the bride's dress and going-away outfit, one bridesmaid's dress, suit hire for the bridegroom, best man and a page boy, wedding rings, church fees, including those for the vicar, reading the banns, the wedding certificate, organist, choir and bells, all the flowers, hire of a Rolls-Royce for three hours, professional photographs and a video, a three-course sit-down meal for 70 people, an evening buffet with disco for 160 guests, a hotel room for the bride and groom and the honeymoon. At nearly £13,000, a London wedding cost most and was around £2,500 more expensive than the same wedding held in East Anglia (see table).

But wherever you wed, a website devoted to all things wedding-related, confetti.co.uk, estimates that once you've added in the average £850 spent on the engagement ring, £1,000 for hen and stag parties and £100 each for presents for the bridesmaids, the total cost of plighting your troth is more like £14,000 - a figure confirmed by research by United Friendly, a provider of insurance-based savings plans. 'Getting married is not just a major personal pledge, it also represents an enormous financial commitment,' says Helen Matthews, its marketing director. 'Yet very few couples or parents make any provision for the huge bill they may face once the confetti has faded.'

But in one way, that shouldn't put you off proposing because the longer you leave it, the worse it will get. With the cost of getting married rising by just over 8 per cent each year - more than twice the rate of inflation - Weddingplan estimates that in seven years' time, the average cost of a wedding will be nearly £20,000. Of course, if the bride's father is a traditionalist and wouldn't dream of letting anyone else pay for his daughter's big day then the spiralling cost needn't be a worry. However, even if this is true, tradition demands that the groom pays for the rings, ceremony, some of the flowers, his own transport to the church, bridesmaids' presents and the honeymoon so you would still have to stump up around £4,000. But perhaps because couples are marrying later - according to the Office for National Statistics, in 1999 the average age of bridegrooms was 30 and the average bride was 28 - a growing number are breaking with tradition by paying their own wedding costs. This could also be part of the reason more is being spent. So how do they do it?

Julie Moulsdale, head of communications at Direct Line Financial Services, doesn't think it is fair to expect her father to pay for her wedding. Although Julie and her fiancée, Johnny, have been engaged since last summer, they do not plan to marry until June 2002. The couple did not start making serious wedding plans until Johnny's flat was sold.

'It didn't seem sensible to commit to a wedding while we were still paying two mortgages,' Julie says. She hopes the savings on mortgage outgoings and other economies, such as 'not going overboard on the wedding dress', will finance the bulk of the final bill.

To amass enough cash for the average wedding, you would need to save £500 a month for the next two years. If you can't wait that long, the alternative is to borrow. A reasonably cheap way of financing a lump sum is to increase your mortgage. Even using the standard variable rate of 7.74 per cent charged by most high street lenders, borrowing an extra £14,000 would add £90 to your monthly mortgage payments.

However, this is expensive in terms of the total interest charged. For example, assuming an interest-only mortgage, over 20 years, the total interest on the additional borrowing could amount to £21,000 - one and a half times the cost of the wedding.

If you would rather not have a wedding debt hanging over you until you finally pay off your mortgage, a popular option is a personal loan. The interest on a £14,000 loan with an annual percentage rate of 10 per cent could add as much as £3,500 to the price of your big day. But by paying £300 a month, the debt would be cleared after five years.

Where does all the money go?

Music/choir/bell ringers £200
Wedding cars £250
Flowers £300

Wedding cake £175
Entertainment £250
Decorations £300
Food and drink £3,000
Wedding dress and veil £900
Bride's shoes and accessories £150
Going-away outfit £200
Hair and make-up£250
Bridesmaids' dresses £600
Page boy outfits £50
Groom's suit hire £50
Best man's suit hire £50
Ushers' suit hire £100
Wedding rings £550
Engagement ring £500
Hen and stag parties £500
Thank-you cards £150
Cake boxes £45
Gifts for attendants /mothers £400
Wedding dress cleaning £80
Honeymoon £2,100
Total £14,000

Greenwich or Gretna?

Wedding costs around the country

East Anglia £10,375
East Midlands £12,135
London £12,890

Northern Ireland £10,670
North West £12,070
Scotland £10,765

South West £11,320
Wales £11,671
West Midlands £11,670

Source: Weddingplan

webTitle: On the market

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Jupiter Global Green Investment Trust
fields.trailText: Jupiter Global Green Investment Trust.
fields.body:
Contact Application forms are available from Jupiter marketing department on 020 7314 4824. The public offer closes on 12 March, or 7 March for Isas and savings.

Aim To produce long-term growth in an investment trust composed of companies that conduct their business with environmental sustainability in mind.

Bells & Whistles 20 per cent of the fund can be invested in unquoted companies, which means it can take advantage of the performance potential of up-and-coming companies.

How it works Fund manager Simon Baker calls the trust a 'pale green ethical fund': it takes a best-of-sector approach, looking for companies that try to solve environmental problems or are making a positive commitment to social well-being. Only companies involved in armaments, tobacco and nuclear power generation are automatically excluded.

Minimum £1,000 lump sum or £30 a month through the regular savings scheme. It can also be accessed via an Isa with an initial investment of £125.

Charges 1 per cent initial, waived during the launch period; 0.75 per cent annual management charge, plus a performance-related fee of 15 per cent of the amount by which it outgrows the stock market.

Tax Liable to capital gains tax unless bought through an Isa.

Risk Medium/high.

Should you invest? Ben Yearsley of adviser Hargreaves Lansdown says Jupiter has a long track-record in green investment and an 'impressive' team. But, as investment trusts are riskier than unit trusts, he says this would best suit 'sophisticated' investors. Anna Bowes of Chase de Vere says: 'The ecology fund has been volatile but has generally outperformed its sector. This is not a guarantee that this trust will do the same, but the management is sound.'

Marks out of 10 Yearsley - 8; Bowes - 6

webTitle: Wealthcheck: A spanner in the works

fields.headline: A spanner in the works
fields.standfirst: The end of car-making at Luton has thrown engineer John Morgan's plans into disarray, he tells  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: The end of car-making at Luton has thrown engineer John Morgan's plans into disarray, he tells Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
John and Sheelagh Morgan
Age 54 and 52
Live in Flitwick, Bedfordshire
Occupations Engineer, civil servant
Earn £32,000, £8,000
Mortgage £70,000
Debts None
Investments Unit trusts, Pep, Isa
Pensions Both have company pensions
Aims To survive redundancy

John Morgan thought he had his life planned out. He intended working for two or three more years and then taking a comfortable early retirement before he reached 60. But just before Christmas he was forced to change his plans.

He works for Vauxhall Motors in Luton where, in the middle of December, the company announced it would stop making cars at the Luton plant in 15 months' time. John was to lose his job after more than 39 years there. He started as an office boy, took his engineering apprenticeship and has been in manufacturing engineering since 1975.

He will be employed until the plant closes in March 2002 and has been offered a separation package: 'The financial offer for early retirement is £41,000, of which £30,000 is tax free. My Vauxhall pension would be £1,641 a month before tax at December 2000, or £1,135 a month if I take a maximum lump sum of £54,000.'

John will have to look for another job before stopping work completely. He has been scanning the local papers for something different but interesting, perhaps in a garden centre: He reckons he will need to earn about £12,000 a year: His ideal job would be working with preserved steam railways, but they only want volunteers.

Sheelagh has 28 years' contributions to the Civil Service pension and together they have various investments with Windsor Life: an endowment for £37,000, a Pep, an Isa, an investment plan worth £6,000 and another worth £11,200: 'The last payment is due on 10 May 2006, my sixtieth birthday.' Their cash savings comprise £1,000 in a Woolwich high-interest account.

Whatever work John finds, they want to continue travelling. 'We like our holidays. If we manage three a year, we are happy.'

Adviser 1: Danielle Leich

When facing redundancy, it is important not to touch the lump sum until you have fully thought through your financial future. We advise people in this situation to keep their money in cash deposits for at least a year while they adjust to their changed circumstances. People often underestimate how much they will need for leisure activities when they first retire.

As John is planning to work part-time, he could defer drawing the pension and live off his new lower earnings until he retires properly. If he takes it now, he must decide whether to take a cash lump sum or the full pension. The difference is about £500 a month so, unless he really needs the capital, or thinks he can earn more than 9 per cent on it, he should take the higher pension.

John and Sheelagh should work out a realistic budget that they can stick to. Then they will know whether they can afford to spend money on fulfilling dreams or need to invest to boost retirement income.

They should not surrender the endowment so close to maturity to redeem the mortgage; instead they could use the lump sums they have. When the endowment matures in 2003, the proceeds can replenish the lump sums.

They should check whether the underlying funds in their investments are still appropriate or whether they need more income but should keep more savings in cash.

They have too many eggs in one basket and should diversify their portfolio to include other companies and funds.

Danielle Leich works for accountant PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

Adviser 2: Anna Bowes

John should keep some of the cash payment for emergencies until he knows that he will be earning enough to live comfortably. Any capital he will not need over the next five or so years can be invested for growth now and switched in retirement to help supplement his income.

For a UK fund, I recommend the Chase Fleming Premier Equity Growth for a modest risk, or the ABN AMRO UK Growth fund for higher risk. When he receives his separation lump sum, he should use his Isa allowances in both good growth and income funds.

We recommend the Fidelity International and Extra Income funds. He can improve on the Woolwich rates by investing up to £3,000 in a cash Isa. The best rates available are via the Internet, with www.smile.co.uk paying 7.25 per cent. Outside the internet, Cheltenham & Gloucester pays 6.75 per cent. He should continue the Windsor Life maximum income plan if he can afford to, as charges are deducted at the beginning.

The select investment policy is also a regular-savings qualifying policy. If it has now matured, he can withdraw it without penalty or tax liability, or he can draw an income without paying higher-rate tax. But he may do better waiting until he has a clearer picture of the near future.

He should review his investment funds to ensure they are performing well. If they are not, he should transfer to a better performing investment, making use of his tax- free allowances.

Anna Bowes works for Bath-based Chase de Vere.

Advice is for guidance only.

Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Rate cuts rescue high-yield bonds

fields.headline: Rate cuts rescue high-yield bonds
fields.trailText: In Britain and the US, high yield corporate bonds - loans by companies - have soared in value.
fields.body:
It is not just stock markets that have taken heart from the interest rate cuts. In Britain and the US, high yield corporate bonds - loans by companies - have also soared in value.

Threadneedle's High Yield Bond fund, for example, is up by 13 per cent since the new year. Yet this firm, like many other fund managers, still believes the sector could rise further.

A further rise would not be before time. These funds were all the rage two years ago, with a spate of heavily promoted launches. Predictably, that was the signal for the sector to turn sour, and they have mostly performed poorly ever since.

With hindsight, it is easy to see why. Corporate bonds are traded in a similar way to shares. Their price is determined by interest rates and the market's assessment of the chances that a company will be able to meet its interest and capital repayments.

Until last week, rates had been rising, and investors were gradually realising that some of the companies issuing the bonds - particularly in the telecoms sector - had very large debts.

They worried about the risk of defaults and scurried for the safer investment- grade bonds, issued by blue chip companies. High-yield corporate bonds fell by 13 per cent last year.

Now, however, interest rates are falling and, while there is still concern over the creditworthiness of some, there is a feeling that higher- rate corporate bonds could have fallen too far, too fast.

Certainly, yields - the traditional way in which they are measured - look attractive. The prices of some bonds have fallen so far that they are offering rates as high as 15 per cent, a huge premium over investment- grade bonds. Despite the spectacular performance so far this year, Threadneedle's High Yield Bond fund is still offering more than 10 per cent. Try getting that from your local building society.

This does not mean bonds are an alternative to the building society. While they are safer than shares - firms will pay their interest bills even if they have to cut their dividend - they are not guaranteed. The price of corpo rate bonds will fluctuate sharply, depending on investors' views of economic and corporate prospects. The higher the yield, the greater the risk.

Funds which invest only in top-rated corporate bonds from blue chips will offer around 5 per cent, half that on many high-yield bond funds.

Many commentators think the spread between investment-grade and high- yield bonds is now too great. Gary Marshall of Aberdeen Asset Management believes that, unless we end up with a 'hard landing', high-yield bonds offer good value.

Those with the appetite for some risk should consider a high-yield fund. Even if the price does not rise, the income is healthy. Sheltering it in an Isa makes it doubly attractive, as bond interest still carries a 20 per cent tax rebate, compared with 10 per cent for shares.

Funds worth considering include Threadneedle, Aberdeen's High Yield Bond, M&G's European High Yield Bond and Gartmore's Global Bond.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Tax wheezes please banks and better-off

fields.headline: Tax wheezes please banks and better-off
fields.trailText: Tax is at the centre of debate in the run-up to the general election, and again the stress is on tax-saving wheezes.
fields.body:
Tax is at the centre of debate in the run-up to the general election, and again the stress is on tax-saving wheezes.

Such schemes are ever more popular with politicians hard-pressed to find ways to actually cut income tax. It is clear from Neasa MacErlean's examination of the Tories' plan to axe basic- rate tax on savings, on page 8, that this reform would be of little help to the millions of people struggling to save after paying a mortgage and supporting children.

To drive home the reality, bear in mind that the average amount saved in a UK household is a mere £750 - this includes pension money, which would be unaffected. Even assuming £750 in a sav ings account, the most you might earn in interest is £45 a year. The tax on that is £9. Anyone serious about saving can already shelter much more than this in an Individual Savings Account; under the previous Tory government there were Tessas.

There is merit, however, in the Tories' idea of restoring the right of non-taxpaying pensioners to reclaim tax now deducted at source on dividends.

Overall, though, the plan seems to be aimed at the well-heeled and, perhaps, at banks, which would doubtless use it as an excuse to shave interest rates even further.

The Government is said to be considering a wide-rang ing inquiry into the insurance industry if it is re-elected. But inquiries are only as good as the action they produce.

Customers have seen relatively little change from the government-ordered banking inquiry that reported last year. For Barclays, now reporting a 42 per cent profit rise, it has been business as usual.

webTitle: Internet banking: A more flexible friend

fields.headline: A more flexible friend by all accounts
fields.standfirst: Marianne Curphey ends her internet series with Smile, IF, Virgin One and Open Plan
fields.trailText: Marianne Curphey ends her internet series with Smile, IF, Virgin One and Open Plan.
fields.body:
Remember the old days, when all banks used to close at 3.30pm? Over the past 15 years the high street banks have responded gradually to change, extending opening hours to 5pm, then opening on Saturday mornings, then introducing telephone banking and now setting up internet banking operations.

Some of these changes (such as longer opening hours) were introduced to steal a march on competitors. Others, such as telephone banking, allowed the banks to save money by running fewer branches.

Though internet banking is another way for the banks to save money, it is also a powerful tool for customers. With an internet bank you have access to your current account and savings details at any time of the day or night. No more waiting in queues for a cashier to come free; no problem checking your balance on a Sunday afternoon.

Over the past fortnight I've explained different types of internet accounts, how high street banks are trying to muscle in on web banking and how to decide which account is best for you.

Smile

Although Smile is a new internet offering, it makes a virtue of its relationship with the Co-operative Bank.

 It can be operated via the internet or through branches. You must pay in your salary, pension or £1,000 a month into the current account.

 You can withdraw up to £250 of cash a day from your current or savings account at Link machines without paying a fee using your Visa debit card.

 The current account pays 4.85 per cent gross AER (compounded interest rate) on interest on credit balances and has an interest-free overdraft facility up to £500. It offers the option of a Visa debit card and cheque book.

 There are favourable rates on the Smile savings account and credit cards for those with a current account.

 The savings account pays a better rate of interest if you already have a current account.

 The basic rate is 5 per cent gross AER, but you could earn an extra 1 per cent gross on your savings by opening both a current account and a savings account.

 You need £1 to open the savings account and you have access to £250 a day of your cash by using a card in Link machines.

Intelligent Finance (IF)

The internet offering from the Halifax works on the principle of the flexible current account. You get a debit card and a cheque book.

 All your accounts are kept separately, but IF calculates the interest that you owe or have earned as though they were part of a single account.  Your current account and savings credit balances are used to offset any personal loans or mortgage debt.

 You can withdraw cash without a fee from any Link machine. Halifax will not surcharge non-customers for using any of its cash machines.

 IF is an internet bank with a range of banking products that are all separate. Halifax aims to run the account so that you receive the maximum interest on your savings and pay the minimum interest on your borrowings.

 IF offers a flexible mortgage below the rate charged by most high street banks. The variable rate is 6.8 per cent (6.97 per cent APR), discounted to 5.3 per cent for the first 6 months. There is no arrangement fee or redemption penalty.

 The current account pays a rate of interest comparable with some of the better internet rates such as Smile, First-e and Cahoot. You get a rate of 5.0 per cent AER gross interest on credit balances.

 There is also a credit card and a personal loan. Each account is separate but if you take out more than one, you can then offset your savings against your borrowings or credit card debt. The card doesn't have an annual fee.

 If, for example, you have £20,000 in savings, £5,000 in your current account, but an outstanding mortgage debt of £25,000 you won't be charged any interest on your home loan.

Virgin One

Virgin One works by running your mortgage and current account as one account. You can use it to pay off existing loans and credit card debts.

 You must operate the account as a current account and pay in your salary, and you need to borrow at least £50,000.

 The interest rate you pay on your mortgage depends on its size. If you borrow up to 50 per cent of the value of your home the rate is 7.1 per cent.The rate rises up to 7.7 per cent is you borrow up to 95 per cent of the value of your home.

 Credit balances attract a rate of 4.0 per cent (4.07 per cent AER).

 You can use the telephone or the internet to organise transfers and transactions and there is no penalty for use of either.

 There's a cheque book and debit card to accompany the account.

 The information about your balance will be updated during the day to reflect transactions such as ATM usage and bill payments.

 There is a facility to see all Switch payments between dates that you specify. On the website you can also view any other Virgin Direct products you hold, including savings, Isas, Peps, pensions and unit trusts.

Virgin Direct reckons that the average UK homeowner could be paying £30,000 too much for their mortgage over the lifetime of the loan.

Open Plan

Open Plan is a combined mortgage/current account from the Woolwich, which you can access by internet, Wap mobile phone, or digital television.

 Open Plan Offset allows you to use your savings to reduce the cost of your mortgage.

 You pay interest on the difference between the amount you have borrowed and the amount you have in your Open Plan current account and savings pots.

 Interest is calculated daily and you can check your balances, make transfers and pay bills. You receive a monthly statement and you can pay gas, electric or other bills online.

 You get interest on credit balances, although this is currently about a third of the best rate from Smile or First-e.

 The interest rate for credit balances is 2 per cent gross per annum AER.

 You get a debit card, cheque book, free overdraft to £100, and you can set up direct debits and standing orders. There is an optional credit card and you can choose how to manage your money - through the branch network, at cash machines, by phone, over the internet, mobile phone and soon on interactive television.

 The interest rate for the mortgage is 6.75 per cent per annum variable (7.0% APR).

Summary

 If you are looking for an all-round package that combines mortgage and current account, then IF.com, VirginOne, and Open Plan offer a comprehensive service.

 If you want a current account that pays you a decent rate of interest and rewards you for having a savings account too, one of the best on the market is the account from Smile.

 If you regularly use your credit card and want to combine a current account and credit card facility, then consider Cahoot.

 If you want an account that offers a good all-round package and doesn't penalise you for using the telephone occasionally, you could look at Smile, IF or Open Plan.
