webTitle: Tax tips

fields.headline: Tax tips
fields.standfirst: 50 ways to cut your bill, plus a few more
fields.trailText: 50 ways to cut your bill, plus a few more.
fields.body:
Most people should probably be able to find two or three things from this list to make their tax affairs more efficient. At the least, it should encourage you to think about the way you and your family plan your finances in the longer run. Some people will find several of the tips appropriate to them. But there has to be a financial health warning: reducing your tax bill should usually be a secondary consideration. Many people have been mis-sold investments because they allowed themselves to be dazzled by the 'tax-free' label. The less money you have, the fewer risks you should take with it. Most of the tips are in five categories:

 Tax-efficient investments

 Organising your affairs to fit your family arrangements

 Getting your full personal allowance and other entitlements

 Avoiding getting into tax trouble

 Saving money by getting your employer to provide items you would otherwise have to pay for

If you do not know much about tax

1 Make sure you get your personal allowance of £4,485. You should not be paying tax on income below this level. Fill in Inland Revenue form R85 if you have income below this amount and are having tax deducted by the bank. Ask your bank, building society or the Inland Revenue for a copy of the form.

2 Avoid paying tax on summer work or part-time jobs if you are a student and earn less in a year than your personal allowance. If you cannot give an employer the right bits of paperwork when you start, they will usually deduct tax from your pay. Unless you are very organised, you might not get round to claiming back the tax. If you cannot give the boss a P45 from a previous employer (saying how much you have earned in the year, allowing the new firm to see how much of your personal allowance you have left), you should fill in form P38(S), a declaration that you expect to earn less than the personal allowance in the year.

3 Don't get into trouble. If you are sent a tax return, you must fill it in and send it back. You can face automatic penalties of £100 if you miss the deadline for completing the form. Tax inquiry centres are usually staffed by surprisingly pleasant and helpful people who will often sit down with you and explain your situation.

4 Don't arouse the suspicions of the Inland Revenue. If you put down strange, unexplained figures on a tax return - income this year of £5,000 after earning £50,000 last year - you are effectively begging them to investigate your affairs. This is a deeply unhappy process and could cost you £1,000 for the professional help you will probably feel driven to seek. There is plenty of room on a tax return to write short explanatory notes such as, 'My income went down because I decided to travel the world for 10 months'.

5 Start thinking about the benefits of tax-efficient schemes such as pensions, especially if you are starting your career. The tax breaks on pensions mean that you only have to put in £78 yourself to get a gross contribution of £100 if you are a basic rate taxpayer and your relief of £22 is added. Added to this, you will receive a contribution from your employer if you are in a company scheme. This could bring that £100 up to £150. Since the sum will be left to grow for decades, you should find it has become a substantial fund by the time you retire. (See the points on pensions below.)

If you want to save

6 Consider an Individual Savings Account (Isa) if you are aged 18 or over. The maximum contribution is £7,000 in a tax year. There is no tax on dividends or capital growth. Isas are better for higher rate taxpayers (because it saves them a higher rate of tax), but there is still a benefit for people whose income is too low to pay tax, as the Lloyds TSB 'Tax Guide 2000/2001' explains: 'Isa managers can claim back the 10 per cent tax credit that comes with dividends and distributions paid until 5 April 2004 and add them to your account.'

7 Think about putting £25 a month into a tax-exempt Friendly society savings plan, but choose a good one: some have offered poor returns. Look at the tax-free offerings from National Savings, but remember that the returns on many of these products, particularly Savings Certificates at the moment, are poor value.

8 Switch the capital from your Tessa (tax-exempt special savings account) into a Tessa-only Isa within six months of its maturing and you can go on letting it build up tax-free interest.

If you want to gamble

9 Remember that prizes from premium bonds, the National Lottery and Gambling are tax-free, unless you are a professional gambler.

If you have children

10 Claim children's tax credit, which starts on 6 April. It is worth up to £442 a year for families with at least one child under 16 living with them at the start of the tax year. But you need to fill in a form to get it. Ring the Children's Tax Credit Helpline on 0845 300 1036.

11 Understand that your children each have their own personal tax-free allowance for income each year (£4,385 in 2000/01). But to prevent too much tax avoidance, the Revenue lets them earn only £100 a year tax-free within this allowance if the money has been given to them by their parents. It is better for grandparents to give them cash if the income could be higher than this.

12 Claim the working families' tax credit if you or your partner work more than 16 hours a week and you have one or more dependant children under 19 at home. This benefit is mainly targeted at households earning less than £20,000 a year - but some people with more can also get it, depending on their circumstances. Ring 0845 609 5000 for more information. Some families can be more than £100-a-week better off.

13 Consider asking your childminder to become a registered childminder if you qualify for the WFTC (see above). Many parents lose out if a friend or a grandparent minds their children. By using a registered minder you can be £70 better off a week with one child, or £105 better off with two or more. Telephone the National Childminding Association for more information on 0800 169 4486.

14 Think of starting a stakeholder pension in your child's name when they start in April. There is no minimum age or earnings requirement. The maximum payment a year is £3,600 gross. (See the points on pensions below.)

15 Look into the possibility of buying a house if your child needs somewhere to live at university. If you can trust them, you could buy the house in their name so that rent received from other tenants goes towards their personal allowance each year and you do not 'suffer' a cap ital gain to incur tax when you sell. They can also take advantage of the 'Rent a Room scheme' (see 'If you have rental property').

16 Set up your nanny as a 'one-person personal service company' rather than an employee. You can save £2,500 this way on a net annual income for your nanny of £11,700. (See page 6 of Cash section on 14 January 2001.) You can now be fined up to £5,000 if you pay cash in hand.

If you are married

17 Use your ability to transfer assets between spouses tax-free. There are many examples of husbands paying higher-rate tax, while the wife's personal allowance is unused. This is not efficient. If some investments were put in her name, the tax bill for the household would be reduced. Transfers of assets can be made between spouses without attracting capital gains tax.

18 Do some inheritance tax planning. (For more information, see below.) One of the great tax advantages of marriage comes only when you die! There is no inheritance tax on assets left to a spouse. Paul Falvey of Grant Thornton advises wealthy couples to leave only up to the individual IHT tax-free threshold (currently £234,000) to their children and then to leave the surplus to the spouse. 'You use up both spouses' exemptions in this way,' he says.

If you want to build up a pension

19 Understand that Pension contributions are attractive because you get tax relief as you pay in the money. A higher-rate taxpayer pays only £60 to get £100 because another £40 is added by the Government. If you can afford it and think you will be able to build up a worthwhile fund, you should seriously consider having a pension. If you have access to a company scheme, you are likely to get contributions from your employer - a valuable benefit.

20 Remember that you are far better off paying pension contributions as a higher rate taxpayer than as a basic rate taxpayer. This is because you get a top-up worth 40 per cent of your gross contribution rather than 22 per cent. So try to maximise your contributions in these circumstances. Consider making additional voluntary contributions if you are in a company scheme.

21 Take advantage of the 'carry forward' rules if you have a lot of spare cash this year, pay into a personal pension and have not made maximum pension contributions in the last six years. This facility ends on 6 April.

22 Think about starting a stakeholder pension - or opening one for your spouse, partner, child (see above) or anyone else if you are already up to the limit on pension payments. Contributions are paid net - up to a maximum net contribution of £2,808, taking you to £3,600 a year gross.

23 See that your pension scheme trustees have names and up-to-date addresses for you and your heirs. Do not forget about sums you built up in jobs you had 15 years ago. If they have your address, these schemes should contact you when you reach retirement age. You do not want all those old pension payments and tax contributions to go to waste if you are run over by a bus.

If you are an employee

24 Check your tax code. All employees receive a copy of this each year from their tax office, and it is often wrong. 'Your employer has a legal obligation to operate this, which gives you so much tax-free income a month,' says Maria Bradley of accountant Smith & Williamson.

25 Expect trouble if you have two part-time jobs. The pay as you earn scheme was designed for people with one job and often works clumsily for those with more. You could be paying too much tax, or too little. 'Take your payslips into a tax office and ask them to check if you are concerned,' says a spokesman for charity TaxAid. If you think you could be underpaying, check with an accountant or - if you can't afford one - with TaxAid (0207 624 3768).

26 Go green. Recent Budgets have introduced environmentally friendly measures, including higher taxes for those with company cars. Instead, employees can buy or lease cars themselves and accept allowances for wear and tear and running costs when using them for business travel.

27 If you have no green sympathies, remember the tax discounts you can get if you increase your company car mileage. 'If it is approaching 2,500 or 18,000 miles [a year], try to use the car for work enough to qualify for the lower tax charge,' says the Lloyds TSB 'Tax Guide 2000/2001'.

28 But if you are really green and fit, you can get the tax benefits of business bicycling. Employees can claim capital allowances, and so much per mile if they use their own bicycle for travel between home and work and, energy levels permitting, between one workplace and another. The provision of a cycle and helmet by an employer can be tax free. Ask first - bikes can be expensive these days.

29 Try saving tax and Getting fit at the same time. 'Under certain circumstances there is no taxable benefit on the provision of sporting or recreational facilities provided by an employer,' says Andrew Tailby-Faulkes of Smith & Williamson. 'A lifelong subscription to Champneys [health club] is excluded as the employer must provide the physical facilities per se .'

30 Remember that if you are a bean counter and pay your subscription to the Institute of Chartered Accountants yourself, you can set that cost against tax. The Inland Revenue has a long list of bodies where subscriptions can be treated like this. It will not save you a fortune but with many chartered accountants' subscriptions costing £161 a year, you could save £65 if you are a higher-rate taxpayer. (You cannot claim if your employer pays for you.)

31 'Donations to charity administered by an employer or freely by an employee are usually tax advantageous,' says Maria Bradley. The charity also gets a top-up equal to the basic rate of tax, and higher-rate taxpayers can claim back the 18 per cent difference between basic and higher rate tax.

32 'move house!' advises Andrew Tailby-Faulkes. 'Up to £8,000 of removal expenses paid to you by your employer will be free of tax.'

33 Remember that the provision of computers is tax-free up to prescribed limits, which are currently £2,000 for any type, including laptops.

34 Ask your employer to provide you with another tax-free benefit - a company mobile phone. Then you can also save money by getting rid of your own.

35 Think about lunch. After all that cycling, the provision of Luncheon Vouchers by your boss has a 15p per day tax exemption.

36 Persuade your employer to set up an Inland Revenue approved share option scheme. Some employees have ended up with lump sums of £20,000 this way.

37 Ask your employer for an interest-free season ticket loan. If the sum you borrow is less than £5,000, you will not be taxed for receiving a 'benefit in kind'. So if you borrowed £2,000 interest-free (and used it for any purpose, not just getting to work), you could easily save yourself £200 in interest that you would have paid on an overdraft, your credit card or loan arrangement.

If you are being made redundant

38 Remember that the first £30,000 of a redundancy payment is usually tax-free. Make sure that your employer structures your payment in the right way so that you receive this tax advantage (you will not usually get a tax-free payment in return for not working out your notice).

39 Think of having any excess over the £30,000 barrier paid into your pension fund if you can afford to do without that extra cash. If your employer pays the money direct, it is not taxable; if you pay, it is but you then get the tax relief on the contribution.

If you are self-employed

40 Claim expenses which are far more generous than if you were an employee. For example, self-employed people who are working from home can claim a share of the gas, electricity and other utility bills. There are no set rules, says tax adviser Sylvia Kalisch of European Media Ventures: 'But there should not be a problem so long as you can demonstrate that it is fair. If a quarter of your flat doubles up as your office, you might claim a quarter of the daytime part of your bills.'

41 If you want a computer take advantage of the currently highly favourable tax rules: you can set the whole cost against tax this year and during the next two tax years, an exemption introduced to encourage this country to become computer-literate. This exemption also applies to software and internet-enabled mobile phones.

42 Keep receipts for your travel expenses. Unlike employees, self-employed people are far more likely to be able to claim travel costs - especially if they work from home.

If you can let part of your home or another property

43 Take advantage of the Government rent a room scheme to take in a lodger and earn up to £4,250 this year tax-free.

44 Think of buying another property and taking advantage of the growing trend to buy to let. 'It can be a very good investment,' says Garry Spencer of Wilbury Financial Management in Worthing, West Sussex. You can set your mortgage payments on the property, maintenance and other expenses against tax. 'You only pay tax on the profits,' says Spencer.

45 Put your properties in your spouse's name if you are letting out more than one property and your partner pays tax at a lower tax rate than you do. But you need to be able to trust them.

46 Make sure you do not have a huge mortgage on the house you live in and a tiny one on a property that you let out. That way round, your profits on letting will be very high and so will the tax you have to pay on it. Switched the other way, your taxable profits are low.

If you are wealthy and can afford to take risks

47 Consider venture capital trusts if you want tax-free dividends and capital gains as well as 20 per cent income tax relief on your investment (up to a maximum of £100,000 in a tax year). You need to have enough money to risk the possibility of losing it if this investment goes wrong - but, according to VCT expert Mavis Seymour of BDO Stoy Hayward, these trusts have been far more reliable than they were expected to be when launched five years ago. Some have paid out very attractive returns - and the minimum investment is usually set by fund managers at £1,000. About 20 are now on the market, and they are expected to raise well over £200m between them before the tax year ends on 5 April.

48 Think about investing in enterprise investment schemes if you really have money to spare and a head for risk. EISs are far riskier than VCTs, which are regulated by the Stock Exchange. Some of the same rules apply, but you can invest £150,000 a year in EISs.

49 Start reading about the various reliefs available on capital gains tax if you think you could be liable to it in one particular year. But there are numerous ways of reducing or postponing CGT - setting gains against losses, for instance, and staggering your gains to take advantage of your CGT allowance each year. It is currently £7,200.

If you are worried about inheritance tax

50 Recognise that the IHT threshhold could catch out many families who do not regard themselves as wealthy. If your home is in your name only and its value is more than £234,000, then your estate is in line for IHT when you die. This is particularly bad news for unmarried couples living together if the property is in one name: it has often happened that the survivor has had to move out to sell the place so they can pay the tax when the original owner has died. fields.bodyText: Most people should probably be able to find two or three things from this list to make their tax affairs more efficient. At the least, it should encourage you to think about the way you and your family plan your finances in the longer run. Some people will find several of the tips appropriate to them. But there has to be a financial health warning: reducing your tax bill should usually be a secondary consideration. Many people have been mis-sold investments because they allowed themselves to be dazzled by the 'tax-free' label. The less money you have, the fewer risks you should take with it. Most of the tips are in five categories:  Tax-efficient investments  Organising your affairs to fit your family arrangements  Getting your full personal allowance and other entitlements  Avoiding getting into tax trouble  Saving money by getting your employer to provide items you would otherwise have to pay for If you do not know much about tax 1 Make sure you get your personal allowance of £4,485. You should not be paying tax on income below this level. Fill in Inland Revenue form R85 if you have income below this amount and are having tax deducted by the bank. Ask your bank, building society or the Inland Revenue for a copy of the form. 2 Avoid paying tax on summer work or part-time jobs if you are a student and earn less in a year than your personal allowance. If you cannot give an employer the right bits of paperwork when you start, they will usually deduct tax from your pay. Unless you are very organised, you might not get round to claiming back the tax. If you cannot give the boss a P45 from a previous employer (saying how much you have earned in the year, allowing the new firm to see how much of your personal allowance you have left), you should fill in form P38(S), a declaration that you expect to earn less than the personal allowance in the year. 3 Don't get into trouble. If you are sent a tax return, you must fill it in and send it back. You can face automatic penalties of £100 if you miss the deadline for completing the form. Tax inquiry centres are usually staffed by surprisingly pleasant and helpful people who will often sit down with you and explain your situation. 4 Don't arouse the suspicions of the Inland Revenue. If you put down strange, unexplained figures on a tax return - income this year of £5,000 after earning £50,000 last year - you are effectively begging them to investigate your affairs. This is a deeply unhappy process and could cost you £1,000 for the professional help you will probably feel driven to seek. There is plenty of room on a tax return to write short explanatory notes such as, 'My income went down because I decided to travel the world for 10 months'. 5 Start thinking about the benefits of tax-efficient schemes such as pensions, especially if you are starting your career. The tax breaks on pensions mean that you only have to put in £78 yourself to get a gross contribution of £100 if you are a basic rate taxpayer and your relief of £22 is added. Added to this, you will receive a contribution from your employer if you are in a company scheme. This could bring that £100 up to £150. Since the sum will be left to grow for decades, you should find it has become a substantial fund by the time you retire. (See the points on pensions below.) If you want to save 6 Consider an Individual Savings Account (Isa) if you are aged 18 or over. The maximum contribution is £7,000 in a tax year. There is no tax on dividends or capital growth. Isas are better for higher rate taxpayers (because it saves them a higher rate of tax), but there is still a benefit for people whose income is too low to pay tax, as the Lloyds TSB 'Tax Guide 2000/2001' explains: 'Isa managers can claim back the 10 per cent tax credit that comes with dividends and distributions paid until 5 April 2004 and add them to your account.' 7 Think about putting £25 a month into a tax-exempt Friendly society savings plan, but choose a good one: some have offered poor returns. Look at the tax-free offerings from National Savings, but remember that the returns on many of these products, particularly Savings Certificates at the moment, are poor value. 8 Switch the capital from your Tessa (tax-exempt special savings account) into a Tessa-only Isa within six months of its maturing and you can go on letting it build up tax-free interest. If you want to gamble 9 Remember that prizes from premium bonds, the National Lottery and Gambling are tax-free, unless you are a professional gambler. If you have children 10 Claim children's tax credit, which starts on 6 April. It is worth up to £442 a year for families with at least one child under 16 living with them at the start of the tax year. But you need to fill in a form to get it. Ring the Children's Tax Credit Helpline on 0845 300 1036. 11 Understand that your children each have their own personal tax-free allowance for income each year (£4,385 in 2000/01). But to prevent too much tax avoidance, the Revenue lets them earn only £100 a year tax-free within this allowance if the money has been given to them by their parents. It is better for grandparents to give them cash if the income could be higher than this. 12 Claim the working families' tax credit if you or your partner work more than 16 hours a week and you have one or more dependant children under 19 at home. This benefit is mainly targeted at households earning less than £20,000 a year - but some people with more can also get it, depending on their circumstances. Ring 0845 609 5000 for more information. Some families can be more than £100-a-week better off. 13 Consider asking your childminder to become a registered childminder if you qualify for the WFTC (see above). Many parents lose out if a friend or a grandparent minds their children. By using a registered minder you can be £70 better off a week with one child, or £105 better off with two or more. Telephone the National Childminding Association for more information on 0800 169 4486. 14 Think of starting a stakeholder pension in your child's name when they start in April. There is no minimum age or earnings requirement. The maximum payment a year is £3,600 gross. (See the points on pensions below.) 15 Look into the possibility of buying a house if your child needs somewhere to live at university. If you can trust them, you could buy the house in their name so that rent received from other tenants goes towards their personal allowance each year and you do not 'suffer' a cap ital gain to incur tax when you sell. They can also take advantage of the 'Rent a Room scheme' (see 'If you have rental property'). 16 Set up your nanny as a 'one-person personal service company' rather than an employee. You can save £2,500 this way on a net annual income for your nanny of £11,700. (See page 6 of Cash section on 14 January 2001.) You can now be fined up to £5,000 if you pay cash in hand. If you are married 17 Use your ability to transfer assets between spouses tax-free. There are many examples of husbands paying higher-rate tax, while the wife's personal allowance is unused. This is not efficient. If some investments were put in her name, the tax bill for the household would be reduced. Transfers of assets can be made between spouses without attracting capital gains tax. 18 Do some inheritance tax planning. (For more information, see below.) One of the great tax advantages of marriage comes only when you die! There is no inheritance tax on assets left to a spouse. Paul Falvey of Grant Thornton advises wealthy couples to leave only up to the individual IHT tax-free threshold (currently £234,000) to their children and then to leave the surplus to the spouse. 'You use up both spouses' exemptions in this way,' he says. If you want to build up a pension 19 Understand that Pension contributions are attractive because you get tax relief as you pay in the money. A higher-rate taxpayer pays only £60 to get £100 because another £40 is added by the Government. If you can afford it and think you will be able to build up a worthwhile fund, you should seriously consider having a pension. If you have access to a company scheme, you are likely to get contributions from your employer - a valuable benefit. 20 Remember that you are far better off paying pension contributions as a higher rate taxpayer than as a basic rate taxpayer. This is because you get a top-up worth 40 per cent of your gross contribution rather than 22 per cent. So try to maximise your contributions in these circumstances. If you think you could be underpaying, check with an accountant or - if you can't afford one - with TaxAid (0207 624 3768). 26 Go green. Recent Budgets have introduced environmentally friendly measures, including higher taxes for those with company cars. Employees can claim capital allowances, and so much per mile if they use their own bicycle for travel between home and work and, energy levels permitting, between one workplace and another. The provision of a cycle and helmet by an employer can be tax free. Ask first - bikes can be expensive these days. 29 Try saving tax and Getting fit at the same time. 'Under certain circumstances there is no taxable benefit on the provision of sporting or recreational facilities provided by an employer,' says Andrew Tailby-Faulkes of Smith & Williamson. 'A lifelong subscription to Champneys [health club] is excluded as the employer must provide the physical facilities per se .' 30 Remember that if you are a bean counter and pay your subscription to the Institute of Chartered Accountants yourself, you can set that cost against tax. The Inland Revenue has a long list of bodies where subscriptions can be treated like this. It will not save you a fortune but with many chartered accountants' subscriptions costing £161 a year, you could save £65 if you are a higher-rate taxpayer. (You cannot claim if your employer pays for you.) 31 'Donations to charity administered by an employer or freely by an employee are usually tax advantageous,' says Maria Bradley. The charity also gets a top-up equal to the basic rate of tax, and higher-rate taxpayers can claim back the 18 per cent difference between basic and higher rate tax. 32 'move house!' advises Andrew Tailby-Faulkes. 'Up to £8,000 of removal expenses paid to you by your employer will be free of tax.' 33 Remember that the provision of computers is tax-free up to prescribed limits, which are currently £2,000 for any type, including laptops. 34 Ask your employer to provide you with another tax-free benefit - a company mobile phone. Then you can also save money by getting rid of your own. 35 Think about lunch. After all that cycling, the provision of Luncheon Vouchers by your boss has a 15p per day tax exemption. 36 Persuade your employer to set up an Inland Revenue approved share option scheme. Some employees have ended up with lump sums of £20,000 this way. 37 Ask your employer for an interest-free season ticket loan. If the sum you borrow is less than £5,000, you will not be taxed for receiving a 'benefit in kind'. So if you borrowed £2,000 interest-free (and used it for any purpose, not just getting to work), you could easily save yourself £200 in interest that you would have paid on an overdraft, your credit card or loan arrangement. If you are being made redundant 38 Remember that the first £30,000 of a redundancy payment is usually tax-free. Make sure that your employer structures your payment in the right way so that you receive this tax advantage (you will not usually get a tax-free payment in return for not working out your notice). 39 Think of having any excess over the £30,000 barrier paid into your pension fund if you can afford to do without that extra cash. If your employer pays the money direct, it is not taxable; if you pay, it is but you then get the tax relief on the contribution. This exemption also applies to software and internet-enabled mobile phones. 42 Keep receipts for your travel expenses. Unlike employees, self-employed people are far more likely to be able to claim travel costs - especially if they work from home. 'It can be a very good investment,' says Garry Spencer of Wilbury Financial Management in Worthing, West Sussex. You can set your mortgage payments on the property, maintenance and other expenses against tax. 'You only pay tax on the profits,' says Spencer. 45 Put your properties in your spouse's name if you are letting out more than one property and your partner pays tax at a lower tax rate than you do. But you need to be able to trust them. 46 Make sure you do not have a huge mortgage on the house you live in and a tiny one on a property that you let out. That way round, your profits on letting will be very high and so will the tax you have to pay on it. Switched the other way, your taxable profits are low. webTitle: It's yours to keep: Slash your tax bill

fields.headline: Slash your tax bills  the rich man's way
fields.standfirst: Our fixing your finances series continues with  Neasa MacErlean  on how to keep more of your income for yourself
fields.trailText: Our fixing your finances series continues with Neasa MacErlean on how to keep more of your income for yourself.
fields.body:
Most people in Britain could probably cut their tax bill, or at least become more tax-efficient. Even if you do not earn enough to pay tax, there are useful things you can do - and pitfalls to avoid.

The lure of saving tax was evident last week when both Labour and the Conservatives unofficially launched their election campaigns with big announcements about tax. The Government unveiled an advertising campaign for the Children's Tax Credit - worth up to £8.50 a week for an estimated 5 million families. But the Tories stole the show with a promise to abolish lower-rate tax on savings from 2003. We can expect to hear a lot about tax during the election. But, if you want to think about your tax affairs now, here are some ideas.

'Anybody on an average salary of about £20,000 a year could probably save a couple of hundred pounds a year,' says chartered accountant and tax adviser Richard Murphy. 'Almost everybody could find something they could save tax on. And if you sat down and did it, you'd probably tidy up your finances too.'

But some people will find it far easier than others. Those most likely to have room for manoeuvre will have some or all of these characteristics: They will

 be wealthy

 be married

 have children

 get on with their parents

 trust their close family

 invest some of their money and tolerate risk

 have some pay from self-employment

 put money into property, shares and other investments

 take a long-term view of tax-planning.

'The wealthier you are, the more options you have and the more risk you can take,' says Anthony Coyte of independent adviser Towry Law. If you earn £100,000 a year, you should consider a whole range of tax-efficient investments from venture capital trusts to letting out property.

If you earn £10,000 a year, you will be doing well to have a savings account. If your income is only £4,000 a year, you should not be paying tax at all, though many pensioners and others are unwittingly paying tax at this level because they have a savings account on which the income is taxed at the basic rate of 22 per cent. Banks and building societies will automatically deduct the tax unless you tell them that you are not a taxpayer and fill in a form allowing them to pay you gross.

'For people without much money, it's more a question of making sure you're not paying the wrong amount of tax,' says a spokesman for charity TaxAid.

It estimates that 'many thousands' of low-paid workers have a tax problem without knowing it. 'We often find people are paying the wrong amount.' In about half the cases they are overpaying; in the rest they are underpaying.

TaxAid has called for a government investigation into how successfully the Pay As You Earn system is working.

Since tax is now so complicated that few understand it, the Revenue could be making mistakes over our affairs without our noticing it.

Tax advisers the Tax Team believe one in four tax returns could be 'incorrectly calculated' by the Revenue. Employers, banks and other financial institutions could also be making tax mistakes when they are dealing with the records of their employees and clients.

If you want to cut your tax bill then, aside from being wealthy, it helps to have a spouse and children.

'Much tax planning is about making the family unit pay,' says Murphy. 'It's harder for an individual to structure these things alone.'

If you have children, you can think of ways for them to use the £4,385 personal allowance. If you have a spouse who is in a lower tax band than you, you can transfer some of your assets - the flat that you let out, perhaps - into his or her name. By doing this, the income will be taxed in a lower band. You can also do this if you are an unmarried couple. But one of the benefits of being married is that transfers of assets between you do not attract capital gains tax, or inheritance tax when you die. Similarly, if you trust your children, you may decide to buy them, for example, a house to rent out at university, or one of the new stakeholder pension in their names.

Many people ignore their tax affairs because they are wary of dealing with the authorities. But this can rebound very badly. The wealthier classes know it is well worth their while to understand the machinations of inheritance tax planning and other subjects that seem complicated at first.

Coyte of Towry Law says: 'People interested in venture capital trusts and other sorts of investment take a lot of care over them.'

For many of the very wealthy, an interest in long-term planning is passed down through the generations. The rest of us can learn from that. If, for instance, you pay pension contributions when you are young, you will reduce the pressing need to make them when you are older because you will have already have built up a substantial pension fund. If you think that you will have a few years as a higher-rate taxpayer, you should try to make those the ones in which you maximise your pension payments because, under the current system, you will get 40 per cent tax relief on them, not just 22 per cent.

But you also have to keep an eye on the way politicians are playing with the tax system. There are occasional rumours that Labour might abolish higher-rate relief on pension contributions. And we do not know how Isas will fare in future.

But the system of Isas - and of Peps, their predecessors - have given a huge new tax-planning opportunity to the wealthy middle classes: they can put away £7,000 a year in these tax-efficient plans. People who do this year in, year out could end up - unless the rules change - with investment portfolios worth hundreds of thousands, but no tax to pay on the income or capital gains.

On the other hand, there is a danger in making financial decisions just for the tax relief. 'Too many people have Isas without understanding what they've got,' says Spencer. 'The value of an equity Isa will fluctuate with the stock market. These may not be a good principal home for your savings.'

Keeping money out of the inspector's clutches

'I'd rather see my money going into what I want than to HM Inspector of Taxes,' says Clive Brewer, who is self-employed and from Tonbridge in Kent. 'I'm naturally stingy in that way. But I do understand there has to be money to run services.'

A client of independent financial adviser Torquil Clark, Clive has bought a personal equity plan and an Isa to keep money away from the taxman.

He regards these as long-term savings. But he is pleased by the idea that there is no tax to pay on the income from them and, unless the rules change, no Capital Gains Tax liability if they are sold.

Brewer, who is married with two children, is happy to be paying into a personal pension and getting tax relief on top of his contributions. As he is self-employed, his payments are made gross of tax, which he claims back. From April this will change: payments will be net of tax, with relief added to their funds by the Government.

He likes this, and the fact that he will be able to take out a quarter of his fund as a tax-free lump sum when he retires, as well as getting the relief now. But he says: 'This is dependent on Gordon Brown and his mates not mucking things up. He's not a great friend of non-state pension schemes.'

Brewer is more interested in his financial arrangements than most of us, and has thought of investing in a Venture Capital Trust. These potentially risky funds have so far produced more reliable returns than expected, and are seen as for the wealthy.

But some now accept investments as low as £1,000, so they may become a tax-efficient flutter for more investors.

On the other hand, there is a danger in making financial decisions just for the tax relief. 'Too many people have Isas without understanding what they've got,' says Spencer. 'The value of an equity Isa will fluctuate with the stock market. These may not be a good principal home for your savings.' Keeping money out of the inspector's clutches 'I'd rather see my money going into what I want than to HM Inspector of Taxes,' says Clive Brewer, who is self-employed and from Tonbridge in Kent. 'I'm naturally stingy in that way. But I do understand there has to be money to run services.' A client of independent financial adviser Torquil Clark, Clive has bought a personal equity plan and an Isa to keep money away from the taxman. He regards these as long-term savings. But he is pleased by the idea that there is no tax to pay on the income from them and, unless the rules change, no Capital Gains Tax liability if they are sold. Brewer, who is married with two children, is happy to be paying into a personal pension and getting tax relief on top of his contributions. As he is self-employed, his payments are made gross of tax, which he claims back. From April this will change: payments will be net of tax, with relief added to their funds by the Government. He likes this, and the fact that he will be able to take out a quarter of his fund as a tax-free lump sum when he retires, as well as getting the relief now. But he says: 'This is dependent on Gordon Brown and his mates not mucking things up. He's not a great friend of non-state pension schemes.' Brewer is more interested in his financial arrangements than most of us, and has thought of investing in a Venture Capital Trust. These potentially risky funds have so far produced more reliable returns than expected, and are seen as for the wealthy. But some now accept investments as low as £1,000, so they may become a tax-efficient flutter for more investors.

webTitle: Cashpoints

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText:
Want cheap credit? Take a hike

An interest-free first six months is offered on purchases made with a new Capital One credit card for hikers. You can choose from two designs, picturing Stanage Edge in the Peak District or High Sweden Bridge, Cumbria. After the intial six months its annual percentage rate (APR) is 12.9 per cent. But new customers transferring balances from rival cards before August will get a 'lifetime rate' of 7.9 per cent APR. If the balance you transfer is at least £1,000 you will receive a free pair of £40 Brasher walking poles, and everyone applying gets a torch set. Ring 0800 9525252.

Want cheap credit? Take a hike

An interest-free first six months is offered on purchases made with a new Capital One credit card for hikers. You can choose from two designs, picturing Stanage Edge in the Peak District or High Sweden Bridge, Cumbria. After the intial six months its annual percentage rate (APR) is 12.9 per cent. But new customers transferring balances from rival cards before August will get a 'lifetime rate' of 7.9 per cent APR. If the balance you transfer is at least £1,000 you will receive a free pair of £40 Brasher walking poles, and everyone applying gets a torch set. Ring 0800 9525252.

Now buy a pension at the Post Office
The Post Office will sell Standard Life's new stakeholder pension through its 18,000 branches from April. It hopes to bring the Government's initiative for the lower paid to 'millions' of people, especially women, this way, says a Post Office official. Customers will be able to make payments over the counter. The Standard Life pension carries a 1 per cent annual management charge. There is a choice of six funds. A special helpline will be available for customers needing help before they buy.

Mortgage moans
If you want to complain about a mortgage you have taken out, a new leaflet from the watchdog Mortgage Code Compliance Board (MCCB) explains what to do. First, tackle the firm that sold you the loan. If it cannot solve the problem, take your complaint on to the Mortgage Code Arbitration Scheme or the relevant financial ombudsman. The MCCB says the most frequent gripe about brokers was a failure to refund fees. The principal complaint against lenders was that they changed the terms of their original loan offers. The leaflet is available free from 01785 218200 or at Citizens' Advice Bureaux.

Flood form
You can check whether a home you want to buy is at risk from flooding or landslips by filling in its postcode on forms downloaded from an updated Home Envirosearch website. The site's owner, the Landmark Information Group, promises results in 48 hours for a fee of £39. The check includes details of hazards such as toxic emissions, radon and shallow mining within a 500 metre radius. You can apply through your solicitor, or by downloading the forms yourself at home-envirosearch.com.

Ethics check
A free guide from the Ethical Investment Research Service aims to help you find out what your pension fund is invested in. A change to the law last year gives you the right to know what social, environmental or ethical stance your fund takes. Ring 0845 606 0324 for a copy.

Fund of knowledge
Our sister magazine Money Observer is offering places at its first one-day seminar to investors wanting to learn how to get richer by thinking like a top fund manager. Fund manager David Hambridge will explain how to pick a fund, and the Money Observer editorial team will answer questions. The seminar, which costs £195, is on 24 March at the Cumberland Hotel, London. Those registering on 0131 466 4242 before 26 February will get a discount of £25.

Provident post
Mutual insurer Friends Provident is asking its 1.7 million customers to verify personal and policy details so that they receive windfalls promptly when the company demutualises later this year. If you are entitled to its mail pack and this has not reached you by 20 February, or you have questions, telephone 0845 071170.

webTitle: It's yours to keep: Tory tax plans

fields.headline: The Tories' family values - help the rich
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean  on Portillo's plan to overhaul tax on savings
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean on Portillo's plan to overhaul tax on savings.
fields.body:
Well-heeled married couples are the people likely to benefit most from tax proposals unveiled last week by the Conservative party. Financial advisers predict a rash of 'asset-swapping' between couples in the unlikely event of a Tory victory in the next general election.

The plans would remove the obligation to pay income tax on savings account and dividend income for people earning less than the higher rate tax threshold, currently £32,785 a year.

So, in the traditional Tory family, the high-earning husband who pays tax at 40 per cent would transfer his building society and other savings accounts to his wife. A lower rate taxpayer, with a part-time job perhaps, the wife would receive income from these assets tax-free. And - under the plans outlined by Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo - the wife would still get sympathetic treatment if the huge size of her portfolio took her into the top tax bracket. She would have to pay 40 per cent tax on income above £32,785 but would get all her investment income below that tax-free.

When the Tory party talks about itself as the party of the family, this appears to be a large part of what it means. The tax benefits that come through a close family go a long way to preserving family members' wealth. Non-married couples can also transfer assets between themselves, but they risk a capital gains tax liability if the gain that the transferring partner realises exceeds the threshold (currently £7,200). Asset transfers between spouses are tax-free.

'This looks as though it would benefit people with clever accountants,' says Simon Farrant of independent financial adviser Towry Law. The plans would give a new lease of life to the tax avoidance industry, since anyone moving down below the £32,785 threshold would shift down from a 40 to a zero per cent tax rate.

The plan will be of most benefit to those wealthy enough to live off investment income. Those with income from savings and shares that comes to just under the £32,785 threshold will pay no income tax. That would mean having a portfolio worth about £500,000.

What Portillo billed as 'the most radical changes to the taxation of savings in a generation' - has four strands:

 Taxpayers below the 40 per cent higher-rate threshold would pay no tax on income from savings.

 If income from savings takes you into the 40 per cent tax band, you would only pay 40 per cent on income above £32,785.

 Taxpayers below the 40 per cent threshold would receive income from shares free of tax. Since they are effectively taxed at 10 per cent on dividend income now, they would get 100, not just 90, per cent of the dividend income in their pocket.

 Non-taxpayers would receive 100 per cent of a dividend, rather than the 90 per cent they receive at present.

In his speech last Monday, Michael Portillo gave the example of someone with £10,000 of savings who would be £120 better off in a year, and £740 better off after five years.

So, even though the proposals would give much scope to the wealthy, there would also be benefits to the less well-off. Since April 1999 non-taxpayers have not been able to reclaim the 10 per cent so-called 'tax credit' on their dividend income.

Philip Spiers of the Nursing Home Fees Agency says that many elderly people had relied on getting the income tax-free and lost out under the new Labour system: 'A lot of them didn't want to sell those shares. Maybe their husbands had bought the shares a long time before.'

One group of people who would not stand to gain from the proposals are higher-rate taxpayers whose salaries or self-employed earnings take them into that bracket. Their tax debts would stay the same. But if a higher-rate taxpayer were married to a lower-rate taxpayer, it would be in the interests of both for the higher-rate taxpayer to make pension contributions and get tax relief. 'The only trouble would then be sorting out the finances if they separated,' says tax adviser Richard Murphy.

Another side-effect of the Tory proposals would be that pensions may be seen as less attractive investment vehicles. Assuming that they were likely to be lower-rate taxpayers on retirement, people may prefer to build up more investments that would be non-taxable than to build up a pension fund, that would be taxed.

The market for tax-free individual savings account would also be dealt a blow by the proposals. Only higher-rate taxpayers would need to invest in them. Although Portillo did not discuss in his speech the treatment of unit trusts, the main equity Isa vehicle, he stated that he did not want to see market distortions pushing people away from stock market investments. It would be very surprising, therefore, if unit trusts were not treated in the same fashion for lower-rate taxpayers.

If William Hague came to power, the aim would be to have these proposals in place by April 2003.

webTitle: Eminem and Elton - the ultimate duet

fields.headline: It's Eminem and Elton - the ultimate duet
fields.trailText: Eminem, the American rapper who has been accused of glorifying violence against women and homosexuals, has offered an olive branch to the gay community by asking Sir Elton John to sing with him at the Grammy Awards next week.
fields.body:
Eminem, the American rapper who has been accused of glorifying violence against women and homosexuals, has offered an olive branch to the gay community by asking Sir Elton John to sing with him at the Grammy Awards next week.

Eminem, currently on his first British tour, asked Sir Elton, a leading gay rights activist, to sing backing vocals on his song 'Stan' at the ceremony in Los Angeles, where he has been nominated for four awards.

Sir Elton said he has agreed because Eminem - real name Marshall Mathers - is the most exciting artist of the moment. He told the Los Angeles Times : 'I know I'm going to get a lot of flak from various people who are going to picket the show. I'd rather tear down walls between peo ple than build them up. If I thought for one minute that he was hateful, I wouldn't do it.'

His decision was criticised by gay rights campaigners last night. Peter Tatchell, of the British campaign group OutRage!, said: 'Would Elton John do a concert with a singer who fantasised about raping Jews and lynching black people? I doubt it.

'Why then is he planning a duet with a rap artist who fantasises about raping women and murdering homosexuals? The idea that Eminem is not homophobic is laughable.'

Scott Seomin, of the US Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation which gave Sir Elton an award for his promotion of gay rights last year, said that his actions 'violate the spirit of the award we gave him. It's hurtful and embarrassing'.

John.arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Sellafield ignored blast alert

fields.headline: Sellafield ignored blast alert
fields.trailText: A major disaster was narrowly averted at Sellafield's nuclear waste plant in Cumbria when more than 2,000 tonnes of high-level nuclear waste almost exploded,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
A major disaster was narrowly averted at Sellafield's nuclear waste plant in Cumbria when more than 2,000 tonnes of high-level nuclear waste almost exploded, The Observer can reveal.

Safety procedures were so lax at one of the plant's waste storage facilities last month that workers ignored alarm warnings of a build-up of explosive gases for nearly three hours. The gases were accumulating in the 21 tanks that each store 100 tonnes of deadly waste.

Ten hours longer, experts say, and the tanks would have been explosive.

Ministers were briefed last Tuesday about the incident, the worst in a long line of safety scandals at the plant. Peter Hain, the Minister for Energy, was informed by the Government's nuclear safety team, the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate (NII), that an incident had occurred at the plant on 26 January.

The NII has launched a major investigation, sending four inspectors to the plant and requesting that the owner of the plant, British Nuclear Fuels Limited (BNFL), report on safety procedures within four weeks.

'This is an extremely alarming situation,' said Andrew Stunnel, the Liberal Democrat spokesperson on energy. 'It shows the cavalier attitude that has dogged the nuclear industry for 50 years.'

Martin Forewood, a campaign co-ordinator for the local activist group Core, who has lived in the area for 25 years, said:'We're constantly reassured by the Government and BNFL that we have nothing to worry about. This incident shows how close we can come to a catastrophic incident.'

BNFL admitted its staff ignored alarms for two-and-a-half hours, and said the situation was 'inadequate'. It said it would take a lot longer than 10 hours for the situation to become critical and risk an explosion. It confirmed that the reprocessing plant at Thorp had been shut down as a result of the incident.

'Those 21 tanks of waste contain huge quantities of the most hazardous materials on the nuclear site, if not the planet' said John Large, one of the world's leading nuclear engineers. 'A similarly sized tank blew up in the Russian area of Chelyabinsk in 1957 and on its own devastated an area the size of central London.

'The only other time something like this has happened in Europe was in France in the Seventies when they rushed to use emergency military generators to cool the tanks and prevent an explosion.'

The incident happened at 8.30pm when engineers were carrying out improvements on the ventilation systems that stop the explosive gases from building up inside the tanks. The engineers incorrectly wired the circuits in the ventilators.

webTitle: Tokyo businessman to be charged over Lucie killing

fields.headline: Tokyo businessman to be charged over Lucie killing
fields.standfirst:
After seven months the search for missing Lucie is over

Grim secret of man in Armani who chatted up Lucie Blackman
fields.trailText: After seven months the search for missing Lucie is over.
fields.byline: Tracy McVeigh and Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.body:
The mystery surrounding Lucie Blackman, the British woman missing in Japan since July, was finally solved yesterday when dismembered human remains found on a beach were identified as hers.

Police said forensic tests and dental records proved the body parts were from Lucie, a Tokyo hostess who was 21 when she disappeared.

Tim Blackman, Lucie's father, last night said he had felt a 'significant feeling of relief' after months of uncertainty when he was told the news.

Fighting back tears, he told a press conference on the Isle of Wight: 'I hope that she had a glass of champagne, felt a bit woozy and then passed out. I hope she felt no terror or pain, and where she is now she is happy. She was a very loving character and I have been privileged to be her father.'

Japanese police said yesterday they would be charging the prime suspect for her murder, 48-year-old businessman Joji Obara, with 'abandoning a corpse'.

Obara, who is regarded as one of the most evil characters to have surfaced in Japanese criminal history, is already on trial accused of drugging and raping five women.

Yesterday he told Japanese reporters: 'I didn't bury the corpse. The police did.' The beach where the body was found, buried in a shallow pit, had already been searched several times by Japanese police over the past few months. The body had been stripped, decapitated and cut into eight pieces. The limbs were wrapped in polythene bags. The head was encased in concrete.

The skeleton was too tall for a Japanese woman's, and police rang the Blackman family in England on Friday to warn them that it could be Lucie's. The cave is 250 metres from Obara's apartment in the town of Miura, 30 miles from Tokyo.

'We have determined the identity of the body, and it was an unfortunate outcome for the friends and family of Lucie,' said Akira Hiromitsu, of Tokyo's Metropolitan Police Department.

Lucie's family, who had spent tens of thousands of pounds in their relentless seven-month search forher, were devastated yesterday.

Her grandfather, Eric Blackman, 78, said the family had been told Lucie was likely to have been drugged before her death.

'Tim called me at noon immediately after putting the phone down to police in Tokyo. He sounded very calm. It was a very brief, matter of fact conversation, and he wants to be left alone now.

'Over the last few weeks he has come to terms with the fact Lucie was dead and that he will never see his daughter again. We had all made our minds up that Lucie was dead, and knew in our hearts the remains were Lucie's.'

webTitle: 'Tokyo Ripper' suspected of killing the English hostess

fields.headline: Grim secret of man in Armani who chatted up Lucie Blackman
fields.standfirst:
He oozed sophistication, but the 'Tokyo Ripper' suspected of killing the English hostess was a brutal serial rapist, report Jonathan Watts and Tracy McVeigh

Tokyo businessman to be charged over Lucie killing
fields.trailText: He oozed sophistication, but the 'Tokyo Ripper' suspected of killing the English hostess was a brutal serial rapist, report Jonathan Watts and Tracy McVeigh.
fields.body:
He wore an Armani suit and expensive cologne and oozed sophistication. Joji Obara appeared every bit the suave, successful businessman relaxing over a drink after a long day's work.

Standing at the bar in the Casablanca Club, he studied the pretty blonde British hostess as she moved among the wealthy customers, taking their orders for cocktails and indulging in friendly chit-chat.

Lucie Blackman had certainly noticed him. The 21-year-old was impressed by Obara's perfect English and polite manners. She was told his name was Kaz and it was his first time in the bar, situated in Tokyo's entertainment district of Rappongi.

The 48-year-old looked different too - he had had cosmetic surgery on his eyes to change their natural slant. According to the owner of the Casablanca, Blackman joined him for a few glasses of brandy. The pair talked for more than an hour.

Kaz, a law graduate of an American university, was described as intense and charming. He owned a Ferrari, a Rolls-Royce and a Mercedes Benz, as well as several properties, including beach resort apartments outside the city. Other hostesses reported being invited by him for a 'drive to the seaside'.

It appears Lucie accepted a similar offer on 1 July, her day off, when she called her friend Louise to say she was off to the coast with a bar customer. The call was made on a mobile phone later traced to Obara - who had invited Lucie to his apartment in Zushi.

With Obara now in custody facing charges of 'abandoning a corpse' and a likely murder charge, focus has shifted to his background, and how the self-styled millionaire playboy came to be known as the Tokyo Ripper.

Obara, who described himself as an introvert, was born with the surname Kim to a wealthy Korean family in Osaka. Despite the discrimination that many Koreans suffer in Japan, his father made a fortune with a taxi business and land holdings that allowed him to send his son to college in the United States and to the prestigious Keio University in Tokyo.

The aspirational young man appears to have grown embarrassed by his humble Korean roots. On returning from the US he adopted a Japanese name - Ohashi - which he later switched to Joji Obara. He was fascinated by Western culture: he drove European cars, wore designer suits and frequented nightclubs with blond hostesses. One report said he wore high-heeled boots to make him look taller and wore dark glasses even in the dingy clubs he used to frequent.

He refused to have his picture taken for the Keio yearbook after his graduation and no picture has been published of him that is less than 10 years old.

Obara's business fortunes mirrored the Japanese economy. During the rapid expansion of the late Eighties he used the money he inherited from his father to invest in the booming property market.

At its peak in 1989 he had assets across Japan worth 4bn yen (£22 million). But in the subsequent property collapse, he was almost wiped out, incurring debts of 8bn yen. Many of his prized properties, including his plush home in Denenchofu, were repossessed.

Far from curbing his expensive tastes, Obara embraced the high life with new vigour. He became a 'face' in the clubs of Roppongi and nearby Ginza, where it is believed he trawled for victims.

Obara was arrested last October on charges of raping and drugging five women and has since emerged as one of the most brutal serial rapists Japan has seen.

Several women testified Obara took them to his Zushi flat where they passed out for more than a day after he offered them an odd-tasting drink. In one case it is alleged the victim never woke up.

At his Tokyo residence police found more than 100 videos of him raping semi-conscious women who had been given a date-rape drug. He had also kept a notebook with more than 50 names of victims and the pseudonyms he had used with them.

Last month prosecutors charged Obara with the death of an Australian woman, Carita Ridgway, who died of organ failure in 1992. It has emerged that she was given the drug found at the Zushi apartment.

Obara has denied all charges, maintaining all the women he had sex with consented. His lawyers say their client is being framed to relieve the pressure on Japan to solve the Blackman case.

'We are looking at attacks that have been happening for 10 to 15 years,' said David Davies, the private investigator who helped the Blackman family in their tireless search for their daughter. A former senior Metropolitan police officer, Davies believes Obara is responsible for at least one other killing. 'He was clearly an expert in luring and charming woman. He is also a dangerous sado-masochist with some deeply disturbing and peculiar sex habits.'

Obara owns an apartment 250 metres from the cave where Lucie's body was found. Four days after her disappearance he was seen walking along the beach late at night with a shovel.

Shortly before his arrest he bought a second-hand speedboat. After insisting that it be made ready for use in one week - half the usual time - he asked the salesman: 'Where is the deepest part of Tsuruga Bay?' (the body of water closest to Miura).

Obara has been the leading suspect since the start of the investigation, which only really began in earnest 10 days after Lucie's disappearance, when her father, Tim Blackman, flew out to Tokyo and began to apply media and political pressure.

Until then the police were treating the case as just another missing person inquiry. Two days before Mr Blackman's arrival a detective from the Azabu police station in Roppongi visited the Casablanca bar and asked the manager if he had heard of a customer named Kaz.

The manager said he could not remember, and when he was asked for his customer records he said he would send along a copy. 'This is a discreet business,' he said after the officer left. 'Every time they question one of my clients, I lose a customer.'

Faced by such resistance, and without a body, police have been unwilling to charge Obara in connection with Lucie's disappearance. Now, however, the long wait seems to be over.

webTitle: Tycoon donors to parties face new scrutiny

fields.headline: Tycoon donors to parties face new scrutiny
fields.trailText: Millionaire donors to political parties could face a cap on their gifts amid public fears about wealthy businessmen buying influence.
fields.body:
Millionaire donors to political parties could face a cap on their gifts amid public fears about wealthy businessmen buying influence.

Sam Younger, chairman of the new funding watchdog, the Electoral Commission, will reopen the controversy in a review of the rules once the election is over.

Speaking to The Observer, Younger warned that the real turn-off for voters was not sleaze but modern politicians failing to convince voters they could make a difference.

However, he said a cap on donations was 'on the surface very attractive' following concern over tycoon Stuart Wheeler's £5 million gift to the Tories and three gifts of £2 million each to Labour from other donors.

'I completely understand the public concern about the agenda of those who might give large donations to political parties and about how parties are responding,' he said. 'That is inevitable, and the greater degree of transparency that can be achieved the better.'

But capping donations - Labour MPs have suggested no one should give more than £100,000 - may mean the taxpayer being asked to stump up for campaigns through state funding, which he warned would be unpopular.

The Electoral Commission, launched tomorrow, will police new rules forcing political parties to declare all donations above £5,000 as well as overseeing spending on the euro referendum, conducting experiments such as internet voting, and maintaining the UK's 107-strong register of official political parties - from Labour and the Tories to the Millennium Bean Party.

He will soon start producing weekly updates on funding for the main parties during the election campaign.

Younger will have powers to seize and examine the parties' books, while MPs face random spot checks on election expense returns. But he says his team will not charge in like a 'blundering elephant' on every minor complaint.

Younger, former managing director of BBC World Services, says he has no personal political leanings, only a mission to reverse the decline in voter numbers. 'There isn't the sense that there was some years ago that we were voting for significant changes of direction,' he argues.

webTitle: Ellen MacArthur won everything, except the race

fields.headline: She won everything, except the race
fields.standfirst: Euan Ferguson  in Les Sables D'Olonne watches as France prepares to welcome Ellen MacArthur, the British sailor who has become the century's first true heroine
fields.trailText: Euan Ferguson in Les Sables D'Olonne watches as France prepares to welcome Ellen MacArthur, the British sailor who has become the century's first true heroine.
fields.body:
Very soon, she will smell the land. Two hundred miles out from these ancient French sands, somewhere under a bruised sky growing lower and grimmer by the second, Ellen MacArthur is almost home; hanging on desperately, with a mast likely to crash down in seconds if her luck finally deserts her, but almost home.

So soon, some time this Sunday morning, she will smell the land; and then she will see the boats, and the helicopters, and the tens of thousands lining the harbour and the sands, and the most remarkable piece of sailing by a British woman begun in the week America went shambolically to the polls, will be over.

She hasn't won the Vendée Globe. That honour, and Ellen's radioed congratulations yesterday, went to Frenchman Michel Desjoyeaux, 'The Professor', who was last night due to sail his yacht PRB, the mouse to whom Ellen has been cat for the last exhilarating fortnight, into port as a filthily wet Les Sables lit up in his honour. He, as has Ellen, has rewritten the record books, sailing round the world single-handed in an astonishing 95 days, tearing the previous time down by 10 days.

His story, an idiosyncratic mix of quiet competence and Gallic inspiration, will be told again and again. But it is Ellen's story that has caught the French imagination, and that of the world. Where the professor was expected to sail in with his boat a forgiveable mess, Ellen has been swabbing and sewing, keeping tidy throughout.

Where the men of the race, the bearded stars, have been seen clambering manfully around their rigging, Ellen has practically been lost inside hers: a tiny figure, almost forlorn, but for the fact that her grit, her refusal to give up, have made her perhaps the first true heroine of the 21st century.

Here, the French, conscious of her size, have begun comparing her to Joan of Arc. Chants of 'Vive Ellen!' have been heard round the Les Sables marina, where much of western France was gathered all yesterday in the rain, soaking itself in sympathy with the sailor whose adventures they have followed, with increasing fascination, since 9 November last year.

It was exhaustion, finally, which robbed Ellen of absolute triumph. One tiny slip, back on day 80, when she allowed herself a brief sleep in the Doldrums - not the hardest sailing by far, but as demanding in terms of crucial concentration as any - after a Herculanean struggle climbing the mast to mend the wind instruments, an endless night time battle worthy of a book or film in itself, and she had allowed Desjoyeaux, 'Mich' as she refers to him, to get the directional jump-start into the trade winds which he needed. After that it was always going to be hard for her to catch up. The astounding thing is that she almost made it.

Had it not been for her crashing into a floating container - one of many thousands dumped annually at sea - her daggerboard would not have been ruined. Even then, she effected repairs and motored on; it was only a couple of days ago, when her forestay unexpectedly went, that she knew the race was over; she could not pile the pressure on the mast without the risk of bringing it down.

Nevertheless, she knows, as she cruises in some time this evening, hoping furiously to catch the tide-barrier in time and enter Les Sables during the evening, rather than having to wait until the next morning, that what she has achieved is beyond any expectations. Beyond those of her parents, who hardly know what to make of their driven offspring; this is not a sailing family. Beyond the expectations of her homeland, which had forgotten how glorious its sailing tradition was and how one story could capture the imagination.

It has done so, quite simply, thanks to Ellen. Not for any false Amazonian stoicism; some of the time she was knackered, and in tears, and she shared it with people, by phone links and email, and it was this vulnerable human element to the tale which held.

We listened to it all. Her awe as she passed the insanely high blue icebergs. Her plaintive emails. Forgetting to eat. Remembering to dream. Celebrating various landmarks with a little champagne, but pouring the rest proudly over the deck. Throwing back the flying fish which landed on her deck, where others ate them. And the tiredness; the 20-minute catnaps and the luxurious two-hour snores, and the hours and hours at the computer, planning and planning and never giving in.

For, ultimately, and despite the fibreglass and computer design and emails and satellite strategising, this was an ancient human story.

For Ellen, for all those taking part, the Vendée Globe challenge was about their own body. About feeding it enough, about resting it just enough, about the drive that came from inside, about being strong enough despite the most ludicrous setbacks and the most maleficent turns of nature. It is about being able, at the last, to sail into this grey port knowing that, no matter what life throws at them, nothing will be able to take away the achievement of the Vendée Globe 2000/2001.

'I just have to keep going,' she radioed yesterday. 'I'm so worried about the mast. I just have to keep going. It's not easy though.'

She will arrive to congratulations from Tony Blair, Lionel, Jospin and Jacques Chirac, who have sent a message from the the Anglo-French summit, and, given the mood here, a memorable welcome from the French. Her parents will fly out in a Royal Navy helicopter tomorrow to see if they can fly over her and talk via the radio. She may have a drink or two.

And then the first thing she will do is climb back into Kingfisher and sail her home.

Related stories
Alone, alone on a wide, wide sea
Le Professeur teaches the world to sail along

webTitle: Letters: Slavery in Sudan

fields.headline: Slavery laboured
fields.trailText: We were surprised that you accepted at face value claims by Baroness Cox and Christian Solidarity Worldwide about alleged 'slavery' in Sudan (News, 28 January).
fields.body:
We were surprised that you accepted at face value claims by Baroness Cox and Christian Solidarity Worldwide about alleged 'slavery' in Sudan (News, 28 January). These claims have been challenged and questioned by reputable human rights organisations. There is considerable evidence, for example, that there have been many staged 'redemptions' within rebel-controlled areas in Sudan.
A. Al-Koronsky
Embassy of The Republic of the Sudan
London SW1

webTitle: Anthony Sampson recalls Mandela's Rivonia speech

fields.headline: How I gave advice on the words that made history his cry
fields.standfirst:
Anthony Sampson, who covered the 1964 trial for The Observer, recalls Mandela's defiant words

Special report: Mandela recordings
fields.trailText: Anthony Sampson, who covered the 1964 trial for The Observer, recalls Mandela's defiant words.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela's last speech in 1964, before he returned to prison on Robben Island, has a unique historical importance in South Africa. For the next 25 years it would provide the key manifesto for the campaign against apartheid, while all other statements from the African National Congress were banned.

But it was much more than a politician's speech: it was a highly personal account of one man's political development and education. And it was written by Mandela in his cell, before it was discussed with his lawyers who tried, largely unsuccessfully, to persuade him to tone it down.

By a surprising accident I saw the speech in preparation shortly before he delivered it in Pretoria. When I was covering one day of the trial for The Observer, Mandela came up from the prison cells, looking thinner and more wan than I had remembered him when I first knew him when I was editor of Drum magazine in the Fifties, but still full of dignity. He looked round and recognised me, and I could not resist making the ANC salute. An Afrikaner policeman quickly hauled me out of the courtroom, and questioned me about my relationship with the accused.

The incident was watched with amusement by Mandela, and when I returned to the courtroom he passed a message through his lawyers asking me whether I could look through his closing speech to advise on its impact on the international media.

So I spent some engrossing hours with the lawyers in their adjoining office, looking through the speech in Mandela's own handwriting. I suggested a few minor changes, most of which were not accepted. What struck me most in the words was the directness and eloquence with which he described his early pride in his Xhosa history and culture which provided his first political motivation.

But it was Mandela's delivery of the climax of the speech which will attract most interest in the recording. Witnesses have given varying descriptions of how he dropped his voice with the final words, 'If needs be, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die,' and followed them with a long silence.

webTitle: TV news shows rapist's home video of assault

fields.headline: TV news shows rapist's home video of assault
fields.trailText: Viewers watched in shock and disbelief as Israeli state television showed part of a home video of a rape that was taped by the rapist himself.
fields.body:
Viewers watched in shock and disbelief as Israeli state television showed part of a home video of a rape that was taped by the rapist himself.

In the video clip, which was shown on Thursday by the Israeli Broadcasting Authority's (IBA) Channel One evening news, a strongly built man was shown physically beating and verbally abusing a woman whose naked body was frequently exposed to the camera, although her face was blanked out.

The woman, the man's housemaid, could be heard moaning and pleading with her attacker to be left alone. Although the two spoke in Russian, Channel One provided subtitles of the conversation in Hebrew.

Channel One's news correspondent explained that this was only a brief preview of a full six-hour videotape in which the attacker documented how he raped and sodomised a woman. The man, identified as Sergi Golov, has been convicted of the rape and is awaiting sentencing by a Haifa court, the reporter said.

'The pictures are hard. We tried to blur out the faces,' Rafik Halabi, head of the Channel One news department, said in a statement. 'This is a testament that should shock, in order to defend and protect women against the aggression of men. I hope this report will help suppress this shocking phenomenon.'

Women's groups questioned why the video had been shown and whether the woman had given her permission, suggesting that the desire for publicity motivated the news producers.

'You don't have to show rape in order to show the horror of rape,' said Yael Balla Avni, Director of the Association of Rape Crisis Centres, who said the video footage was cut 'just seconds before the woman was actually raped'.

The fact that Channel One's news is available on the internet allows anyone so inclined to save the graphic footage and look at it over and over again, like a peep show or pornographic site.

Graphic clips like this can have a negative effect on men's treatment towards women, according to Ronit Abraham, who works at the Centre of Violence Against Women. This organisation has 80 volunteers who, between them, speak Russian, Arabic and Hebrew and offers women practical solutions to their problems, including the best way to approach and work with police.

'Instead of supporting victims of rape, such footage can encourage people with sick minds to carry out similar acts. The news producers could have done a much more serious report by interviewing victims of violence and rape. But the media always wants blood to tell a story.'

Figures released last year estimate that at least 20 per cent of the families in Israel live in a violent atmosphere - verbal or sexual.
