webTitle: The Rivonia Trial

fields.headline: The Rivonia Trial
fields.standfirst: The historical background to Mandela's final public speech for 27 years.
fields.trailText: The Rivonia Trial, named after the suburb of Johannesburg where sixteen leaders of the African National Congress had been arrested in July 1963, began on 26 November 1963.
fields.body:
The Rivonia Trial, named after the suburb of Johannesburg where sixteen leaders of the African National Congress had been arrested in July 1963, began on 26 November 1963.

Mandela and his fellow defendants were charged with 221 acts of sabotage designed to "ferment violent revolution".

The ANC had been operating underground since being outlawed in April 1960, one month after the Sharpeville Massacre of 67 protestors by police. The police had collected hundreds of documents from the ANC hideout at Rivonia about Operation Mayibuye (Operation Comeback).

Under the new General Law Amendment (Sabotage) Act of 1962 and the Suppression of Communism Act, the defendants faced the threat of the death penalty.

Mandela had a growing international reputation and the ANC sought to use the trial to win worldwide support and attention, hence Mandela's speech from the dock on April 20th which was delivered from his handwritten script.

For example, the speech was extracted in The Observer on Sunday April 26th, under the headline "Why I am prepared to die".

Mandela was described as "the black pimpernel of South Africa, on trial in Pretoria with eight others on charges of attempting a revolution by violence".

The newspaper told its readers that "the alleged offences are punishable by death. Last week he appeared in the witness-box for four-and-a-half hours to explain his stand. He admitted that he had organised sabotage. He explained why he had turned to violence, and what kind of South Africa he was prepared to die for" to introduce "the historic speech which could be his last".

On June 11 1964, at the conclusion of the trial, Mandela and the seven other defendants - Walter Sisulu, Govan Mbeki (father of current South African President Thabo Mbeki), Raymond Mhlaba, Elias Motsoaledi, Ahmed Kathrada and Denis Goldberg - were convicted. Mandela was found guilty on four charges of sabotage. All eight were imprisoned to life imprisonment.

The United Nations Security Council condemned the trial and began moves towards international sanctions against the apartheid regime. But it was 27 years before Mandela was released from prison on February 11th 1990, becoming President of South Africa following the first democratic multi-racial elections in 1994.

webTitle: So this bloke walked into a bra...

fields.headline: So this bloke walked into a bra...
fields.trailText:
Boy Meets Girl C4
Omnibus: Nancy Mitford BBC1
Position Impossible C4
The Real Erich Von Daniken C4
Tonight With Trevor McDonald ITV
fields.body:
Boy Meets Girl C4
Omnibus: Nancy Mitford BBC1
Position Impossible C4
The Real Erich Von Daniken C4
Tonight With Trevor McDonald ITV

Mel Gibson's observation about women and penis envy in What Women Want ('they're not envious. Most of them don't even like it') was tested in Channel 4's deeply pointless 'sex swap' challenge, Boy Meets Girl.

Watching the girls stuff socks down their boxers revealed that, even in the spurious guise of a 'social experiment', size mattered, and if one had to wear a sock-penis it had better be the sort of sock a girl could be proud of: sports socks, for example, rather than pop-socks, helpfully adjusted ('up there, down a bit there') by Lewis, a female to male transsexual. But just as the women all chose to impersonate the members of The Red Hot Chilli Peppers ('as soon as the sock went in, that was it!' said Lisa-as-Lee), none of the men-who-would-be-women opted for a flat chest, either. Funny that.

'Beyond drag, beyond camp, beyond mere dressing up...' insisted voiceover artiste Gail Porter (and how I wished she'd joined in too), but there was no evidence of it here: everybody looked laughably draggy and camp. There's no disguising an Adam's apple, stubble and bricklayer's hands, after all - and, more interestingly, no hiding a fear of, or loathing for, the opposite sex either. Of the initial eight sex-swappers, only six were allowed to carry on the experiment into Week Two. The pair who were rejected - Helen as 'Bob' and Stan as 'Stacy' - were both actors whose alter egos turned out to be rather unpleasant two-dimensional cliches, revealing more about Helen and Stan than perhaps either would have liked.

Helen's 'Bob' was, physically, the most convincing of the lot, but the character was 'aggressive and emotionally aloof'. 'Bob' clammed up, angrily, when asked 'how do you treat a woman in bed, Bob? Do you treat her right?'while Stan's 'Stacy' was a parody of the frigid man-hater, whose greatest regret was 'losing my virginity'.

'Stan wouldn't let himself be a weak woman because he's a strong man,' explained one of the judges, even though Stan hadn't created a strong woman, but merely sketched a madly surrealist cartoon in a fake Chanel suit.

BBC1's Omnibus on Nancy Mitford, screened to complement the dramatisation of Love In A Cold Climate (to be reviewed next week), revealed that although the whole of Miss Mitford's life was spent in a cartoonish Pursuit of Love (doubtless while wearing kosher Chanel, too) she ended up Loveless In A Chilly Emotional Climate. I guess the downside of a lifetime being professionally witty and gay and not appearing to take anything terribly seriously may be that when one finally does take something seriously, nobody will actually notice.

After a failed marriage and a deeply shallow friendship with a man called Hamish ('she wilfully refused to see he was homosexual,' rued her biographer), Nancy fixated on a Frenchman with appalling facial pustules and moved to Paris to be near him. Unfortunately he wasn't remotely interested in being anything other than good friends and, shortly after he announced his engagement to another, Nancy was diagnosed with cancer. I'm sure she carried on being witty and gay until the bitter end. Indeed, on her death bed, she told her sister, the Duchess of Devonshire, that she only regretted that she couldn't squeeze in one more day's hunting. 'It was a very happy, full life,' said another Mitford gel, Lady Diana, 'but the men in it... they were hopeless.' Which was not only presumptuous but, frankly, just a wee bit rich coming from the woman who married Oswald Mosley.

It was both a fashion moment and a cue for a bumper sticker - 'enlightened sexual beings do it with accessories'. The woman in the Kama Sutra had changed her blouse for each position, while the man was wearing the same red hat in each. 'There's quite a lot about who's putting whose hands, and where...' said the man from the Wellcome Institute, sounding archly Mitfordish, to Sanjeev Bhaskar, as they both pored over the source material in C4's Position Impossible. But despite its punning title, this was a largely sniggerless journey from Penzance to India in search of the seed of Eastern sensuality. Bhaskar seems like a nice bloke, but the only qualification for this job seemed to be the colour of his skin, which perhaps wasn't quite enough. The star of Goodness Gracious Me ('cheque please!') was clearly torn between the desire to deliver stand-up funnies or really getting to grips with his subject, and in the event he didn't quite manage either. At the Tantric Sex workshop in Penzance, where a very unattractive man called John and his 'assistant' Hannah were up to all sorts of tricks, like a saucy Paul Daniels and Debbie McGee, Bhaskar squirmed when he was urged to 'play the inner flute' and 'dance the snake awake'. That's the Kundalini energy 'snake' that lives at the base of one's spine, by the way, and you really can't fake it with a pair of old socks.

In India, our host was far more comfortable and, indeed, affected a bit of gravitas - though I'd imagine Varanasi does that to you. On the whole, though, Position Impossible was a hybrid of a documentary: it looked lovely, but there wasn't much depth to it. A bit like the illustrations, really. After all, who, aside from Nancy Mitford, wouldn't lose themselves in a union of spiritual and sexual ecstasy without also losing their hat?

I thoroughly enjoyed The Real Erich Von Daniken. When I was about 13, I was a big fan of Von D, just after the Harold Robbins phase and right before the Jane Austen crush kicked in. It all made deliciously perfect sense at the time: well, of course aliens had built the pyramids and Stonehenge, and naturally those sketches etched into the Peruvian earth were parking bays for spacecraft, and I needn't feel embarrassed because a whopping 59,999,999 other readers all agreed. It was a jolly good wheeze and all the more fun for being the work of a hotelier with a distinct lack of qualifications in archaeology or history or indeed any other relevant discipline.

Von Daniken at 65 now looks like a retired stand-up comedian - a chunky Swiss Bob Monkhouse, with an even more impressive filing system for all those cosmic jokes than Bob's. There's no doubt, though, that whatever scams he pulled to make himself a bestselling author, Von D was given a very rough ride when he was tried, ostensibly for embezzlement and fraud in relation to his hotel business, and then denounced in court by the prosecution as 'a validity-craving, lying, insecure, criminal psychopath with an hysterical character', before being given a three-and-a-half year sentence.

These days Von D plies his unfashionable trade at places like The Eclectic Viewpoint Convention in Texas and has just come up with his best wheeze yet: the Mysteries of The World theme park, scheduled to open near his home in Interlaken in 2002. Imagine: no jet lag, no steamy jungles accessed only by lengthy and terrifying bus journeys, just a short stroll from Peru to Egypt via Wiltshire, with a pit-stop for cosmic refreshments. I can hardly wait.

Though in pursuit of an early night, I caught ITV's trailer for Thursday's Tonight With... while channel-hopping. Hello? Trevor McDonald interviews Eminem's mother ? 'Is he a dangerous menace or is it just hip-hop hype?' Well, no sensible TV reviewer would dare miss it. In the event it wasn't Sir Trev, but Fiona Foster who spoke to Debbie Mathers, Eminem's spun-sugar haired, panda-eyed mom, currently suing her son for $10 million for defamation. This was almost the best, and easily the funniest part of what turned out to be National Eminem Week.

Anyway, it turns out that Eminem's success is really just the revenge of the nerds: Debbie told us how young Marshall got hit by a snowball thrown by a classroom bully at an impressionable age and so life was never quite the same again chez Mathers. Just a few years later he was to be seen shouting 'none of you fake arse bitches get a piece of my cake' during a birthday party, but one couldn't help noticing, however, that this threat was issued straight to camcorder, rather than at any of the presumably non fake-arse un-bitches who happened to be present, which tell-tale piece of performance sort of gives the game away. Eminem is about as much of a threat to society as was Von Daniken in his heyday and when Mathers proudly eventually shows off his plans for The Great Pop Scams theme park just outside Detroit, Malcolm McLaren will be seething in his bath chair.

webTitle: Family misfortunes

fields.headline: Family misfortunes
fields.standfirst: Game show host and funnyman Les Dennis is happy to talk about patching up his marriage to Amanda Holden after  that affair with Neil Morrissey - but it's too early to start laughing it off
fields.trailText: Game show host and funnyman Les Dennis is happy to talk about patching up his marriage to Amanda Holden after that affair with Neil Morrissey - but it's too early to start laughing it off
fields.body:
Before last summer, you may not have thought about Les Dennis that much. He was always there on the third channel, the chipper host of Family Fortunes, an old-fashioned game show that was beginning to look a little bedraggled next to its newer, flashier rivals. As cheesy and unreal as a Kraft processed slice, Les wasn't simply being eclipsed by the competition; he was also being gently shunted out of the limelight by his wife of six years, the actress Amanda Holden, as she made a name for herself in TV drama.

Then in May, something awful happened. Amanda and Les split up, after her on-set affair with Neil 'Men Behaving Badly' Morrissey came to light in the tabloids. I say 'awful' advisedly. It can't have been nice for any of those involved, and the redtops' coverage of events - the spurned embrace, the trial separation, the pale bands on the ring fingers - certainly brought out the prurient worst in me. Messy and humiliating, this was a Charles and Di for Heat readers. And oh dear, how we gorged on it.

If the summer had drawn to a close with a visit to the lawyers' office, Les Dennis might just have fallen off the radar altogether: after all, showbiz is littered with the corpses of failed relationships. But he didn't, because it became apparent that he and the missus were going to do the unexpected thing, the difficult thing, and give it another go. The peculiar consequence of this is that Les's profile is now at a career high, thanks to the dubious attentions of the tabloid press, which has always been fascinated by the 17-year age gap between the pair, and is currently daring the relationship not to go wrong again. Holden continues to take a kicking, whereas her husband, once considered irredeemably naff, is cast with patronising affection as the besotted victim ('Poor old Les'). How galling, how modern, that a very public cuckolding, and a brave attempt to repair a marriage, has had such an effect. Thirty years in light entertainment never brought him public recognition quite like this.

We meet at the Oldham Coliseum, where Les, a slight, pale man with none of the overweening presence associated with seaside specials, is appearing in Misery, a stage play adapted from the Stephen King novel. He's shortly to appear in Brookside. Neither role is straightforwardly comic, which is a departure for him. Cynics and conspiracy fans might assume that the scandal actually broadened his career options, giving him access to a new range of roles, but Les, in his rather hesitant way, is very indignant about this. The Brookside bods first approached him a few years ago when he was unable to fit the soap into his schedule, and the Oldham gig is not exactly flash - he's working for the Equity minimum - and is not expected to transfer. In any case, he's always done theatre: lots of rep and musicals. Indeed, last May, he was appearing in Chicago. Cynics and conspiracy fans noted the fact that he was playing the wronged husband, but he whipped the rug out from under them when he left the show to attempt a reconciliation.

Les hasn't done an interview since he and Amanda got back together, and to be honest I've got no idea why he wants to break the silence now. I'm expecting him to fob me off with lots of bonhomie, but it becomes apparent that he's more interested in smoke-signals, some very black and precise indeed, than smokescreens. We repair to a nearby café: more specifically to the grotty little dining room upstairs where he always has lunch, and which is never used by anyone else. Les, 47, does not play to the gallery. Gags are very thin on the ground, and he apologises for this at one point. There is something disconcertingly serious about him, something nervous and tired and earnest. At first he booms, rather than talks, and after a while I realise this is the sound of anxiety: bravado in the face of yet more curiosity.

At one point, an old man comes up the stairs with a cup of tea, and sits at the next table, goggling a bit. Les says, 'Are you OK? We're doing an interview here, is that all right?' and tries to keep going, but I can see from his eyes that he's completely thrown by having an audience. 'You come into this business and you know that [tabloid interest] is part of the life,' he says, lowering his voice. 'Jonathan Ross told me that it's fame tax. I like that phrase. It's something you have to deal with, but sometimes, when there are five cars outside your house at six o'clock in the morning, that's hard. It would be so easy to become angry.' When some more footsteps are heard on the stairs, he loses the thread. 'It's kind of difficult, maybe, to talk in front of someone else...' he whispers.

'Shall we go somewhere else?'

'Shall we? Yeah,' says Les with obvious relief, pushing aside his tuna sandwich. On the way back to the theatre, he says he had told his press agent earlier that he wasn't going to talk about his marriage, but 'I feel I've got to, to some extent. I have chosen to talk to you because I feel like I've got to say something. The thing that has really got to me is the fact that I've been portrayed as the good guy, for one thing. Or "the devastated guy". It's not as simple as that. I'm old enough to know what I want. Certain people have said in the press, "Oh Les, you know it's time to leave," but I want to say that A, the story that's out there isn't necessarily accurate; and B, it's nobody's position to tell me what to do.' There follows a rather surreal moment as Les Dennis awkwardly drops 'that which does not kill you makes you stronger' into the conversation. I don't know what I was expecting today, but it wasn't Nietzsche.

Les was born in Liverpool, one of four children. His dad managed a betting shop; his mother was a factory worker at Lucas Aerospace. At school, he joined the drama group - along with Clive Barker, who would become a successful horror writer, and Jude Kelly, who now runs the West Yorkshire Playhouse - but the comedy route seemed to offer a quicker hit, a better return. When he was 11, he stepped in front of his first real audience, at the Butlins in Pwllheli, and ran through his impressions. 'If you don't have a style of your own, it's easier to nick other people's. A lot of people do impressions to begin with. Mine were something to hide behind: I didn't have to be myself. I was a different person. That was immediately obvious when I started out.'

As a girl, his mother Winnie had her own showbiz dreams. She'd sung solo in the Liverpool Cathedral choir, and had been offered a spot in a talent show when she was 14, but her own mother had told her that she couldn't enter, that she had to go into the factories, so that was the end of that. When Les showed an interest in performing, Winnie supported him to the hilt. At weekends, she'd chauffeur him to talent contests in a Triumph 1100, bought with the two-shilling pieces she'd fed into her 'car box' over the years. 'My mum could see that I wanted to do it, but that I needed that nudge. She saw that I wanted to do it, so she encouraged me - but she wasn't a showbusiness mum, she didn't drag me there.' Les used to get terrible stage fright (still does), and heightened the tension by always turning up and putting on his costume much earlier than was necessary. Once in front of the curtains, his fears dissolved. Since he was always short on confidence, this sense of being in control, of belonging, became addictive.

The impressions gave way to a comedy 'set' and in 1974 he won New Faces . After that, he became a fixture on light-entertainment shows, and teamed up successfully with another young comic, Dustin Gee, who died of a heart attack in 1986. This pattern of professional success and personal tragedy is a recurrent theme in Les's life. In 1987, he landed Family Fortunes: a big break, but it meant he and his first wife, Lynne, who had met at school, had to leave the security of Liverpool and move to London with their son Philip. The process was difficult, and in 1990 he and Lynne divorced.

In 1993, when he was 39, he met Amanda, pretty, outgoing and 22, in Bournemouth, where she was appearing in a touring production of The Sound of Music. Three years later, they got married - and invited Hello!, which, as we now all know, is a bit like inviting all the fairies but one to a christening. 'It was at the time when we thought, "Maybe we need the publicity",' says Les, on the very edge of a smile. Hello! paid them in wedding photos: no cash changed hands. But there's little doubt this particular deal, the sale of their privacy, compromised them last summer. 'Yeah, I think we're less likely to do that again. We're going to be very choosy about what we do. Maybe it's important to not be a celebrity couple from now on.'

He wants to make it clear that he takes partial responsibility for what happened. 'I have to take account of the fact that in a seven-year marriage, I might have made mistakes as well. Not - never - infidelity,' he adds, stumbling over his words in his anxiety to make that plain. 'Nothing to do with other people. But maybe I was caught up in my work, which is what I've done before. I just mean that I'm not a picnic. That's what you see on television, this nice guy, but nobody's like that, it's not human. It's hard on your partner if that's how you're seen.

'Who knows what will happen in the future? Who knows - 10 years down the line, five years, 10 days? But I know Amanda and I will be in each other's life, in some capacity, always.' Look, he says, there are no kids involved, they could walk away tomorrow if they wanted to, but it comes down to this: he loves her, she loves him. 'And we're doing OK, thanks, despite what has been written. We're not prepared to give up.' At the moment, they're both staying in a flat in Manchester, where Amanda is filming a new drama, but in a few weeks she'll go back to their home in north London, and he'll be left on his own. When the subject of trust comes up, he lets me know that this is none of my business.

He knows how the situation looks: he's walked around it enough times. 'You see the thing is, if I sit here and defend Amanda, I sound like the saint again. I'm not the saint. But if I say I'm not the saint, it's a Catch 22: people will say, "Oh my God, isn't he coming across as just like this caring bloke." It's not as cut and dried as that.'

Les talks about his wife constantly with almost defiant pride, often referring to her when the conversation has moved into quite different territory. When I ask if the light-entertainment tag has hindered his attempts to be taken more seriously, he says: 'I'm always aware of that. But maybe that's my chip, my problem. My wife might say that. She'd say, "Come on, people are aware that you're better than that, don't be silly".' He believes that he has relied too much on Amanda's support: she was always there to prop him up, and that must have taken its toll on her. Success didn't sweep away his lack of confidence; if anything, it made the problem worse. 'I didn't believe in myself enough. And that can become difficult to cope with. I think I was always doubting myself, saying I wasn't very good, and maybe that was frustrating for her.'

Les has a theory about his lack of self-belief, and articulates it like someone who has done time on the couch. He thinks it was inherited from his dad, who 'couldn't believe that anyone from a working-class background could be an actor or an entertainer. "We can't do that. Get a bloody proper job!" ' As a boy, he was aware that his father was always terribly self-conscious. When they went out, he was always being told to pipe down, not to make a fuss, that people were looking. They weren't, of course. 'And that's the irony, because I've inherited what my dad had, and this time they are looking.'

I think back to his discomfort in the café. The shy funnyman - the sad clown! - trapped in a circus of his own devising: it's all too predictable, really. But somehow, being in the audience today isn't such a laugh.

webTitle: Nine die as US sub sinks trawler

fields.headline: Nine die as US sub sinks trawler
fields.trailText: Nine people were feared dead last night after a United States navy nuclear submarine fitted with state-of-the-art navigation equipment blundered into a collision with a Japanese fishing boat taking children on a study trip.
fields.body:
Nine people were feared dead last night after a United States navy nuclear submarine fitted with state-of-the-art navigation equipment blundered into a collision with a Japanese fishing boat taking children on a study trip.

President George W. Bush expressed his 'regrets and condolences' for the accident off the coast of Hawaii, which appeared to have killed four Japanese high school pupils, two teachers and three crewmen. Twelve people were injured.

US Coastguard ships and helicopters were searching for survivors last night, but hopes were fading for people trapped on the Japanese ship, the Ehime Maru, which sank minutes after the collision with the USS Greeneville.

The engine room of the 54-meter fishing boat was ripped apart when the Greeneville surfaced immediately below the Ehime Maru's bows about nine miles south of Waikiki. Of the 35 people who were on board for the study trip to fish for tuna and swordfish, only 26 were able to escape.

'Most were below deck in the rooms or galley,' said US Petty Officer Michael Carr, who interviewed survivors. 'After the lights went out, everyone started yelling that the water is coming into the ship. That's when most of the people we saw started fleeing.'

In Japan, where the news of the accident was met with sadness and bewilderment, the government set up a taskforce to coordinate its response as officials in the children's' home town of Uwajima fielded questions from worried parents. 'It's a bit chaotic,' said municipal official Masanori Mori. 'There's a great deal of shock.'

The Japanese Prime Minister, Yoshiro Mori said: 'The most important thing now is the search for the missing people. I pray that we will find them soon.'

US Secretary of State, Colin Powell, telephoned his Japanese counterpart, Yohei Kono, to apologise and pass on Bush's condolences. The navy began an investigation into why the five-year-old Greeneville, which is armed with Tomahawk missiles, made such a fundamental mistake despite clear safety procedures.

webTitle: 'The struggle is my life'

fields.headline: 'The struggle is my life'
fields.standfirst: Nelson Mandela timeline
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela timeline
fields.body:
1918 - Nelson Mandela born on July 18 in country district of Transkei, 600 miles south of Johannesburg. Father, of Tembu royal blood, stripped of chieftainship for insubordination.
1934-38 - educated at Methodist colleges Clarkebury and Healdtown.
1939-40 - studies at Fort Hare university, centre of black intellectual elite.
1941 - moves to Johannesburg. Works for a time in gold mines. Meets Walter Sisulu, through whom he is employed as an articled clerk by liberal white lawyer Lazar Sidelsky.
1943-49 - studies law at mainly white University of Witswatersrand.
1944 ¾ marries Evelyn Mase, Sisulu's cousin. Divorced 1957.
1948 - election of Afrikaner Nationalist government committed to more rigorous segregation policy of apartheid.
1950 - Mandela co-opted on to National Executive of African National Congress.
1952 - sets up first African law firm in South Africa with student friend and activist colleague Oliver Tambo. Joins Indians in Defiance Campaign, arrested for breaking curfew.
1954 - successfully defends his place on the roll of attorneys after prosecution by Law Society.
1956-57 - Treason Trial of 156 activists of all races; eventual not guilty verdict.
1958 - Mandela marries Winnie Madikizela.
1960 - Sharpeville massacre of 67 protesters by police on 29 March. Political temperature soars and ANC is banned on 8 April.
1961 - Mandela forced underground, declares in press statement written from hiding: "The struggle is my life".
1962 - Mandela tours Africa to gain support for the ANC's guerrilla army.
In November, sentenced to five years' imprisonment for incitement and leaving the country without a passport.
1963 - Rivonia trial begins on 3 December. Eight defendants - six of them black, two white - charged with sabotage designed to provoke revolution.
1964 ¾ the defendants are sentenced to life imprisonment on Robben Island.
1980 ¾ campaign by Percy Qoboza, editor of the black Post newspaper, to get Mandela freed.
1981 - Brent council names the first ever street after Mandela, leading to many more across the world.
1982 - Mandela moved from Robben Island to Pollsmoor prison.
1984 - township uprisings spark large anti-apartheid rallies in Europe and US.
1988 - Mandela's 70th birthday commemorated by Wembley concert.
1990 - Mandela freed from prison after 27 years, on 11 February.
1991 - Winnie Mandela given suspended sentence for her part in the 1988 abduction and murder of Stompie Seipei. Soon afterwards, she and Nelson separate.
1993 - Mandela wins Nobel Peace Prize, along with President FW de Klerk.
1994 - elected and inaugurated as President of South Africa following first free and democratic elections.
1997 - hands over ANC leadership to Thabo Mbeki in December.
1998 - Mandela marries for third time, to Graca Machel, widow of former Mozambique president, Samora Machel
. 1999 - Mandela's term ends. Thabo Mbeki wins Presidential election to succeed him.

webTitle: Life support

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Joaquín Cortes took to dance because of his glamorous uncle, the highly acclaimed flamenco star Cristóbal Reyes, who taught him when he was a child. In some ways, he's still very much a boy at heart
fields.trailText: Joaquín Cortes took to dance because of his glamorous uncle, the highly acclaimed flamenco star Cristóbal Reyes, who taught him when he was a child. In some ways, he's still very much a boy at heart.
fields.body:
Joaquín Cortes, 32 My first memory of Cristóbal is from when I was very young. I was living in Madrid at my grandparents' house. I think I first saw him dance when I was quite a lot older, but I wanted to start dancing because when I was little, Cristóbal was thought of as a hero in our family, you know? He got to travel all over the world and everyone would wait for him to come home with stories and presents, and I'd listen to his stories as if he were Marco Polo, so from a very young age I wanted to be like him. I just thought it would be great to travel around the world.

So I set up my own company, started to travel, and when I came to do the show Pasión Gitana we ended up working together. I didn't find working with him difficult. It was a very good show and a very special collaboration. I believe that every person is their own world, and my uncle is a very dedicated person, very much in love with his profession. Well, you can't really describe it as a profession - it's a whole way of life. And his life and his passion is dance. He's unusual, though, because although he's deeply immersed in the gypsy culture, he's still very disciplined, and the gypsy culture is usually much more about living in the moment, about feeling: there are no timetables. Yet within that culture, he is someone who has so much respect for his work. I think that was one of the things that made the biggest impressions on me when I was young.

Rather than being an inspiration to me, he was more a point of reference, a way of looking at how to succeed in my art. I wouldn't say he has faults, but he does have a very strong character, and people like us who are passionate about what we do - well, we have a strong temperament, and sometimes that has to come out. Cristóbal has a very strong temperament and so do I, and there have been times we've confronted each other on stage and it's got very 'heavy', there's been a lot of tension. But it's of the moment and it's always resolved. I have great respect for his work. I've been dancing now for nearly 20 years and I have great respect for both our careers.

Cristóbal Reyes, 54 Joaquín is my sister's son, so my first memory of him is of course the day he was born. But in a professional capacity, it was when I took him to audition for a children's television programme. They had to imitate Hollywood stars and dance all kinds of styles - classical, flamenco - and sing. Joaquín was chosen. He ended up being quite famous in children's television.

I realised when he was very young that he had great potential. I was his personal teacher in flamenco, but all his other dance teachers were amazed and excited about him. When I went to see him at a dance class - well, you could see straightaway he was a child prodigy.

I've been a professional dancer for 40 years now, and I worked with Joaquín for the first time for four years on Pasión Gitana. Working together has been a great experience, on a professional and a family level. At the moment, I'm directing, choreographing and dancing with this company that's called Pura Pasión, and he's co-produced the show with Señor Pino Sagliocco, so Joaquín's only involved on the production side. We haven't danced together since Pasión Gitana and we don't have any plans to, but you never know.

But when I work with him - well, I'm his uncle and I've raised him and watched him grow up, but I've also been his teacher, so 70 per cent of what you see in Joaquín is what I've given him, it's mine.

Joaquín is very disciplined, but he's a perfectionist, which is a big problem of his that at times gets too much. He likes to be a perfectionist in everything - at home, on the stage, in every part of his life. He was a typically mischievous, playful child, but from a very young age, he was dancing, training and studying. Inside he's still like a child, because he missed out on his childhood. That's why I think he's still very young in some ways - he gets excited about things, he doesn't go out drinking or smoking, he's got a football team and plays a lot. He gets enthusiastic like a child.

I just thought it would be great to travel around the world. So I set up my own company, started to travel, and when I came to do the show Pasión Gitana we ended up working together. I didn't find working with him difficult. It was a very good show and a very special collaboration. I believe that every person is their own world, and my uncle is a very dedicated person, very much in love with his profession. Well, you can't really describe it as a profession - it's a whole way of life. And his life and his passion is dance. He's unusual, though, because although he's deeply immersed in the gypsy culture, he's still very disciplined, and the gypsy culture is usually much more about living in the moment, about feeling: there are no timetables. Yet within that culture, he is someone who has so much respect for his work. I think that was one of the things that made the biggest impressions on me when I was young. Rather than being an inspiration to me, he was more a point of reference, a way of looking at how to succeed in my art. I wouldn't say he has faults, but he does have a very strong character, and people like us who are passionate about what we do - well, we have a strong temperament, and sometimes that has to come out. Cristóbal has a very strong temperament and so do I, and there have been times we've confronted each other on stage and it's got very 'heavy', there's been a lot of tension. But it's of the moment and it's always resolved. I have great respect for his work. I've been dancing now for nearly 20 years and I have great respect for both our careers. Cristóbal Reyes, 54 Joaquín is my sister's son, so my first memory of him is of course the day he was born. But in a professional capacity, it was when I took him to audition for a children's television programme. They had to imitate Hollywood stars and dance all kinds of styles - classical, flamenco - and sing. Joaquín was chosen. He ended up being quite famous in children's television. I realised when he was very young that he had great potential. I was his personal teacher in flamenco, but all his other dance teachers were amazed and excited about him. When I went to see him at a dance class - well, you could see straightaway he was a child prodigy. I've been a professional dancer for 40 years now, and I worked with Joaquín for the first time for four years on Pasión Gitana. Working together has been a great experience, on a professional and a family level. At the moment, I'm directing, choreographing and dancing with this company that's called Pura Pasión, and he's co-produced the show with Señor Pino Sagliocco, so Joaquín's only involved on the production side. We haven't danced together since Pasión Gitana and we don't have any plans to, but you never know. But when I work with him - well, I'm his uncle and I've raised him and watched him grow up, but I've also been his teacher, so 70 per cent of what you see in Joaquín is what I've given him, it's mine. Joaquín is very disciplined, but he's a perfectionist, which is a big problem of his that at times gets too much. He likes to be a perfectionist in everything - at home, on the stage, in every part of his life. He was a typically mischievous, playful child, but from a very young age, he was dancing, training and studying. Inside he's still like a child, because he missed out on his childhood. That's why I think he's still very young in some ways - he gets excited about things, he doesn't go out drinking or smoking, he's got a football team and plays a lot. He gets enthusiastic like a child.

webTitle: How the lost recordings were recovered

fields.headline: How the lost recordings were recovered
fields.standfirst: Painstaking work that brought historic speech to life
fields.trailText: Painstaking work that brought historic speech to life
fields.body:
A chance conversation brought together the little-known and inaudible court recordings with the rare equipment and expertise necessary to resurrect the sounds of Mandela's spellbinding speech.

Dr Rob Perks, the British Library's Oral History Curator, was at a conference in South Africa when he was told of the existence of the remarkable tapes.

"The National Archives of South Africa had been trying to recover the sound from the belts for years, and someone just happened to mention it to me, he said.

"We had one of the few remaining dictabelt machines in the world - I have very rarely seen a machine like it before in my life".

The dictabelts were developed in America by the Dictaphone company and were mainly used in offices in the 1950s and 1960s.

"Obviously some got to South Africa, where they were routinely used to record court proceedings", Dr Perks said. "There must be hundreds of dictabelts in the National Archives. The whole Rivonia trial was recorded".

Even when the belts were reunited with one of the rare machines needed to play them, the process of picking up the sound from the famous trial was lengthy and fraught with obstacles.

The dictabelts were only supposed to be used once and because they were stored folded flat there were creases in them that initially rendered them unplayable, even with the right equipment.

"Our technicians had to go to incredible lengths to modify and rebuild the surviving dictaphone equipment, just to get any sound at all. We used a hot plate to heat the belts up and take the crease out, enabling the needle to track in the groove", said Dr Perks. "The tracks are rather similar to those on an LP".

"It was also very difficult to determine the speed that the belt should be played at. In the end we used the hum that was recorded on the belt to determine the cycle of the original machine. Bearing in mind that the electric current is different in South Africa, we were able to tell from the pitch of the noise the correct speed".

Dr Perks said he was amazed how few recordings there are of Mandela from the 1960s. The tapes convey the drama of the future president's historic declaration.

"What amazed us, given the age and fragility of these dictabelts, is just how good the sound quality is".

webTitle: Henry Thomas

fields.headline: Henry Thomas
fields.standfirst: The return of the kid from ET
fields.trailText: It isn't, needless to say, a comeback. As far Henry Thomas is concerned, he has never been away. As far as the rest of us are concerned, he is still cute little Elliot, ET's friend. 'I hope eventually that people remember other roles when they think of me, but I am really mostly concerned with putting my best foot forward right now. Indictment was one of my best films. My favourites are Raggedy Man and Niagara, Niagara.' The problem is, of course, that everyone in the world saw ET, and very few saw Niagara, Niagara. But more will see All The Pretty Horses, the adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's gruff Western best seller, in which Thomas co-stars with Matt Damon and Penelope Cruz.

But more will see All The Pretty Horses, the adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's gruff Western best seller, in which Thomas co-stars with Matt Damon and Penelope Cruz.

Since ET, Thomas has been this far up the food chain only once before, in Legends Of The Fall. In the meantime, apart from decent indie films ( Suicide Kings), he has done bad TV movies and unnecessary sequels, including playing the young Norman Bates in Psycho IV: The Beginning. Thomas will be 30 this year.

He has lived all his life in or near San Antonio, Texas. Like a lot of actors - Keanu Reeves, Russell Crowe - he regards being in the movies as a poor second best to rock stardom, and has a band called The Blueheelers. His other obsession is with the Celts, as shown by his tattoos and an interest in the Welsh language.

All The Pretty Horses opens on 9 March

webTitle: Scenes from a marriage

fields.headline: Scenes from a marriage
fields.standfirst: Ingmar Bergman confronts his own life in a film which his ex-lover Liv Ullman directs. The result is art house cinema at its most refined
fields.trailText: Philip French: Faithless is a serious, adult film of the highest quality. It is art house cinema at its most refined, the kind of picture that many of us, at our moral best, most want to see when we go to the pictures
fields.body:
At Cannes last May the Palme d'Or and the best actress award should have gone to an outstanding Swedish movie, Liv Ullmann's Faithless and its leading actress Lena Endre. Instead they went to another Scandinavian film, Lars von Trier's terrible Danish musical Dancer in the Dark and its dim star, Björk. Trier's film, an aberration in an interesting career, is almost forgotten, while Faithless has taken its place in one of the great oeuvres in movie history, that of Ingmar Bergman.

Now in his eighty-third year, Bergman has only directed one film since the early 1980s, the television movie In the Presence of a Clown, a magisterial meditation on the function of theatre and cinema, shown at Cannes in 1998. It would have surely reached our small screens had British TV's film-buying officers not been such a league of frightened philistines.

He has, however, kept busy directing other people's plays for the Dramaten, Sweden's national theatre, and writing screenplays for other people to direct. Until now these screenplays have been for costume pictures, based on autobiographical fictions about the lives of his parents and his own early days. With Faithless he confronts his elderly self head-on through a writer called Bergman (played with characteristic melancholy dignity by his lifelong friend Erland Josephson) in a film stylistically indebted to the late Bergman manner that began with Persona, his first collaboration with Ullmann.

Solitary, white-bearded, stooping, this ageing hero is a Prospero figure, contemplating his life from the small, flat, rocky windswept island of Faro in the Baltic, where Bergman has regularly retreated from the world to write and think since the late 1950s, and which has provided the setting for several notable films, Through a Glass Darkly and The Passion of Anna among them. This Prospero's cell is a warm, uncluttered study, with shelves of LPs and CDs, a couple of leather chairs, a plain writing desk with notebooks and pencils. The stripped pine walls are bare but for a small photograph of August Strindberg, whose spirit hovers over the film, and through an internal window we can see a 16mm projector and some cans of film.

One of the first things we hear on the soundtrack are the tinkling, endlessly repeated opening bars of Papageno's aria in The Magic Flute, 'Ein Mädchen oder Weibchen wünscht Papageno sich', about the love and companionship that's missing from his life. In the opera, the aria conjures up Papageno's perfect soulmate, Papagena, and he is warned of the dire consequences that will befall him should he be unfaithful to her, a theme that echoes through Faithless.

In the film this yearning tune from Mozart is revealed as coming from a tiny music box, now in Bergman's possession, which passes from hand to hand among the film's characters. The Magic Flute we know to be Bergman's favourite opera, and in the 1974 film he made of it at the Drottningholm Theatre the entranced little girl in the audience is Linn, Ullmann's daughter by Bergman.

As Papagena appears as if by magic, so the beautiful young actress Marianne (Lena Endre) suddenly appears to Bergman in his study - at once his muse, an embodiment of a former lover and the protagonist of an expiatory drama he's writing. Bergman and Marianne act as if they're in a confessional, unable to decide who is the priest and who is the penitent.

It turns out that Marianne is the leading lady of the Swedish theatre, happily married to an internationally acclaimed conductor, composer and musician, Markus (Thomas Hanzon), by whom she has a gifted nine-year-old daughter Isabella. The well-ordered Markus, who pretentiously compares his love-making with Marianne to conducting The Rites of Spring, is contrasted with David (Krister Henriksson), a brilliant, wayward stage and film director, up to his neck in debts, and neglecting the two children of his broken marriage.

Marianne drifts into an affair with David that's consummated in a Paris hotel bedroom that, like the stylised décor of Cries and Whispers, is all red, as if we're within a pulsing human heart. They think they can control their affair without disturbing Markus, and when Markus does find out in a confrontation of farcical embarrassment, they believe they can start a new life together. In both they're mistaken. Markus is not the simple soul he appears to be; in fact in a coda he's revealed as monstrous.

But the worm in the apple of Marianne's Eden is apparent at the beginning. During their Paris assignation David is consumed by retrospective jealousy and its compulsion to seeking shameful, detailed revelations. This sado-masochistic confrontation, which forces a lover to make confessions that bring extreme pain to the interrogator, is seen by Bergman as central to the roles of the director and actor, and is what ultimately destroys the love between Marianne and David. As the sensitive child Isabella observes the painful proceedings and becomes a pawn in the emotional and legal battles, tragedy ensues. The tone and consequences are far worse than in Bergman's cool, analytical Scenes From a Marriage, where the husband and wife were played by Josephson and Ullmann and there were no children.

'Must it be this painful, must we always pay?' Marianne asks; the answer is a resounding yes. But in what the Bergman character calls this 'diversion before death', there is maturity in the understanding and magnanimity in the forgiveness.

Apart from Marianne, David is the only other character Bergman directly confronts, towards the end and quite briefly. We realise that he's an earlier version of the director himself when Bergman reaches out to his tormented doppelgänger and, in a deeply affecting moment, gives his cheek a comforting stroke. Perhaps we never get over the accumulated guilt and transgressions of a lifetime, but, so Bergman seems to be suggesting, at some stage we may earn the right to forgive our younger, less experienced selves.

Faithless is a serious, adult film of the highest quality. It is art house cinema at its most refined, the kind of picture that many of us, at our moral best, most want to see when we go to the pictures. You'll not find a better acted movie this year, and it puts Lena Endre into the front rank of world actors.

webTitle: Red highlights

fields.headline: Red highlights
fields.standfirst: To show cabbage off, you need pungent mustard and ham
fields.trailText: To show cabbage off, you need pungent mustard and ham.
fields.body:
Given that red cabbage and mustard are both members of the brassica family, it should not be surprising that they have an affinity for each other in the kitchen: a sulphurous compound is responsible for both the strong smell of cooking cabbage and for the sharpness of mustard. Black mustard (Brassica nigra) is one of three plants that can be made into the pungent condiment, along with yellow mustard and reddish brown Chinese mustard. The seeds are ground to make a smooth purée, or left whole to provide some texture.

Mosimann's is a decent brand of coarse-grained mustard, but a flavoured one helps to ring the changes. Those made by Highfield Preserves in Tiverton are variously seasoned with Devon cider, whisky, sundried tomato and hot sweet chilli. They developed from a kitchen-table beginning, when Jennifer Fraser used some of husband Ian's spare wine (they had a vineyard at the time) to mix the powder into a paste, and are available at various outlets: from the National Trust via Paignton Zoo to the Mary Sumner Shop (24 Tufton Street, London SW1; 020 7222 5533), often under an own label. The Mary Sumner Shop is a trading arm of MU Enterprises (hasn't the Mothers' Union come a long way) which is a charity supporting mother and family projects at home and abroad, and charges £2.99 for a 12oz (170g) jar.

Ordinary ham knuckles or shanks are easy to get, but superior ones are well worth seeking out. John Ward, the third generation to run his family business, Cheshire Smokehouse (Vost Farm, Morley Green, Wilmslow, Cheshire; 01625 548 499), can still lay his hands on good-quality pigs locally, but has to work hard to get them skilfully slaughtered. EU regulations have decimated the country's slaughterhouses, replacing perfectly good small-scale and local operations with fewer, bigger and less wieldy ones.

To take one example, veterinary fees of £80 an hour have to be costed in at the rate of two or three hours a day for most days of the week, which pushes small abattoirs out of business. But it is the small abattoir that produces the quality John Ward is after: properly hung meat with firm flesh and well-set fat. While supermarket pork will probably have undergone a muti-needle injection of brine (and polyphosphates, which help retain water, and thus increase the apparent weight) and be ready for sale in little more than 48 hours, his pork is dry-cured by being salted for three weeks. In terms of quality, he wins hands down. Expect to pay £2.50 for a ham shank, but in view of the £10 carriage fee, it is well worth stocking up on fine whole hams and first-rate bacon, smoked or unsmoked.

Nigel Jerrey takes a rather different approach. He, too, is the third generation of his family to cure hams and bacon - at Emmett's Store (Peasenhall, near Saxmundham, Suffolk; 01728 660 250) - and they have always used a traditional wet cure: not injecting, but soaking the joints of outdoor reared pigs for 10 to 14 days, pickling them in black treacle, brown sugar and Guinness for four to five weeks, then smoking the result for three to four days. Any moisture picked up during brining is evened out by loss during smoking. Whole hams are sold uncooked (7kg to 8kg at £10.50 per kg) or cooked (6kg to 7kg at £12 per kg).

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

webTitle: Well being

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: the art of health-enhancing flirtation, heart murmurs and saggy throats
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: the art of health-enhancing flirtation, heart murmurs and saggy throats.
fields.body:
'Sometimes it just takes a lady to smile and make your day complete.' So sang Jerry Jeff Walker, the country-singing roué of 'Mr Bojangles' fame. For PC purposes, obviously feel free to substitute 'gentleman' for 'lady', for it is this subject of the everyday social intercourse between us that I wish to expound upon today, or at least that aspect of it so finely developed by our cousins at the other end of the Channel Tunnel: flirting. The French have mastered this (fine) art almost to the point of it being a national cultural institution. But why, you may ask, in the context of alternative health, would I mention such a thing? Were I to be pontificating instead on the benefits of those other Gallic staples, red wine and garlic, you would hardly look askance, but if I posit the idea of flirting as invaluable for your self-esteem and hence your general wellbeing and by extension your immune system, I wonder whether your eyebrow starts spoiling for some self-raising action.

We, the natives of these Great British Isles, are not normally comfortable with flirting. Perhaps island life breeds insularity and a fundamental unease over personal boundaries, which makes full eye contact (the basic currency of flirting) uncomfortable for us. Perhaps we are still unwittingly held hostage by Victorian prudishness or maybe it's just the weather that makes us shy and reticent to reach out from our souls to strangers in the street or in a café. Because, let's face it, without alcoholic support we do tend to be a socially timid bunch. Not that I'm criticising - I find our awkward ways quite fetching and indeed indulge in them all too often myself.

Intrinsically, we all want to be acknowledged. Road, air, trolley and all the other new-fangled 'rages' we are now said to subscribe to result from feeling unacknowledged by strangers. As any driving instructor will tell you, a lot of this can be offset by initially establishing eye contact, for once eye contact is made, souls connect and you feel acknowledged. Once acknowledged, your basic sense of decency is evoked and it is hard to feel anger.

Not wishing to stray here into negative territory, however, let me return to my theme, namely that flirting is good for your immune system. As attested to by the vast sums of money spent annually in the UK by both ladies and gentlemen on cosmetics, toiletries, clothing, grooming, and even cars and interior design and other lifestyle accoutrements, that aspect of ourselves we most wish to be acknowledged for - whether consciously or otherwise - is our essential desirability, and yes, of course, status... which again leads back to desirability.

And what better way, other than becoming a celebrity or media star, which uses up inordinate amounts of valuable energy, to get your daily acknowledgment dose than from a bit of harmless flirting. I'm not in any way suggesting promiscuity or a new sexual revolution, simply the willingness to indulge in eye-to-eye contact and the occasional smile to make your day and theirs complete.

Flirting is the expression of the sexy part of your character. It doesn't make you a slut or libertine. There is a clear distinction between a brief soul-to-soul connection through the eyes, facial expression and general body language, and giving someone the come-on. Obviously the extent to which you take things is your business, but that is not the point. I'm well aware of the possible dangers of 'flirt signals' being misinterpreted and resulting in trouble, for which I deeply recommend proper self-defence training, yet I'd suggest that the benefits are worth the risk.

The beauty of a good flirt is that it need lead nowhere. You are neither being unfaithful to your partner nor to your better instincts when you smile and let flutter those lashes. You are merely bouncing a bit of harmless sexual energy between you that will help you both feel better about yourself, as a living artform, if you like, and more able to infuse any real-time relationships with more spark. In a long- term, monogamous relationship, it is also crucial that you flirt with each other, connecting your erotic selves through a moment of (heartfelt) eye contact as often as you can.

The French, from whom we stand to learn much in these matters, are sophisticated enough to flirt without self-consciousness, prudishness or feigned coyness, even (and often especially) when in the company of partners who never seem to display jealousy. They simply accept that, like fine wine, garlic (and possibly skin creams), it's good for your health.

Now if you find my suggestion in any way scandalous, do not read what follows, as it describes an ancient Oriental Taoist method for moving internal energy in such a way as to render you more sexually magnetic to others, and which, if practised every day for 90 days or so, will increase your personal flirtability factor to near Parisian levels.

Imagine being able to inhale through the soles of your feet, up the inside of your legs, into your perineum (between your legs), and up to the tip of your uterus or penis, and then being able to exhale from there, back down to your perineum, across the top of your thighs, and down the outside of your legs to the soles of your feet. Repeat this with mind and breath in unison up to nine times. Additionally, supplement it with some basic auto-suggestion along the lines of, 'I am sexy!', 'I'm so sexy!' or even, 'God, I'm so sexy!'

And please remember that feeling sexy and desirable is for everyone, as the ongoing iconic status of such (august) folk as Sir Sean Connery and Catherine Deneuve would confirm. I would say in closing, however, that for the sake of both propriety and basic aesthetics, winking should be eschewed, if at all possible.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I'm 32, and for 10 years have suffered from irregular heartbeats. It only seems to happen after drinking coffee or just before I get a cold. Is this anything to worry about?
James Recht, email

Although it is quite likely that this is due to deficient kidney chi, not holding the 'heart fire' sufficiently in check, it would be prudent of you to arrange a check-up with a good heart specialist, as it's possible you my have a heart murmur or leaking valve. However, assuming it's more of an energy disorder, you could benefit from taking hawthorn tincture and lily of the valley, eating lots of radishes and massaging the chest region with essential oil of rose. Additionally, visit a shiatsu or acupuncture specialist to boost the kidney chi and reduce heart fire if necessary. And, of course, reduce caffeine intake and perhaps indulge in a bit of yogic breath-control training.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I'm in my early 40s and am concerned that my throat is starting to sag and wrinkle. Is there any natural alternative to cosmetic surgery that you can suggest?
Andrea Newton, Maidenhead, Berks

In addition to massaging your throat on a daily basis using good-quality neck-firming cream as lubricant, with one hand on either side of your throat, with alternating movements in the manner of starting a fire by twirling a stick between your hands and using a good exfoliant to promote cell renewal, try, while sitting comfortably with spine straight, hanging your head back an inch or two with jaw open. Close your jaw slowly and feel the stretch through your throat. Hold like this for 30 seconds or so and return the head to upright slowly. As well as firming your throat, this treatment has the added benefits of stimulating your thyroid and clearing up sore throats.

webTitle: Chocoholics at work

fields.headline: Chocoholics at work
fields.standfirst: Depp, Binoche, Dench - every one is someone's favourite.  David Gritten joins the shoot of the Oscar-tipped Chocolat in a typical sunlit French garden - somewhere in Somerset
fields.trailText: Depp, Binoche, Dench - every one is someone's favourite. David Gritten joins the shoot of the Oscar-tipped Chocolat in a typical sunlit French garden - somewhere in Somerset
fields.body:
Dame Judi Dench, in the garb of an elderly French matron, shifted her weight in her canvas chair, wrapped her shawl round her shoulders and looked up from her tapestry work to peer balefully at a muddy English field. 'So here we are in Wiltshire,' she told me, a distinct edge in her voice. 'Or possibly Somerset.' Dramatic pause for effect. 'Do you know, it might even be Dorset.'

They have killer timing, these theatrical dames, especially when they strive for dry humour. I informed her that here, near the village of Bruton, we're in Somerset by a matter of a few miles. But one saw her point: this sodden, windswept part of the West Country seemed an odd location for a film set entirely in France.

It's also a prosaic place to shoot a movie whose star actress trades on a 'comment dit-on?' enigmatic quality. One can think of several kind things to say about Somerset, or possibly Wiltshire; but 'enigmatic' is not a word that swiftly comes to mind.

Yet there she was, Juliette Binoche, tramping across a field, her beautiful dark eyes darting shyly about her, her trademark vestigial smile dancing on her lips in perpetual celebration of some private joke. If she seemed vaguely out of place, it clearly suited her. 'I'm in a good mood,' she announced, giving a dazzling smile. 'I feel we're lucky as actors to be able to go to different countries and meet different people.'

This is a turn-up for the books. Journalists approach Binoche on film sets with trepidation; she is not known for being upbeat. I have observed her tense and moody on two previous films, though on seeing them one understood why. Damage (1992), counts as a rare lapse by its director, the late Louis Malle. That same year, in the abject disaster Wuthering Heights, she was miscast hopelessly as Emily Bronte's heroine Cathy opposite an uncomfortable Ralph Fiennes as Heathcliff.

This current film, an adaptation of Chocolat, based on the bestseller by Anglo-French author Joanne Harris, looks altogether more promising. Financed by Miramax, headed by that incorrigible Europhile Harvey Weinstein, it has been well received in America, and will have a glitzy première in London tomorrow. On Tuesday, it should receive several Oscar nominations; this year, Chocolat is the Miramax film to benefit from Weinstein's legendary, aggressive Oscar campaigning, which in previous years helped Shakespeare in Love, The English Patient, Il Postino and The Cider House Rules .

Chocolat is set in 1959 in a small, quiet, uptight French town, and is being shot partly in the West Country rather than France to qualify it as a British film, and thus save considerably - because of tax breaks - on its budget. Binoche plays Vianne Rocher, a striking looking Frenchwoman who settles there with her young daughter, and opens up a chocolate shop across the square from the church. She sells mouth-watering candies and has an uncanny knack of anticipating each customer's precise desires, which she satisfies with exactly the right confection.

Her talent for temptation brings her in conflict with the community's more self-righteous citizens, and the mayor (Alfred Molina) tries to run her out of town. Meanwhile Vianne allies herself with a band of travellers who live at the edge of town in poverty; one, a handsome wanderer named Roux, is played by Johnny Depp. 'This is a light piece, a happy piece,' Binoche said gaily in the warmth of her trailer. 'It's about chocolate, you know, how bad can that be?'

Clearly, then, Binoche likes this film, and with good reason; it puts her in distinguished company. There's Depp, Molina and Dame Judi, who plays Armande, a witch-like older woman in the town, and one of Vianne's early allies. The formidable Swedish actress Lena Olin is Josephine, a townswoman whose unhappy life is transformed by chocolate's healing powers. The great classical actor John Wood is Guillaume, an elderly citizen who finds rejuvenation in Vianne's candies. And legendary veteran French screen star Leslie Caron ( Gigi, An American In Paris) portrays a disapproving widow, Madame Audel.

Swedish director Lasse Hallström, still basking in the success of last year's The Cider House Rules, is corralling the whole troupe. Famously one of the world's most patient, affable directors, he is working for the first time with his wife Olin; his bonhomie makes the company cheerful enough to ignore the English weather.

Chocolat will count as a significant entry on Binoche's CV. Four years have now elapsed since she made the transition from European art-house icon to internationally recognised film actress. In The English Patient, she was a French-Canadian nurse in World War II traumatised by grief when her lover is killed in action. The film cleaned up at the 1997 Oscars, and Binoche became the first French actress in 37 years to win an Oscar, since Simone Signoret in Room at the Top. Hollywood was at her feet; a fortune was hers for the making. So what did she do? She returned home, and in what looked like bloody-mindedness made five French-language films in a row. Oh, and she took a role at Islington's Almeida theatre, in a production of Pirandello's play Naked. It paid £250 a week.

It has taken her this long to return to English-language filmmaking. Why did Binoche wait, rather than capitalise on her success in The English Patient ? She sighed impatiently. 'My aim is not to be an American star. Otherwise I would have moved there.'

She had long been declining Hollywood's entreaties. She turned down Steven Spielberg's offer to play the female lead in Jurassic Park, which went to Laura Dern; and she could have had Emmanuelle Beart's part in Mission: Impossible. In retrospect, then, her judgment seems admirable.

Rays of sunlight darted through the clouds, and Bruton became temporarily transformed into a sunlit day in the garden of a French cottage. Dench, Wood and Caron were among eight characters seated at a banqueting table, and Olin scurried around pouring wine. Then Binoche emerged, carrying a huge platter of seafood, and followed by French child actress Victoire Thivisol, who plays her daughter. Binoche smiled broadly: 'Bon appetit, everyone!' The assembled company went 'aaaah!' at the sight of the food. And Hallström murmured: 'Cut!' After four takes, he had his scene, and the cast dispersed. The mood seemed relaxed. In part, Binoche deserves the credit; lead actors as much as directors can dictate the mood of a set. Caron, who played her mother in Damage, observed that she has matured. 'Her personality has opened up so much,' she said. 'And I think it's because she has children now. I admire her level-headedness. Her attitude is very good-natured. Very few young women have that attitude of always being game.' Dench was equally complimentary: 'Juliette is so easy to work with. On our very first day, we had a big scene to do. There was no awkwardness, we just got on with it and did it, and it was lovely. She has a divine sense of humour, which I like.'

And Hallström noted: 'She's a great actress, Juliette. She's got taste. But this is a different venue for her too, I think. For once she's playing a character that's warm and outgoing and generous. It's different for her.'

Nothing, it seemed, could ruin Binoche's mood on this day. She is even relaxed about fame's attendant irritations: 'It's a question of choices. We were shooting recently in a French village, and people came along to see me. So I had lots of autographs to sign. You can decide: "I won' t do that, it's stupid." But it's like offering chocolate - it's about the gesture of doing it. You have to be open to other people, because your work makes some connection with them. Sometimes I wasn't in a mood for it, but you have to deal with your emotions, admit you don't feel like doing it and say to the person, "I'm sorry, this isn't the right time".' Usually, then, her celebrity doesn't become intrusive? 'Oh no. I mean, it's not as bad for me as it is for American stars. That's a completely different world. You become a prisoner.' And even when she's in a good mood, the feisty Mme Binoche is no one's idea of a prisoner.

Chocolat opens on 2 March. The Observer will be running special screenings - see paper on 25 February for details
