webTitle: The killing of a college boy

fields.headline: The killing of a college boy
fields.standfirst: It was the first day of term for 18-year-old Abdul Osman and his friends, the start of a new life of opportunity and independence. But by the end of the morning, he lay bleeding to death in the local police station. John Gibb chronicles five minutes of madness
fields.trailText: It was the first day of term for 18-year-old Abdul Osman and his friends, the start of a new life of opportunity and independence. But by the end of the morning, he lay bleeding to death in the local police station. John Gibb chronicles five minutes of madness.
fields.body:
The first day of a big trial at the Old Bailey is always a bit of an event. Barristers standing around the doors of the court, witnesses smoking on the benches outside, the jury waiting to be sworn in and the police team carrying boxes of documents into the exhibits room. It was 30 October last year when I first met Detective Chief Inspector Peter Ship, who was waiting for the judge to get some preliminary business in Court 15 out of the way. Ship looks like my kind of copper. Short back and sides, dodgy suit, not someone to mess with. He's been a detective in the Met for 24 years and now he runs a murder squad at Edmonton Green. A squad is a team of 20 and Ship has 18 murders on his books. This one was complicated. Five defendants, three of them juveniles, racial overtones. It has been a year coming to court and the police investigation has generated 3,000 pages of statements and transcripts.

11.30am and Judge Giles Forrester is ready to begin. Senior Treasury Counsel William Boyce, of silken voice and imposing presence, rises to his feet to open the case for the prosecution. The story he tells over the following month and a half could be refined down to no more than five minutes of irrational violence which was to shock and traumatise a community and blight the lives of at least two families.

On the morning in question, 13 September 1999, Southgate College in north London is busy with the registration of 1,200 new students. The town centre is full of 16- and 17-year-olds who have already signed on, been given a tour, and told to go away until the next day - the first day of term. College security guards are keeping an eye on newly arrived, heavily testosteroned 16-year-olds eager to mark out their territory, and the shops and restaurants in the town are perking up with the sudden increase in business after spare summer months.

Southgate is a racially diverse college. In spite of the variety of nationalities and the consequential cultural cocktail, there is no history of racial problems in the student community. Heather Barret-Mold, the vice- principal, says that on the rare occasions when there is a dispute, it is due to the implacable question of teenage hormones which, in her experience, cause trouble wherever adolescent children gather. 'We have 2,500 full-time students here and we do all we can to make sure the atmosphere is calm and welcoming,' she says.

At around 12.30pm, five young Somalis, having finished their business in the college, turn left out of the front gates and start walking along the road. They are on their way to Chase Side, the high street which runs through the centre of the town and carries on to Hadley Wood and the wastelands of the northern M25. A second group, made up of Afro-Caribbean and Asian boys, is lounging around on the pavement by a car parked on Ashfield Parade by the Southgate sorting office, just outside the college grounds. Both groups are dressed in trainers, coloured tops and chinos. One of the Asians, a short chubby youth, is noticeable for his spiky, greasy hair and a thin beard. His name is Bodrul Miah.

As the groups draw level, there is a brief verbal confrontation - no more than a minor exchange of discourtesies - which is over in a couple of minutes. It is the fag end of an altercation which took place on a college induction day the previous Thursday, between Mohammed Abdullahi, one of the Somalis, and an Asian called Avinash Aubeelack, who is not present on this second occasion. The origin of the dispute is unknown but, in the opinion of the police and the college authorities, was likely to be of the 'Who you looking at?' variety and nothing more. However, it is serious enough for the security staff to be called to calm everyone down.

Mustafa Osman walks over, talks to the group on the pavement and, believing that whatever dispute there was has now been amicably settled, offers his hand to Ryan Reid, one of the West Indians. When the gesture is rejected, Mustafa shrugs and, together with his four companions, carries on down the road towards the high street with the idea of visiting an arcade near the bus terminal for a game of pool before lunch at McDonald's. It is the Somalis' first excursion in the area and the five young men appear at this stage to have gone the wrong way, turning left before the bus station and walking down a curved road called Crown Lane which runs parallel to the high street.

When they reach the back entrance of Southgate police station, they decide to retrace their steps towards the college. As they walk back on the right-hand side of the street, they see the other group jogging down Crown Lane towards them. Anthony Alexander, one of the boys who was with them earlier, has now been replaced by Aubeelack. He is accompanied by Ryan Reid, Mohammed Basil Mollany, Marcus Oranu and Bodrul Miah, all students from Southgate.

The two groups come face to face outside Rodwin's toy shop, opposite an alleyway which runs down the side of the Rising Sun pub. It is unclear precisely what words are said at this stage. What is certain is that the verbal aggression degenerates into a fist fight started by Reid and Miah. As the first blows are struck, Reid passes a black-handled clasp knife to the spiky-haired Miah, who opens it up and conceals it behind his back before producing it seconds later, tossing it from hand to hand and lunging forward in an attack on Mustafa Osman, stabbing him first in the arm and then in the back.

As Mustafa shouts in pain and turns to get away, his cousin, Abdul Osman, produces a canister of mace and aims it in the direction of Miah. He then pockets the canister and attacks Miah, trying to take the knife out of his hand and punching him in the face as he does so. The fighting has erupted out of nowhere and for no clear reason. It progresses without any regard to witnesses or passers-by as all 10 boys become involved.

In the centre of the melee, Miah now turns his full attention on Abdul Osman and begins stabbing him violently. Holding the knife in his right hand, he plunges it repeatedly into the Somali's torso. Witnesses describe the stabbings as a series of fast, sweeping movements which sound like someone beating a carpet. Six cuts are later found in Osman's jacket. Osman, unable to defend himself, suffers wounds to his stomach before a final, dreadful blow as Miah plunges the knife into his neck, slicing through the carotid artery. The blow is sufficiently violent to cut through two thick layers of leather in Osman's jacket collar and penetrate four inches into his flesh.

The assault against the Somalis continues across the road. There is no dialogue between the groups, just the desperate expletives and shouts of hand-to-hand fighting. A second knife is produced by Aubeelack, who is unable to use it before it is taken from him by Abdullahi. Now the groups begin to separate as Reid and his associates start to appreciate the enormity of what they have done.

Abdul Osman knows that he has been badly hurt. The blood is pumping from his neck and out of his nose and mouth. He spins round, runs across the road and down the alleyway beside the Rising Sun. By the time he reaches Chase Side, about 100 yards away, he has lost a lot of blood. He turns left and begins to limp along the pavement towards the police station, haemorrhaging as he goes. His route is marked with pools of blood; the road, the pathways and the brick walls of the alleyway are sprayed with dark arterial blood. He is dying as he runs.

Mustafa Osman, unarmed and badly injured, also decides to get away and runs down Crown Lane away from the skirmish. After a while, Miah, who has set off in pursuit, calls it a day and returns to his associates, saying, 'Let's go after the other one.' Mustafa, however, has collapsed on the pavement and is given first aid by a female passer-by. Miah, coming down from his blood lust, leaves the scene and makes his way home by bus to Tottenham to clean himself up.

Miah is covered in blood, both from the wounds he has inflicted on Abdul Osman and from a cut on the top of his buttocks. There is no clear explanation for this wound, although the police believe that, while attempting to hide the blood-stained knife, he tucked it into his trousers and stabbed himself. He has the wound stitched and dressed at the North Middlesex Hospital, claiming he slipped while climbing over a fence.

Immediately after the fight, Abdi Hassan, a Somali and a cousin of Mustafa Osman, escapes to the high street to find a phone where he can call for assistance. He runs through the bus depot to the White Hart pub, where he dials 999. Both groups are now dispersing, fast. Abdul Osman, helped by Mohammed Mohammed, the fifth member of the Somali group, has managed to reach the police station. Weak from loss of blood, he half crawls and is half carried up the steps of the building. He manages to reach the reception area, where he loses consciousness and falls to the floor.

Back in Crown Lane, Abdullahi, Abdul Osman's cousin, starts to pursue Ryan Reid and another West Indian, Marcus Oranu. The three boys run down the alleyway and turn back to the college. As he chases them, Abdullahi, mad with rage, once again confronts Aubeelack, who has also left the fight and is now standing outside the college gates. As they struggle, Aubeelack repossesses the weapon and in the process wounds Abdullahi in the wrist. Aubeelack now runs away from the scene. The knife is never found.

Abdullahi returns to the town centre and follows the trail of blood from Crown Lane back to the police station, where he pushes his way through the crowd gathering outside the building, runs up the steps and looks through the door into the reception. He can see Osman in a pool of blood on the floor and hears a policeman say, 'The boy's dead.'

The sight of his dead cousin has a devastating effect on Abdullahi. He leaves the police station, dodges the police who try to stop him, and runs wildly back to the college; witnesses later describe him as 'rabid'. As he arrives at the gates, he sees Miah's younger brother, Nural, a boy he has known since secondary school. There is now uproar in the college, underlined by the sound of police sirens. As Abdullahi, bleeding heavily from his cut wrist, starts to attack Nural, shouting, 'Your brother's just stabbed Abdul,' the first police car arrives on the approach road.

Abdullahi, pursued by a woman police constable, now runs into the college, where he sees Reid. He attacks him, shouting 'There's the man who stabbed my cousin.' Reid runs, pursued by the police, and is eventually arrested by the WPC. It is 12.50pm - 20 minutes since the five Somalis left Southgate college on their way to McDonald's.

The police, faced with this sudden and completely unexpected eruption of violent disorder, have done what little they can to make Abdul Osman comfortable. The reception office has been converted into a casualty station, but Abdul's wounds are too serious to be dealt with by first aid and the air ambulance is called from the London Hospital at Whitechapel. Alarmed that a pitched battle has been fought in Southgate town centre, the police cordon off the town and traffic begins to crawl to a halt throughout north London. The air ambulance lands on a roundabout and paramedics are with Osman within 60 seconds. They perform open-heart surgery on the floor of the police station, but can do nothing to save him. Abdul Osman is pronounced dead on the way to hospital.

Police response to the murder is immediate and intense. They are faced with a teenage black boy who has been stabbed to death in London just a matter of weeks after the publication of the Macpherson report. What's more, he has died in a police station. Within minutes of Osman's death, the forensic teams from Edmonton are working at the scene of the battle and a 20-strong murder squad under Peter Ship is in place.

Meanwhile, Bodrul Miah, now back in his home, sets about altering his appearance, shaving his head and beard and disposing of the clothes he has worn during the fight. Miah's father, Basharath, arrives home at seven in the evening and between them they decide he should leave the country. Basharath arranges for an emergency passport and buys his son a one-way ticket to Bangladesh for the morning of 15 September at a cost of £251. Two days after the killing in Southgate, Bodrul Miah is on his way out of the country.

It is a difficult investigation. There are many witnesses, but most are reluctant to come forward. Those who do are confused about what they have seen. No weapons are ever found. The murder is the result of 10 boys fighting each other in parallel streets at the same time. There is no obvious motive. It is over very quickly and finishes with the protagonists leaving the area at great speed in different directions. The scene of death is complex, with trails of blood leading in all directions. To make it worse, apart from the floor and walls in the police station, the blood is outside and rain is forecast for that night. The crime area, which includes three busy main roads, remains cordoned off by the Metropolitan Police Tactical Support Group until the following morning.

The postmortem is carried out within hours of the crime and the police know they are dealing with a murder. Reid is under arrest and the police are certain that most, if not all, of those involved are students at Southgate. They have statements from the surviving Somalis and are beginning to piece together the complex details of the fight. The word which no one mentions is 'race'.

I talk to a bus driver who was on duty in the Southgate depot on the day of the killing. 'We believed it was a race murder,' he says. 'The Somalis are a different culture, a race apart, and they were picked on by the Asians because they are peaceful people, but nobody will admit it. Nowadays, a white man kills a black and all hell breaks loose; black kills another black and it's an embarrassment.'

The police, however, deny that it is a racial incident, as do the social services, local Enfield MP Steven Twigg, the college and everyone involved in the analysis of what has happened. The local population of Southgate, however, seems to be of a different opinion and the word in the Rising Sun is that it is a 'tribal' matter which got out of hand.

The police admit to concern about local unrest in the streets and go quickly to the college authorities for help. DI David Osborne, who is given day-to-day charge of the investigation, tells me, 'Without the college, we would have struggled. Its CCTV system helped us trace the movements of both groups and meant we could dispose of problems caused by disputes over who actually took part in the fight. We were able to produce a clear picture of Bodrul Miah before he changed his appearance and prove that Aubeelack was involved in the fight. The Somalis and many of the street witnesses identified him as the short, fat Asian - the aggressor with the knife. We had to deal with the local community, set up liaison officers to help the parents and decided to create a multi-agency group which would keep the various communities in touch. The priority was the safety and peace of mind of the children in the college.'

'We never treated it as a crime caused by racial hatred,' says DCI Peter Ship. 'There was no history of racial conflict at Southgate College. We saw it as an unjustified assault by five teenage boys during which an innocent victim was fatally stabbed.'

The police piece together the movements of the two groups. Within a week, they know that Miah is involved but has no motive. They know he vanished on the day before he is due to start at college, but have no idea of his whereabouts. They interview his father, expecting to find him at home, but Basharath claims he has lost touch with his son and believes he is working outside London.

The police assume Miah is still in Britain and settle down to a long period of detailed investigation. They recreate what happened during the fight and they work out from the video evidence and witness statements who was involved. Within a couple of months, they know who brought the weapons and they know where everyone was including Bodrul Miah. Basharath's detention five months after the murder is followed by Nural's visit to Bangladesh. Bodrul Miah is told that his father is under arrest and agrees to return to the UK. He gives himself up at Edmonton Green police station on 8 March 2000.

There are five counts on the indictment. Reid and Miah are charged with murdering Abdul Osman; Miah and Aubeelack with wounding with intent to do grievous bodily harm to Mustafa Osman. Miah, Reid, Mollany, Oranu and Aubeelack are charged with violent disorder and Basharath Miah with attempting to pervert the course of justice.

The case comes to trial at the Old Bailey on 30 October 2000. Mollany and Oranu plead guilty to violent disorder, having named Miah as the murderer in their police interviews. Their evidence could consequently not be used in court.

Abdul Osman had been a bright 18-year-old, one of a family of 10 who had been brought up single-handedly by their mother, Hawa Farah, after their father left them and went to live in the north of England. The family had emigrated to London from the Yemen and had lived in Edmonton for 14 years. The other Somalis in the group, Mustafa Osman, Abdullahi, Hassan and Mohammed, were all close friends or relatives who had known each other for years. None of them was known to be violent.

Throughout the trial, the police liaison officer, Bob Kendall, drives Abdul's mother and her daughter Zainab to court, where she sits only a few feet away from the boy accused of murdering her son. The two women come to the Old Bailey every day and during Ramadan they leave the court at noon to say prayers in an upstairs room. I talk to them in the Old Bailey canteen. They tell me that Abdul was no troublemaker, that he had lots of friends and that they miss him dearly because he made his mother smile and she was always happy when he was there. 'The police took us to where he was killed and it was very hard because we walked where he walked. People need to understand the effect the murder of a son has. I wouldn't wish it on anyone in the world.'

The trial is a lengthy, solemn, occasionally bad-tempered affair. Senior Treasury Counsel William Boyce, prosecuting, is forced to translate much of the Afro-Caribbean jargon and to meticulously dissect and repeat for the jury every choreographic detail of the fight on Crown Lane and every nuance of the defendants' behaviour. Vera Baird QC defends Miah, who declines to give evidence after Reid is comprehensively filleted by prosecuting counsel. She is forced to rely on a defence of mistaken identity. There is a total of 14 wigs in court and the complexities of the proceedings in the end result in a three-month trial.

Miah's rapid disappearance after the fight is explained away as attending a family wedding. But why he flies to Bangladesh and completely changes his appearance on the day he was due in college is impossible to explain away. Reid lies repeatedly in the witness box - to the despair of his counsel, Sally O'Neill. He also claims that he knows none of the other defendants, in spite of the fact that the police formally cautioned him with Miah and Mollany after catching them smoking pot in a car in Epping Forest in April 1999.

There is an inevitability about the result. On Tuesday 23 January, after three days' deliberation, the jury convicts Miah of murder, convicts Miah and Aubeelack of attempted wounding, convicts Reid, Mollany, Oranu and Aubeelack of violent disorder and convicts Basharath Miah of attempting to pervert the course of justice.

Judge Forrester delays sentencing for a month and expresses great sympathy and admiration for Abdul Osman's family for attending court every day.

There is often a sense of anticlimax at the end of a long criminal trial. Barristers and solicitors stand around making small talk and saying goodbye. The brief camaraderie between court staff and the police fragments as the boxes of evidence are carried away to be stored in damp cellars somewhere in the capital, and hacks from the press benches loiter expectantly, trawling for indiscretions.

The last days of the trial of Bodrul Miah and his associates are no different. After Basharath Miah and Reid briefly return to face Judge Forrester and have their bail applications rejected, half a dozen members of the police team gather outside the court doors trying to decide where to go for a pint or two. Peter Ship, now promoted to Detective Superintendent, shows no overt sign of triumph. 'It was a difficult operation for us, but our multi-agency approach worked well and we're happy with the result.'

Late on the Tuesday afternoon, I watch Abdul Osman's mother and his sister leaving the Old Bailey for the last time and stepping out into an empty world. They talk to me of their gratitude to the police, the witnesses who came forward, the prosecuting counsel; the transient people of the law who had filled the family's lives for a year. But justice does little to heal the wounds of the bereaved and Abdul's mother has persistently refused counselling. Now they are alone with memories of a loved one violently done to death.

The judge's comments on the women's dignity and courage and their constant presence in court almost certainly had an effect on the jury's deliberations. But their son and brother had been taken away, simply because a young man had gone to college armed with a knife. It's impossible to know how many lives will be damaged by this one act of stupidity.

There were 131,500 serious assaults in London between April 1998 and the end of March 1999. It is not racism which has become endemic in society, it is violence.

The police, however, deny that it is a racial incident, as do the social services, local Enfield MP Steven Twigg, the college and everyone involved in the analysis of what has happened. The local population of Southgate, however, seems to be of a different opinion and the word in the Rising Sun is that it is a 'tribal' matter which got out of hand. The police admit to concern about local unrest in the streets and go quickly to the college authorities for help. DI David Osborne, who is given day-to-day charge of the investigation, tells me, 'Without the college, we would have struggled. Its CCTV system helped us trace the movements of both groups and meant we could dispose of problems caused by disputes over who actually took part in the fight. We were able to produce a clear picture of Bodrul Miah before he changed his appearance and prove that Aubeelack was involved in the fight. The Somalis and many of the street witnesses identified him as the short, fat Asian - the aggressor with the knife. We had to deal with the local community, set up liaison officers to help the parents and decided to create a multi-agency group which would keep the various communities in touch. The priority was the safety and peace of mind of the children in the college.' 'We never treated it as a crime caused by racial hatred,' says DCI Peter Ship. 'There was no history of racial conflict at Southgate College. We saw it as an unjustified assault by five teenage boys during which an innocent victim was fatally stabbed.' The police piece together the movements of the two groups. Within a week, they know that Miah is involved but has no motive. They know he vanished on the day before he is due to start at college, but have no idea of his whereabouts. They interview his father, expecting to find him at home, but Basharath claims he has lost touch with his son and believes he is working outside London. The police assume Miah is still in Britain and settle down to a long period of detailed investigation. They recreate what happened during the fight and they work out from the video evidence and witness statements who was involved. Within a couple of months, they know who brought the weapons and they know where everyone was including Bodrul Miah. Basharath's detention five months after the murder is followed by Nural's visit to Bangladesh. Bodrul Miah is told that his father is under arrest and agrees to return to the UK. He gives himself up at Edmonton Green police station on 8 March 2000. There are five counts on the indictment. Reid and Miah are charged with murdering Abdul Osman; Miah and Aubeelack with wounding with intent to do grievous bodily harm to Mustafa Osman. Miah, Reid, Mollany, Oranu and Aubeelack are charged with violent disorder and Basharath Miah with attempting to pervert the course of justice. The case comes to trial at the Old Bailey on 30 October 2000. Mollany and Oranu plead guilty to violent disorder, having named Miah as the murderer in their police interviews. Their evidence could consequently not be used in court. Abdul Osman had been a bright 18-year-old, one of a family of 10 who had been brought up single-handedly by their mother, Hawa Farah, after their father left them and went to live in the north of England. The family had emigrated to London from the Yemen and had lived in Edmonton for 14 years. The other Somalis in the group, Mustafa Osman, Abdullahi, Hassan and Mohammed, were all close friends or relatives who had known each other for years. None of them was known to be violent. Throughout the trial, the police liaison officer, Bob Kendall, drives Abdul's mother and her daughter Zainab to court, where she sits only a few feet away from the boy accused of murdering her son. The two women come to the Old Bailey every day and during Ramadan they leave the court at noon to say prayers in an upstairs room. I talk to them in the Old Bailey canteen. They tell me that Abdul was no troublemaker, that he had lots of friends and that they miss him dearly because he made his mother smile and she was always happy when he was there. 'The police took us to where he was killed and it was very hard because we walked where he walked. People need to understand the effect the murder of a son has. I wouldn't wish it on anyone in the world.' The trial is a lengthy, solemn, occasionally bad-tempered affair. Senior Treasury Counsel William Boyce, prosecuting, is forced to translate much of the Afro-Caribbean jargon and to meticulously dissect and repeat for the jury every choreographic detail of the fight on Crown Lane and every nuance of the defendants' behaviour. Vera Baird QC defends Miah, who declines to give evidence after Reid is comprehensively filleted by prosecuting counsel. She is forced to rely on a defence of mistaken identity. There is a total of 14 wigs in court and the complexities of the proceedings in the end result in a three-month trial. Miah's rapid disappearance after the fight is explained away as attending a family wedding. But why he flies to Bangladesh and completely changes his appearance on the day he was due in college is impossible to explain away. Reid lies repeatedly in the witness box - to the despair of his counsel, Sally O'Neill. He also claims that he knows none of the other defendants, in spite of the fact that the police formally cautioned him with Miah and Mollany after catching them smoking pot in a car in Epping Forest in April 1999. There is an inevitability about the result. On Tuesday 23 January, after three days' deliberation, the jury convicts Miah of murder, convicts Miah and Aubeelack of attempted wounding, convicts Reid, Mollany, Oranu and Aubeelack of violent disorder and convicts Basharath Miah of attempting to pervert the course of justice. Judge Forrester delays sentencing for a month and expresses great sympathy and admiration for Abdul Osman's family for attending court every day. There is often a sense of anticlimax at the end of a long criminal trial. Barristers and solicitors stand around making small talk and saying goodbye. The brief camaraderie between court staff and the police fragments as the boxes of evidence are carried away to be stored in damp cellars somewhere in the capital, and hacks from the press benches loiter expectantly, trawling for indiscretions. The last days of the trial of Bodrul Miah and his associates are no different. After Basharath Miah and Reid briefly return to face Judge Forrester and have their bail applications rejected, half a dozen members of the police team gather outside the court doors trying to decide where to go for a pint or two. Peter Ship, now promoted to Detective Superintendent, shows no overt sign of triumph. 'It was a difficult operation for us, but our multi-agency approach worked well and we're happy with the result.' Late on the Tuesday afternoon, I watch Abdul Osman's mother and his sister leaving the Old Bailey for the last time and stepping out into an empty world. They talk to me of their gratitude to the police, the witnesses who came forward, the prosecuting counsel; the transient people of the law who had filled the family's lives for a year. But justice does little to heal the wounds of the bereaved and Abdul's mother has persistently refused counselling. Now they are alone with memories of a loved one violently done to death. The judge's comments on the women's dignity and courage and their constant presence in court almost certainly had an effect on the jury's deliberations. But their son and brother had been taken away, simply because a young man had gone to college armed with a knife. It's impossible to know how many lives will be damaged by this one act of stupidity. There were 131,500 serious assaults in London between April 1998 and the end of March 1999. It is not racism which has become endemic in society, it is violence.

webTitle: Health: Singing lessens stress

fields.headline: Good vibrations
fields.standfirst: Take a deep breath and let it all out... Wendy Moore sings her way to a stress-free life
fields.trailText: Take a deep breath and let it all out... Wendy Moore sings her way to a stress-free life.
fields.body:
The woman twists and contorts her body, wheeling and spinning across the room, her voice rising in ecstatic whoops and yells then dropping to mournful moans and grunts before she collapses in a heap on the floor. And then it's my turn.

I came here seeking a brief escape from the stresses and strains of everyday modern life. But right now my instinctive stress flight response is in full throttle and urging me to sprint for the door, run like hell, anything rather than stand up and perform spontaneous singing and dancing in front of a bunch of complete strangers.

But there is no graceful way out. And something about the trance-like beat of the African drums, the unearthly hum of the harmonium, combined with the soothing candle-lit glow of the room and - perhaps most of all - the serene encouragement of our teacher compels me to get up and twirl, stomp, groan and yell like the best of them.

By the end of the two-hour session, it feels safe, normal and even cathartic to jump around and sing out in a way most of us have not done since music and movement classes in primary school.

This is natural voice therapy. The weekly workshops in north London - and another in southwest London - are meant to release hidden emotions and anxieties, and promote relaxation and mental healing through singing. Using a mixture of mantra, Sanskrit chanting, Indian scales and pure improvisation, coupled with movement and balance drawn from various cultures, the aim is to 'free the inner voice'.

According to Nikki Slade, who teaches the classes, singing for the soul is going to become as popular as yoga within the next 10 years. 'Everyone will be doing some form of chanting or singing,' she predicts. 'It will be as important as drinking water.'

Of course, singing is already natural to most of us. Whether we do it secretly in the shower or car, or in full public view in church or the football stadium, most of us sing for pleasure. We all know the uplifting boost of singing in harmony with others, while hearing the blues can evoke grief in anyone. But is there more to singing than this transitory change of mood?

Slade, a professional singer and actress who took up voice therapy 10 years ago, believes the voice is the key to good mental health. And while the idea may sound a bit kooky, she is fast winning acclaim for her work from mainstream psychiatrists and mental health organisations.

'The voice is a powerful instrument, physically, mentally and emotionally,' she says. 'In singing, you are communicating with a higher intuitive awareness that we all have.' She believes singing of any kind - alone or in a group - is therapeutic but that coming together with the explicit intention of using voice to express deep-down emotions can be '10 times as powerful'. She adds: 'I believe in the beginning, there was sound; in the beginning, there was vibration. We are all in an orchestra on this planet.'

She is herself testimony to the healing power of song. After spending 10 years singing and acting in the West End, in 1989 she suffered a mental breakdown - or 'psychotic episode' - and spent a month on a psychiatric ward. Singing kept her going. 'The one thing that really mattered was singing,' she recalls. 'I sang every day.' The experience was a watershed. When she recovered, she spent a year training as a 'natural voice coach', then started her own groups.

Her workshops and residential weekends now attract people as diverse as computer consultants, architects and office workers. Through voice and movement, Slade seeks to release and develop the emotional needs of each participant. It is not unusual for people to break down in tears during a group, while one woman found a session so liberating she promptly resigned from her much-detested job.

'It is completely unique,' says Sarah, 28, a drama therapist who has been coming to the north London group for six weeks. 'I really enjoy the freedom - the combination of voice and body. I think it works at a very deep level. I go away feeling more in touch with myself.'

Another regular attender, a receptionist who does not want to be named, adds: 'I think we are getting more and more stressed as people. This is just a place to be really loopy.'

But the link between voice and mind may go even deeper. For the past seven years, Slade has been working with a group of people recovering from serious mental-health problems. Set up initially as a form of music therapy for a drop-in centre in Chiswick, the group has now spawned its own band, Carsos, which has just produced its first CD. The sessions began using vocal exercises as a means of communication with people in the group, explains Slade. But over the years, the emotions expressed evolved into a repertoire of songs.

Last year, with a £20,000 grant from mental-health charity Mind, and help from professional musicians and recording technicians, Carsos produced its CD, Breakthrough , which contains 13 accomplished and evocative songs. Among the band members is George Noel, who wrote and sings a track called 'Feeling Free'. The meaning of the title becomes clearer once you discover that Noel, who is diagnosed as schizophrenic, was released after a long stretch in Broadmoor high-security hospital eight years ago. Now living in a hostel, he says: 'Music is one of the best methods of communication.'

Paul Mathew, another Carsos member and manager of the drop-in centre, has also experienced the healing potential of singing. When he suffered a psychotic breakdown 10 years ago and was incarcerated in Brixton prison for four weeks following a trail of minor crimes, he kept his spirits high by singing his favourite pop songs. 'Singing kept me in touch with myself,' he says. Now recovered, and having retrained as a psychotherapist, he says the voice workshops have made a significant contribution towards helping group members.

'It has had an enormously transforming effect,' he says. 'I have seen huge changes in self-esteem, confidence, socialising ability, everything.'

Although music therapy has long been used in the NHS to work through various problems with children and adults, it normally involves playing instruments. The value of using the voice for healing is a new idea. But now Slade's work is attracting support from NHS psychiatrists, while Carsos has been invited to perform next summer at the culmination of a year-long festival of the mind and arts hosted by the Royal College of Psychiatrists (RCP).

Dr Larry Culliford, a consultant psychiatrist in Brighton, who introduced Slade's work to the college, is a firm supporter. He believes singing works on two levels: by physically encouraging people to breathe and use their whole body better, and emotionally helping them find creative resources.

'There are hidden reserves of strength and hope, and indeed happiness, that singing somehow spontaneously helps people to find. It may be this is one of the ways in which mind and body are interrelated.' says Dr Culliford.

'One cannot overestimate the value of using your voice in a regular way,' he adds. 'I think it is just a naturally exuberant thing for humans to do.'

Another enthusiast is Professor John Cox, president of the RCP, and himself a semi-professional singer - 'a traditional English tenor' - who performs annually at the Edinburgh fringe festival. He believes singing can make a major contribution to mental health. In Victorian times, he says, asylums had their own orchestra and choir, conducted by the chief doctor.

'All singing can be liberating, whether it is "Auld Lang Syne" at the end of a party or "Abide With Me" at a football match,' says Professor Cox, who will help launch the college's mind and arts festival this summer with a rendition of Vaughan Williams' 'Ten Blake Songs'.

At the same time as catching on in Britain, singing therapy is also becoming a popular movement worldwide. Voice tutor Chloe Goodchild, who taught Nikki Slade, recently used singing as therapy in a high-security prison in New York and has also worked with politicians - she declines to divulge who - in Britain. One of her pupils is currently working with women damaged by war in Kosovo, who are now exchanging songs with women in Northern Ireland. Goodchild believes: 'Singing can cut through personal history and get right to the heart of the matter and to the soul of who you are.'

Music therapist Margaret Lobo also uses singing to work with adults and children with psychological and emotional problems, ranging from autism to stress, at her studio in Twickenham.

'I believe we sang before we spoke at one time,' she says. 'I think it is very important we get the whole nation back to singing.'

Case notes

 Doctors believe that singing is valuable aerobic exercise, encouraging better posture and deeper breathing. It is also thought that singing releases endorphins in the body, which relieve pain and reduce stress. Using singing as a therapy for relaxation, overcoming depression and anxiety, and even treating clinically serious mental-health problems, is a growing movement.

 Nikki Slade runs weekly voice workshops at the Institute of Arts Therapy Education, 2-18 Britannia Row, London N1, and at the Landmark Arts Centre, Ferry Road, Teddington, Middlesex. For details of these, as well as one-day workshops and residential weekends, call 07932 043 277.

 Chloe Goodchild leads voice workshops in the UK and abroad. For details, contact 08700 768 769, or try her website www.chloegoodchild.com

 Margaret Lobo offers music therapy for all ages at her centre, the Otakar Kraus Trust, 3 Twining Avenue, Twickenham, Middlesex. Call 020 8894 2007 for further information.

webTitle: If Madonna likes chess, we like chess

fields.headline: If Madonna likes chess, we like chess
fields.standfirst: Check mates
fields.trailText: Check mates.
fields.body:
As the weather vane was to pre-20th-century meteorology, so Madonna is to modern life. Both are in the business of predicting the present. Those twirly birds on church spires told you which way the wind was blowing - the same wind you could feel on your face. Madonna tells us what our favourite fads are. What she does today is what we do, er, today.

A valuable public service it is, too. As weather vanes let us peer at them without having to venture into the rain, so Madonna offers us bulletins from the fashionability front that we can scan from the comfort of our favourite chair. She's told us that we like Ali G, that we enjoyed Guy Ritchie's first movie and that we thought cowboy hats should have lasted longer as a high-chic item than they did. Along with us - well me, anyway - she's got a taste for fish'n'chips, likes a good gastro pub and has taken up yoga. Like many of us, she's created her own melange of worship - in her case, part deep Orthodox Jewish, part Highland Fling (in mine, part atheist, part atheist).

Now she's playing chess. She has kept the Scottish connection, though. Her coach is the champion of our northern half-brother of a country, Mr Alan Norris, an edgy man based in London who is starting to get fed up with phone calls from people like me. 'It's not about Madonna, is it?' he said, clearly not intending to reveal any details.

'Not necessarily,' I hedged. While I'd have been fascinated to hear about Madonna's chess life - does she puts on a kilt to castle? - I wanted to know whether Madonna's taste for the ancient Eastern board game was a true reflection of our current enthusiasms. Or has she stopped being the weatherperson who tells us which way the wind is blowing? Is chess becoming an acceptable pastime? Is it severing its umbilical link with the dandruffed, the obsessive and the young-men-with-nervous-laughs? (I used to play. I know.) 'Well,' said Mr Norris. 'I'm getting busier, if that's anything to go by.'

There is other stuff to go by. Chess is also being played by other people with one name, Bono and Sting. And by a roll call of celebrities - ie Stephen Fry, Steve Martin, Guy Ritchie, Greta Scacchi, Chris Evans, Lennox Lewis, Martin Amis and snooker player Steve Davis, president of the British Chess Federation. Madonna plays at the Bel Air chess club along with Tim Robbins, Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts.

So is all this chess-as-fashion stuff just hooey? It's certainly Hoey. Talk to anyone in a chess organisation and they will complain that chess is not recognised as a sport in the UK, which means no Lottery money, even for Braille chess. So they are lobbying the minister for sport, Kate Hoey. Nick Hawkins is a pretty good chess player - graded at 187, compared to a club average of 117. He's a marketing director of the British Chess Federation. He says chess is certainly becoming more popular. The BCF gives a figure of 4m who can play the game and 40,000 club members - a 25 per cent rise from the previous day, when the London Chess Centre suggested 3m players. 'Chess was fashionable in the 20s,' said Hawkins, 'when the world champion was a US-based Cuban, José Raoul Capablanca. Another big player was the star of Capablanca.'

Capablanca ? 'Sorry, Casablanca . You can see Bogart was a chess player because he moves the pieces correctly. Then Kasparov's success made it fashionable in the 70s.' And now? 'More young people than ever play it.' Two of them are Martin Amis's sons.

What is chess's new attraction? 'It's linked to the revolution in attitudes towards our bodies,' said Chris Duncan of the London Chess Centre. 'People have concentrated on physical fitness in the gym. Now they're looking for fitness of mind.'

Hawkins developed this thought. 'Madonna has a high IQ and likes to exercise control. She can develop her skills and work on strategic control.' As a lecturer, Nick finds that chess-playing work is directly correlated to quality of academic work. In a world where Bill Gates has become that rich, demonstrating your brain power by playing chess is scarcely an idiotic option.

Finally, I checked in with Robert, an old friend who used to be something of a chess fiend. What's he up to now? 'As we speak,' he said, 'I'm in chessclub.com.' He was playing chess with someone somewhere else who was masquerading under a false name. What's it like, Robert? 'Really good. Love it. It's like anonymous sex.'

Inspired, I surfed the virtual-chess world. I found an active, slightly nerdy but fun subculture: clips of TS Eliot reading A Game Of Chess , downloads of the two Madonna videos which feature the game. I also found a cri de coeur: 'We'd really like to see a match between Madonna and Yoko Ono.' Pure pawnography, of course.

PS Alan Norris is available for hire on 07930 418 768, at £30 an hour. For that, you get high-quality coaching, whatever your level. You also get to touch the bishop that touched the hand...

And by a roll call of celebrities - ie Stephen Fry, Steve Martin, Guy Ritchie, Greta Scacchi, Chris Evans, Lennox Lewis, Martin Amis and snooker player Steve Davis, president of the British Chess Federation. Madonna plays at the Bel Air chess club along with Tim Robbins, Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts. So is all this chess-as-fashion stuff just hooey? It's certainly Hoey. Talk to anyone in a chess organisation and they will complain that chess is not recognised as a sport in the UK, which means no Lottery money, even for Braille chess. So they are lobbying the minister for sport, Kate Hoey. Nick Hawkins is a pretty good chess player - graded at 187, compared to a club average of 117. He's a marketing director of the British Chess Federation. He says chess is certainly becoming more popular. The BCF gives a figure of 4m who can play the game and 40,000 club members - a 25 per cent rise from the previous day, when the London Chess Centre suggested 3m players. 'Chess was fashionable in the 20s,' said Hawkins, 'when the world champion was a US-based Cuban, José Raoul Capablanca. Another big player was the star of Capablanca.' Capablanca ? 'Sorry, Casablanca . You can see Bogart was a chess player because he moves the pieces correctly. Then Kasparov's success made it fashionable in the 70s.' And now? 'More young people than ever play it.' Two of them are Martin Amis's sons. What is chess's new attraction? 'It's linked to the revolution in attitudes towards our bodies,' said Chris Duncan of the London Chess Centre. 'People have concentrated on physical fitness in the gym. Now they're looking for fitness of mind.' Hawkins developed this thought. 'Madonna has a high IQ and likes to exercise control. She can develop her skills and work on strategic control.' As a lecturer, Nick finds that chess-playing work is directly correlated to quality of academic work. In a world where Bill Gates has become that rich, demonstrating your brain power by playing chess is scarcely an idiotic option. Finally, I checked in with Robert, an old friend who used to be something of a chess fiend. What's he up to now? 'As we speak,' he said, 'I'm in chessclub.com.' He was playing chess with someone somewhere else who was masquerading under a false name. What's it like, Robert? 'Really good. Love it. It's like anonymous sex.' Inspired, I surfed the virtual-chess world. I found an active, slightly nerdy but fun subculture: clips of TS Eliot reading A Game Of Chess , downloads of the two Madonna videos which feature the game. I also found a cri de coeur: 'We'd really like to see a match between Madonna and Yoko Ono.' Pure pawnography, of course. PS Alan Norris is available for hire on 07930 418 768, at £30 an hour. For that, you get high-quality coaching, whatever your level. You also get to touch the bishop that touched the hand...

webTitle: Jane Clarke: Chewing the fat

fields.headline: Chewing the fat
fields.standfirst: Why cholesterol can be good for your heart. Plus, boosting babies and cooling hot flushes
fields.trailText: Why cholesterol can be good for your heart. Plus, boosting babies and cooling hot flushes.
fields.body:
My 26-year-old brother is about to become a first-time father and, perhaps for the first time in his life, Paul is realising that there's more than his own wellbeing at stake if he's inherited our family's weak-heart gene. He's not the only one who is concerned: the Department of Health has recently charged health authorities with improving the state of British men's health, which is generally so bad that 20,000 more men than women die before the age of 65 each year. This is because more of them smoke, have unhealthy diets and are overweight. The truth is, men are more likely than women to suffer from heart disease.

If, like Paul, you are taking stock of your health, the first step is to have your blood-fat profile and blood pressure checked. If you have high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL or 'bad' cholesterol), low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL or 'good' cholesterol) and hypertension (high blood pressure), you have an increased risk of developing heart disease. The build-up of LDL within the blood vessels leads to hypertension, while HDL carries LDL to the gut for excretion, so if tests show that you have too much LDL and not enough HDL, you need to correct this imbalance.

The good news is that increasing your HDL levels through nutrition is simply a matter of boosting your intake of oily fish, garlic and alcohol. It is the omega-3 fatty acids that oily fish such as mackerel or salmon contain that encourage your body to produce HDL, as does garlic. In addition, garlic and fish oils contain antithrombolitic agents that reduce your risk of developing a blood clot or thrombosis, which can cause a heart attack or stroke. Try to eat some garlic every day and oily fish once a week. Consuming any form of alcohol in small amounts is better for your blood-fat profile than abstention. The best measure seems to be drinking a couple of glasses of wine a day or a pint of cloudy, yeasty beer.

If your LDL levels are too high, you will need to reduce the amount of saturated animal fats, such as butter, cheese and fatty meats, that you eat, while also increasing your intake of fibre. Having three or four pieces of fresh fruit a day, along with a salad or vegetables with your main meal, will give you a healthy dose of fibre and antioxidants, the nutrients that discourage LDL from being deposited in the blood vessels. However, because fibre can only perform its heart-protecting function in the presence of water, try to drink 2.5 litres a day.

Keeping your weight within the ideal range will also help to reduce the likelihood of your developing hypertension.

Nutrition news

Researchers at King's College, London have just released some alarming findings: apparently the number of overweight children under 11 years of age has risen by 50 per cent over the past decade and almost one in 10 boys and one in seven girls is overweight. A recent study published by Professor Philip James, chairman of the International Force on Obesity, has furthermore highlighted the fact that well- meaning parents of low-birth-weight babies are sowing the seeds of obesity in their children by overfeeding them.

If your baby's birth weight is lower than average, it is important to give them a well-balanced diet rather than stuffing them with rich food or feeding them high-calorie snacks. If they're constantly being offered food, they will not be able to recognise when they're truly hungry or full and will develop unhealthy eating habits.

Your questions

I have been suffering from hot flushes at night, but don't want to take hormone-replacement therapy. Are there any nutritional measures that can help?
Jeanette Smith, Oxford

Research carried out by many scientists, including Dr John Lees, of Portland, Oregon, suggests that hot flushes and other menopausal symptoms are caused by a progesterone deficiency. The Mexican yam is thought to contain high levels of progesterone, while root vegetables, such as carrots, parsnips, beetroot and pulses, encourage the body to produce this hormone. Some women find that vitamin E, which is found in avocados, mangoes, seeds, nuts and blackberries, helps to reduce hot flushes. In my professional experience, women who ensure that they have a well-balanced diet that includes plenty of the above foods, and who also avoid caffeine completely, seem to suffer from fewer menopausal symptoms, although it's not clear why. I therefore recommend that you adjust your diet accordingly and, because carrying excess weight often causes your body to become overheated, also try to keep your weight within the ideal limits.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. webTitle: Go see

fields.headline: Go see
fields.standfirst: James Bond memorabilia
fields.trailText: James Bond memorabilia.
fields.body:
Connery, Lazenby, Moore, Dalton or Brosnan. Who cares? Real Bond enthusiasts will tell you that the debate is not about who made the best Bond, but who had the best gadgets, and hard-core fans will scour the world for mint-condition Oddjob dolls, original Airfix models of Little Nellie - Sean Connery's mini-helicopter from You Only Live Twice - and the exact poker chips used in Licence To Kill.

This week our ongoing obsession with all things Bond gets a more local shot in the arm; at Christie's, in London, they're holding an exhibition of more than 250 pieces of Bond memorabilia before putting the whole collection up for auction.

The pieces, all privately owned, range from special 'JB 007' number plates used for the promotion of Thunderball (estimated sale price: £2,500-4,500) and Miss Moneypenny's diamond brooch from On Her Majesty's Secret Service (£1,500-2,000) to the 'JB' monogrammed pyjamas, dressing gown and velvet slippers worn by Roger Moore in Live And Let Die (£3,000-5,000).

Highlights of the show? Depends on your tastes. There's the silver 1965 Aston Martin DB5 driven by Pierce Brosnan in GoldenEye (£100,000-150,000), the Walther PPK air pistol brandished by Sean Connery in the From Russia With Love film posters (£3,000-5,000), as well as that bikini, the one Ursula Andress wore in Dr No, which has been put up for sale by Andress herself and is expected to fetch upwards of £40,000. Steep, perhaps, but it comes highly recommended - Andress claims she owes her fame to Honey Ryder's skimpy costume. 'My entrance in the film on that beautiful beach seems to now be regarded as a classic moment in cinema,' she reflects. 'That bikini made me a success.'

The exhibition will run over the next three days. The auction, which anyone can attend, takes place on Wednesday, 14 February.

 Christie's, 85 Old Brompton Road, London SW7 (020 7581 7611). Viewing times: today 1pm-4pm, Monday 9am-7.30pm, Tuesday 9am-5pm, Wednesday 9am-12pm. The auction begins on Wednesday at 2pm.

webTitle: Almost infamous

fields.headline: Almost infamous
fields.trailText: In many ways Almost Famous is a fabulous movie. The problem is Kate Hudson's sweet but coy turn as Penny Lane, the self-styled 'band aid', and Happy Groupie.
fields.body:
I might be a dried up old battle-axe now, but, in my 'yoof', I was 'hot' - hot enough to be denounced as a groupie. It dates back to the days when I used to staple squawking diatribes together, call them 'fanzines' and sell them at gigs to punters I liked the look of. Forcing my photocopied 'masterpieces' upon doe-eyed boys in crumpled Wire T-shirts was my first taste of 'career fulfilment.' Crucially, although I loved music, I wasn't particularly interested in musicians, probably realising even then that the only reason 90 per cent of guys joined bands was because they were so radioactively ugly there was no other way they were ever going to get laid. Not that this attitude made any difference.

However much one insisted that it was music one loved not musicians, one invariably got saddled with a reputation as a slut who'd do anything for a backstage pass. Just being seen in the same vicinity as goons with guitars was enough to make you 'a sure thing'. Women hanging around musicians meant only one thing - they were groupies, not to be taken seriously. Around this time, I was always coming across girls sobbing in the loos: because the guitarist they'd slept with in Hull wasn't keen to continue the 'relationship' in Bath. Watching these heartbroken, naive girls practically succumbing to the vapours was pure John Peel-meets-Jane Austen. Here, ladies and gentlemen, were your so-called hardened 'groupies'.

That's why Cameron Crowe's new movie, Almost Famous, made me sigh. In many ways, it's a fabulous movie, based on Crowe's own experiences as a youthful rock critic for Rolling Stone magazine in the 70s. The problem is Kate Hudson's sweet but coy turn as Penny Lane, the self-styled 'band aid', and Happy Groupie, who considers herself to be equal to the musicians she beds. This character is based in part on infamous rock groupie Pamela Des Barres, who romanced, among others, Frank Zappa, Keith Moon and Jimmy Page. In her memoir, I'm With the Band, Des Barres comes across as being as nice as she is deluded. In her mind, she was her paramours' 'tour wife', their lover and 'muse'. In reality, of course, she was little more than a sex snack with portfolio.

At least Miss Pamela was treated 'real nice'. Reading the seminal Led Zeppelin biography, Hammer of the Gods, it becomes clear that the majority of, often underaged, real-life groupies from the Almost Famous era, were viciously sexually exploited and abused, unlike Penny Lane, who is shown being 'sexually exploited and abused' in a rather gentle, nurturing, photogenic fashion. I thought at first that I was overreacting as a 'woman' (and a humourless one at that) until I spoke with a respected male rock critic from the time, who commented, unprompted, upon the movie's 'sanitisation' of the twisted mores of the era. This confirmed my belief that that evergreen sexual icon of rock culture, the 'Happy Groupie' (the emancipated good time gal who knows the score and just wants to get laid) is all but a myth.

The Happy Groupie no longer exists in the rock world, if she ever really did in any significant numbers. In reality, the 'Happy Groupie' is just another of those male-generated myths, which gives men the licence to behave abusively and somehow get applauded for it. Men, bless them, are always trying to con women into believing they should feel honoured to be allowed to have sex with them, but only rock stars, movie stars and footballers have ever got away with it. It's worth remembering that, when they've got away with it, it has mainly been with the young and naive (who couldn't hope to know the score), rather than the experienced and liberated (who do).

The fact that the Happy Groupie remains such a powerful misogynistic icon also says a lot about male wannabes in the rock industry. The fallacy being that only women are groupies. Chrissie Hynde might rightly roar with laughter at the thought of male groupies making themselves 'available' but the fact is that they do exist, just not in an overtly sexualised way, and not only for female stars. For, contrary to popular belief, men love to hang around rock stars, they might even covertly want to sleep with them, they just don't get the chance. That's where all those drug dealers, hangers on, and other jealous woman-denigrating saddos come from. When people talk sneeringly of 'groupies', they think only of women. But I've seen male drug dealers and hangers on passed around rock star circles as cavalierly and disrespectfully as any girls. It would seem that, of all groupies, male ones have the potential to be the unhappiest of all.

webTitle: Phil Hogan: On wills

fields.headline: Where there's a will...
fields.trailText: Why tempt the gods of misadventure by going through the rigmarole of drawing up wills when we have so much to live for?
fields.body:
Naturally I'm happy to accept that in theory either one of us could get knocked down by a Korean jet ploughing through our back garden tomorrow, but surely it goes without spelling it out in £5 notes that I would like my wife to have my half of the estate, which admittedly currently stands at 95 per cent prime debt (though I believe we are now pretty close to legal ownership of the eldest's new school uniform and briefcase with combination lock), so why tempt the gods of misadventure by going through the rigmarole of drawing up wills when we have so much to live for, with the little one now at nursery three mornings a week and Leeds still in the European Cup?

'It's no big deal - everyone makes a will nowadays,' says my wife. 'There's no point waiting till you're actually on your deathbed.'

'Why not? You wouldn't go out and buy a flame-thrower on the off-chance that you might one day buy a house next door to people with an annoying dog, would you?'

She's had her head in the paper all morning, tutting. I have noticed that she has recently become magnetically attracted to the Telegraph for its lurid accounts of unusual fatalities. Hardly a day goes by without her bringing my attention to a single mother of triplets suddenly disappearing into an unmapped subterranean cavern while out rambling or someone claiming to have caught mad cow disease from a dentist's mouth clamp, and what were we to make of the member of the Turkish parliament who dropped dead after being involved in a fist fight on the floor of the debating chamber? It could happen to anyone! My wife has accordingly procured a 'raft' of competitive will and testament sales literature and rung a firm in the village to see if they would be interested in our giving them our entire annual Walkers crisps allowance in exchange for their stating the obvious on a scroll of novelty parchment.

The thing is, she is now saying, what if I had a heart attack tomorrow putting the wheelie bins out and then she collapsed with the shock (of my putting the wheelie bins out, not my untimely death)? What would happen to the children? I remind her that at least three of them are capable of using a telephone.

'No,' she says, 'I mean...'

I know what she means, but what does she think people did during the Blitz when entire families were firebombed in their beds? A favourite auntie would step in of course. How about Uncle Simon - the boys all love him and he has a nice big house near Disneyland in Paris, and a highly paid job as financial director of a global telecommunications giant. All he has to do is pass his driving test and come to terms with having no life and hire some counselling staff for Caroline his wife. And if not, well what are orphanages for? Gary Glitter was in one, and it didn't do him any harm.

'Humour me,' says my wife.

So I start with Barclays' will-writing service booklet, whose cover bears a picture of a man and his son paddling at Brighton or somewhere, no doubt just seconds before they were swept out to sea by a freak typhoon. But it's quite boring to read and in the end I have to fail their blurb on the technicality of using the word 'chattels' too many times. I try the next one, which begins with an impartial account of how your family could easily be left in penury and misery for want of a simple no-fuss visit in your own home with a fixed fee regardless of how many days the salesman has to sit in your living room administering the Chinese water torture that comes courtesy of their modern obligation-free, bereavement-without-strings package. Yet another offers an exciting portfolio of post-death facilities, such as making sure your organs go to the right place if you're not taking them with you, or enabling you to make your wishes known with regard to whether you'd like your life support unplugged if you're suffering from a degenerative brain disease and are unable to catch the doctor's eye.

My wife comes to join me. 'How's it going?' she says.

'Excellent,' I say. 'I'm feeling ill already.'

Gary Glitter was in one, and it didn't do him any harm. 'Humour me,' says my wife. So I start with Barclays' will-writing service booklet, whose cover bears a picture of a man and his son paddling at Brighton or somewhere, no doubt just seconds before they were swept out to sea by a freak typhoon. But it's quite boring to read and in the end I have to fail their blurb on the technicality of using the word 'chattels' too many times. I try the next one, which begins with an impartial account of how your family could easily be left in penury and misery for want of a simple no-fuss visit in your own home with a fixed fee regardless of how many days the salesman has to sit in your living room administering the Chinese water torture that comes courtesy of their modern obligation-free, bereavement-without-strings package. Yet another offers an exciting portfolio of post-death facilities, such as making sure your organs go to the right place if you're not taking them with you, or enabling you to make your wishes known with regard to whether you'd like your life support unplugged if you're suffering from a degenerative brain disease and are unable to catch the doctor's eye. My wife comes to join me. 'How's it going?' she says. 'Excellent,' I say. 'I'm feeling ill already.' phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Loafer's guide

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: PJ Harvey
fields.trailText: PJ Harvey.
fields.body:
Who he? She is Polly Jean Harvey, the shy, secretive Yeovil-born songstress nominated as Best Female Artist in the Brit Awards this month, while still keeping enough credibility to feature in the Best Solo Artist category of the NME 's alternative Brat Awards. But don't worry about the gender confusion. She's no stranger to it herself. Polly grew up on a sheep farm in Dorset, the only young woman in the area, and has confessed that early on, she often longed to be male.

So, one of the lads, then? Not at all. She's pulled off a rare balancing act: critical and commercial success with the boys from the music press, while writing dark, challenging songs which examine female sexuality and eroticism in a way that's more threatening than titillating, as well as examining her own sometimes troubled mental state. She's admitted that the almost instant fame that followed her 1992 debut Dry was hard to handle, and led to a breakdown in the mid-90s when she became thin and fragile-looking.

And how is she now? Better. She seems more confident in her thirties. Written half in New York, half in Dorset, her latest album Stories From the City, Stories From the Sea shows a more joyful side, but there are still flashes of the old anger in lines such as ' Speak to me of heroin and speed, of genocide and suicide/of syphilis and greed'. She may dress up like a smoky nightclub siren, but easy listening isn't her forte. More primal scream than slinky torch songs, this is music you tend to play alone, at night, when feeling angst-ridden.

You make it sound bleak. At a time when the charts are cluttered with manufactured bands and the hopefuls in Popstars want fame but rarely express any desire to make good music, we should all give thanks that an English eccentric like Harvey can thrive.

Where can I hear more? This week's three London dates at the Shepherd's Bush Empire are already sold out, but you could start with her new single, 'A Place Called Home', out on 26 February.

webTitle: The perfect love letter

fields.headline: The perfect love letter
fields.standfirst: Corin Redgrave
fields.trailText: Corin Redgrave.
fields.body:
Most great love letters are written in the first great flush of romance, so their theme is simple - 'I'm in love with you and only you. And I'm in love with you more than anyone has ever been in love with anyone and I will love you forever.' It's a magnificent boast and a defiance of common sense because no great love lasts at that level of intensity.

A beautiful love letter is as much about the writer as it is about the object of affection, because love is one of the best kinds of education. Having performed several times in Wilde's De Profundis , his love letter to Bosie, I've come to realise that it is an extraordinarily powerful achievement of self-analysis. Even in solitary confinement, afraid of losing his reason, he reached astounding self-knowledge as to why he entered into this relationship and what it did to him.

The writer finds that they are empowered by their love, so it becomes a letter of gratitude. Even Karl Marx, whose intellectual achievements didn't owe anything to his lover Jenny von Westphalen, wrote beautifully appreciative letters to her.

As the post gets worse and email takes over, great romantic correspondences will become harder and more rare. In Robert Browning's day, the post came four or five times a day so he and Elizabeth Barrett Browning (above) were able to exchange letters constantly. He has this wonderful flying prose that careers down a rocky path, oblivious to the potholes and dangers on its way. Hers is extraordinarily fine and elusive and together they discuss their plans and fears for the future. In their case, perhaps the first flush of love did go on forever.

Shakespeare wrote that the best way to make love last for eternity is to write it down so that it outlasts mere human beings. We can't all be Shakespeare, but if we listened to our hearts and tried to express what we found there, we could try.

webTitle: Shop around for    a discount broker

fields.headline: Shop around for    a discount broker
fields.standfirst: Low charges but no advice?  It's not as simple as that, says Alexander Garrett
fields.trailText: Low charges but no advice? It's not as simple as that, says Alexander Garrett.
fields.body:
It is hard to believe that, a decade ago, few investors even questioned the charges they had to pay every time they put money into a new Pep or unit trust. What many came to realise was that, with around 5 per cent of their money going straight into the coffers of those who sold them the investment, their investment would do well to more than tread water during the first year.

The arrival of discount brokers changed all that as a new wave of lean and hungry intermediaries calculated that they could return most of the commission they were paid by the fund management group, and still make a handsome profit.

Nowadays, the picture has become far more confusing for the investor: there are many more options available to anyone looking for a cut-price deal, but the level of advice or service you receive with each of them can vary enormously.

The way discounting works is this: fund management groups set an initial charge for each of their funds, of which the average is around 5 per cent. If the fund is sold via an intermediary, they usually receive 3 per cent commission from the fund manager; but discount brokers rebate their initial commission to the investor, reducing the charge to you to around 2 per cent. However, fund managers often offer their own discount against the initial charge of, say, 1 per cent or 2 per cent. (If you buy direct from the fund manager, this is the only reduction you will get.) So with luck, the slice of your initial investment that is not usefully invested is whittled down to 1 per cent or less.

Until a year or two ago, most intermediaries offering such deals usually did so on an 'execution only' basis, meaning you had to know which fund you wanted, because there was no advice on offer. And they were content to rely on the annual renewal commission - typically 0.5 per cent - from the fund manager in order to make a living.

Some intermediaries then began offering discounts as well as advice; and another camp honed the charges down even further, by rebating some of their annual renewal commission to investors. And as if that were not confusing enough, along came 'fund supermarkets', a new type of internet-based service where you can mix and match funds in your Isa, again at reduced charges.

According to Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of London-based intermediary Bestinvest, there is not much to choose between the discounts offered by most brokers. The difference, he says, is in the level of service and advice that you receive.

'Everyone is now on a pretty flat price structure, giving everything back upfront,' he says. 'But we are the only discount broker in the UK which also gives advice.'

As well as individual recommendations, Bestinvest offers clients a quarterly review of their portfolio, with advice on the overall structure as well as individual funds; it also supplies regular research bulletins.

A different tack has been taken by Bath-based Chartwell, which has been locked in a dispute with fund manager Fidelity over its offer to refund half of the annual renewal commission to investors, in addition to initial commission. Fidelity threatened to stop dealing with Chartwell, some believe under pressure from other intermediaries, but has now agreed to discuss the issue.

What Chartwell's offer means is that you pay only a flat fee of £20 for transacting each deal in addition to any initial charge which is not discounted, and each year you will receive a cheque for half of the renewal commission. If your Isa investment stood at £7,000, and the renewal commission is 0.5 per cent, that means your cheque in the first year would be for £17.50. As Chartwell's Tim Cockerill points out: 'Over a period of time, that will easily cover the initial fee.'

Like many discount brokers, Chartwell offers the option of providing advice on choosing a fund. In its case, it charges a flat fee of £150 for a consultation, which is still considerably less expensive than the £350 somebody paying a 5 per cent initial charge on a £7,000 Isa would have to cough up. And they can then take advantage of the best discounts available to make their investment.

Cockerill stresses that, in spite of its stand on discounts, people should be very wary of simply looking for the cheapest deal. 'I think the discount story has gone as far as it can go,' he says, adding: 'A lot of people still don't know what they want and need advice.'

The majority of investors do continue to take advice, and pay for it through commission. Execution-only deals are, by all accounts, still in a minority. But if you have an intermediary whose advice you trust, there can be no harm in asking if they will consider rebating at least some of their commission. They may say no, of course.

Those determined to go it alone now have another option: the fund supermarket. But although the ability to pick your own funds online is an attractive one, the discounts available at sites such as Egg or Fidelity are still generally not quite as good as those offered by the discount brokers.

webTitle: Isa special: So, what's inside the wrapper?

fields.headline: So, what's inside the wrapper?
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles unravels the mysteries of tax-free investing
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles unravels the mysteries of tax-free investing.
fields.body:
 The individual savings account is a tax shelter, a wrapper that protects the investments held within it from both income and Capital Gains tax. Up to £7,000 can be invested in Isas in the 2000-2001 tax year and the subsequent four years. After 2006 the limit is scheduled to drop to £5,000.

 Most Isas run for as long as you want, although some have a fixed term because of the nature of the underlying fund. The deadline for every tax year is 5 April.

 To invest in an Isa, you must be resident in the UK for tax purposes and aged 18 or over. From next year 16-year-olds will be able to take out a cash mini-Isa or the cash component of a maxi-Isa.

 There are two types, the maxi Isa and the mini Isa. The maxi Isa allows you to invest £7,000 with one company while the mini lets you split £7,000 between three different companies in three 'mini' Isas. This means you can invest in either one maxi Isa or three mini Isas a year.

 Three different types of investment can be placed in an Isa: stocks and shares, cash and life insurance. The former includes unit trusts, investment trusts and open-ended investment companies (Oeics). The cash part covers bank and building society accounts, cash unit trusts and certain National Savings products. Life insurance has to be a single- life investment-linked insurance policy. You can invest in shares and bonds directly or in funds that invest in these. Shares and bonds from any officially recognised stock market anywhere in the world are eligible.

 In a maxi Isa you can invest the whole £7,000 in stocks and shares. Or you can decide to split the allowance between the three other components - £3,000 in cash, £1,000 in life insurance and the remainder in stocks and shares. But you cannot move your money between the different investment components in a maxi Isa. Money contributed to the cash component must stay in the cash component. Regardless of how many components a maxi Isa offers, the scheme must be run by one Isa provider.

 A mini Isa holds just one component. Each tax year you can open one cash mini Isa, one stocks and shares mini Isa and one life assurance mini Isa. Each can have a different provider.

 By investing only £1 in a mini cash or life insurance Isa, you automatically reduce the amount of stocks and shares investments you can protect from tax from £7,000 to £3,000.

 You may not open a maxi and mini Isa in the same tax year. Once you have opened a mini or maxi Isa, you cannot change to the other type. If you open too many mini Isas, or a mini Isa and a maxi Isa in the same tax year, you will be required to close the offending Isas on a last in-first out basis, and any returns earned will be taxed at the relevant rate.

 Should you be unhappy with the performance of your Isa you can swap providers at any time. Just apply to the new provider.

 Top-ups made to an Isa taken out during the current tax year will be allowed until 5 April. If you want to make further contributions after that date you will have to open a new Isa.Once you have withdrawn money from your Isa, that part of your Isa allowance is lost for good and you cannot top it up again at a later date.

 You can transfer up to £9,000 capital from a maturing Tessa into a Tessa-only Isa to continue earning interest tax-free, but you must do it within six months of the Tessa maturing. This does not apply to the interest earned on a maturing Tessa.

 Peps cannot be rolled into Isas but, from 6 April, Peps will be subject to the same investment rules as Isas. As a result, you will be able to select international investments for your Peps.

 The Government has introduced a set of standards - Cat standards - which some product providers have signed up to voluntarily. Isas that meet the Cat standards are deemed to have low charges, provide easy access and have reasonable terms.

 Husbands and wives have their own Isa allowance, so a couple could invest up to £14,000 in the 2000-001 tax year.
