webTitle: Isa special: Against a rainy day

fields.headline: Against a rainy day
fields.standfirst: Lisa Bachelor on the best tax-free home for your emergency savings
fields.trailText: Lisa Bachelor on the best tax-free home for your emergency savings.
fields.body:
According to independent financial advisers, we should all be keeping a minimum of three months' salary as rainy day savings in a bank or building society.

As this can add up to quite a substantial amount of money, it is imperative to get the best interest rate possible, especially as this cash may be sitting there for some time. Despite this, many of us still hold large sums in current accounts mainly earning meagre rates of interest, often below 1 per cent.

Cash Isas, on the other hand, are an ideal home for this money as interest is tax-free - unlike a standard building society or bank savings account, which will deduct 20 per cent tax (higher rate taxpayers pay another 20 per cent on top later).Also, rates on cash Isas can be excellent.

Chancellor Gordon Brown is trying to encourage more people to save in cash Isas: he announced in his pre-budget statement in November that from April they will be available to 16- and 17- year-olds, who at the moment fall below the age limit for Isa investment.

Up to £23,000 can be invested in a cash mini Isa or the cash component of a maxi Isa. However, more choice and better rates are generally available from mini cash Isas, so if you are investing nothing or a limited amount (up to £3,000) on the stock market, opt for a mini.

Best rates for a mini cash Isa come from Smile, the internet arm of the Co-operative Bank, at 7.25 per cent, while Monmouthshire building society and First Direct are not far behind with rates of 6.75 and 6.68 per cent respectively. If you don't mind giving between one and three months' notice to get at your money Investec Bank and Julian Hodge bank are offering 6.85 per cent. Rates on cash Isas are generally excellent at the moment, but this may not always be the case, so you may have to swap between Isa providers to keep with the best rate. If you are looking for stability there are a few fixed-rate deals available.

The Julian Hodge Bank, for example, is offering a fixed rate of 6.40 per cent for between three and five years.

'There are three main things you should look for in a mini cash Isa,' says John Stewart of independent financial adviser PMI. 'Rate, accessibility and minimum investment limits. Accessibility is something people often forget to check. Some providers who come in with leading rates will soon drop that rate, and if the rate becomes uncompetitive you need to be able to move accounts easily.'

The majority of cash Isas are instant access accounts, although some ask for between one and six months' notice to withdraw your money, while others limit the amount of free withdrawals you can make.

As rates stand at the moment, there seems no real advantage to taking out a mini cash Isa notice account, because rates on these accounts, although they can be competitive, don't tend to be any better than those on instant access accounts.

If you are worried that you may have missed something in the small print when choosing an Isa, you can always opt for a Catmarked product. Cat stands for Cost, Access and Terms and is a set of rules laid down by the Government to help consumers get a fair deal.

CAT marking is voluntary, and although there are plenty of Catmarked products to choose from, the majority of mini cash Isas don't meet these standards. To boast a Catmark, a cash Isa must, among other things, not impose any one-off or regular charges of any kind, the minimum transaction size must be no greater than £10 and interest rates no lower than two percentage points below base rate.

Like most good things, the mini cash Isa comes with strings attached. Isa rules limit you to a maximum investment of £3,000 in any one tax year, which may sound quite a lot to hold on deposit, but it doesn't amount to much when you consider how much advisers are recommending you keep tucked away. The £3,000 limit is the total amount allowed into the Isa, so you can't reach this limit, withdraw money and then put more in, as you will be breaking Isa rules.

Of course, there is nothing to stop you investing your full limit in a cash Isa and keeping money in a bank or building society savings account as well.

As rates stand at the moment, there seems no real advantage to taking out a mini cash Isa notice account, because rates on these accounts, although they can be competitive, don't tend to be any better than those on instant access accounts. If you are worried that you may have missed something in the small print when choosing an Isa, you can always opt for a Catmarked product. Cat stands for Cost, Access and Terms and is a set of rules laid down by the Government to help consumers get a fair deal. CAT marking is voluntary, and although there are plenty of Catmarked products to choose from, the majority of mini cash Isas don't meet these standards. To boast a Catmark, a cash Isa must, among other things, not impose any one-off or regular charges of any kind, the minimum transaction size must be no greater than £10 and interest rates no lower than two percentage points below base rate. Like most good things, the mini cash Isa comes with strings attached. Isa rules limit you to a maximum investment of £3,000 in any one tax year, which may sound quite a lot to hold on deposit, but it doesn't amount to much when you consider how much advisers are recommending you keep tucked away. The £3,000 limit is the total amount allowed into the Isa, so you can't reach this limit, withdraw money and then put more in, as you will be breaking Isa rules. Of course, there is nothing to stop you investing your full limit in a cash Isa and keeping money in a bank or building society savings account as well.

webTitle: Isa special: Riskier funds for a spicier retirement

fields.headline: Riskier funds for a spicier retirement
fields.standfirst: With 20 years to go to retirement, Mindy Ramzan has opted to spread her money around several overseas products, she tells Claire Burston
fields.trailText: With 20 years to go to retirement, Mindy Ramzan has opted to spread her money around several overseas products, she tells Claire Burston.
fields.body:
Mindy Ramzan has invested the maximum Isa allowance of £7,000 into a range of international investment funds in the hope that she will increase her savings enough to provide a substantial nest egg in retirement.

The 40-year-old accountant, from Purley in Surrey, has a sound knowledge of investment and describes herself as having a medium risk profile.

As such, she can afford to invest in slightly spicier funds to achieve her investment goals. She has chosen several Fidelity funds - American Special Situations, European and Managed International - in which to invest this year' s Isa allowance.

Ms Ramzan says: 'The interest rates on bank and building society accounts have been poor over the past few years, which is why I started investing in equities, mainly in the form of UK funds.

'But I am now very keen to diversify my investments. That's why I've spread my money among several overseas funds.

'I have built up a portfolio of Isas and Peps with other fund management groups. Most of those invest in UK companies so I thought I would take the opportunity to use this year's tax allowance to invest in some international funds.'

These more risky international funds Ms Ramzan invested in three months ago are balanced by many of her other investments, which have a much lower risk profile.

'The risks may be greater but I expect the returns - over the next 20 or so years - to be better to compensate,' she says.

'I am looking to retirement with these funds, so I have a long-term investment view. I am not likely to be tempted to dip into the funds before then, so can afford to take more risks.'

She has stuck with her original investments, made over a period of seven years, but says she would consider switching if performance tails off.

'I am a bit concerned about the American fund I have invested in with all the talk about a slowdown in the US economy,' she admits. 'That is certainly one I will keep an eye on.'

webTitle: Isa special: The world and all that's in it

fields.headline: The world and all that's in it
fields.standfirst: The further afield you go, the greater the risk. Heather Connon on travels with your Isa allowance
fields.trailText: The further afield you go, the greater the risk. Heather Connon on travels with your Isa allowance.
fields.body:
Emerging markets, Europe, American smaller companies, Japanese special situations, fixed-interest or global growth - you could probably find a different type of Isa for every £1 of your £7,000 allowance. How should investors chose?

A good rule of thumb is that the further afield you go, the riskier the investment is. European and US funds will be slightly riskier than a general British fund - not only are you punting on the performance of those markets, you are also exposed to currency risks. The developed far eastern markets, such as Japan and Hong Kong, are a bit less predictable. Riskiest of all are emerging markets such as Chile, Korea or China, where performance can be hit by anything from a hike in US interest rates to a change of government or an outbreak of civil unrest.

Investors should also be careful not to base decisions on what is happening now. Stock markets usually look 18 months ahead - although they often get their predictions wrong. Small investors should also be looking to the future. Equity investment should only be undertaken for the long term.

So do not be too worried about current events in the US. Economists may be warning about a hard landing, but the stock markets are already confident that Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan will cut interest rates by enough to keep the stock markets happy. The Nasdaq technology market, in particular, has jumped sharply since Greenspan started cutting rates at the beginning of the year.

This is a traditional pattern. 'In any period of aggressive interest rate cuts, equity markets in the years after show strong positive returns,' said Gary Marshall of Aberdeen Asset Management.

Michael Wrobel of Gartmore agrees: 'Markets climb the wall of worry. If you look 18 months ahead, it is not too long before the economy starts to look healthy again.'

Others are more cautious,. Sarah Arkle of Threadneedle Investments warns that the recent surge in US markets was a knee-jerk reaction to the rate cuts. There is still uncertainty over how technology stocks, in particular, will cope with a slowing economy.

Emerging markets, including Latin America and the Far East, are also anticipating recovery in the US. Most did very badly last year - the notable exception is China - as it became clear that the US economy was slowing. The first two months of 2001 have seen them rise steeply in the wake of the US rate cuts. Arkle is especially keen on Latin America generally and Mexico in particular, where stock market valuations look low and economic prospects look encouraging.

But the risks are high - Aberdeen's Marshall lists political and currency factors as just two things to be wary of. Indeed, few Isa investors should consider direct investment in emerging markets. The risks are too great and the returns have been too low.

Japan, too, has proved dodgy for private investors. The Nikkei has been in the doldrums for more than a decade, yet every time it appears to touch bottom, it takes another lurch downwards. Gartmore's Wrobel thinks a stronger political will is needed for a sustained recovery here - and that looks unlikely at the moment.

European markets performed strongly last year, fuelled by continued restructuring of the economy and a strengthening euro. But fund managers believe it still looks attractive. Aberdeen's Marshall points to increasing numbers of cross-border mergers - in banking for example - and says there is 'an awful lot to go'.

Britain, ostensibly a part of Europe, is also attractive. Threadneedle is overweight here, says Arkle, partly because of her US worries. 'Corporate profit growth is reasonably solid. We are expecting 7 per cent earnings growth, which puts the market on just under 20 times earnings. That is reasonable.'

But Arkle, like a number of managers, is particularly keen on corporate bonds. These are loans to companies which are traded on markets, rather like shares. Their price - usually described in terms of the yield on the stock - varies depending on investors' views of the prospects for the economy and the company.

Last year was a poor one for corporate bonds. Rising interest rates combined with worries about the US and concern about huge borrowings in telecoms to put investors off. This year they have recovered sharply but yields are still good. Aberdeen's Marshall points out that some bonds are still yielding 15 per cent; Threadneedle's corporate bond fund is offering 10.1 per cent.

John Hatherly, head of global analysis at M&G, cautions that corporate bonds are not as risk-free as they are often promoted. The higher the yield on the fund, the greater the risk. M&G has a range of funds, offering from 5 per cent yield upwards.

M&G is one of a growing number of managers investing according to which industry or sector a company operates in, rather then where it is based. Vodafone, BP and Glaxo may be British but their operations are anything but. And you cannot take a view on telecoms without considering, say, Japan's NTT.

'We are in global markets now,' says Hatherly. 'But not to the exclusion of everything else. Most UK investors will invest in what they are familiar with. We're saying that the next layer after that should take a more global view.'

This approach is reflected in the growth of global funds, which claim to offer exposure to growing companies wherever they are. Examples are M&G's Global Leaders or Global Technology funds, Aberdeen's Global Champions and Threadneedle's Global Select. Others have global funds for specific sectors - such as Legal & General's Healthcare fund.

webTitle: World in brief

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Muslim militants burn Kashmir villagers to death
fields.body:
Muslim militants burn Kashmir villagers to death

Fifteen people were burned to death when houses caught fire during an attack by militants on a village in India's strife-torn Jammu and Kashmir state. Since Muslim separatists took up arms 11 years ago, more than 30,000 people have died violently.

Bulgaria bars king from vote

Bulgaria's exiled King Simeon II denounced a ruling by the Constitutional Court that he was ineligible to stand in presidential elections due at the end of next year. Opinion polls show Simeon is the only serious rival for President Petar Stoyanov, expected to seek a second term.

UN official in Rwanda accused of ivory smuggling

The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Rwanda has been arrested at Nairobi international airport allegedly trying to smuggle elephant tusks and animal skins out of Kenya. The official was named by the local press as Lt-Col Masud Mohamed.

Refugees in Guinea crossfire

United Nations aid workers struggled to rescue tens of thousands of refugees caught in fresh fighting between rebels and government forces in southern Guinea. The fighting, close to the Sierra Leone and Liberian borders, has cut off many camps from outside aid.

Six-week TV strike ends

Czech Television workers ended their six-week-long strike after a TV veteran, Jiri Balvin, was appointed interim director. The strike was over allegations of political interference.

Croc shock

Saltwater crocodiles swam in the streets of Cairns, north-east Australia, as high tides caused floods.

Women's rally over violence

Singing and waving banners at a rally in Addis Ababa, Ethiopian women finished a week of protests against rising domestic violence.

They delivered petitions to Premier Meles Zenawi and to parliament demanding more police protection and harsher sentences against offenders. Candle-light vigils preceded the rally.

webTitle: Breakthrough to end hysterectomy

fields.headline: Breakthrough to end hysterectomy
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of women could be saved the trauma of hysterectomies by a radical procedure that can make the operation unnecessary.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of women could be saved the trauma of hysterectomies by a radical procedure that can make the operation unnecessary.

A new procedure will mean that the number of hysterectomies, the second most common operation in the UK, will fall by about a third. The previously experimental keyhole operation will be officially approved later this week by a joint study from the Royal College of Obstetrics & Gynaecology and the Royal College of Radiologists.

Each year around 23,000 women in Britain have hysterectomies to remove fibroids, benign growths in the womb that can lead to heavy periods and incontinence.

The growths can also be killed by blocking the artery that supplies them with blood, causing them to wither away. A small bead is put in the artery through a small hole in the groin. The procedure, known as uterine artery embolisation, is quicker, cheaper, less painful, has fewer side effects and is less likely to lead to complications than a hysterectomy.

The procedure was pioneered in France, and is now widely available in the US. It has so far been carried out 9,000 times across the world. However, in the UK it is generally available only privately, and few doctors are trained to do it.

In dozens of cases, women have become pregnant after having the operation. Fibroids, which block the womb, make many women infertile, and having them killed off can make women fertile again.

The report by the royal colleges is a comprehensive study of the operation, which concludes it has little risk, and is successful in about 90 per cent of cases. Dr Tony Nicholson, president of the British Society of Interventional Radiology and co-author of the report, said it should be taken up across the NHS: 'It has the potential to significantly reduce the number of hysterectomies.'

Fiona Buckton, a 41-year- old solicitor had UAE last year, paying £2,500 to have it done privately. She said: 'I felt concerned about losing my womb, and the sense of loss that results. Also it would be difficult to take three months off work.

'I had the new procedure, and it was no more painful than a normal period. I was back at work in 10 days.'

Hugh Bayley, MP for York, called on the operation to be made more widely available. 'I am glad this has been supported by doctors' he said. 'I hope that health authorities will allow this procedure to be used where the medical evidence shows it appropriate.'

Royal College of Radiologists information for patients: www.rcr.ac.uk

webTitle: UN peacekeeper accused of smuggling elephant tusks

fields.headline: UN peacekeeper accused of smuggling elephant tusks
fields.trailText: The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Rwanda has been arrested at Nairobi international airport allegedly trying to smuggle elephant tusks and animal skins out of Kenya.
fields.body:
The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Rwanda has been arrested at Nairobi international airport allegedly trying to smuggle elephant tusks and animal skins out of Kenya.

The arrest fuels a growing belief that UN officials, diplomats and humanitarian aid workers are now among the biggest buyers of African ivory.

The UN official was named by the local press as Lt-Col Masud Mohamed. He was in transit, waiting to board a flight to Dubai - one of the busiest staging posts for endangered African animal parts - when stopped by police.

Kenya Airports Commandant Christopher Isoe said that when confronted with the police's suspicions, Mohamed, a Pakistani national, attempted to claim diplomatic immunity. But, unimpressed, airport police opened his suitcases and are alleged to have found four tusks, a dozen pieces of worked ivory and a leopard skin.

'The man is not a visitor to Kenya and there is nothing like diplomatic immunity for him,' Isoe said.

Mohamed was taken straight to Nairobi Magistrates Court, but refused to enter a plea. He will reappear in court tomorrow.

Mohamed's case could have been lifted straight from last year's report by the UK-based organisation, Save the Elephants (STE).

'We spent six months following the ivory trade all over Africa, and it became clear that UN workers and diplomats - mainly from North Korea - have become one of the biggest markets for ivory,' said Dr Esmond Martin, one of the report's co-authors.

Other prominent buyers include French military personnel and Spanish, Italian and French tourists, according to the report. Entitled The Ivory Markets of Africa, it is described as the first comprehensive look into the African ivory market for 11 years.

Following the trade for six months through 13 African countries, the authors found some 110,000 ivory items displayed in more than 650 out lets. They concluded that more than 10 tonnes of raw ivory is being sent to key Asian markets each year from countries including Cameroon, Mozambique and the Democratic Republic of Congo, much of it through diplomatic channels.

The study also found that since a 1990 ivory trade freeze, prices have fallen and there has been a marked drop in demand in virtually all African cities. Many ivory vendors see little future in the trade, it claims. Accord ing to Martin, retail sales have fallen by at least 50 per cent across the continent, and as much as 95 per cent in some areas.

Save the Elephants founder Dr Ian Douglas Hamilton says this drop in prices shows the ivory trade ban has been largely successful. For 10 years elephants in Kenya and other East and Central African countries have enjoyed a much lower rate of poaching.

Despite a one-off sale of Zimbabwean ivory to Japan last year, the UN has maintained its ban on ivory trading. However, it is coming under increasing pressure to lift the ban from southern African countries including South Africa and Zimbabwe; both claim the trade can be managed sustainably.

Kenya, which has been flooded with guns from conflicts along its borders over the past 10 years, wants the ban maintained.

Douglas-Hamilton said: 'If the incentive to poach is restored by expansion of the ivory trade there would likely be another elephant holocaust worse than that of the Seventies and Eighties.'

webTitle: Mandela's freedom cry rings out again

fields.headline: Mandela's freedom cry rings out again
fields.standfirst:
Few people heard the ANC leader's speech at his trial in 1964 - but none of them forgot it. Now, after 36 years in the vaults, the world can hear a tape of his defiant declaration

Special report: Mandela recordings
fields.trailText: Few people heard the ANC leader's speech at his trial in 1964 - but none of them forgot it. Now,  after 36 years in the vaults,  the world can hear a tape of his defiant declaration.
fields.body:
The powerful last words spoken by Nelson Mandela in public before he was sentenced to life imprisonment still ring in the ears of those who were in court that day.

Now, thanks to technicians at the British Library, the world can hear one of the twentieth century's most important speeches. After four months of work, the official recording made at his trial in 1964 has been restored by the library's National Sound Archive in London. Last week Mandela's declaration that he was 'prepared to die' for his beliefs sounded again - in time for the eleventh anniversary of his release from prison.

Stunned to hear of the recovery of the recording, Mandela said yesterday: 'I knew nothing about the existence of these tapes. I am very interested to know how this was done and to hear them for the first time.'

A copy has been sent to Mandela. But the voice of the 45-year-old we shall hear is very different from the mild and statesmanlike tones of his later life. Calling on the strength of his Xhosa forefathers, Mandela - or Accused Number One - makes an emotional, three-hour defence of guerrilla warfare and blames the white regime for making Africans' lives unbearable in their own country.

While his voice is immediately recognisable, the words are likely to stir up strong emotions for blacks and whites.

Recordings of the trial had been kept in storage in South Africa but they could not be played because the courtroom Dictaphone system had become obsolete. Then, after a chance conversation at a conference in South Africa last autumn, the British Library offered free use of its expertise and equipment.

'We had one of the few remaining machines in the world,' said Dr Rob Perks, the library's curator of oral history. 'The Dictabelt used in Pretoria was very unusual and had been developed in the 1950s for office use.'

Addressing Judge Quartus de Wet in the Palace of Justice on 20 April 1964, Mandela denounced the apartheid system and set out the objectives of the African National Congress. 'We want a just share in the whole of South Africa,' he said. 'We want security and a stake in society. Above all, my lord, we want equal political rights, because without them our disabilities will be permanent.'

The charges Mandela and his co-defendants faced were punishable by death. As it was, his life was spared and he was held in prison, chiefly on Robben Island, until 1990.

At the time of the so-called Rivonia trial, Mandela was serving five years' hard labour for sabotage but was taken to Pretoria to stand in the dock with nine other leaders who had been arrested at their Rivonia headquarters.

According to the late Mary Benson, who attended the trial, Mandela did not want to make the speech. He hoped to explain his views under cross-examination but his comrades persuaded him to use his statement to speak without interruption about the foundation of the ANC and its military wing, Umkhonto we Sizwe. As Mandela puts on his spectacles and rises to speak, the prosecutor, Percy Yutar, can be heard attempting to intervene by arguing that Mandela's words will not have the value of sworn testimony. But the defendant goes on to argue that the ANC was not under the influence of the Communist Party, as alleged, and that his political convictions sprang from his experiences.

Referring to the massacre of 69 unarmed Africans in 1960, he asks: 'How many more Sharpevilles would there be in the history of our country? And how many more Sharpevilles could the country stand without violence and terror becoming the order of the day?'

Speaking to The Observer at his home in South Africa this weekend, Yutar said he still had court documents from the trial. Yutar had a public reconciliation with Mandela in 1995. Now 90, he plans to write a book arguing that he saved his future President's life by switching the charge against him from treason, with its mandatory death sentence, to sabotage.

Hilda Bernstein, wife of a co-defendant, has recalled that Mandela's mother and his then wife, Winnie, were in court for the end of the speech.

'During my lifetime,' Mandela said, 'I have dedicated my life to this struggle of the African people. I have fought against white domination and I have fought against black domination.

'I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons will live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. It is an ideal for which I hope to live and to see realised. But, my lord, if it needs be, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die.'

Bernstein has written of the audible sighs that followed. It is now possible for others to hear them too. According to Bernstein's account, Yutar's opening remarks were to have been broadcast by the state-run South African Broadcasting Corporation. The prosecutor had been given a microphone. But the judge banned the broadcast at the last minute.

Thanks to the British Library, it is Mandela's arguments, not Yutar's, that will be heard first by the South African people.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Smith says minimum performance standards for libraries are overdue
fields.body:
Smith says minimum performance standards for libraries are overdue

The Government is to crack down on public lending libraries which fail to provide a high level of service. New guidelines announced by Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary, will set a benchmark for performance for the first time. Those libraries which fall short, with inadequate opening hours or lack of computer access, will be given three years to improve, writes Vanessa Thorpe.

Smith denied that the monitoring system would be used to 'name and shame' failing local authorities. He said libraries had suffered under the Conservative government when there had been 'no emphasis at all' on provision.

The new targets are based on the work of the top 25 per cent of libraries and any necessary changes are expected to be funded by the increased spending settlements going out to councils. Smith said he was completely opposed to any suggestion of charging for borrowing books which were a 'fundamental part' of public access to education.

Teenagers held over death

A man aged 18 and a girl of 16 were being questioned over the death of former merchant seaman Alfred Wilkins, 67, whose home in Grimsby was set on fire. Wilkins had been cleared three months ago of indecently assaulting a little girl. Local residents waged a hate campaign against him after his acquittal. The local council said it had hoped to rehouse him.

69 flood warnings issued

The Environment Agency issued two severe flood warnings, both in Kent, and 67 flood warnings, the majority in southern England, East Anglia and the North East. Water up to a metre deep poured into homes in Yalding, Kent, liable to flooding because it is at the confluence of the rivers Beult, Teise, and Medway.

In Yorkshire areas close to the River Ouse were again under water. In Scotland heavy snow was expected to result in floods as a thaw sets in, but ski slopes reported the best conditions for decades.

Search for gold bullion

Detectives investigating the Brink's-Mat robbery spent a third day searching a builders' merchants in Hastings for stolen gold bullion, drilling holes up to about 4ft deep, without success. Around £10 million from the £26m robbery at Heathrow Airport in 1983 is still outstanding.

Parents on murder charge

A couple charged with murdering their eight-week old son were remanded in custody when they appeared in a magistrates' court. Paul Hill, 21, and Lisa Wardle, 20, of Grimsby, Humberside, were remanded until 19 February. Shaun died on Wednesday after being taken to hospital.

Irish censors lift Ulysses ban

A film version of James Joyce's Ulysses is to be shown for the first time in Ireland - 33 years after censors banned it for being sexually explicit and 'subversive to public morality'.

Green light

Ambulance crews in Surrey testing green uniforms similar to those in the TV series Casualty received less public abuse. Their standard navy blue uniforms are often confused with those of the police.

Drug find

A passing motorist found 300 bars of cannabis resin worth £250,000 which had been left beside a tree near Bullington Cross, Hampshire.

Men reject pill

Only four out of 10 men say they would take a male contraceptive pill, according to an NOP poll commissioned by the Science Museum. The pill is undergoing trials in Edinburgh.

Reinstated pilot dies

Captain Stuart Clapson, 54, a British Airways pilot that a tribunal ruled had been unfairly sacked for shouting at a female passenger who claimed there was a bomb aboard a flight, has died weeks after winning his job back.

Lottery results

The winning numbers are 7 9 12 17 20 32. The bonus ball was 30. Lottery Extra numbers were 9 10 12 14 36 39.

The Thunderball numbers were 4 9 12 14 24. The Thunderball was 12.

webTitle: Germany declares war on invasion of 'Denglisch'

fields.headline: Germany declares war on invasion of 'Denglisch'
fields.trailText: Germany is ready for war with the English again - but this time the barricades are up against an invasion of nouns, verbs and adjectives.
fields.body:
Germany is ready for war with the English again - but this time the barricades are up against an invasion of nouns, verbs and adjectives.

A proposed language purification law aimed at repelling English words is receiving support from academics, linguists and politicians who want hefty fines for anyone caught speaking the bastardised tongue they call 'Denglisch'.

Flirt, baby, power, edutainment, clever, administration and underwear have become part of everyday vocabulary. Other words such as kidnap, relax and pick-up have been Germanised and the list, say experts, is growing by the day.

Conservative politician Eckart Werthebach, 56, Interior Senator for Berlin, is behind the law which he says is necessary to protect German from extinction. 'The language is being abandoned, thanks to a growth in Americanisms, and older, less edu cated people, foreigners living in Germany who don't speak English, and to some extent children, are excluded.'

The plan has increasing popular backing. An opinion poll in Focus magazine showed that 53 per cent of Germans are against use of English words. Complaints by older Germans that they no longer understand simple everyday tasks because of the increasing use of English are rising. 'I sometimes feel like I'm living in a foreign country,' said Gertrud Braun, 53, a newsagent in Berlin.

The popular daily tabloid Bild last week published a list of words which it says are gravely under threat, and a further list to which Germans have as good as said 'Auf wiedersehen'. Shopping, happy, sale, event, statement, cancel and dressing have largely cancelled out their German equivalents, says the paper, while words like slow motion, last-minute, make-up and and highlights have usurped home-grown words.

Last week the German Language Union launched a petition against BSE - Bad Simple English - which said: 'We, the undersigned, will no longer accept the unopposed public undermining and displacement of our language.

'We protest [at] the totally one-sided takeover by English expressions.'

Its chairman, Professor Walter Krämer, said there was a definite case for imposing fines when people were put at risk because of Denglisch. 'If it says in a taxi "fasten your seatbelt" instead of "bitte anschnallen", the driver would have to pay a fine of at least 50 marks.'

webTitle: Revealed: how Africa's dictator died at the hands of his boy soldiers

fields.headline: Revealed: how Africa's dictator died at the hands of his boy soldiers
fields.standfirst: President Laurent Kabila's blind faith in his teenage warriors was a fatal error, reports  Stuart Jeffries
fields.trailText: President Laurent Kabila's blind faith in his teenage warriors was a fatal error, reports Stuart Jeffries.
fields.body:
The teenage killer of Laurent Kabila is still on the run a month after the Congolese president's murder, according to a dramatic account of his assassination which has emerged in Paris.

The report also casts new light on why the 'child soldiers' of the ex-president's army turned against Kabila and plotted his assassination.

It suggests there was no international conspiracy, nor were Congolese rebels who control much of the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo responsible. Rather, Kabila's kadogos (Swahili for child soldiers) committed parricide against a man they believed to have betrayed them.

Kabila had believed that the kadogos who had served him loyally since his rebellion in 1997 against ex-president Mobutu were utterly loyal. He even told a visiting foreign businessman: 'They will never do anything against me. They have been with me since the beginning. They are my children.'

Kabila's young killer entered the president's office at the Marble Palace in Kinshasa on 16 January, as the increasingly paranoid and isolated Kabila was discussing with an economics adviser a looming summit with France he hoped would be his political salvation.

The assassin bent over Kabila, and the president, assuming the teenager wanted to talk to him, leaned towards him. The kadogo then produced a revolver and shot the president four times, and then escaped with other conspirators while the palace resounded with gunfire.

At least three of those involved in the plot, including the unnamed killer himself, fled Kinshasa, crossed the river Congo and may have gone into hiding in Brazzaville, capital of the neighbouring Congo.

The investigation casts doubt on the official version of Kabila's murder. According to Justice Minister Mwenze Kongolo, Kabila was killed by another bodyguard called Rashidi Kasereka, 18, who was then shot dead.

But, according to yesterday's report in Le Monde, Kasereka played a minor role in the assassination team. A sub-lieutenant who took part in the assassinations, identified by Le Monde only as 'A.L.', said that Kasereka was killed by Kabila's bodyguards while the real killer escaped.

'A.L.' was in charge of 35 men who were posted outside the presidential palace. Two men got inside the building, four others hid in the palace to provide cover.

'Rashidi was one of four men giving covering fire to our partner. But Rashidi never got out. The rest of us, we ran about 300 metres to where we had left our six vehicles. Then we split up and disappeared into the city.'

The plot to kill Kabila started in early January when a dissident group of kadogos went to Brazzaville and drew up a document setting out Operation Mbongo Zero. 'Mbongo' is a Swahili word for buffalo, a reference to the ex-president's corpulence.

A copy of the assassination plan has been kept by one of the plotters, identified by Le Monde only as 'Abdoul'. Consisting of three unsigned hand-written pages, it explains how the conspirators would infiltrate strategic positions in Kinshasa, including the presidential palace, the national radio and television station and the headquarters of the country's electricity company. It involved some 75 members of Kabila's bodyguard at the presidential palace, many of whom were arrested after the killing.

The roots of the boy soldiers' dissension go deeper. Kabila founded his Alliance of Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire in 1996, backed chiefly by Rwandan and Ugandan forces (with whom he later fell out), but with support from the kadogos, from the east of the country.

Kabila consolidated his power base by organising the assassination of one of the co-founders of the Alliance, Andre Kisase Ngandu, who had been chief of the National Council of Resistance for Democracy, a group opposed to Mobutu to whom many of the kadogos belonged.

One of those kadogos was 'Abdoul', who supported Kabila during the 1997 coup d'etat, but never pardoned him for killing his former leader: 'I marched with Kabila, but I knew he was a traitor.'

Resentment against Kabila grew. Last June, in a desperate roll of the dice, Kabila agreed to meet the Rwandan president General Paul Kagame, to devise a plan to protect his teetering regime. Kagame was a long-time enemy of the kadogos and thus the meeting alienated them further.

At the same time, Kabila was sowing internal dissension. According to Abdoul, he treated his 'children' with contempt: 'We knew no one in Kinshasa. All the time we were with Kabila. But he treated us badly. We didn't have salaries, all the money came from him. We were like beggars.'

Increasingly paranoid, Kabila started to devour the children of the revolution. Last November, he believed he had discovered a plot against him and arrested, tortured and killed soldiers loyal to Commandant Anselme Masasu Nindaga who had days earlier made a subversive speech at a reunion for 1,200 kadogos in Kinshasa.

The day before his assassination, Kabila had witnessed the execution of 47 kadogos, all believed to be plotting against him. His terror had turned on those who had been his closest allies, the boy soldiers who had marched with him from eastern Congo four years earlier.

webTitle: WWI leader had officers shot 'to goad troops'

fields.headline: War leader had officers shot 'to goad troops'
fields.trailText: Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig, the First World War commander, issued orders that more officers should be executed for cowardice in a bid to strengthen the 'fighting spirit' of his troops, new evidence has revealed.
fields.body:
Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig, the First World War commander, issued orders that more officers should be executed for cowardice in a bid to strengthen the 'fighting spirit' of his troops, new evidence has revealed.

Haig - along with other senior generals - said that military courts were being too lenient with officers convicted of cowardice or desertion. Less than two months after his orders were circulated, the first British officer to be condemned to death for alleged cowardice, 21-year-old Edwin Dyett, was shot at dawn in France. Dyett said he had got lost in no-man's-land but was convicted of desertion. A few weeks later a second young officer was executed.

The new evidence will boost demands, recently rejected by the Government, for a pardon for the 306 British servicemen executed in the First World War. Opponents of the move have called it 'sentimental and ignorant'.

John Hipkin, leader of the pardons campaign, said the new evidence 'basically explains why a number of innocent young men died. It's a missing link'.

Haig's hardline stance was revealed during research by historian and author Lawrence James and is featured in BBC History magazine next week. James found a reference to the command in the unpublished five-volume diary of Major-General Sir Aylmer Haldane, a senior officer who fought in the Boer War before commanding a brigade in the 1914-18 conflict. Haldane often commanded actions from positions in the trenches and knew the reality of contemporary battle.

In October 1916, in the aftermath of the Somme offensive, Haldane attended a conference for senior staff at a château behind the lines. His diary records that his commanding officer, Lieutenant-General Sir Edmund Allenby, 'read out confidential ... papers [from headquarters] regarding leniency that courts martial were showing to officers tried for offences for which men were shot.' The order clearly said that more officers should be executed.

Andrew MacKinlay, MP for Thurrock and a key campaigner for a pardon for executed 'deserters', said the reference revealed the contempt for life shown by the generals and the 'double standards' applied to officers and private soldiers by military judges.

'Despite the obvious patriotism, loyalty and sheer guts of the soldiers in the trenches, Haig and his staff continued to suspect that they were not up to the job,' said James last week. 'In fact, incidences of disobedience were very rare. Officers frequently led their men forward on almost suicidal missions, despite their serious misgivings.'

There is even evidence that some senior officers believed in a kind of 'frontline eugenics' and used executions as a way of culling the weak and unfit. At the end of 1916, 20 men from the 35th Division, composed of unusually short men, so-called 'bantams', received death sentences.

'People say you shouldn't rewrite history, but when the truth is revealed by new evidence you must. A pardon is long overdue,' said Hipkin.

webTitle: Guilty secrets of town  with blood on its hands

fields.headline: Guilty secrets of town  with blood on its hands
fields.standfirst: Stephen Downing walked free last week, 27 years after being jailed for the murder of Wendy Sewell. His conviction is certain to be quashed. But if he is innocent, then who is guilty?  Amelia Hill  reports from Bakewell, which has known the truth all along.
fields.trailText: Stephen Downing walked free last week, 27 years after being jailed for the murder of Wendy Sewell. His conviction is certain to be quashed. But if he is innocent, then who is guilty? Amelia Hill reports from Bakewell, which has known the truth all along.
fields.body:
For 27 years, the small town of Bakewell has been living with guilt. Children born long after the horrific events of that chilly, sunny day cheerfully rattle off the tale of the young woman with questionable morals who was murdered in the graveyard on the edge of town and how a gentle, mentally disabled boy was fitted up for the crime.

But their parents speak more softly, describing how they bumped into one of the real murderers just last week at the local supermarket and how these men, with blood three decades old still on their hands, continue to laugh openly at the law and torment the families of the bereaved for kicks.

The 1973 murder of Wendy Sewell, the woman dubbed the Bakewell Tart with a taste for illicit, outdoor sex who slipped Mars Bars into the hands of men who took her fancy - an unmistakeable sexual signal for those who had lived through the Sixties - hit the headlines again last week.

Stephen Downing, victim of Britain's longest alleged miscarriage of justice, was a bewildered boy when he disappeared into jail all those years ago, tearfully protesting his innocence.

He is now a middle-aged man with the lowered eyes and bowed shoulders of one who has spent his formative adult years being beaten into submission alongside some of Britain's most notorious murderers. As his parents field phone calls from neighbours and read out letters of congratulations from supporters in their neat front room, Downing fiddles with intense, childlike fascination with gadgets that were undreamt of in his small town at the time of his incarceration - the television remote control is a revelation to him - while the idea of going out for a pint is so novel as to leave him bewildered.

But although Bakewell turned out in force to greet Downing with undisguised delight when he returned home to the tiny, genteel town last Wednesday, his release has only served to replace the millstone of collective guilt they have carried around their necks for three decades with another, heavier burden.

Because they know three things: that they stood by while a child was incarcerated despite incontrovertible evidence pointing to his innocence; that the true killers still live among them and could be responsible for at least two other murders; and that, despite their genuine delight at seeing Downing finally walk free, his name has been cleared only because one man devoted six years of his life fighting for justice in the teeth of attempts on his life, more death threats than he bothered to count, malicious gossiping intended to soil his name and apathetic silence.

Don Hale, the editor of the local newspaper, is Bakewell's real-life Poirot. From the day six years ago when Downing's parents contacted him in a frenzy of anticipation after receiving an anonymous letter from a woman claiming to have sent Hale new information that could clear their son's name, he has not faltered.

'Initially, I didn't want to touch the case,' he admits, directing his slight, bemused smile down at the table and toying with his glasses in gentle, modest mannerisms that belie the ferocious determination which has seen him triumph over the might of the Debyshire police, the Crown Prosecution Service and the Government itself.

'It seemed like a crazy thing to do. The case had been done and dusted for 30 years, but when I tried to prove Stephen's guilt instead, I came across so many inconsistencies, faults and downright falsehoods in the prosecution's case that it could only point to one thing: the boy's absolute innocence.'

The graveyard where Wendy Sewell was bludgeoned to death in a vicious and frenzied attack during her lunch hour on 12 September 1973 sits high up on the Derbyshire hillside, its wild ivy-covered trees and sculpted yew hedges casting a lowering, Gothic shadow over the town that spreads out in the valley below.

It was here that Downing, a 17-year-old boy with a reading age of 11 who had never had a girlfriend and kept hedgehogs in his garden shed, worked doing odd jobs in the deconsecrated chapel. It was also where Sewell, with her taste for outdoor sex, came to meet boyfriends during the two-hour lunch breaks she regularly took from her local secretarial job in the Forestry Commission.

'She didn't conceal what she did during those lunchbreaks,' claimed a local who lived near Sewell on the outskirts of the town. 'She never tried to hide what she was like, there was no point: it was a small town and everyone knew what she was at.'

There is plenty of evidence that Sewell was not shy: other locals relate how, when her husband used to leave for work in the mornings, she would turn a light on in the porch to signal that the coast was clear. During one of the couple's many break-ups, she rented a room over a wool shop where she met men until she was asked to leave. When she gave birth to a son and had it adopted, at least three men believed themselves to be the father.

Sewell and her husband, David, had forged some sort of reconciliation at the time of her murder and were once again living under the same roof. There is no indication that she had tempered her behaviour, however, and colleagues remember how she spoke about an argument she had had with her current boyfriend the night before she disappeared.

At 12pm, she received a phonecall or a visit in the office and her boss, on the phone in the other room, remembered hearing raised voices before Sewell popped in with a note telling him she was nipping out for lunch. A friend who met her rushing up the hill a few minutes later said Sewell was excited and indicated that she was on her way to meet her boyfriend to make up after having argued.

At 1pm, Downing stoked the fire in the chapel, slung his coat around his shoulders and headed home to feed the two baby hedgehogs he had rescued and have a bite of lunch with his mother. As he walked up the long path from the back of the graveyard to the front entrance, he later told police he remembered seeing Wendy striding back and forth behind the chapel on a parallel path, close to the wood.

He took no notice and walked on. Five witnesses saw him leaving the graveyard at this time with his characteristic unhurried, shambling gait and by the time his mother returned home not more than seven minutes later Downing had already boiled the kettle and was in the garage, changing his boots.

At around 1.20pm, Downing left home and, waving to the man in the graveyard gatehouse, walked back to the shed. No more than five minutes later, he was back, hammering on the gatehouse door and shouting about a woman who had been attacked.

His return coincided with the arrival of three workmen who went with him to where he had left Sewell. She was still alive and, at their approach, got to her feet and began stumbling around. The men watched as she tripped and fell, smashing her head against a gravestone. Hale believes it was this final fall that killed her: had she been restrained or lain still, her life might never have ended and Downing's nightmare would never have begun.

She was still alive by the time the police and ambulance arrived but was unconsious by the time she reached the hospital. Downing was pulled in immediately for questioning, although the police insisted he was merely helping them out - he was neither cautioned nor allowed a solicitor. The boy, already in a state of severe shock, was questioned for nine hours.

Downstairs, they sent away his father, who arrived six times to pick up his son. They wrote out a confession in pencil full of words Downing didn't understand, saying he had murdered Sewell and sexually attacked her between 12.50pm and 1.08pm, which they eventually persuaded him to sign in ink. By the time Sewell died two days later without regaining consciousness, Downing was bang to rights.

After being contacted by Downing's parents, Hale started his investigation by simply knocking on the doors of houses overlooking the graveyard and almost immediately struck gold - an old woman greeted him with open arms: 'I'm so glad someone is finally doing something about this,' she said, ushering him into the house.

She had seen a van parked outside the front of the graveyard at the time of the murder and had noted two men behaving in a unusual manner. She had written down the registration number and description of the men on the back of a cigarette packet and taken it to the police station but had been told to go away.

Hale asked her if she still had the notes taken on the day of the murder and unbelievably she opened a drawer full of clutter and pulled out the cigarette packet.

'It was beyond belief, 22 years she'd kept that box,' said Hale. 'It was yellowed and dusty but still completely legible - and damning to the police case.'

Hale had the registration number traced and found that it belonged to another man known to Sewell, the man she'd been on her way to meet that day.

When Hale took the case back to court to ask for an appeal, he was turned down. But then came his second stroke of luck. In a village miles away, Jane Atkins, a young girl at the time of the murder who had run away from home shortly afterwards, happened to read about the case in a local paper left in a restaurant where she was waiting on tables.

She contacted Hale and revealed that on the day of the murder, she had entered the graveyard from the back just after the one o'clock news had ended and seen Downing leaving at the front - she had recognised his walk.

As she walked through the graveyard, she saw Sewell alive and well in the arms of her boyfriend, a well-known local businessman. She could prove that Sewell was alive and well long after Downing had left the scene of the crime.

Painstakingly combing over ground deep in the silt of the years, Hale uncovered more witnesses: local people who could prove Downing's innocence or at least throw doubt on the police case. Some of these people had approached the police and been turned away and others had covered their eyes and ears to Downing's plight.

As Hale dug, more scum rose to the surface. A man covered in blood had been seen by numerous witnesses running from the scene of the crime, identified by many at the time, but the police didn't want to know.

As Hale started peeling back the layers, certain people began to get nervous. Twice he narrowly escaped being run down by a car, then he received a phonecall from a man who said that was his last chance and that 'if you don't drop that story, you only have another couple of weeks to live'.

Hale said lightly: 'That's how I knew I was getting close.' He admitted, however, that when the phonecall was followed by a high-speed car chase by two lorries that slammed repeatedly into the back of his car forcing him to escape over open fields, he was seriously scared.

He moved house with his wife and went ex-directory. The police gave him a mirror on a stick to check the bottom of his car for bombs and suggested he drop the whole thing.

Downing, raped, tortured and bullied in jail, quite possibly owes his life to the fact that Hale didn't pay the slightest attention to the attempts on his life, and since Hale's final success on Wednesday the whole country knows it. On the day Downing's bail was granted, he gave 48 interviews and, in the days since, his mobile phone has barely stopped ringing.

But although delighted that his battle is almost won, Hale can't help but feel left out: a Sunday tabloid bought up Downing's story six months ago and has tried ever since to cut Hale out of the proceedings - banning him from seeing the family for four days, and making it difficult for him to talk to them ever since - while the lawyers have hoovered up his painstakingly collected findings and presented them as their own.

From being the black sheep challenging the institutions, Hale is now the inconvenient cog everyone prefers to overlook. He now has 28 days to draw up a final file to present at Stephen's appeal to ensure the continuation of his current freedom and then he wants to go on to nail the guilty men.

'Of course I'll do it,' he said. 'But it's difficult sometimes to keep my enthusiasm up after being kicked in the teeth like this now.

'I just feel I have been cut out of it,' he said unhappily. 'I feel like I've done all the work and everybody else is getting the praise. Of course I'm delighted that Stephen is free but apart from that I feel I've got nothing back after all this time.

'I'm not in it for the money but I've got very little credit, even in court.'

webTitle: Medicine to raise women to new heights of passion

fields.headline: Medicine to raise women to new heights of passion
fields.standfirst: For women, the research is the biggest advance since the vibrator 100 years ago
fields.trailText: For women, the research is the biggest advance since the vibrator 100 years ago.
fields.body:
No need for the oysters, red wine and log fire. Drugs companies are spending millions of pounds developing pills to help women desire sex and ensure they enjoy it. Hoping to repeat the worldwide success of Viagra, researchers are now trying to unravel the secrets of women's sexuality.

They claim we are on the brink of a sexual revolution, where medicine can unlock the doors to sexual heaven. According to a TV documentary this week, The Fall and Rise of Sex , the advances will allow everyone to enjoy good sex well into old age.

The loss of sexual desire, and the inability to become physically aroused, can be as emotionally devastating for women as for men, and is responsible for ruining thousands of marriages. However, most medical research has been into male sexual dysfunction, particularly impotence.

Female sexual dysfunction had until recently been presumed to be simply psychological. Only in the last few years have doctors realised it can often have treatable physical causes - such as the menopause or abdominal surgery.

Some scientists are trying electronic methods to arouse women. Last week researchers from North Carolina announced that they could bring women to orgasm with electronic implants in their spine. Clinical trials into the new technology will start in the US later this year.

Dr Jennifer Berman, a urologist at the Univerisity of California in Los Angeles, said: 'We have focused on how to maintain and promote fertility, but not necessarily on sexual function and response, and that is really what's changing.'

For women it will be the biggest scientific advance since the vibrator was invented more than 100 years ago as a health product to help them relieve 'nervous tension'.

Researchers at the University of Washington in Seattle are studying what happens to women during arousal by showing them erotic films in a magnetic resonance imaging machine. Their research shows the clitoris normally expands by 80 per cent, and they can now test whether drugs can help achieve this. Viagra has proved effective at helping some women become physically aroused, but it only works for a minority.

However, often the problem for women is not physical arousal but the desire for sex in the first place. Julia Heiman, professor of behavioural sciences at the University of Washington, said: 'What's interesting now is that because such a large number of women have been identified with low desire that there's starting to be some interest in treating sexual desire pharmacologically.'

The biggest breakthrough came accidentally after a male researcher from the University of Arizona tried an experimental skin-tanning drug and ended up with an erection for eight hours. Rather than improve erectile function like Viagra, the drug worked by improving desire.

Researchers now think the drug is more likely to be useful for women than for men, who suffer a lack of desire less often.

Women can also copy even more basic desire enhancers from men: the male hormone testosterone. Gabriela Buich went off sex after her hysterectomy, and found testosterone has helped. 'I do have libido, it sort of goes in and out, but there is libido. I kind of feel like I'm having a little bit of maleness right now,' she said after the treatment.

However, Dr Ian Osterloh, of Pfizer, which produces Viagra, said it was early days: 'The research is much further back than it is with male sexual dysfunction - there are fewer experts in the field.'

But even if the drug companies do hit on the holy grail of a pill that promotes perfect sex, we could simply get worn out. Therapist Dr Leonore Tiefer warned: 'We're now going to have the 20-year-old vagina in the 60-year-old lady to go with the 20-year-old erection in the 60-year-old man. I'm not sure the genitalia can bear all that.'

 The Fall and Rise of Sex will be shown on Channel 4 on Tuesday, 10pm

However, most medical research has been into male sexual dysfunction, particularly impotence. Female sexual dysfunction had until recently been presumed to be simply psychological. Only in the last few years have doctors realised it can often have treatable physical causes - such as the menopause or abdominal surgery. Some scientists are trying electronic methods to arouse women. Last week researchers from North Carolina announced that they could bring women to orgasm with electronic implants in their spine. Clinical trials into the new technology will start in the US later this year. Dr Jennifer Berman, a urologist at the Univerisity of California in Los Angeles, said: 'We have focused on how to maintain and promote fertility, but not necessarily on sexual function and response, and that is really what's changing.' For women it will be the biggest scientific advance since the vibrator was invented more than 100 years ago as a health product to help them relieve 'nervous tension'. Researchers at the University of Washington in Seattle are studying what happens to women during arousal by showing them erotic films in a magnetic resonance imaging machine. Their research shows the clitoris normally expands by 80 per cent, and they can now test whether drugs can help achieve this. Viagra has proved effective at helping some women become physically aroused, but it only works for a minority. However, often the problem for women is not physical arousal but the desire for sex in the first place. Julia Heiman, professor of behavioural sciences at the University of Washington, said: 'What's interesting now is that because such a large number of women have been identified with low desire that there's starting to be some interest in treating sexual desire pharmacologically.' The biggest breakthrough came accidentally after a male researcher from the University of Arizona tried an experimental skin-tanning drug and ended up with an erection for eight hours. Rather than improve erectile function like Viagra, the drug worked by improving desire. Researchers now think the drug is more likely to be useful for women than for men, who suffer a lack of desire less often. Therapist Dr Leonore Tiefer warned: 'We're now going to have the 20-year-old vagina in the 60-year-old lady to go with the 20-year-old erection in the 60-year-old man. I'm not sure the genitalia can bear all that.'  The Fall and Rise of Sex will be shown on Channel 4 on Tuesday, 10pm

webTitle: It takes just four minutes to log into paedophile web

fields.headline: It takes just four minutes to log into paedophile web
fields.standfirst: This club had its own chairman and treasurer. Its business was child abuse
fields.trailText: The computer was already switched on in a quiet corner of The Observer's London offices. I picked a search engine at random. So far so simple. Typing in the most innocuous term which sprang to mind, 'pre-teen', I expected to have a long, complicated trawl through the world wide web ahead.
fields.body:
The computer was already switched on in a quiet corner of The Observer's London offices. I picked a search engine at random. So far so simple. Typing in the most innocuous term which sprang to mind, 'pre-teen', I expected to have a long, complicated trawl through the world wide web ahead.

But it took four minutes. Without being asked for payment or identification or a credit card number, the computer screen showed a series of the most disturbing photographs I have ever seen - graphic pornographic images of little children.

I had asked an IT expert to help me discover just how accessible child porn really was on the internet. I thought we might find a suggestion of it. But these were not dirty pictures: this was child abuse of the most horrific kind. Some images were of naked little girls who had been encouraged to strike adult porn star poses. A click on the mouse took us straight to another website, again with a strip of photographs across the middle of the screen.

'Very littli (sic) girls 3-9 year old,' ran a banner headline. 'Free photos from Russian Undegraund (sic) Server.' The face of a child aged no older than seven was pictured pushed against the genitalia of an adult male. Next to her came a picture of a tiny child whose body was being violated by the man holding the camera.

The experiment was over, I could not stomach any more but shutting down the web page was so difficult; endless pop-up adverts directed the user to an endless array of other sites where children had been abused in horrific circumstances.

One such child was Donna, aged 10, whose photograph was put on the internet by the father of her best friend. No one who knew her had any idea she was being abused until the man was arrested after a complaint by another child. Donna's horrified mother was told her daughter had not only been raped but that rape had been filmed and put on the internet.

The Observer also visited chatrooms where sexual fantasies were discussed and liaisons arranged. It took longer, perhaps up to an hour, before a paedophile, anonymous behind his electronic protection, cruised through one of the chatrooms looking for 'young boys'.

A spokesman for the National Crime Squad said last night that the speed at which we had found such images was no surprise. 'Availability of paedophilic material is a massive problem,' he said. 'The availability of these sites is increasing and we are working on ways of preventing this happening.'

webTitle: The dormant cannibal inside us all

fields.headline: The dormant cannibal inside us all
fields.trailText: Cannibalism, one of the greatest taboos, is both loathed and feared. Yet the mindset of those few who have deliberately eaten human flesh turns out to be closer to our own than we would like to think.
fields.body:
Cannibalism, one of the greatest taboos, is both loathed and feared. Yet the mindset of those few who have deliberately eaten human flesh turns out to be closer to our own than we would like to think.

As cinema audiences prepare to thrill once more to the unsavoury antics of Hannibal Lecter, the monstrous creation of novelist Thomas Harris, the team working on a new television series about cannibals has uncovered some unpalatable truths.

For the first time, the psychological profile of an Identikit cannibal killer has emerged from their study of the behaviour of four notorious offenders. According to the makers of the Channel 4 series Cannibal, which starts next week, the abhorrent crime is the result of a combination of fairly unremarkable factors. What is more, they have proved cannibalism was once a regular feature of life in this country.

In making the first film in the series, The Real Hannibal Lecters, the director Katharine English and her team of consultant psychologists set out to examine the psychological traits of Jeffrey Dahmer, Andrei Chikatilo, Issei Sa-gawa and Arthur Shawcross. The first two serial killers are both dead - Dahmer murdered in prison and Chikatilo executed in Russia - but English came face to face with the surviving cannibals, Sagawa and Shaw cross. Treading in the footsteps of Harris's fictional FBI agent Clarice Starling, English visited both murderers and interviewed them about their pathological impulse to eat the bodies of their prey.

'There were striking similarities,' she said, 'not only in the kind of neurological problems we found but in the upbringing of these men.'

All four shared a marked lack of normal function in an area of the brain known as the pre-frontal cortex, and they exhibited sexual problems which directed their libido away from penetrative intercourse. The killers all suffered a strong sense of dislocation from their mothers very early in childhood.

But, for English, the differences between the cannibals were just as fascinating. 'Both Sagawa and Dahmer had an obsessive need to connect and commune with their victims, while Chikatilo and Shawcross, in contrast, were both driven by a deep-seated violence.'

English said she became aware during the interviews that both the cannibal killers she met were teasing her in a way which will be familiar to fans of Harris's novels, The Silence of the Lambs and Hannibal. In Tokyo, Sagawa talked of his unacceptable urges and said he would like to eat her.

'Interviewing Shawcross,' she said, 'I was also aware that he felt he was behaving like Hannibal Lecter... we sensed that he was enjoying talking about his alleged cannibalism to a young woman.'

The second two programmes in the Cannibal series have unearthed evidence of past cannibalism. Archaeologists researching the burial site found at Eton College near Windsor have confirmed Iron Age Britons were cannibals. Bones found snapped and scored with flint tools match those of animals butchered for food.

Series producer Daniel Korn said he believes cannibalism has always been a dormant human characteristic. 'It is something nobody wants to think about,' he said, 'and it has been censored out of existence in most modern cultures.'

webTitle: Russian migrants fearful as gang boss comes to Britain

fields.headline: Russian migrants fearful as gang boss comes to Britain
fields.trailText: A key member of a ruthless gang of Russian criminals is on the loose in Britain, running brutal protection rackets, vice rings and frauds,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
A key member of a ruthless gang of Russian criminals is on the loose in Britain, running brutal protection rackets, vice rings and frauds, The Observer can reveal.

The man, who holds numerous passports and goes by several names (most recently Karelin), was the mastermind behind the multimillion-pound credit card and counterfeiting ring for which two men were jailed earlier this month. Although half a dozen members of the ring were captured, Karelin remains at large.

The wide reach of his criminal empire and the fear he generates among one of the UK's fastest-growing ethnic communities mean few people are willing to talk, and those who do ask not to be named. 'There are increasing numbers of Russian businesses over here, and many people are doing very well,' says one community member. 'In Russia it is normal to pay for protection, and working here it is often no different. Men like Karelin are a thorn in the side of the community here. For the most part people are here to work hard and make a good life for themselves. The few criminals among us means everyone gets tarred with a bad brush.'

Karelin is believed to be a member of the vori v zakone, a term which translates as 'Thieves in law'. Established in the heart of the brutal Russian prison system, the Thieves have enhanced status and command respect among others by adhering to a strict code of conduct. They must forsake their families and never marry, reject any relationship with anything which represents the establishment, never co-operate with the authorities and, most importantly, must earn money only through criminal activity, even if only petty crime.

According to Dr Paddy Rawlinson, an expert on Russian organised crime, low-level racketeering is a growing problem among the 200,000 citizens from Russia and other former Soviet bloc countries who now live in the UK. 'The initial fear that followed the break-up of the Soviet Union was that the Russian mafia would come here and take over absolutely everything. The reality of Russian organised crime in the UK is that they prey on the most vulnerable members of their own community. Many Russians in this country don't have documents and work in poorly paid jobs or sweatshops. As a community they tend to stick together. In short, they are easy targets for protection rackets and extortion.'

Well-paid executives here are now being targeted for extortion. Last month armed police from Scotland Yard's Kidnap and Specialist Investigation Unit freed a Russian businessman kidnapped from his home in Essex, shooting out the tyres of the gang's car in an ambush. The victim, who had been beaten and tortured, was also the victim of a kidnapping two years ago. Four men, all Russians, have been charged in connection with the incident.

Three murders in London and the South East have been linked to Russian criminals. In 1993 Ruslan Outsiev, the self-proclaimed Prime Minister of the former Russian Republic of Chechnya, and his brother, Nazerbeck, were both murdered. Each was shot three times in the head. Outsiev, a former mafia member, had been slain by his interpreter, Gagic Ter-Ogrannisyan. A few months after Ter-Ogrannisyan was convicted of murder, his British sister-in-law, Karen Reed, was gunned down on the doorstep of her Surrey home in an apparent revenge attack. Her killer has never been caught.

Earlier this month two of Karelin's recruits, Vladimir Strogvin and Alexander Tanov, were jailed for four years for their part in his most recent scam. State-of-the-art machines and equipment, much of it imported from Russia, had been set up in a flat in Streatham, south London, to produce copies of Visa, MasterCard and American Express cards. Some were sold on for £300 a time, while others were used for extravagant shopping sprees, buying designer clothes and electrical goods later sold on the black market. Karelin is currently believed to be running similar credit card scams in other parts of the country, as well as a number of other activities.

According to Jim Moody, former head of the FBI's Organised Crime Unit, the code that criminals like Karelin follow is both their stength and their weakness. 'Regardless of what is going on in their lives, they have to continue carrying out illegal activities. They have to make a living solely through crime. If they stop, they instantly lose their status and with it all their power.'

Next week the National Criminal Intelligence Service will release the results of a detailed study into the impact of criminals from the former Soviet Union. A threat assessment released last year noted: 'In no criminal market in the UK have FSU crime groups established a significant presence, although they have become notably visible in the areas of prostitution, cigarette and vehicle smuggling. Those involved in such crimes are as likely to be Lithuanian as Russian.'
