webTitle: Former slob Joe Decker becomes fitness king

fields.headline: 'Fat boy' is work-out king
fields.standfirst: Former slob Joe Decker ran, swam and cycled for 23 hours to become world's fittest man
fields.trailText: Former slob Joe Decker ran, swam and cycled for 23 hours to become world's fittest man.
fields.body:
As a teenager, Joe Decker was an overweight couch potato. He devoured beer, pizza and Twinkies, took no exercise and saw his weight balloon. When he joined the US army, his inability to run two miles in 16 minutes meant he had to endure the humiliation of extra training in the 'fat boy programme'.

Yet last week Joe Decker was named the world's fittest man after completing the most gruelling physical challenge on earth in a record time. In the space of 24 hours, and without stopping to sleep, he ran, cycled and swam further, did more muscle-busting exercises and lifted far heavier weights than the previous winner of the Physical Fitness Challenge.

Scarred by endless jibes about his weight, 30-year-old Decker is now enjoying the title bestowed on him by Guinness World Records, the ultimate authority on incredible feats. Last week they named him 'the work-out king of the world'. Where once he had layers of unwanted blubber, now he has lean, honed muscle.

Decker's tilt at the title began with a 100-mile cycle ride and 10 miles each of running, hiking and rowing, moved on to five miles of powerwalking, six miles kayaking and a two-mile swim. He then completed another 10 miles on a skiing machine, 3,000 abdominal crunches, 1,100 jumping jacks, 1,000 leg-lifts and 1,100 push-ups and finally ended with a three-hour gym session in which he lifted 278,540lbs in weights. Incredibly he did all 13 events back-to-back, never stopping once to rest, much less sleep.

Chris Sheedy of Guinness World Records said: 'His achievement is momentous, unbelievable, superhuman. When his letter arrived I thought, "to do all this in such a short time isn't physically possible". But he sent us videos, eyewitness statements, doctors' reports - more evidence than we needed to validate his claim. It's as well he did, otherwise I wouldn't have believed he'd done it all.'

The previous record-holder, Steve Sokol of San Jose, California, took 23 hours and 43 minutes in August 1998 to complete all 13 challenges. Decker matched or bettered Sokol's achievements in 22 hours, then spent two hours lifting more and more weights in a bid to ensure that whoever tries to outdo him will have to demonstrate almost bionic capabilities. Competition rules say any successful challenger must equal all the holder's feats, and improve on at least one.

Decker, from Illinois, is no ordinary athlete. From Monday to Friday he gets up at 4.45am and from 5.30 leads a 90-minute class for serious fitness fanatics. After a quick breakfast he heads to the gym for several hours, then spends the rest of the day taking classes - always outdoors, come rain, snow or sunshine - and running his own business advising companies on employee health. For a bit of light relief, he runs 20-50 miles on a Saturday and cycles up to 100 miles on Sunday. His tee-shirt bears the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche's dictum 'what does not kill me makes me stronger'.

Pain and suffering do not worry him. He rates his training work outs from one to 10 on a personal 'nausea scale'. Several times a week he does an eight or a nine, just short of 'full-blown hurling'.

Decker is always looking for new ways of testing his limits. His favourites are ultra-marathons and adventure challenges. He has experienced hallucinations, disorientation, dehydration, swollen feet, sleep deprivation, extreme tiredness, tunnel vision and mind-numbing tedium during races lasting up to week at a time. During a 520-mile race across the Himalayas by foot, mountain bike and rope he almost died.

Why does he do it? His spur could be a childhood of extreme poverty or maybe it's his physique, more that of a weightlifter than an athlete, or the memory of being called 'fat boy'.

'I'm an average person,' he insists. 'What I've done is something just about anybody could do if they put their mind to it. Don't just want to do something; if you want to attain something, get off your butt and make it happen.'

Think you're in shape?

In 24 hours the world's fittest man completed 13 events:

Cycling: 100 miles
Run: 10 miles
Powerwalk: five miles
Kayak: six miles
Hike: 10 miles
Swim: two miles
Abdominal crunches: 3,000
Jumping jacks: 1,100
Push-ups: 1,100
Leg-lifts: 1,000
Skiing machine: 10 miles
Rowing machine: 10 miles
Lift: 278,540lbs

fields.headline: This club had its own chairman and treasurer. Its business was child abuse
fields.standfirst: It takes just four minutes to log into paedophile web
fields.trailText: It seemed like an ordinary club, with a chairman, a treasurer and a board of long-serving and respected members.
fields.body:
It seemed like an ordinary club, with a chairman, a treasurer and a board of long-serving and respected members.

Everyone had a nickname and there were the usual petty rows: grumbles that too many members were being allowed in without going through the official channels or being approved by the hierarchy.

But it was the sinister entry fee that exposed the fact that this was no ordinary club: each new member had to supply 10,000 pornographic images of children.

This was the Wonderland Club, an international online paedophile ring which ran for four years before finally being smashed by the biggest international police operation ever undertaken.

Tomorrow, seven British members of the ring will be sentenced at Kingston Crown Court for 'conspiring with others to distribute indecent images of children'. The legal jargon masks a terrible reality: Wonderland was an international network of paedophiles involving the rape of boys and girls live on camera and the traffic in images of the torture of children as young as two months.

The international investigation to crack the ring was the biggest in policing history, taking in 13 countries and 180 men. Led by British officers, on 2 September 1998 police forces simultaneously kicked in the doors of 107 homes and made 104 arrests.

The suspects included the usual collection of outsiders: unemployed loners in UK bedsits, a father and son in a US trailer-park. But they also numbered a computer consultant in an Italian penthouse apartment, a German professor and a Canadian medical student who had trained on a children's hospital ward. The more senior members of the club earned their status by providing photographs and videos of themselves performing sex acts with children. In a perverse paedophile version of Hollywood, certain children became 'stars'.

One prolific abuser, Gary Salt, invited other members to visit his Stockport home to pose with children in front of the webcam as if they were meeting a screen hero. Thesheer weight of the physical evidence illustrates the enormity of Operation Cathedral - 750,000 individual images of children and 1,800 computerised videos depicted children being sexually abused.

The images were so appalling that National Crime Squad officers who had to sift through the mountain of material had compulsory therapy sessions to help them deal with what they saw.

'These really are quite horrific images,' said Alex Wood, deputy chief inspector of the NCS. 'These are kids being subjected to the most serious, serious, abuse.'

The ring began to unravel after the arrest of Ronald Riva in Greenfield, California. Officers discovered that Riva had raped his daughter's 10-year-old friend in front of a camera which relayed the live image onto the internet. The child, who had been invited to a slumber party by Riva's daughter, is one of only two of the 1,236 Wonderland victims to have been traced. The other, a Portugese boy, has disappeared and police fear he may have been murdered.

Among six men who had typed messages of encouragement to Riva was Ian Baldock, a 31-year-old computer consultant from St Leonards, East Sussex. The FBI informed the UK police, who soon realised the scale of the enterprise they had stumbled on. Operation Cathedral was born.

'At first there was not enough police knowledge or power,' said Wood.

'We had to bring in computer experts who worked with us for 14 months. Once we had traced actual computers we then had to establish who was using that computer at a particular time and with many of them in libraries and universities it wasn't easy.'

Round-the-clock surveillance on suspects had to be introduced to ensure none had access to children while the investigation was ongoing. At one point, the operation almost collapsed when one British man, Gavin Seagers, was discovered working with Sea Cadets. The police knew that if they arrested him they risked tipping off the whole network. Tracing the victims of the Wonderland Club is now a priority. New technology is being tested out by Interpol based in Lyons, France, to enable photographs sent in by social services and families to be 'matched' by computer against the victims' photographs. Already 900 children have had their photographs 'sanitised' and stored and police forces across the world will be able to access them.

The British Government introduced legislation last month to increase maximum sentences for the possession of child porn from six months to five years. Those caught producing or distributing the images will now receive sentences of 10 years rather than the present maximum of three. But the new sentences will not apply to the Wonderland Club.

Next month the internet Crime Forum at the Home Office will publish a report on chatrooms where child abusers discuss their fantasies. Police have become concerned that these forums are being used to 'groom' children and lure them to meetings with paedophiles. The report is likely to make depressing reading. A Home Office spokesman told The Observer : 'We have a very co-operative relationship with internet service providers, but it is technologically impossible for them to stop this stuff.'

In April, a new cyber-crime unit will start work involving 80 officers from the police, Customs and the National Criminal Intelligence Service.

According to the National Association of Probation Officers most internet offenders do not see themselves as criminals and few receive treatment. Spokesman Harry Fletcher said: 'We are only beginning to understand the scale of this crime. It is a major problem that their offending behaviour is not being challenged.'

webTitle: Saudi expat community rocked by arrests of Westerners

fields.headline: Arabian nightmare
fields.standfirst: The murky world of expatriate life in Saudi Arabia has been rocked by the arrests of three Westerners for murder. But are they being framed?  Paul Harris reports
fields.trailText: The murky world of expatriate life in Saudi Arabia has been rocked by the arrests of three Westerners for murder. But are they being framed? Paul Harris reports.
fields.body:
Alexander Mitchell had an admission to make. 'I confirmly confess that I was ordered to carry out an explosion here in Riyadh, which took place on Friday the 17th of November, the year 2000.'

The Scotsman squinted at the television autocue before continuing his statement, which was riddled with grammatical errors: 'The explosion was directed against Mr Christopher Rodway, who is a British nationality. I placed the explosive device under the driver's seat of Christopher's car.'

Minutes earlier, Mitchell had arrived under heavy armed guard at the studios of Saudi national television in downtown Riyadh with Canadian William Sampson and Belgian Raaf Schifte. They were about to admit killing Rodway and blowing up another car in which three more Britons and an Irish woman were injured.

But to observers, something appeared odd. Looking dazed and frightened, the trio sat separately behind a desk and used a pointer stick to show how they carried out the attacks. Mitchell said he had been ordered to use a remote control to carry out the bombing, but would not say who gave the instructions or why.

The 46-year-old also used street maps to show the location of the victim's houses and the exact sites of the blasts. He would have known that, under Saudi Arabia's strict interpretation of Islamic law, convicted murderers are beheaded, usually in public, to deter others.

His friends were astonished. 'His words made no sense, especially saying he was commanded to carry out the attack. He was a jovial man about town, with fingers in a lot of pies but always good for a laugh,' said one. Another thought Mitchell looked drugged or was suffering from the effects of extreme fatigue.

The authorities had hoped the arrests and confessions would lead to swift justice and put an end to speculation about the possibility that terrorists were active in this prosperous state. The authorities hoped that blaming infidels from the West would prove that the Saudis were a peaceful people.

But the authorities were wrong. The country is buzzing with rumours about the decadent high life of the Western residents of 'Happy Valley', and dark mutterings about whether innocent men are to be put to death.

It was a sunny day when the 4x4 car pulled up to a crossroads in the centre of Riyadh four months ago. Inside were Rodway, who worked in a hospital, and his wife, Jane. Seconds later an explosion tore through the vehicle, shattering the silence that usually hangs over the Saudi capital's streets on the Muslim holy day of prayer.

A bomb had almost severed Rodway's leg. As frantic passers-by rushed to the scene and called the emergency services, it was clear his chances of survival were small. Later that evening Rodway died. Jane was lucky. She escaped with minor injuries.

Five days later, on 22 November, a second car bomb went off. The targets this time were driving down Riyadh's old airport road. The blast injured all of them, with one, Mark Paine, requiring major surgery to save a leg.

Panic spread rapidly through the expat community. Islamic terrorists were suspected as the attacks came soon after a suicide bombing that killed 17 US sailors in Yemen. Warnings were issued to check cars and a host of events on the usually busy expat social scene were hastily cancelled.

When a third bomb exploded in the eastern city of Al Khobar, pressure on the Saudi police reached its peak. David Brown, a British Coca-Cola executive, lost an eye when a juice carton left on his car exploded in his face. Now terrified of having its international image damaged, the Saudis moved quickly. Mitchell and other Westerners were already known to the police for their past role in the illegal alcohol trade and were arrested on 17 December, along with six other foreigners, for drinks offences.

But in pinning the crimes on Western suspects linked to the underground drinking industry, the Saudis lifted the lid on one of their best kept secrets - the decadent high life enjoyed by foreigners living there. Despite strict laws that include a ban on drink, drugs and women drivers - upheld by the Mutawwa'in religious police - it is possible to party around the clock in Saudi Arabia.

Alcohol is freely available. Diplomats and their visitors used to rely on foreign embassies sneaking liquor into their compounds in diplomatic bags. But recently the scene has exploded into a fully-fledged industry, fuelled by smuggling over the long and porous desert border with Yemen.

Other merchandise comes in from neighbouring Bahrain, where alchohol is legal. Most of it is brand-named and expensive: a bottle of malt whisky costs more than £125.

There is also a thriving cottage industry in home-brewed beers, wines and spirits. Thousands of gallons are distilled inside the self-contained compounds in which most foreigners live and where makeshift bars are set up. Deliveries are usually made on a Friday, when most of the local population are at mosques praying.

But the pubs are an open secret. They are bought and sold, have names such as Raffles and the Empire Club, regular discos and breweries in their backrooms. Mitchell once owned a bar called Celtic Corner, which had its own membership lists and a gymnasium. Last year he sold up to Rodway and Saudi police have seized on the transaction as a possible source of dispute between the two men.

But it is not only Westerners who are living it up in the desert: the high life attracts the cream of Saudi society. Some are there for the drinks, others are there to make money. Saudi business relies heavily on patronage and, according to diplomatic sources, all the leading Western bootleggers have senior Saudi backers who take a slice of the illegal profits.

'Saudi is not like it used to be. You can get anything you want there if you are willing to pay for it, and some of the people hanging around these bars are very senior people. It is big money,' said Barry Jones, who lived for several years in Riyadh and worked in publishing.

The parties are often wild. Many of the expat workers, from nurses to oilmen, are single. With money to spend and severe restrictions on public shows of decadence, what goes on behind closed doors is often hedonistic. One former resident joked last week that few marriages survived an extended stay in the country.

According to former residents, drugs too are becoming part of the expat lifestyle, though they are not tolerated by the authorities. Marijuana, cocaine and even heroin are available to those willing to pay. The penalty for those caught trying to smuggle in drugs, usually 'mules' from countries such as Nigeria and Pakistan, is death. With such a vibrant market for illicit goods, Saudi police claim it was no surprise that turf wars would erupt now and then. The apparent involvement of three Westerners in the alcohol trade and the sale of illegal bars seemed to confirm that shady dealings would lead to trouble.

Despite the arrests of Mitchell, Sampson and Schifte, the bombings continued. An explosion rocked the plush Euromarche mall in Riyadh on 10 January. The blast injured no one but destroyed a telephone booth and damaged a passing car. And it was this explosion that could lead police to those behind the previous bombings, including the explosions admitted by the three Western suspects.

Saudi dissidents, speaking to The Observer, revealed last week that a note claiming responsibility for the Euromarché bombing was left at the scene. The note, which did not identify a specific group, warned of more and bigger attacks to come unless the Saudi government released political prisoners.

The opposition groups are Islamic fundamentalists, appalled that so many Westerners have been allowed into a country which guards the holiest shrines of Islam. They want them out and the Saudi royal family along with them. Yet the government relies on foreign expertise. Almost 300,000 Europeans and North Americans work in the country.

If opposition groups are proved to have been behind the Euromarché bombing, some observers believe that linking them to the other bombings will be irresistible.

'Most of the Islamic opposition people want to get foreigners out of the country. All these bombs have been targeted at foreigners,' said Said Aburish, a Middle East expert and author of a book on corruption in Saudi Arabia.

Many of Saudi Arabia's small opposition groups take their inspiration from Osama bin Laden, who planned the bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. Ironically, the weapons and explosives used by these groups enter along the same routes used by alcohol smugglers - overland from Yemen.

Raids by the police are common. The Observer has learnt that last November, after the first two bombings, more than 50 people linked to the opposition were arrested. 'The government knows it was jihadi (Islamic) groups behind all these four attacks. They just do not dare to admit it,' said Saad al-Faqih, head of the London-based Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia, an opposition group campaigning for peaceful reform.

Mindful of huge business interests in the country, Britain has played a careful diplomatic game, refusing to condemn outright the Saudi action in arresting Mitchell. But the trio face a long period of uncertainty while diplomats try to find a solution and avoid a trial that would almost certainly be held in secret. The men could escape death if Rodway's family accept 'blood money'. But Rodway's father, Jerry, has already called for his son's killers to be executed.

Tory MP David Wilshire MP will this week table Commons questions to Foreign Secretary Robin Cook demanding stronger moves to protect Mitchell's rights. 'It would seem that the British Government is unwilling to kick up a fuss for fear of upsetting people who we do a lot of business with,' Wilshire said.

Questions are also likely on why the men confessed. Human rights campaigners believe they were subjected to psychological torture. Locked up alone, denied food and threatened with abuse, a confession was inevitable, they claim. Eventually the men - exhausted, confused and terrified - were told to admit to the bombings.

Meanwhile, the executioner's sword is being sharpened. Observers fear that could mean the truth may never be known.

webTitle: Fast food facts

fields.headline: Fast facts
fields.standfirst: One small bite for man, one giant problem for mankind
fields.trailText: • A central London parking meter earns more per hour than most fast food staff.
fields.body:
 A central London parking meter earns more per hour than most fast food staff.

 Britons spend £1.26 billion a year on burgers. The fast food industry as a whole is worth more than £5bn a year.

 Wimpy opened Britain's first fast food restaurant in 1962, followed by KFC in 1965, Pizza Hut in 1973, McDonald's in 1974 and Burger King in 1980.

 McDonald's customers in Britain each year eat their way through £58 million of beef, £39.5m of chicken products, 52,000 tonnes of French fries, 453 million buns and 7 million gallons of milk.

 One million people work for McDonald's worldwide, feeding 35 million people a day.

 Burger King has 9,400 outlets in 56 countries. McDonald's has 23,000 branches in 105 countries.

 A low-fat burger in the US was abandoned because it tasted too bland.

webTitle: Letters: Lockerbie and hypocrisy's rule

fields.headline: Hypocrisy's rule
fields.trailText: I welcome the comments by Stuart Millar and Richard Ingrams on the Lockerbie bombing trial. Apart from the questionable verdict, there is the hypocrisy of our Government supporting the Americans in their bombing of Iraq and sanctions against Libya.
fields.body:
I welcome the comments by Stuart Millar and Richard Ingrams on the Lockerbie bombing trial. Apart from the questionable verdict, there is the hypocrisy of our Government supporting the Americans in their bombing of Iraq and sanctions against Libya, which they attempt to justify by reference to UN resolutions, while taking no action against Israel for its continuing refusal to accept any such resolutions.

It hardly needs saying that the death toll of Arabs in the latest troubles in Israel exceeds that of the Lockerbie crash.
E.J. Thatcher
Rickmansworth, Herts

 'A blighted verdict', according to Stuart Millar, and that goes for the whole 12-year investigation of Lockerbie. If we assume the perpetrator to have been the Libyan state, we presume it was in retaliation for the raid on Tripoli. Who is being brought to justice for that act of state terrorism in which Britain played part?
Harvey Quilliam
Maghull, Merseyside

webTitle: Isa special: Easy way to invest in the best

fields.headline: Easy way to invest in the best
fields.standfirst: Helen Pridham kicks off our 10-page guide to buying tax-free bargains
fields.trailText: Helen Pridham kicks off our 10-page guide to buying tax-free bargains.
fields.body:
If you are the sort of person who relishes managing your money, this time of year will hold no dread for you. Not for you the rush to beat tax deadlines and to postpone decisions about if, when and how to invest.

For the less well organised, however, the hardest months of winter collide with the dying months of the tax year. If you have spare money to invest, this means a scramble to use up your Individual Savings Account (Isa) allowance by 5 April. Sheltering your savings from tax is always a good idea - even if you have only a few pounds in the building society. But it is not easy choosing the best Isa for a serious long-term investment, and this year is more difficult than most because of the uncertainty about the US economy.

Many investors take the line of least resistance and look through a few Isa advertisements to find one which takes their fancy. Or you might come across one of the growing number of Isa recommendation magazines published by firms of financial advisers.

These methods of choosing your Isa have several drawbacks. The Isa managers who do most advertising tend to be last year's winners, but as investment adviser Warren Perry of Bristol-based Whitechurch Securities says: 'Buying the best performing funds from last year means investors often end up with a hotchpotch of high risk funds.'

Advertising also appears to taint some of the recommendations published by advisers. Choosing each year's Isa in isolation is not the ideal way to organise your investments anyway. If you want to get the best out of them, you need to consider your investments in the round. 'Before you make any decision about this year's Isa ,take stock of what you have already,' says Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of investment adviser Bestinvest.

Like many colleagues, he believes that building a balanced portfolio, which spreads your investment across different stock markets and funds with different styles of investing, is the only way to minimise risk and get good, consistent returns. If you are a first time investor, Bestinvest suggests a variety of different portfolios to meet different needs. (These can be found in the company's free Isa Guide, or on their website www.bestinvest.co.uk which also provides useful information about funds.)

If you already have a couple of Isas and maybe some Peps as well, you will need to try to work out the existing geographical spread of your investments. This will often reveal a gap that can be filled with this year's Isa.

For example, if all your investments are in the UK, you could consider adding some overseas funds. Mark Howard of adviserMaddison Money Management suggests: 'A very rough rule of thumb would be to have around 50 per cent in the UK, 25 per cent in Europe and the rest in the US and other markets.'

When you review your existing investments, you may find they also need changing to give you a more diversifed portfolio. If you own Peps, making sure you have the right spread of investment will become much easier after the end of this tax year. This is when rules for Peps will be brought into line with Isas.

This change will have major effects. It will remove the geographical restrictions from Peps. Previously, investors were able only to place £1,500 of their annual Pep allowance in funds that were not predominantly invested in the UK and Europe. It will also allow investors who bought single-company Peps (which could be invested in just one company's shares) to switch their money into unit or investment trusts and spread their risks better.

While you are examining your existing investments you should also check whether their performance is up to scratch. Comparative unit trust, and investment trust performance statistics can be found in magazines such as Money Observer and Money Management. Useful internet sites for researching funds include x www.trustnet.com, which provides performance and other useful information, x www.iii.co.uk, which lists funds' total expense ratios, x www.standardandpoors.com, which assesses fund managers, and x www.citywire.co.uk for latest fund news items.

If you decide your current Peps or Isas are not performing well enough, you can switch them to other managers without harming their tax-free status. However, this can be costly. You could be face another set of initial charges on the new unit trusts or Oeics - open-ended investment accounts, another form of mutual saving - of up to 5.5 per cent. Making the switch via a discount broker who will take no commission will cut the cost to around 2 per cent, but you could face the same problem in future.

A much more cost effective way of managing your Peps and Isas in the long run is to use an online 'fundsupermarket'. Buying an Isa like this, allows you to invest your annual allowance in several different companies' funds at no extra cost. The other big advantage is that switches between funds cost only 0.25 per cent or 0.5 per cent.

Fidelity, the leading provider of this type of deal, now also accepts Pep transfers. Although fund supermarkets were initially designed for investors to use via the internet, some investment advisers, such as Bestinvest, will set up a fund supermarket Isa or Pep transfer for investors who prefer to make traditional paper-based applications.

webTitle: It takes three to tango

fields.headline: It takes three to tango
fields.standfirst: Lindsay Duncan is a grieving mother. Toby Stephens shines. And Elvis lives - in Bolton
fields.trailText: Lindsay Duncan is a grieving mother. Toby Stephens shines. And Elvis lives - in Bolton
fields.body:
Mouth to Mouth Royal Court, London SW1
Japes Theatre Royal, London SW1
Martha, Josie and the Chinese Elvis Palace Theatre, Watford

In 1994, My Night with Reg provided the Royal Court with a big hit, and the London stage with a new vision - one that, in the manner of new visions, now seems self-evident: it showed the world through the eyes of a group of friends under the threat of Aids.

It also provided its dramatist with a flexible template for future plays. A Kevin Elyot play is a memory play. It tracks back from the present (the new one is prefaced by a Proust quotation) towards a transforming historical moment. The mood is elegiac and regretful. Liaisons are covert and complicated. The sexual charge is gay.

All this is true of Mouth to Mouth. It begins with a taut, mysterious exchange between Lindsay Duncan (mute and fragile in dark glasses) and an uneasy Michael Maloney. It flashes back to scenes between Duncan and her teenage son: a delicious episode shows them resolving a quarrel as they tango together. It shows Maloney snogging this son - not for the first time. It discloses the son's early, perhaps suicidal death; it reveals that the boy's father was the man he thought was his uncle. It suggests that the Maloney character, a floundering writer, is going to salvage his career by using all this as material.

Exquisitely directed by Ian Rickson - so that the whole drama seems to be performed in one breath - and flagged up as sensitive by mauve lighting, this is a beguiling evening, an evening that holds you. But it's as if the tragedy has been grafted on to a smaller, more niggling plot. Too many crucial moments don't make sense. Lindsay Duncan - who's terrific at being louche in a scarlet petticoat - is required to display grief by an exorbitant stammer. It's as if she's taking an Open University course on losing it.

In a series of very funny cross-patch memoirs, Simon Gray has recorded how disagreeable it is struggling to get a play put on. You could deduce some of these troubles from his plays, which chronicle the lives of people - teachers of literature, editors of small magazines - who may, if Shakespeare is extruded from the syllabus, be on the point of extinction. But, from the buoyant literary allusions, and the packed dialogue, you also deduce something worth struggling for. Gray is the most intricately literary of contemporary dramatists. Sardonic, alert, crammed.

Japes - the misleadingly jaunty title refers to a nickname - is a case in point. Two brothers and one woman are followed over 27 years. One man's a lauded writer - first seen in his twenties being self-importantly blocked; later glimpsed haggard with triumph after a TV show. He (the insufficiently feline Jasper Britton) marries the girl. His younger brother, an unpublished drunk, sleeps with her (everyone knowing and not saying, and therefore getting by) throughout the courtship and marriage. Toby Stephens lights up this part with a virtuoso performance - by turn nonchalant and lolling, ramshackle and desperate; full of charm and full of fire. Clare Swinburne can't do the same with the female part. With a ruthless logic, her role is underwritten, to underline the fact that for the two brothers she barely exists as a character: they fancy her but are preoccupied with each other.

Japes contains one scene and one character too many. The child of the wife and lover would have been more potent left to the imagination. And Gray is more inward with the defining detail of the Seventies and Eighties. John Gunter's ugly design - grey walls which look as if someone's dragged a chisel through wet cement - doesn't sharpen Peter Hall's production. But it doesn't disguise the subject of an uneven but astute play. Towards the end, a vigorous assault is launched on 'in yer face' theatre: you could see this as a continuation of Gray's grumbling memoirs, but it's also a repudiation of the idea that being explicit is the same as being precise. Gray, the fluent wordspinner, turns out to be an advocate of keeping it buttoned.

Charlotte Jones's last play, In Flame, moved from the Bush to the West End. Her fourth will open at the National later this year. Meanwhile, Martha, Josie and the Chinese Elvis is at Watford. It features a middle-aged woman running a cosy household in Bolton - and working as a dominatrix. She has a simple 30-year-old daughter who fantasises about being an ice-skating champion; she employs a cleaner with an obsessive-compulsive disorder. Her doorbell plays 'Love me Tender'; her most regular client - a dry-cleaner who dresses up as an ultra-frilly-knickered French maid - makes a cocktail called 'A Catastrophe'.

From the start, everything is light and loopy, and laced with camp innuendo: 'a nice girl is always in control of her gusset'. But the play takes off when the main act - Tim Wong, a nervous trainee Elvis impersonator - arrives. This isn't just because of the music, and the extravagant imitation of those splayed and shaking legs. Watching an act of impersonation in the theatre - where, after all, everyone on stage is pretending to be someone else - always has a receding-mirror thrill. In this case, it also slips neatly into a crossword puzzle-style pattern. Wong's Elvis isn't the only character to rise from the dead. And he's not the only focus of obsession.

Lawrence Till's production has had them roaring at Watford. By the time it gets to the West End, a few bumps - a slowish start and some over-jolly acting, especially by Debra Penny who seems bent on doing a Sue Pollard impersonation - should be smoothed out. Some things don't need to be. Belinda Lang undergoes a lovely transformation from holy drudge to raven-haired temptress. She provides one of the high points of the evening - another tango: the lissom Lang arches herself over her portly partner and flicks her tongue over his bald head. 'From the front to the back,' instructs the madam. 'It's more hygienic.'

webTitle: Thank you for the Days

fields.headline: Thank you for the Days
fields.standfirst: The first designer couple are now enjoying a much-deserved renaissance
fields.trailText: The first designer couple are now enjoying a much-deserved renaissance
fields.body:
Robin and Lucienne Day Barbican, London EC2 until 16 April

The most striking thing about the Barbican's exhibition of Robin and Lucienne Day is its clear demonstration of the impact of fashion on the reputations of even the most level-headed of designers.

You see the two of them emerging from the Royal College of Art, surviving the war and then purposefully striding straight into early success in the 1940s. His big win in the same Museum of Modern Art furniture design competition that got Charles Eames started, was followed by posters and signage for the Festival of Britain, and a commission to design the furniture for the Festival Hall.

She did textiles for Heal's, most notably the Calyx pattern that brought the spirit of Calder and Miro into the domestic world - and she still remembers being beaten down on the fee by a director sceptical that they would ever sell. Their work was fresh, optimistic and managed to catch the mood of the the time.

Together with their striking looks, it made them Britain's first designer couple. Smirnoff photographed them for an advertising campaign in their bright, spare house in Chelsea, with its walls stripped back to the brickwork and painted white, and its cork tiled floor, in a successful attempt to make vodka smart. He sports a snappy pencil-thin bow tie, she is elegant in a new look dress. They moved rapidly from radical fringe to mainstream. When progressive city firms wanted to demonstrate how up-to-date they were, they put a Day boardroom table in their offices. When BOAC wanted to put the finishing touches to its gleaming new fleet of silver VC10s, it was the Days they asked to give style and colour to the cabins.

When the new universities of the 1960s fitted out their halls of residences, it was Robin Day's furniture that filled their study bedrooms, and Lucienne's fabrics that were used for the curtains and the single upholstered chair. In canteens and church halls, it was Robin Day's polypropylene stacking chair that architects specified. At least 14 million of them have come off the Hille production line since 1963. They were so ubiquitous that they became invisible, which, of course, is what Robin Day, with his preference for modest and intelligent design, wanted.

For much of the second half of the twentieth century the Days' work formed the background to a certain strand of life in Britain, the Britain of British Rail, and the Barbican itself, never extreme, never overtly fashionable, but modest and comfortable. And, of course, as that Britain still unembarrassed by the the idea of public service, of progressive architects, and the welfare state, began to retreat, and look threadbare in the 1970s, so the Days' work became no longer invisible, but the essence of an embarrassing past, whose face no longer fitted, ripe for modernisation.

Fashion never stops. And the Days have now been propelled forward again. From being regarded as dowdily old hat, they have acquired the status of retro chic. But it would be a travesty to see them as charming period pieces resurrected for the delectation of Wallpaper readers, and the dealers who are rapidly transforming the relics of the 1970s into collectable antiques.

Both the Days are still working. As Tom Dixon, Habitat's design director says, they have spent 50 years designing together in the same room, their drawing boards touching. Robin Day's shrewd visual intelligence, and Lucienne's sensitivity to colour is revealed as transcending the limitations of period. The storage system designed to lean against the wall that Robin Day originally produced with Clive Latimer for that Museum of Modern Art competition in 1948 is finally being put into production by Habitat, and is as relevant now as it ever was. The panel sofa designed last year for the Sheridan Coakley, the manufacturer who has done more than anyone to establish a new generation of British designers 50 years after the Days first came to prominence, shows the work of a designer who has lost none of his powers. Indeed there is a clear link between the quiet, unemphatic logic of Day's work with the restrain of some of those younger designers, most notably that of Jasper Morrison.

webTitle: Barbara Windsor's in a ballet?

fields.headline: Barbara Windsor's in a ballet?
fields.trailText:
Cohabitants, Clore Studio Upstairs, ROH
Romeo and Juliet, Royal Ballet, ROH, London WC2
fields.body:
Cohabitants, Clore Studio Upstairs, ROH
Romeo and Juliet, Royal Ballet, ROH, London WC2

In the studio at the top of the Royal Opera House, dancers chant the Cockney lament: 'It's the rich what gets the pleasure, it's the poor what gets the blame.' Their non-paying audience mingles with the affluent opera crowd from the auditorium below. On their nights off, Royal Ballet dancers give their services free to the Artists' Development Initiative, run by Deborah Bull. It offers them the chance to experiment - without taking the blame if they're not perfect.

Cohabitants (last performance this Wednesday) is a show shared by choreographers Tom Sapsford and Cathy Marston, friends from Royal Ballet School, now in their twenties. Sapsford opens the bill with 'Last Night at the Empire', a tribute to the glory days of British music hall. His droll survey encompasses the recorded voice of Barbara Windsor, who started her career at the Brick Lane Music Hall in the East End.

That's where this cabaret should be presented, rather than in the cavernous Clore Studio. Jason Carr at the piano is sidelined as the cast of four perform their amazing feats and strange turns (to quote from the manual that inspired Sapsford). Luke Heydon is the master manipulator, a sinister Dr Coppelius playing with his clockwork dolls. The female trio lurch between mechanical obedience, chorus girl sauciness and East Ender cheek. What the show needs is an experienced theatrical director to pull it together, pace it and stop us secretly applauding the death of music hall.

Cathy Marston's 'Traces' is a substantial piece for nine dancers, its focus and time-scale constantly shifting. Set to folk-based music by Yann Tiersen, it takes us through the pangs of adolescence. A gaggle of boys rampage through a playground, pointedly ignored by the girls. Then the first, clumsy encounters get under way, provoking resentment among those left out. Ben Maher's clever costumes adapt as the playmates grow up and pair off.

Christina Arestis is the glamorous girl everyone wants and nobody gets; Rachel Rawlins the quiet one who falls in love; Jenny Tattersall the firebrand. Edward Watson broods as the outsider you can't help watching. His presence is so electric that he's bound to become a murderer or a rock star. Marston's quicksilver choreography exploits the dancers' personal qualities, intercutting them like characters in a mini-series. Because episodes happen simultaneously, the piece deserves subtler framing and lighting than a workshop studio can provide.

The main stage's Romeo and Juliet has gone back to the drawing board for a redesign. It could do most of all with redirection. Nicholas Georgiadis has abstracted his architectural set, leaving its stairs and arches intact throughout but making scene changes emblematic rather than realistic. The action is speeded up; the ballet's dramatic emphasis shifts; the dancers can no longer rely on the decor to do their acting for them.

In the ballroom scene the massed might of the Capulets has now to be conveyed through imperious dancing instead of an intimidating set. The opening march is an amble, Tybalt a pussycat, Lord Capulet an old buffer in his dressing gown. At the first two performances, with Sylvie Guillem as Juliet and Nicolas Le Riche as Romeo, the lovers' tragedy took place in a vacuum. webTitle: Chasing the legends

fields.headline: Chasing the legends
fields.trailText: Wynton Marsalis Symphony Hall, Birmingham
fields.body:
Wynton Marsalis Symphony Hall, Birmingham

Fate has arranged things very conveniently for Wynton Marsalis. Here he is, ensconced as leader of the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra, the world's most lavishly funded jazz outfit, dedicated to performing jazz of all styles and eras, and fate hands him two major centenaries in quick succession.

In 1999, it was Duke Ellington, and this year it is Louis Armstrong, both artists whose work he idolises. Marsalis and the orchestra are touring Britain with Swingin' The Kingdom , a programme featuring Armstrong's music alongside pieces by Ellington, Monk and others. A recording will be broadcast on Radio 3 tomorrow night at 7.30pm.

Like Armstrong, Marsalis is a trumpet virtuoso, and they were both born in New Orleans. Beyond that, it is difficult to imagine two men more different. Armstrong, a child of the streets, raised in an institution for 'Colored Waifs', and Marsalis, the Juilliard-trained prodigy.

Marsalis's command of the instrument appears absolutely effortless. By contrast, Louis was virtually self-taught, applied enormous pressure to his lips when playing and suffered greatly in later life as a result. But the effort and sense of struggle created the urgency that was an indispensable part of his music. The ebullient Armstrong more or less invented jazz as we know it today, but always thought of himself as an entertainer.

Marsalis, the son of a jazz musician, has dedicated his life to securing a place for jazz in the mainstream of high culture. He has an easy and pleasant stage personality, but a showman he ain't.

Most big bands today are simply too loud, and their music too busy, but Marsalis has nurtured a subtle and flexible ensemble with a sound all of its own. The five saxophonists, in particular, produce one of the most beautiful blends I have ever heard. The arrangement of Thelonious Monk's 'Four In One', especially the orchestrated piano solo, would frighten the life out of most players, with its breakneck runs and unpredictable accents.

Ever since he was appointed artistic director of the Lincoln Center's jazz project a decade ago, Marsalis has been a controversial figure. His policy of nurturing the jazz tradition upsets the 'progressives' and the power of patronage invested in his office has caused dark mutterings among those not favoured. But he believes passionately in his mission. This must be the only travelling band whose crew includes an education officer.

Best of all, he has created a wonderful band, which he leads with great flair. In the course of this he has restored to jazz many beauties which were in danger of being discarded as outmoded bric-a-brac, the muted effects, growls, smears and gasps of former times and good old-fashioned swing.

Swingin' The Kingdom continues on Tuesday in Brighton; Poole (Weds); and Leicester (Thurs)

webTitle: Head to head with seven tons of novelty dung

fields.headline: Head to head with seven tons of novelty dung
fields.trailText:
T te à T te Bridewell Theatre, London EC4
Arditti Quartet St John's Smith Square, London SW1
fields.body:
T te à T te Bridewell Theatre, London EC4
Arditti Quartet St John's Smith Square, London SW1

Dung, now almost passé as the stuff of contemporary art, still ranks as a novelty in opera. Seven tons of it, complete with dung beetle, amorous creepy-crawly and spider featured in one of five short operas commissioned by T te à T te, an adventurous little company dedicated to bringing 'surprising, dangerous and intimate opera of the highest quality to the widest possible audiences'. Their claims are justified. This lively programme, entitled Shorts and directed by Bill Bankes-Jones, opened a season of contemporary opera at Bridewell Theatre.

Quirky though the subject matter of these operas may be, their intentions are serious. Production standards are high, the three singers (who share all the roles) are young, deft and able to act, and the works themselves offer contrasting musical and textual interest. Enigmatic interludes by Rachel Leach linked piece to piece. Each composer conjures sharply differing textures from only three instruments - clarinet, harp and cello - superbly played by Stuart King, Lucy Wakeford and Adrian Bradbury, and meticulously conducted by Orlando Jopling.

The first work, Miss Treat by Des Oliver to a libretto by Meredith Oakes, was dexterous and funny. In a love triangle, the woman tries to keep two men in tow, only to lose both. Damian Thantrey (baritone) played the cheated lover, his petulance cleverly echoed by a testy clarinet line. Nicholas Sears (tenor), the challenger, had suave music to match his smooth-talking personality. Hilary Dolamore, a confidently skilled and versatile soprano, shrieked, whined and uttered incoherently as the hapless girl. Oliver's music cleverly mirrored the patterns of everyday speech with a rhythmic fluency few composers master. His setting of 'Wanker!' must class as the finest (if perhaps only) treatment of the word in all opera.

From domestic drama to pocket-sized epic: in Julian Grant's Platform 10 or The Power of Literature, to a text by Christina Jones, two trainspotters, mournfully carolling the passing of the steam age, encounter Anna Karenina on the station platform. The collision of these kagoule-wearing monomaniacs with a fur-clad tragic beauty out of Russian literature had strange pathos. Grant devised urgent train music from screeching clarinet with insistent, percussive cello rhythms depicting a diddly-dom era now silenced by welded tracks.

Gary Carpenter drew on patriotic songs, bugle calls and martial music for his bizarre collaboration with Simon Nicholson. Doggone told the true story of 7,000 dogs recruited by the British Army in the First World War for active service in the trenches. With absurdist ingenuity, these creatures were conveyed by pictures of the HMV gramophone dog staring out in military ranks from rows of metal music stands, which collapsed to surprise percussive effect at the end. Damian Thantrey's acting skills as dog-cum-sol dier were put to the test. He passed (on all fours) with flying colours and wagging tail.

Elfyn Jones's elegiac The Nightjar, to words by Toby Slatterthwaite after a story by Ray Bradbury, conveyed the black grief and regrets of a middle-aged couple whose grown-up son has died. The Bach-like solo cello writing, offset by mellow harp and clarinet rhapsodies, had bleak power. In contrast, the last composition was the knottily farcical Seven Tons Of Dung, with a libretto by Bill Bankes-Jones and music by David Bruce. Hilary Dolamore gamely encased herself in green nylon to play Caterpillar, with whom Beetle is in love until she carelessly turns into a butterfly ('Oh bugger! What a waste of such a gorgeous creepy-crawly'). Performances run until 24 February. This engrossing evening is far more bracing (and inventively operatic) than anything on offer elsewhere in a moribund opera season.

Janácek, whose impassioned stage works are now prized after years of relative neglect, still for me holds more fascination as a composer of chamber and keyboard music (not a fashionable view). He waited until he was 69 to compose his First String Quartet ('Kreutzer Sonata'), and told Kamila Stosslova, the younger married woman with whom he was in love, that he had in mind 'the suffering of a woman, beaten and tortured to death' of Tolstoy's story. Together with his second quartet, 'Intimate Letters', these two ardent works were played by the virtuosic Arditti Quartet in an imaginative programme which interwove quartets (including two premieres) by Adrian Jack.

The works were ideally paired. If Janácek's music is red-blooded with episodes of almost blanched intensity, Jack's are the reverse - shades of white with splashes of colour. His 'Third and Fourth Quartets' hold their emotion within. They have the hushed concentration of a conversation in progress, sotto voce , across a room, suddenly bursting out in sound before receding again. Silvery, sensuous melodies (achieved by using string harmonics) emerge from gently rocking accompaniments. The effect is at once transparent and alluringly elusive.

Tolstoy, who featured in both these evenings, thought opera an exploitative waste of human resources. He would have warmed both to T te à T te's flair for economy and the marriage of passion and intellect in Janácek and Adrian Jack's quartets.

webTitle: Actually, you can get something for nothing

fields.headline: Actually, you can get something for nothing
fields.standfirst: U2's free show proved they can still perform at their soaring best. Most of the time...
fields.trailText: U2's free show proved they can still perform at their soaring best. Most of the time...
fields.body:
U2 Astoria, London W1

Something dreadful nearly happened. Standing in the long queue for the most intimate gig U2 have staged since the days when John Peel played their records, in about 1863, I mentioned with an innocent chuckle that a tout had just offered me £400 for my ticket. The response I was looking for was amused derision, but suddenly the queue was awash with excited talk of what a person could buy with such a sum. Twenty rare U2 interview discs! A night on the town with Lady Victoria Hervey! 1,200 tea towels!

Actually, no one specifically mentioned the interview discs, but for a moment, I had a vision of ending up inside the Astoria for this free, fan-only show, alone, save for hordes of Japanese and American fanatics who had been willing to fork out the 800 quid touts were demanding. That most people elected to hold the high ground and decline to sell is a tribute to both the band and our human capacity for extreme stupidity.

Not that being a U2 fan is stupid. No one of sound mind and ear could feel comfortable with everything they've done: their success is down to the fact that, even when you hate them, you love them a little, too - often for the same reasons. Why? Because when they're at their soaring, chiming best, as they are during 'One' tonight, few other bands can touch them. Because a performance like this makes you realise that, like the squashed moth on your windscreen, they've travelled a huge distance over their 20 years, while also sort of staying in the same place. And because Bono is a media-watcher who hates being considered naff, but will grasp that nettle with selflessness and courage when he thinks that the situation demands it. And it so often does. Bless.

All of which goes some way to explaining why the kids aren't here. U2 grew up with post-punk modernism, with the notion that rock must be pushed forward and periodically reinvented to be vital and interesting. But the generation who followed aren't remotely interested in this project, finding an impossible, alien romance in the trad stuff punk had aimed to supplant - hence Oasis, Travis, Coldplay, Stereophonics. Against our better instincts, some of us get grumpy about such reverence, but in the event this evening's show deftly illustrates - as if the Eighties hadn't done enough - both the thrills and pitfalls of the rock modernist agenda.

Bono is looking more like Roy Orbison every day. A woman near me starts crying as he appears, beaming, in black leather jacket and shades. He wears the shades to hide the heroic collection of bags under his eyes, just as Edge dons his black skull cap to camouflage baldness. In fact, you know your audience is middle-aged when you remove your sunglasses and they gasp as if you'd just whipped off your G-string. But, dressed down in jeans and T-shirts, U2 look lean and sound sharp. 'We're back to reapply for the job,' the singer declaims - adding, before the Astoria janitors have time to get worried, that the job they seek is 'best band in the world'. All right, then.

When the dust had settled, how preposterous did this seem, not six months after Radiohead had toured one of the most transporting shows ever seen? Not particularly, for the most part. It was pleasing to note that U2's appearance in such a modest venue felt extraordinary rather than Madonna-does-Academy surreal. At no point did you find yourself thinking 'What's that bunch of 40-year-old dads doing up there?' It was a strange set, though. The lights were spare as they began with impressive first showings of material from the open and engaging current album All That You Can't Leave Behind . The devotional 'Stuck In A Moment You Can't Get Out Of' was near perfect, Orbison meets Al Green, something quite different for U2. 'Beautiful Day' thundered excitably by and 'New York' was even better than on the record, swelling to one of the most stirring crescendos of the night (stirring crescendos being a U2 speciality).

There were a few older pleasers, too. The single which got them noticed in the UK, 'I Will Follow', was fresh and pacy, while the aforementioned 'One' sent a shiver down your spine. Then, three quarters of the way through, the band's energy unexpectedly drained away, as they finished on a trio of nondescript tunes ('All I Want Is You' 'Bad' and 'Forty') I'd forgotten or didn't recognise, and which reminded me why I've often found these people so frustrating.

Where had it gone? And why had they chosen to leave the likes of 'Gloria', 'Pride', 'Sunday Bloody Sunday' and the peerless 'With Or Without You' hanging on the vine? Afterwards, some contended that the eccentric choice of material was admirable, others that it was a foolish indulgence. In the end, I found myself wondering, 'Could that performance have been worth £800?', to which a friend countered in exasperation, 'Andy, is anything worth £800?'. And the answer is that, yes, approximately 2,400 tea towels are.

webTitle: Figure that one out...

fields.headline: Figure that one out...
fields.standfirst: Julian Opie's work poses questions about images and emotions. But what's the point of his matchstalk nudes?
fields.trailText: Julian Opie's work poses questions about images and emotions. But what's the point of his matchstalk nudes?
fields.body:
Julian Opie Lisson Gallery, London NW1 to 17 March
Barbara Kruger South London Gallery, SE5 to 18 March

There's been no getting away from Julian Opie these past few months. Anyone who disagrees should look again - namely at all those billboards, buses, T-shirts and ads that promoted the latest album from Blur. There they were, over and again, four faces reduced to simple black outlines: Damon, Graham, Alex and Dave as they might have been drawn by Hergé. These images came in every size, from CD to full-scale hoarding. Nor was there any idea of a limited edition, based on some priceless original. If you bought the album, it could even be argued that you now own a quartet of Opie portraits.

I daresay most collectors would disagree, especially those prepared to pay £12,000 for a large Damon, or £18,000 for an outsize Alex. But that's the problem with a market that prizes the rare or unique - it can so easily be thwarted by an artist who doesn't hold back. Once Opie has fixed on his visual symbol, he will reproduce it in every conceivable format or size. A quick leaf through the catalogue he has produced for this show - based on those mail-order brochures for furniture or software - gives a comprehensive guide to the merchandise. You can buy animals, buildings and people as prints, wooden blocks or signposts. You can get landscapes on aluminium or video; portraits come in wallpaper or vinyl paint.

Opie's blithe attitude to what he sells is both humorous and winningly frank. After all, he could hardly pretend to be producing complex masterpieces, each carefully nuanced by hand. At 44, Opie has run through a lot of different ideas, from visual gags to neon sculptures and quietly minimal paintings. But he developed the notion of modular art - units that came in build-your-own systems - even before his Hayward show in 1994, and he's stuck with it ever since. Most of the work at the Lisson Gallery is update and diversification: landscapes, portraits and nudes, genres of old master painting.

The basic Opie unit is a representation of a representation. He takes a photograph, feeds it through a computer and then reduces it to a few quintessentials - for a portrait, it's the jawline, hairline, ears and neck, plus the features transcribed in his deadpan shorthand. This mainly consists of customised punctuation: angled commas, double hyphens and black full stops for eyes. Sometimes there are glasses; I specially like the way he indicates the rimless variety with a single ingenious contour. Occasionally there are highlights - rather sentimentally, in the eyes of children. The colour is bright and flat, the outlines have a zippy register and the final image is generally affectless, homogenised and irreducibly simple.

Some find these pictures playful; others feel that they are infused with melancholy. If that seems an extreme response, bear in mind that there are people who become distressed by that sign for Elderly People Crossing the Road. Opie understands the power of signs - he's exploited it with his strategic signposts of shy animals, described in reflective paint, ready to be caught in the headlights of a darkened road. But his portraits are more likely to erase than evoke emotion. They tell you how little can really be learned from a snapshot: the human animal caught in a flash.

Opie can take the riddles of representation too far, however, as with his stick-figure nudes. These are painted on building blocks - the head as a circle on a wooden cube, for example - and must have something to say about two versus three dimensions, though it's hard to tell quite what. But his ongoing series of roadscapes have got somewhere new by virtue of size. These generalised paintings, with their relentless white lines and views of mountains, trees and houses, used to be monotonously large. Now that they are tiny, like souvenirs, they instantly catch on your memory of other times and places.

To say that Opie repeats himself would be no more than a trade description. It's the slight variations that make all the difference to this road movie - the sense that there is always further to go and more to see on the trip. One Opie on its own can look blank or cute or even wilfully simplistic. Together, in his bulk-buy modular system, they add up to a bigger view of the world as a language of limitless images.

The South London Gallery has a video installation by Barbara Kruger , the veteran American moralist. You remember Kruger: 'I shop therefore I Am', 'Don't be a jerk!' and other accusatory or hortatory messages, generally printed on T-shirts or written up in neon, to the reported irritation of pedestrians in Times Square.

Kruger never whispers if she can possibly shout. This time, she has hired a bunch of screaming heads to do the job on her behalf. A dozen actors, on three video screens, yell repeated sequences of abuse in deafening unison: 'You're not cool/ skinny/ pretty enough!', 'I hate you!', 'Who do you think you are?' This cycle of rejection is occasionally broken by swift reconciliations, illustrating, I guess, the awful proximity of love and hate.

Kruger seems to be aiming for the brutal effects of Bruce Nauman, but the piece has none of his piercing directness - largely because her actors are so clearly reading from autocues. It's the same old problem with her work: exactly who is she addressing? After 40 minutes of this hammering cacophony, the main feeling you have, to borrow one phrase, is that 'it's got nothing to do with me'.

webTitle: He's just a slim chancer

fields.headline: He's just a slim chancer
fields.standfirst: Eminem is grotesque and comic on disc. But on stage, he and his alter egos simply don't cut it
fields.trailText: Eminem is grotesque and comic on disc. But on stage, he and his alter egos simply don't cut it
fields.body:
Eminem Manchester Arena

You've got to feel sorry for Eminem: how on earth could he live up to the hype? Short of bringing on Kurt Cobain for an encore, this show was never going to equal expectations. He arrived in Britain as the most famous and notorious pop star in the world. Love him for his verbal dexterity or loathe him for his apparent misogynist and homophobic tendencies - Eminem is not someone who provokes a neutral reaction - there is just no one bigger at the moment.

Manchester was put on red alert as the rapper and his entourage - a cast of hundreds, we were told - descended on the north-west. Outside the venue before the gig there was no sign of the coming apocalypse as the predominately female teenage crowd huddled together in the chilly night. 'The only crimes I've seen today have involved peroxide abuse,' quipped a TV reporter to camera.

There were also the protesters. Eminem's savagely comic rapping, which has understandably enraged gay and women's groups, lies at the heart of his appeal. Hip-hop lyrics aren't famed for their equal opportunities sentiments, and Eminem is hardly the first or most transgressive rapper to use denigrating epithets. But he is the biggest-selling one by some distance, and that, of course, is why he is under the microscope.

It's hard to take his grotesque cartoon imagery seriously and, if you don't, he is funny - although the moment when his devilish alter-ego Slim Shady raps about sexually assaulting his mother on 'Kill You' provides an unsavoury test of faith (his mum didn't like it either: she's suing him for $10 million). What really makes Eminem so interesting is the relationship between his no-dad, white-trash record persona and the real thing. The implicit self-commentary and criticism on his recent No 1 'Stan' takes hip hop's solipsism into rare territory.

Even before the extraordinary events of the past 12 months, Eminem had started making the instalments on the price of fame. His first album, The Slim Shady LP, was rude and witty. His second, The Marshall Mathers LP, is steeped in paranoia and anger about his distorted public image. One wonders what he's going to say on his third album.

There were few clues to be found in his performance. It begins lamely with a jumpy, grainy Blair Witch- style video before the man himself appears onstage, resplendent in baggy dungarees, white hockey mask and chainsaw (which remained turned off due to venue restrictions). He stands in front of a mock-up of the dilapidated house that features on the cover of his latest album. The crowd roar with approval; however, it soon becomes apparent that, while lyrically, Eminem pushes the envelope, he can't repeat the trick onstage. After a truncated 'Kill You' and 'I'm Back', he brings on his protégés D-12 for 20 minutes. It's a cheeky move that doesn't work. Eminem and mates lark about the stage as the crowd wait to hear the songs they've actually heard before.

The mood picks up with 'Stan'. Dido is singing in London, so the 16,000-strong crowd provide a full-throated accompaniment. Eminem, inexplicably, cuts it short. Instead he inserts a series of adolescent skits into the show. In one, he sits on the front stoop and gets 'drunk' on Bacardi. In another, he pops an 'ecstasy pill'. He had earlier made sure the Manchester crowd were card-carrying substance abusers: 'I wanna know if I'm amongst some drug addicts [massive roar]. Good, then I feel right at home.' It's an ironic moment since most of the hooting crowd would struggle to get served at an off-licence.

The show is big on such wheezes but soft on content. He stops for a 10-minute animated film, whose sole purpose it seems is to insult a Will Smith lookalike. The film's jokes are received in embarrassing silence. Everyone is pleased when he reappears on stage, strapped to an electric chair. The house has been replaced with a medieval castle, for no dis cernible reason, and the evening is in danger of descending into something more akin to pantomime than a performance by the most talked about man in music.

Eminem clearly wants to have it both ways. He spends much of the night massaging his fans' visceral desire for safe violence and obscenity, but he can't resist a poke at the media for their two-dimensional reporting. Before the resounding 'The Way I Am', Eminem takes the opportunity to berate the media and other naysayers. 'I'm tired of people talking shit about me,' he announces. He struggles to make himself heard over the crowd who are delighted to find him in a chatty mood. He looks petulant as he tries to hush them.

As Eminem spent much of last year on two huge US ensemble tours, Up in Smoke (hip hop) and Anger Management (rock), you would expect something better. At times he seems lazy. He teases the audience with the start of 'My Name Is', then clearly can't be bothered to do his first hit.

That's a surprise because the show is designed to reach the blinkered devotee and you can't believe he's missed an obvious opportunity. Similarly he only does one song as an encore, 'The Real Slim Shady'. After barely 80 minutes, he's off.

The rapper has hardly lived up to the hype and his mystique has been stripped away. If nothing else, we've seen that he isn't so tough, after all.

webTitle: Who let the dogs out?

fields.headline: Who let the dogs out?
fields.standfirst: The stomping Australian show Tap Dogs returns to Sadler's Wells with their celebration of the working man. With 700 now dancing around the globe, the man who invented them keeps marketing the myth
fields.trailText: The stomping Australian show Tap Dogs returns to Sadler's Wells with their celebration of the working man. With 700 now dancing around the globe, the man who invented them keeps marketing the myth
fields.body:
Dance, our oldest form of self-expression, is always returning to its fabled primitive origins. Stravinsky in The Rite of Spring located its source in the savage celebration of the vernal equinox by Russian tribes: Michael Flatley in Riverdance derived it from the moist, boggy subsoil of Celtic folklore. Dance needs a mythology to explain it, to account for the frenzy which overtakes the lumpen, earthbound human body. Perhaps a god has come to visit the dancer, dispensing his or her legs from their customary obedience to gravity.

The origins imagined by both Stravinsky and Flatley are romantically remote. But what accounts for the persistence of dance in our urbanised, industrial world? Another myth has grown up, which shows dance to be the sublimation of work. A few years ago at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, the dancers in Stomp rampaged through an industrial scraphead, salvaging junked kitchen sinks as percussion instruments; currently at the Old Vic, Matthew Bourne's greasy mechanic in The Car Man transforms the routines of automobile repair into strutting flamenco. But the most cleverly persuasive contemporary myth about the reinvention of dance is to be found in Tap Dogs, the Australian show which, first seen here in 1995, returns to Sadler's Wells next week.

The dogs themselves are a gang of would-be building workers, clowning around and showing off on site. Rather than tights, they wear distressed jeans and rumpled T-shirts. Instead of effem inate ballet slippers, they're shod in elastic-sided heavy-duty boots, with metal plates positioned around the soles so their steps belligerently hammer the floor. In their back pockets, they carry screwdrivers, used to adjust or reinforce those deafening cleats. While dancing, they deploy blow-torches and metal-cutters, triumphantly transforming work into play.

Since that first tour in 1995, Tap Dogs has become an institution, and something of a franchise operation. A year ago there were eight contingents of dogs on the road, indefatigably tapping in different parts of the globe. They were rounded up for the closing ceremony of the Olympic Games last year, when 700 of them took over the stadium. Kicking and stamping their way skywards on a metal gantry, they embodied Australia, with its combination of proletarian grit and sensual exuberance. The dogs are also available for celebrations more mercenary and less cosmically joyous than the Olympic finale. They have appeared at industrial binges in honour of BMW, Toyota, Audi and Mercedes Benz: there's no car in their show, but their bodies, after all, are the sleekest and most revved-up of vehicles.

As one of the current dogs, Douglas Mills, bragged at rehearsals last week: 'It's got bigger and bigger, and it's gone everywhere.' So how does the show's creator and choreographer, Dein Perry, manage to oversee his burgeoning litters of pups? His representative in the London cast is Jim Doubtfire, a grizzled tapper of nearly 30 who calculates he has a couple more seasons as a canine left in him: 'Dein's back in Australia, but we send him videos. That way he knows whether the lads are doing it proper'.

Perry, in between vetting those tapes, keeps himself busy mythologising his own creation. Tap Dogs now has its own corporate legend, a tall tale combining inspiration with perspiration. Perry, a working-class boy in the grim steel town of Newcastle north of Sydney, taught himself to tap on the sly in a backyard garage. Convinced he had no chance of a stage career, he settled for union membership and a steady job as a machinist. But a government grant encouraged him to try out a show which he first called Tap Brothers.

Thus saith the myth; the rest, after that initial Sydney season in 1995, is more reliably documented history. If it all sounds familiar, that's because it's mythical. Baz Luhrman dreamed up a similarly heroic story about the aspirations of a different kind of dancer in his film Strictly Ballroom, also set in Sydney; the north of England now has its own version of Dein's parable in Stephen Daldry's Billy Elliot - and, to solemnise this merger of myths, Jamie Bell, who plays Billy in the film, will be a guest at the press night of Tap Dogs on Tuesday.

Perry has recently dealt with the genesis of the show in his own film, Boot Men. His pitch for it cunningly welds his own private saga on to another one of Australia's newly invented epics of ancient times. 'It's sort of Mad Max meets a tap dancer,' he says, leaving the rest to your imagination.

When confronting a myth, you need to prepare yourself for the discovery of fiction, or outright fraud. Mythology, as Roland Barthes understood, is merely an adroit and infectious way of telling lies - in this case, a convenient means of fusing the grind of heavy industry with the feckless freedom of dance. At least in The Full Monty the steelworkers waited until they were unemployed before they began bumping and grinding; in Tap Dogs, they perform while still on the job. Still, despite my scepticism, I was looking forward to meeting some of my compatriots when I went to watch the dogs record a television programme at a studio in Acton. But from a distance, they already looked odd - scrawny and unsunned, more like refugees from the orphanage in Oliver! than the beach bums I was expecting. And when they opened their mouths (which should have been a giveaway, since Australians, when talking, try not to do so), I heard the dropped aitches and swallowed consonants of British slang: all but two of the company came from the Home Counties.

Doug, whom I quoted above, lives with his mum in Tunbridge Wells; Martyn Herbert - that Olde English spelling of his first name would be laughed to scorn in Australia - trained in East Grinstead; and one of their colleagues even has the forelock-tuggingly feudal name of Nicholas Yeoman. No wonder that, when Tap Dogs visited Copenhagen last year, a newspaper described them as 'curs without pure-bred pedigree'. Mongrels, I thought (which in Australia, I should explain, is a term of more or less affectionate abuse).

Being British, the current dogs are unhealthy with a vengeance. 'Very high fag intake,' sniffed the woman who had to interview them after their television performance. The show's backstage lore tells of steel buckets positioned in the wings so that the boys - if they've eaten too soon before the more acrobatic episodes - can throw up and then gallantly carry on dancing; all I saw was the furtive exchange of cigarette packets before they whirled on for their solos. The tour manager told me they had a week of circuit training ahead of them, to tone up for the opening. But they were busily negotiating 'ciggie breaks' at regular intervals in their work-outs.

More endearingly, their Britishness means the possibility of failure has to be ironically incorporated into a show which is supposedly about impeccable physical skills. One of the segments I watched began with Jim twirling a basketball and bouncing it between his stocky legs. 'If I drop this, don't laugh,' he said to the others. 'If I faint,' he added, after a spasm of smoker's coughing, 'just keep on going.'

The show's myth, like the Australian creed of mateship which it draws on, finesses another potentially embarrassing contradiction. The tap routines are courting dances, performed by an all-male cast whose jeans, boots and flannel shirts imitate a strictly encoded, now rather old-fashioned gay look. One of the Village People, back in the 1970s, was a construction worker.

Tap Dogs even risks a urinal scene, with much innocent splashing of pee. But the decorum of the show is resolutely homosocial, never homoerotic. Chris Ernest, a recent recruit, insisted: 'We're just good friends.'

But in between television takes, the upright manly postures of the troupe began to bend, as Jim, answerable to the absent Dein Perry, fetishistically fussed over Chris's costume: 'Put your T-shirt down. And loop your flannel shirt round your waist. It should be like a cowboy belt.' 'It feels more like a bra,' winced Chris, tying the shirt sleeves at his waist. 'Love your tail,' commented Doug. Jim made sure the garments formed exactly the same pattern as they'd done on hundreds of other previous dogs on four continents: 'Here, Mum'll do it for you. There you go, son.'

Of course the spontaneous emergence of Tap Dogs on the factory floor in Newcastle is another myth not to be trusted. It is, thanks to its director Nigel Triffitt (an old mate of mine from my Tasmanian schooldays, I'm proud to say), a learned and ingeniously allusive piece of stagecraft. Theatre first deferred to industry during the Russian revolution, when the visionary director Vsevolod Meyerhold drilled his actors in biomechanical exercises which had been devised to improve the efficiency of American workers. Chaplin danced with a spanner while toiling on a production line in Modern Times.

The exhilarating moment when the dogs erect their set is borrowed from the scene when a team of dancing frontiersmen build a barn in the musical Seven Brides for Seven Brothers. The finger-clicking cue for the basketball scene recalls the strutting street gangs of West Side Story - although, since the show is not American, its dances are devoid of crackling aggression and never explode into violence.

Noticing these quotations does nothing to lessen the show's impact; they simply establish that it's by no means the innocent, homegrown, improvised product it purports to be. What we have here is a myth customised for the marketplace - an efficient machine, designed to make money but also (I must admit) to dispense pleasure.

Tap Dogs opens tomorrow and runs until 3 March at Sadlers Wells, London EC1 (0207 863 8000)
