They have appeared at industrial binges in honour of BMW, Toyota, Audi and Mercedes Benz: there's no car in their show, but their bodies, after all, are the sleekest and most revved-up of vehicles. As one of the current dogs, Douglas Mills, bragged at rehearsals last week: 'It's got bigger and bigger, and it's gone everywhere.' So how does the show's creator and choreographer, Dein Perry, manage to oversee his burgeoning litters of pups? His representative in the London cast is Jim Doubtfire, a grizzled tapper of nearly 30 who calculates he has a couple more seasons as a canine left in him: 'Dein's back in Australia, but we send him videos. That way he knows whether the lads are doing it proper'. Perry, in between vetting those tapes, keeps himself busy mythologising his own creation. Tap Dogs now has its own corporate legend, a tall tale combining inspiration with perspiration. Perry, a working-class boy in the grim steel town of Newcastle north of Sydney, taught himself to tap on the sly in a backyard garage. Convinced he had no chance of a stage career, he settled for union membership and a steady job as a machinist. But a government grant encouraged him to try out a show which he first called Tap Brothers. Thus saith the myth; the rest, after that initial Sydney season in 1995, is more reliably documented history. If it all sounds familiar, that's because it's mythical. Baz Luhrman dreamed up a similarly heroic story about the aspirations of a different kind of dancer in his film Strictly Ballroom, also set in Sydney; the north of England now has its own version of Dein's parable in Stephen Daldry's Billy Elliot - and, to solemnise this merger of myths, Jamie Bell, who plays Billy in the film, will be a guest at the press night of Tap Dogs on Tuesday. Perry has recently dealt with the genesis of the show in his own film, Boot Men. His pitch for it cunningly welds his own private saga on to another one of Australia's newly invented epics of ancient times. 'It's sort of Mad Max meets a tap dancer,' he says, leaving the rest to your imagination. When confronting a myth, you need to prepare yourself for the discovery of fiction, or outright fraud. Mythology, as Roland Barthes understood, is merely an adroit and infectious way of telling lies - in this case, a convenient means of fusing the grind of heavy industry with the feckless freedom of dance. At least in The Full Monty the steelworkers waited until they were unemployed before they began bumping and grinding; in Tap Dogs, they perform while still on the job. Still, despite my scepticism, I was looking forward to meeting some of my compatriots when I went to watch the dogs record a television programme at a studio in Acton. But from a distance, they already looked odd - scrawny and unsunned, more like refugees from the orphanage in Oliver! than the beach bums I was expecting. And when they opened their mouths (which should have been a giveaway, since Australians, when talking, try not to do so), I heard the dropped aitches and swallowed consonants of British slang: all but two of the company came from the Home Counties. Doug, whom I quoted above, lives with his mum in Tunbridge Wells; Martyn Herbert - that Olde English spelling of his first name would be laughed to scorn in Australia - trained in East Grinstead; and one of their colleagues even has the forelock-tuggingly feudal name of Nicholas Yeoman. No wonder that, when Tap Dogs visited Copenhagen last year, a newspaper described them as 'curs without pure-bred pedigree'. Mongrels, I thought (which in Australia, I should explain, is a term of more or less affectionate abuse). Being British, the current dogs are unhealthy with a vengeance. 'Very high fag intake,' sniffed the woman who had to interview them after their television performance. The show's backstage lore tells of steel buckets positioned in the wings so that the boys - if they've eaten too soon before the more acrobatic episodes - can throw up and then gallantly carry on dancing; all I saw was the furtive exchange of cigarette packets before they whirled on for their solos. The tour manager told me they had a week of circuit training ahead of them, to tone up for the opening. But they were busily negotiating 'ciggie breaks' at regular intervals in their work-outs. More endearingly, their Britishness means the possibility of failure has to be ironically incorporated into a show which is supposedly about impeccable physical skills. One of the segments I watched began with Jim twirling a basketball and bouncing it between his stocky legs. 'If I drop this, don't laugh,' he said to the others. 'If I faint,' he added, after a spasm of smoker's coughing, 'just keep on going.' The show's myth, like the Australian creed of mateship which it draws on, finesses another potentially embarrassing contradiction. The tap routines are courting dances, performed by an all-male cast whose jeans, boots and flannel shirts imitate a strictly encoded, now rather old-fashioned gay look. One of the Village People, back in the 1970s, was a construction worker. Tap Dogs even risks a urinal scene, with much innocent splashing of pee. But the decorum of the show is resolutely homosocial, never homoerotic. Chris Ernest, a recent recruit, insisted: 'We're just good friends.' But in between television takes, the upright manly postures of the troupe began to bend, as Jim, answerable to the absent Dein Perry, fetishistically fussed over Chris's costume: 'Put your T-shirt down. And loop your flannel shirt round your waist. It should be like a cowboy belt.' 'It feels more like a bra,' winced Chris, tying the shirt sleeves at his waist. 'Love your tail,' commented Doug. Jim made sure the garments formed exactly the same pattern as they'd done on hundreds of other previous dogs on four continents: 'Here, Mum'll do it for you. There you go, son.' Of course the spontaneous emergence of Tap Dogs on the factory floor in Newcastle is another myth not to be trusted. It is, thanks to its director Nigel Triffitt (an old mate of mine from my Tasmanian schooldays, I'm proud to say), a learned and ingeniously allusive piece of stagecraft. Theatre first deferred to industry during the Russian revolution, when the visionary director Vsevolod Meyerhold drilled his actors in biomechanical exercises which had been devised to improve the efficiency of American workers. Chaplin danced with a spanner while toiling on a production line in Modern Times. The exhilarating moment when the dogs erect their set is borrowed from the scene when a team of dancing frontiersmen build a barn in the musical Seven Brides for Seven Brothers. The finger-clicking cue for the basketball scene recalls the strutting street gangs of West Side Story - although, since the show is not American, its dances are devoid of crackling aggression and never explode into violence. Noticing these quotations does nothing to lessen the show's impact; they simply establish that it's by no means the innocent, homegrown, improvised product it purports to be. What we have here is a myth customised for the marketplace - an efficient machine, designed to make money but also (I must admit) to dispense pleasure. Tap Dogs opens tomorrow and runs until 3 March at Sadlers Wells, London EC1 (0207 863 8000)

webTitle: Forget drugs. City clubbers are on a new buzz now - consciousness

fields.headline: Forget drugs. City clubbers are on a new buzz now - consciousness
fields.trailText: Since the late Eighties when Acid House emerged accompanied by the placating words of Bobby McFerrin's 'Don't Worry, Be Happy', clubs have been standardised. They are places to escape, take an E, dance, flirt and forget.
fields.body:
Since the late Eighties when Acid House emerged accompanied by the placating words of Bobby McFerrin's 'Don't Worry, Be Happy', clubs have been standardised. They are places to escape, take an E, dance, flirt and forget.

But recently the term 'conscious clubbing' has crept on to club flyers, posters and into politically correct conversations at trendy minimalist bars in Hoxton. Non-profit-making monthly club nights such as Raha at La Scala and asleep at the wheel at Club 333 pump out politically charged live music, visuals, art, talks and poetry readings designed as an antidote to the numbing effects of commercial clubs. 'We're trying to bring consciousness back in,' explains Alex Estrellado, one third of Purple Banana Products, which is the brains behind Raha and the main popularisers of the term 'conscious clubbing'. This is a bold move. Intercepting people's route and right to oblivion may not be taken kindly; it may not even be possible, ever.

Raha ('the path' in Hindi) packs out its venues. Up to 2,000 people come to see performances from Asian Dub Foundation, Daddy G from Massive Attack, Cornershop, Irvine Welsh, Primal Scream and Organic DJs. These are big names that are attracted by the club's ethical foundations and Purple Banana Products hopes that ordinary clubbers will be attracted by these big names.

Walking into Raha it would be easy to imagine you were in a regular club night until about 1am. Just at the time when most clubbers are preparing to be purged from the week's routine, the music stops and the whole venue is hushed for half-an-hour of speakers who talk and teach about the campaign of the night. Clubbers have seen Goodness Gracious Me star, Meera Syal, and Raman Mundair, the author, talk on Asian women vulnerable to self-harm and Howard Marks and Channel 4's Mark Thomas, who hosted a Free Satpal Ram night. All this talk proves a successful catharsis. The music resumes and the crowd continue, with an added buzz of energy.

But Purple Banana's claim that it is doing something new has a distinctly old ring to it. Campaign driven events have always been com mon in Britain and the coffee shops and Happenings in the Sixties, Woodstock, Andy Warhol's debauched affairs, punk, and even Blair's celebrity soirees, all had a political and polemical agenda. But now, in this age where branding and packaging has become a staple, it seems necessary to label this form of clubbing in order to distinguish it from the commercial club. The members of Kohoutek (a non-profit collective, which aims to create awareness of the effects of neo-liberal economic globalisation) wriggle at the mention of their club night, asleep at the wheel in London's Old Street, being a 'conscious' club night.

'The deal was always to create a feel to the night and to give it grounding in something other than clubland,' says Oli, one of the seven members of Kohoutek. Watching the clubbers shake and lurch under suspended video montages of demonstrations and police brutality is a strange sight. It is a confusing experience, and deliberately so: these are nights designed to complicate in order to prevent slumber.

These new club nights are not claiming to change the world, but they are altering the concept of clubbing. Rather than following McFerrin's tract 'Don't Worry, Be Happy', they are introducing a new version, 'Worry, And Be Happy'. A contradiction in terms? Actually, no. A night of conscious clubbing certainly leaves you feeling like a better person the next day, as you stroll to the pub to get plastered.

The next asleep at the wheel will be at Club 333 on 22 February. More information on Purple Banana Products' upcoming projects on www.consciousclubbing.com

webTitle: Should I tell my wife that I am a rubber fetishist?

fields.headline: Should I tell my wife that I am a rubber fetishist?
fields.trailText:
i have kept a secret from my wife for 30 years of married life: I find rubber fetish exciting. This has led to encounters with prostitutes who seem to regard it as 'normal' but these encounters leave a deep sense of guilt. I would value your opinion on whether I should discuss this with my wife.
C.A. of Telford
fields.body:
i have kept a secret from my wife for 30 years of married life: I find rubber fetish exciting. This has led to encounters with prostitutes who seem to regard it as 'normal' but these encounters leave a deep sense of guilt. I would value your opinion on whether I should discuss this with my wife.
C.A. of Telford

The horns of your dilemma present different points of view to me as a would-be adviser. They are, first, to engage with you by getting inside an obsession I don't share and, second, to understand why, after 30 years of suffering in silence, you want to spill the beans now.

Fetishism is still regarded as a deviation, but only by those who are not themselves in thrall. Secrecy in sexual matters is all-pervading and is an ideal growth medium for misinformation. Masturbation used to be similarly seen as abnormal, harmful behaviour. Fetishism is so common that it could be seen as normal, as your ladies of the night confirm. It is neither sinful nor harmful unless a combination of addiction, shame and guilt lead you into risk-taking behaviour - which does unfortunately seem to have happened.

Rubber is not all that illogical as a sexual stimulant, seeing that it has a texture very like skin. Similarly a penchant for fur is a reminder of a hairy-coated past. Fixation with these totems tends to be exclusively male, so there is the usual gender comprehension gap.

Your wife might have accepted the rubber if introduced to it early in the relationship. She might even do so now, but you can hardly expect her to hear tales of the demi-monde with equanimity. With them you have doubly betrayed her, by indicating her inadequacy to meet your needs, and by exposing her to damaging sexually transmitted disease.

I fear your wish to discuss the guilt feelings with your wife may be a mark of extreme selfishness, rather than a wish to put things right. If you believe such a course will give you relief then you are seriously deluded.

Try to understand your wife's perspective, oblivious as she is that her staid and respectable spouse is actually a frequenter of bordellos and, worse, a client with colourful, specialised tastes. Her entire being will come crashing down about her ears; your marriage and probably your reputation too will be the first casualties.

You are not the person she sees from first awakening to goodnight kiss. You have the choice of destroying both your lives, or allowing her to live in deluded peace, while struggling with your demons alone.

It is not a happy choice, I agree. But the guilt attaches to the infidelity with real live people rather than inanimate objects, and maybe for the future that is something which lies within your control.

Readers' replies

Quite frankly I am amazed at what you are suggesting! I have always been attracted to shiny materials such as rubber and have told my partner this. She knows that I like to dress in it and I adore seeing her dressed in it too. It's something we sometimes share and it helps to spice life up a bit!

But to keep this hidden for 30 years. I'm wondering if it's the attraction of other women dressed in rubber that appeals and excites you. Your wife will be devastated if you tell her what's been going on.

Tell her about your need and bring it into your own sex life if you can. If you talk to her about your needs she may even tell you about hers and what turns her on! It's the love and cuddles after the dressing up that makes life worthwhile.
Anon

Next week's problem

My husband and I recently moved house and I cleared out my son's bedroom (he is 24 and has left home).

I discovered a bundle of notebooks he had kept when he was a teenager. The life I discovered bore little resemblance to the life I thought he led. It emerges he was sexually promiscuous and indulged in under-age sex with a girl of 12 when he was 16. I blame myself for reading the diary and want to confront him. What do I do?
W.D. of Wales

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on the problem must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: Anything to declare? Just him...

fields.headline: Anything to declare? Just him...
fields.standfirst: Emily Barr  went round the world hoping she would find herself. Instead she found a husband
fields.trailText: Emily Barr  went round the world hoping she would find herself. Instead she found a husband
fields.body:
I was in China when I met the man who is now my fiancé. We were both drinking in the same bar. James invited my friend and me to join him, with a slight edge of desperation in his voice, which stemmed from the fact that he hadn't spoken English for over a week. We travelled through Tibet, Nepal, India and Pakistan together for the next three months.

One of the good things about meeting a life partner in an exotic location is the fact that there's always a good story to tell. When I meet people who can't remember the day they first met, I feel sorry for them, because my first meeting with James is etched on my memory. I remember the smell of the bar. I can remember how many bottles of Chinese beer were consumed (four). I remember the way we discovered that we used to live two miles from each other. The whole encounter, and the months that followed it, are extraordinarily vivid. Now that so many of us take time away from home, work and the routine of dividing our lives between the two, we are more likely than ever to find lasting romance on a trip abroad.

Perhaps the best stories involve Britons finding new lives with Masai warriors, or Australians finding love with Eskimos. However, the lasting relationships are often between compatriots thrown together by their experiences.

Nozomi Goto had been living in Japan for four years when she met the man who is now her husband. 'I met one of his friends at a concert,' she remembers. 'I was a music journalist at the time. At that point, Chris was on his way to Tokyo and his friend thought we'd get on, so he decided to introduce us. He also didn't like Chris's ex-girlfriend, and he was hoping I'd split them up. I did, but not on purpose. I didn't know about that until afterwards.'

Julie Rockall and Carl Leach met while working in New Zealand, surrounded by the scent of sausages. 'It was my first night working on a hot-dog stand in Auckland,' writes Julie from Borneo, where the two of them are currently trekking. 'Carl was already working for this company. It was his night off, but his local pub was 20 yards up the street, so my boss got Carl out of the pub to 'babysit' me by sitting on the cool box and drinking beer. We actually got together three days later on Christmas morning, drinking beers after selling hot dogs all night.'

Nozomi, a Canadian, and Chris, a Briton, were immediately attracted to each other. In fact, theirs is a story of heartwarming romance. Nozomi explains: 'Within three months we'd decided to get married. It took another two months for the paperwork to come through from the British embassy.' Then they had a low-key ceremony.

'We waited in line and our papers were stamped, and the woman congratulated us and bowed. We had our own ceremony afterwards. We went to where we first met, which was outside a really busy train station. It's horrible, with people smoking everywhere. We sat down and exchanged rings and said our vows to each other.

'There are good and bad days in Japan for getting married, so I admit I got my numbers done and we got married on an auspicious day. Then we met some friends - just our friends from Japan, no one came from home - and went out for a five-course dinner at a really nice restaurant.

Spending time together while travelling is magical and intense. I loved the months when James and I were looking no further ahead than the next rickshaw ride. Julie and Carl were both about halfway through a two-year trip when they met in New Zealand, and spent the next year together, happily on the road.

Eventually, however, the day must come when you have to go home, and get back to what might, depending on your perspective, be termed real life. For Chris and Nozomi, the first question was whose country to go to. Britain was Chris's obvious choice as he was in Japan for only a year on an Oxford University programme. 'I wanted to go somewhere new, anyway,' says Nozomi, who had never visited this country. 'On 23 December 1999, we came to Britain. I left everything in Japan. I'd been there four years, and my whole life was there. It was a very, very strange experience.

Not least because, initially, they were living with in-laws she had never previously met. When James and I came back from India, we landed with a bump, and discovered that, not only was it raining, but we had no income, no jobs, and nowhere to live. From sleeping in cheap guesthouses every night, we were flung into the world of staying at each other's parents' houses like teenagers. We also had to decide what we wanted to do. Where would we live? How would we make a living? Suddenly, there were no certainties. The feeling of having the rug pulled from under your feet is something that seems to affect all couples who face this situation.

'We had been together for a year,' remembers Julie, 'but had never met each other's friends or family, and the only mutual friends we had were ones we'd met on our travels. It was strange putting faces to people we'd talked about for a whole year.' They, like us, found the only certainty in their life was a negative one: 'We knew that we didn't want to return to the same professions as we'd had before we left England, but we didn't know what we wanted to do. We just wanted to be able to carry on travelling in some way.'

Nozomi, meanwhile, found it far harder than she'd anticipated to get a job. 'It was horrible!' she recalls. 'I'd worked for a national newspaper in Japan, but that didn't count for anything. If your credentials aren't from here, no one's interested. I didn't know anything about Britain. For the first year, I was in complete depression. I was thinking about going back to Japan and to Canada. I said to Chris, why don't I go home and work for a while? But we didn't want to be apart. And so one of us had to bite the bullet.'

James and I pulled ourselves together after a few months, and rented a house in Greenwich. He started the course he'd always wanted to do, and I (rather optimistically) set about trying to make a living by writing a book. Within no time at all, we both decided that London - however pleasant it was - was not the place for us, and we are now happily ensconced in Brighton.

Julie and Carl replied to an advertisement for seasonal staff at a youth hostel, reasoning that they could use their free winter months to travel. That was six years ago. They have been running the YHA hostel in Salcombe, Devon, for the past two years. 'It gives us a chance to help out foreign travellers in our country, as we are so often helped out in other countries,' says Julie.

They are, even now, sweating their way through the jungle on their annual trip. As for Nozomi, she works for a website in Oxford, and is tentatively feeling happy. 'If you'd asked me six months ago, I would definitely have said I was miserable. I think it's harder settling in a new place when you're older,' she says (she is 29). 'You have to start all over again, get to know the country. I'm sure I'm going to like it more in time. That was what happened in Japan: I liked it more and more.'

And that, perhaps, is the point. It takes time to adjust to the new realities of a relationship, once the travelling is (temporarily) over. Julie and Carl say they would never have met if they'd stayed at home, and are happy that they get to go away for several months each year. James and I are getting married and buying a flat, but we hope to live in Asia for a few years. Nozomi and Chris are looking forward to moving house and expanding their family. 'That's right!' she laughs. 'I'm going to get a kitten.'

Backpack by Emily Barr is published by Headline at £5.99. To order a copy for £4.99 call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171

We actually got together three days later on Christmas morning, drinking beers after selling hot dogs all night.' Nozomi, a Canadian, and Chris, a Briton, were immediately attracted to each other. In fact, theirs is a story of heartwarming romance. Nozomi explains: 'Within three months we'd decided to get married. It took another two months for the paperwork to come through from the British embassy.' Then they had a low-key ceremony. 'We waited in line and our papers were stamped, and the woman congratulated us and bowed. We had our own ceremony afterwards. We went to where we first met, which was outside a really busy train station. It's horrible, with people smoking everywhere. We sat down and exchanged rings and said our vows to each other. 'There are good and bad days in Japan for getting married, so I admit I got my numbers done and we got married on an auspicious day. Then we met some friends - just our friends from Japan, no one came from home - and went out for a five-course dinner at a really nice restaurant. Spending time together while travelling is magical and intense. I loved the months when James and I were looking no further ahead than the next rickshaw ride. Julie and Carl were both about halfway through a two-year trip when they met in New Zealand, and spent the next year together, happily on the road. Eventually, however, the day must come when you have to go home, and get back to what might, depending on your perspective, be termed real life. For Chris and Nozomi, the first question was whose country to go to. Britain was Chris's obvious choice as he was in Japan for only a year on an Oxford University programme. 'I wanted to go somewhere new, anyway,' says Nozomi, who had never visited this country. 'On 23 December 1999, we came to Britain. I left everything in Japan. I'd been there four years, and my whole life was there. It was a very, very strange experience. Not least because, initially, they were living with in-laws she had never previously met. When James and I came back from India, we landed with a bump, and discovered that, not only was it raining, but we had no income, no jobs, and nowhere to live. From sleeping in cheap guesthouses every night, we were flung into the world of staying at each other's parents' houses like teenagers. We also had to decide what we wanted to do. Where would we live? How would we make a living? Suddenly, there were no certainties. The feeling of having the rug pulled from under your feet is something that seems to affect all couples who face this situation. 'We had been together for a year,' remembers Julie, 'but had never met each other's friends or family, and the only mutual friends we had were ones we'd met on our travels. It was strange putting faces to people we'd talked about for a whole year.' They, like us, found the only certainty in their life was a negative one: 'We knew that we didn't want to return to the same professions as we'd had before we left England, but we didn't know what we wanted to do. We just wanted to be able to carry on travelling in some way.' Nozomi, meanwhile, found it far harder than she'd anticipated to get a job. 'It was horrible!' she recalls. 'I'd worked for a national newspaper in Japan, but that didn't count for anything. If your credentials aren't from here, no one's interested. I didn't know anything about Britain. For the first year, I was in complete depression. I was thinking about going back to Japan and to Canada. I said to Chris, why don't I go home and work for a while? But we didn't want to be apart. And so one of us had to bite the bullet.' James and I pulled ourselves together after a few months, and rented a house in Greenwich. He started the course he'd always wanted to do, and I (rather optimistically) set about trying to make a living by writing a book. Within no time at all, we both decided that London - however pleasant it was - was not the place for us, and we are now happily ensconced in Brighton. Julie and Carl replied to an advertisement for seasonal staff at a youth hostel, reasoning that they could use their free winter months to travel. That was six years ago. They have been running the YHA hostel in Salcombe, Devon, for the past two years. 'It gives us a chance to help out foreign travellers in our country, as we are so often helped out in other countries,' says Julie. They are, even now, sweating their way through the jungle on their annual trip. As for Nozomi, she works for a website in Oxford, and is tentatively feeling happy. 'If you'd asked me six months ago, I would definitely have said I was miserable. I think it's harder settling in a new place when you're older,' she says (she is 29). 'You have to start all over again, get to know the country. I'm sure I'm going to like it more in time. That was what happened in Japan: I liked it more and more.' And that, perhaps, is the point. It takes time to adjust to the new realities of a relationship, once the travelling is (temporarily) over. Julie and Carl say they would never have met if they'd stayed at home, and are happy that they get to go away for several months each year. James and I are getting married and buying a flat, but we hope to live in Asia for a few years. Nozomi and Chris are looking forward to moving house and expanding their family. 'That's right!' she laughs. 'I'm going to get a kitten.' Backpack by Emily Barr is published by Headline at £5.99. To order a copy for £4.99 call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171

webTitle: ICI is more dramatic but Unilever wins applause

fields.headline: ICI is more dramatic but Unilever wins applause
fields.trailText: Four years ago, Imperial Chemical Industries paid $8 billion (£6bn) for a bundle of flavourings, fragrances and other speciality chemicals businesses from Unilever, marking the start of a restructuring programme at both businesses.
fields.body:
Four years ago, Imperial Chemical Industries paid $8 billion (£6bn) for a bundle of flavourings, fragrances and other speciality chemicals businesses from Unilever, marking the start of a restructuring programme at both businesses.

The most dramatic restructuring has been at ICI. In the year before the Unilever deal, sales described as speciality - mainly paints at that time - accounted for just a third of the £7.5bn total and half of the £350 million trading profit. Last year, international businesses - as speciality chemicals are now called - accounted for £5.6bn of the £7.8bn sales from ongoing businesses and virtually all the £612m trading profit. In the intervening period, it has ditched practically everything we associated with ICI, from the ethylene cracker at Teesside to its polyester business.

Outwardly, the restructuring at Unilever has been rather less dramatic (although the 5,300 people who lost their jobs in the last year may not think so). There have been some disposals - Elizabeth Arden cosmetics is the most recent. And it is paring back its brand portfolio - 600 of its 1,670 products have gone so far, including British names such as Radion and Blue Band. Another 250 are targeted for 'delisting' by the end of next year and the aim is to focus on just 400 so-called 'power brands'.

There have also been acquisitions - most notably the Knorr and Hellmans group Bestfoods, and Ben & Jerry ice cream last year. But Unilever still makes the Persil, Stork and Bird's Eye fish fingers which made it famous. And the split of the business between detergents, personal care and food has not changed dramatically.

The impact on the two share prices has been just as profound, but not in quite the way you would expect. ICI, despite the dramatic transformation, has seen its shares tumble to less than two-thirds of where they were when the Unilever purchase was announced. Unilever, by contrast, has all but doubled.

Last week's results from the two companies give some clues as to why.

First, ICI. On the face of it, its performance was decent enough: sales from its continuing operations rose by 3.8 per cent while operating profits jumped by 15 per cent. Look behind the figures, however, and the City found plenty to disappoint. National Starch, which now accounts for more than a third of the business, suffered a 1 per cent fall in profits for the year - and, more worrying, a 20 per cent fall in the last quarter.

Brendan O'Neill, ICI's ebullient chief executive, shrugs off the decline. He says fears over the millennium bug made fourth quarter of 1999 particularly buoyant; the US slowdown is affecting demand but should be over relatively quickly; and the restructured company is far more resilient than old ICI would have been when oil prices trebled, as they did last year.

He pointed to the performance of other divisions - the Quest flavourings and fragrance business was up 10 per cent and paints 12 per cent - as proof that ICI really had been transformed. In old ICI, all the businesses suffered together. But ICI's transformation was intended to make it resistant, if not immune, to economic cycles.

If National Starch's profits can be hit so much by a mere dip in US demand, what will happen if there is a slump. Investors looked back at all the other ICI restructurings which tried, but failed, to shift it up the value chain and wonder if recession-proofing for ICI is like the gold at the end of the rainbow - never quite reached.

As worrying is the balance sheet. O'Neill points to the dramatic improvement in interest cover - trading profits are now more than three times the interest bill - as evidence that its borrowings are under control. Others point out that its debt is still a massive £2.8bn, pretty much where it started the year. And it is difficult to see it falling much more - the small amount that remains to be received from disposals will be eaten up by the £500m which has still to be spent on restructuring.

Its longer-term targets are not that different from Unilever's. It aims to increase sales by between 4 and 5 per cent from organic growth, with another 1 to 2 per cent from acquisitions. The performance of National Starch, together with the fact that its debt levels make acquisitions difficult, has made the City doubt it can do that.

Investors are willing to give Unilever the benefit of the doubt despite the fact that its sales, excluding acquisitions and disposals, rose by just 1.9 per cent - well below its target of 5.8 per cent. Margins, too, may have jumped to a record 12.1 per cent but that is still some way below the target of 16 to 17 per cent. And, following the Bestfoods deal, its borrowings are €26.5 billion (£16.9 bn).

But Unilever chief Niall FitzGerald can point to real progress on his Path to Growth programme. Sales of the leading brands, which will be the focus of attention, grew by 3.9 per cent over the year. These accelerated to 4.9 per cent in the third quarter, and now account for almost 80 per cent of sales. Margins increased by a full 1.7 per cent, even excluding Bestfoods. Add in the benefits from bedding down that deal, and the targets for 2004 look a little more realistic.

It is being much more innovative - FitzGerald actually donned an apron to demonstrate its new range of Enjoy frozen foods; and its snack size Magnums have proved appealing. He says the concentration on a smaller number of brands does focus executives' minds. Dove, for example, one of its more established brands, grew by 20 per cent last year as it was extended from everything to skin and haircare. He is promising an extra €1.5bn of sales from such initiatives this year.

Investors were disappointed by Unilever's performance, and the shares fell back slightly on the day. But after a recent strong run they stand on roughly 18 times expected earnings.

ICI shares, also strong this year, were likewise hit by disappointment over the figures. Based on expectations of flat profits this year, they stand on around 11 times forecasts for 2001. It has already warned that it will halve the dividend this year, putting the yield at 3.3 per cent compared with Unilever's 2.5 per cent. That does not look expensive, but the shares are unlikely to recover much until it is clear National Starch can get back to growth.

Unilever's rating is more demanding but its prospects are more exciting than ICI's - one analyst says its shares could be worth 1,000p if it can achieve its targets. FitzGerald has proved he has the energy to transform Unilever: the shares are worth buying.

webTitle: Letters: Alder Hey organs scandal

fields.headline: The big issue: We must not let the children suffer
fields.trailText: Mary Riddell is right when she questions the motives and sense of those crying for compensation and sackings following the revelations of the Alder Hey report (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
Mary Riddell is right when she questions the motives and sense of those crying for compensation and sackings following the revelations of the Alder Hey report (Comment, last week). When our youngest daughter died shortly after birth six years ago we were devastated. But it was at the point of her death that we felt we had lost her, her essence, her future. We were grateful for the two hours we had with her, her photos are on show along with all the other family snapshots.

You don't 'get over' such an experience, merely learn to live with it and reconsider your values. If tomorrow I was told all her organs had been removed it would not alter the past, and if I thought that such an act had led to even one child living when they might have died and a single family being saved from the distress we went through because of losing her, then I would be grateful to salvage some shred of hope out of a situation which so totally lacked it.
R. Smithson
Ipswich, Suffolk

This morning while we read the paper, eating our breakfast, or travelling to work, a young child awakes to do battle. A day-by-day battle. It's a battle for life, and it's a struggle that has suddenly become tougher than ever before. This child is one of the many patients at the Alder Hey Children's Hospital in Merseyside that wake to a different routine of dialysis, chemotherapy, and prayers. The terrible acts that have been committed and family suffering experienced from these evil crimes should not be overlooked. However, Alder Hey should not be an evil name.

Since the uncovering of what has taken place, organ donations are desperately low and charity funds have plummeted. What we are witnessing but fail to see, is that these children are the ones who are left to suffer.
Philip Guilfoyle
London SW19

How I cheered in support of Mary Riddell's critique of the GMC and echo her call for its demise. The GMC's motto 'protecting patients, guiding doctors' should actually read 'protecting doctors, misguiding patients'. From recent horrific revelations, Dr Shipman et al, it would appear that doctors literally 'get away with murder'.
Joan Harvey
Markyate, Herts

webTitle: It will never be the same down your local boozer

fields.headline: It will never be the same down your local boozer
fields.trailText: Not even ex-footballers fancy running pubs these days. And brewers certainly don't. Everywhere you look the giants of the brewing industry are anxious to offload their boozers faster than you can say 'make mine a large one and panatella'.
fields.body:
Not even ex-footballers fancy running pubs these days. And brewers certainly don't. Everywhere you look the giants of the brewing industry are anxious to offload their boozers faster than you can say 'make mine a large one and panatella'.

Next month, in a watershed for the industry, Whitbread, whose fine pedigree as a purveyor of intoxicating substances either on or off the premises stretches back more than 250 years, will offload its 3,000-strong pub estate, probably to Japanese bank Nomura. Whitbread is joining a very long queue.

In addition to Whitbread's massive disposal, Bass currently has 900 of its pubs on the market, while Scottish & Newcastle is looking to sell 1,300 pubs from its estate. Britain's biggest regional brewer, Wolverhampton & Dudley, currently in play, boasts a portfolio of 1,800. Allied Domecq, of course, sold off its entire estate two years ago and now spends most of its time unsuccessfully trying to buy up spirits and wine firms to add to its drinks cabinet.

In all there are more than 6,000 public houses up for sale, roughly 10 per cent of the UK's entire pub portfolio.

It's not hard to see why the big brewers are keen to offload huge chunks of their estates. The leisure sector has suffered terribly in recent years as the City developed a thirst for high-growth technology stocks, and the pub trade has suffered more than most.

What growth there was in the leisure sector came from coffee bars and health clubs. Meanwhile high alcohol taxes have put pressure on even the biggest firms to squeeze margins.

If that wasn't hard enough, consumer tastes have become ever more 'sophisticated', to use the industry's jargon. Costly refurbishment programmes, not to mention the increasingly urgent need to dream up new themes for old chains, as the punters' attention spans shorten, have also taken their toll. The only firms now really interested in running pubs are the specialised retailers, which have never tried their hand at running breweries but are good at fleshing out new concepts after vast amounts of market research.

These firms, like Nomura's Unique Pub Company or Punch Taverns, have grown large thanks to the 'Beer Orders' Act of 1989, which limited the number of pubs each brewer could own. The thinking behind the Act, like most Thatcherite ideas, was that it would stimulate competition.

The reality was that it allowed new companies into the market, companies that could strike deals with suppliers of their choice. Naturally, the biggest suppliers were able to offer the most attractive deals, leading to the concentration of brands and the death of more than 40 UK breweries.

The 6,000 pubs currently on the market are likely to be joined by thousands more. This huge number means the pub retailers will be able to snap up chains for a song and expand their estates very quickly. This will give them more clout with multinational brewers, a move that will inevitably put pressure on those UK brewers still vainly trying to juggle owning pubs and beer brands.

As the global brewing industry continues to consolidate, the jugglers' task will only get harder.

Analysts at Merrill Lynch point out that international beer brands still represent less than 10 per cent of the total market, with the top five brewers together accounting for just 34 per cent of global market share.

This compares with more than 70 per cent for soft drinks and tobacco.

And as the consolidation process continues the face of the local boozer changes. Punch, for instance, has seen the future. After the Irish pub craze comes the Japanese bar. Camra members are left crying in their beer.

webTitle: Letters: We must not let the children suffer

fields.headline: Costing the child
fields.trailText: As a 40-year-old woman I have spent the last 20 years making decisions about how many children I will or will not have.
fields.body:
As a 40-year-old woman I have spent the last 20 years making decisions about how many children I will or will not have.

The costs to my relationships, career, health and finances have all been real issues. Dr. Penelope Leach (News, last week) may hate the idea that childcare costs may deter people from producing children they cannot afford to maintain. I hate the idea of responsible members of society subsidising the offspring of the irresponsible.
C.M. Johnson
Doncaster, S Yorks

webTitle: Letters: Jurassic lark

fields.headline: Jurassic lark
fields.trailText: Toward the end of Andrew Rawnsley's column (Comment, last week), just prior to the regal nod to 'the wisdom of the saloon bar', we   are presented with the pejorative coupling of Mr Scargill and the Jurassic period.
fields.body:
Toward the end of Andrew Rawnsley's column (Comment, last week), just prior to the regal nod to 'the wisdom of the saloon bar', we are presented with the pejorative coupling of Mr Scargill and the Jurassic period. Perhaps a more pertinent coupling would be that of Mr Scargill and the British journalist, whom 'we cannot hope to bribe or twist'. The latter, by and large, richly deserve the ironic continuant of the above in quotes. Whereas the former, history teaches us, would have his integrity doubted by only the buffoon or the poltroon.

Neither appellation, I'm sure, could be laid at the door of the Hartlepool electorate - a point of view which will be vindicated, hopefully, after the next general election. Then, perhaps, New Labour, the British journalist and other authorities on palaeontology can revise their opinion of Joe Public.
William Smith
Grimsby, Lincs

The latter, by and large, richly deserve the ironic continuant of the above in quotes. Whereas the former, history teaches us, would have his integrity doubted by only the buffoon or the poltroon. Neither appellation, I'm sure, could be laid at the door of the Hartlepool electorate - a point of view which will be vindicated, hopefully, after the next general election. Then, perhaps, New Labour, the British journalist and other authorities on palaeontology can revise their opinion of Joe Public. William Smith Grimsby, Lincs

webTitle: Letters: Badger watch

fields.headline: Badger watch
fields.trailText: While I agree with Richard Ingrams' concerns regarding the impending pigeon pogrom in London (Diary, last week), he undermines his own credibility with one of his characteristic rants against our wild mammals and those who seek to protect them.
fields.body:
While I agree with Richard Ingrams' concerns regarding the impending pigeon pogrom in London (Diary, last week), he undermines his own credibility with one of his characteristic rants against our wild mammals and those who seek to protect them. Not the fox this time, but the badger.

He asserts that badgers are a greater risk to human health than dogs and pigeons. Yet there is not a single recorded case in the UK of a badger transmitting anything more deadly than a flea to humans, and the only attacks have been against the likes of baiters who torment them or upon those involved in their conservation.
Nic Davies
Newborough, Staffs

webTitle: Letters: Bible belters

fields.headline: Bible belters
fields.trailText: I was so astonished to read W.H. Simcock's assertion (Letters, last week) that 'throughout the Bible abortion... is not only tolerated but sanctioned and encouraged' that I looked up all his references, in several translations.
fields.body:
I was so astonished to read W.H. Simcock's assertion (Letters, last week) that 'throughout the Bible abortion... is not only tolerated but sanctioned and encouraged' that I looked up all his references, in several translations.

All (except Jeremiah, who, in his distress, is lamenting his own birth) are Old Testament prophetic warnings about what God will do if evil people do not mend their ways. In no sense can they possibly be interpreted as giving mankind any power or responsibility to end the life of an unborn child. Further, Jesus (himself the fulfilment of Old Testament prophecy) preached a new Covenant - that God is love, and that every individual is of equal value and worth (Luke, 12.6).
Mrs J.M. Bond
Redmarley, Glos

webTitle: Letters: BBC on-line revenue

fields.headline: On-line revenue
fields.trailText: Unlike television and radio, the key characteristic of internet technology is that it is open to everybody, anywhere, anytime.
fields.body:
Unlike television and radio, the key characteristic of internet technology is that it is open to everybody, anywhere, anytime.

So how do you ensure that UK licence payers are not subsidising the rest of the world's internet users logging into a special international BBC Online? The Government some 18 months concluded that there is no reason why these websites should not be run on a commercial basis, accepting both advertising and e-commerce revenues.
Caroline Thomson
BBC director of public policy
London W1

webTitle: Classicwatch: Voyage in the Dark

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: A deceptively simple love story
fields.body:
Voyage in the Dark
Jean Rhys
(Penguin Classics £6.99, 158pp)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This is Jean Rhys's third novel, published in 1934 when the author was in her early forties. Rhys wrote only one more before her 20-year hiatus of alcoholism and obscurity, after which she produced her best-known work, The Wide Sargasso Sea.

In many ways the heroine of Voyage, Anna Morgan, can be seen as a predecessor of Antoinette in the later book, though Anna manages to retain her girlish innocence and never quite reaches the vengeful womanhood of Rhys's other heroines. Late in her life, Rhys spoke of Voyage as her personal favourite among her books.

Anna, an 18-year-old chorus girl, falls in love with a young man named Walter. Like Rhys, Anna grew up in the West Indies and is baffled and disorientated by England. As Rhys's biographer Carol Angier explains in her excellent introduction, Anna, moved by her feelings, is a true child of the tropics, whereas Walter, with his emphasis on reason and words, is typically English.

Voyage in the Dark is a deceptively simple love story, astute in its portrayal of women, and one of Rhys's finest works.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: States of Denial

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: This is how scholarship should be - zesty, engaged, witty, and always accessible
fields.body:
States of Denial
Stanley Cohen
Polity £15.99, pp344
Buy it at a discount at BOL

With images of disaster and atrocity raining down on us from every quarter, it's hard not to resort to a balming fatalism. Sociologist Stanley Cohen's timely book about how people and societies deny information which is too disturbing or threatening serves as a brilliant corrective. Cohen's professional interest has been seeded by his own experience, first of growing up in South Africa, and later of working in Israel, both countries where the abuse of human rights has become so 'normalised' as to be virtually invisible to the majority.

Cohen takes aim at the kind of attitude expressed by the late Alan Clark, who claimed that 'I don't really fill my mind much with what one set of foreigners is doing to another'. Drawing on a fabulous range of psychological, social and political sources, he catalogues the various techniques of denial, including 'pseudostupidity' (a refusal to believe what you see), as practised by some Americans after the My Lai massacre of the Vietcong; 'splitting' (where a person carrying out an atrocity psychically detaches themselves); 'inner emigration' (a retreat into private life to avoid the unbearable outer reality, adopted during apartheid by many liberal white South Africans); and other methods from euphemism to legalism.

The most shocking example of the last was the letter from an Israeli official about a 63-year-old Palestinian woman shot dead by Israeli soldiers. Her husband wasn't entitled to compensation, the letter claimed, because he'd benefited from her death, no longer being obliged to support her.

While Cohen appreciates that some switching off is necessary, he's scathing about the concept of 'compassion fatigue'. Without idealising political activism and always sensitive to the complexities of altruism, he attributes the dimming of human compassion to an individualism fostered by the global market. Cohen writes marvellously. This is how scholarship should be - zesty, engaged, witty, and always accessible. He appeals to fraternity, and calls the torturers' bluff. Doubtless they'll continue to torture, but Cohen has supplied us with an important dictionary of their and our self-exculpation.

webTitle: Paperbacks: 10 Feb

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Marion Meade is no hagiographer, but Allen is no saint... plus The Tale of Murasaki, Under the Skin, Cornucopia and Books and Company Issue Nine
fields.body:
The Unruly Life of Woody Allen
Marion Meade
Phoenix £8.99, pp384
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Few people have no opinion about Woody Allen. Even before the squabbles over his sadly named children, Allen's films - the increasingly flawed products of a gloriously tangled ego - have always demanded a response. Meade is no hagiographer, but Allen is no saint, despite his perfect jokes, and her account suits him well. She holds nothing back: the analysis of Satchel, aged two and a half; Allen's hair transplants; his fascination with girls, and his 'tepid little affair' with Soon-Yi. Meade's unruly biography takes every imaginable detail, from sandwich fillings to childhood crises, and packs them into a clotted, Day-Glo, all-American rush that leaves her reader sullied, exhausted, and dazed with Schadenfreude.

Fans of Allen will be distressed; his detractors' suspicions will be confirmed. However, the trashy lives of famous people fascinate most of us, and this torrent of speculation, mundanity and alarming fact is an absorbing insight into a messy and uncovetable life.

The Tale of Murasaki
Liza Dalby
Vintage £6.99, pp416
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Liza Dalby, anthropologist and geisha, is an expert in lost and forbidden worlds. Now she has turned her attentions to Murasaki, the Japanese woman whose eleventh-century Tale of Genji foreshadowed, and overshadowed, the slow evolution of the novel. From Murasaki's own diaries, poetry and the Tale itself, Dalby has recreated an astonishingly elaborate and beautiful society, fraught with court intrigue and the dictates of elegance, where verses between friends shimmer with multiple meanings, and fans, robes and hairstyles are as eloquent as poetry.

At this distance, fears and passions are speculative. Despite Dalby's excavation of her subject's every unassuming word, Murasaki's youthful romances and adult disappointments remain shadowy: it is her poetry, and Genji himself, which live.

The externals of her life, however, are vivid enough to compensate. As an open door to a scented, silken world, and to the experiences of an extraordinary woman, The Tale of Murasaki has hypnotic power.

Under the Skin
Michael Faber
Canongate £6.99, pp296
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Michael Faber's charming chiller of a debut is a weird and lovely hybrid - one of the sweetest nastiest novels you'll ever read. Half hitcher-horror set in the Scottish Highlands, half a ghoulishly beautiful story of humanity, inhumanity and moral ambivalence, Under the Skin examines the beguiling squalor of which, surely, only human beings are capable, and then turns that assumption squarely on its head.

Isserley, its reluctant anti-heroine, is equally split. Surgically altered, gorgeous and deformed, she cruises country roads in search of muscled solitary men; not for sex - she's in no shape for that - but to serve other grislier purposes whose shocking revelation has the horrible sheen of truth. From a nacreous winter dawn to the baldest bodily specifics, Faber is an intelligent and wildly original writer and the result is revolting, sad and worryingly enjoyable all at once.

Cornucopia
Paul Richardson
Abacus £7.99, pp342
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As gentle and odd as the land it celebrates, this gastronomic tour of Britain is like the renegade grandson of Jane Grigson and Bill Bryson. It lacks beauty, dazzling social observations or a single useful telephone number; nevertheless, its ancestors would be proud, as Grigson's passion for British food and Bryson's relaxed, self-deprecating observations indirectly inform every page. Cornucopia is Sunday-supplement food writing made flesh: hedonistic, leisurely fodder for foodies.

Moreover, the food Richardson temptingly describes - the wild mushrooms and farm cheeses, the hop shoots, saffron cakes and legs of happy organic lamb - and the power of his case for old, real, good natural food, easily compensate for moments of self-indulgence and an odd emphasis on 'hearty, masculine' ingredients (as opposed to food for 'homosexual waiters' 'ladies' and 'till girls').

It is a tribute to the power of food, and passionate writing, that even cooks and eaters from these inferior categories may find his book hard to resist.

Books and Company
Issue Nine: Winter 2000

Subscription £30 p/a, pp108
www.booksandcompany.co.uk

Susan's Hill's quarterly literary journal 'about books for those who delight in them' is exactly what it claims to be. Issue Nine celebrates an impressively wide range of writing, from Bulgakov to Vega, Virgil to Gaskell, for purposes ranging from nostalgia to foal-midwifery.

What's more, its essays fulfil many functions: advice (on What Boys Read); pleasure (Polly Samson on bedside reading); cosy insiderishness (Nancy Mitford's niece on Mitford); recommendation (the insanely underrated Howard Jacobson); and education (The Trollope Society on... well, guess).

Cultured, modest and faintly grand - more naturally a magazine for Hons rather than Rebels.

webTitle: Young Adolf by Beryl Bainbridge read by Michael Tudor

fields.headline: Young Adolf by Beryl Bainbridge read by Michael Tudor
fields.trailText: Before the First World War, young Adolf Hitler is an unwelcome guest in the modest Liverpool home of brother, Alois.
fields.body:
Young Adolf
Beryl Bainbridge
Read by Michael Tudor Barnes
Unabridged 5hrs
Soundings Audiobooks £18.49 incl p&p (mail order 0191 253 4155)

Before the First World War, young Adolf Hitler is an unwelcome guest in the modest Liverpool home of his razor-blade merchant brother, Alois, and his sister-in-law Bridget. A failed art student, idle and dirty, he spends the days sprawled on the couch, contributing nothing to the household expenses, convinced that he is being pursued for having evaded military service in Austria. He suffers bursts of temper, railing prophetically against the contamination of Europe by 'impure blood', and spitting at the portrait of his father, Adolf senior, the 'bastard' whose beatings still haunt his nightmares.

The narration gives the brothers heavy accents without slipping into caricature - although Adolf needed a younger voice to be convincing as young Adolf. These accents emphasise the sense of a foreign intrusion into the very English Liverpool, further heightened by the sinister figures - one in distinctive golf shoes, another with a bandage round his head - who apparently stalk Adolf. Bainbridge revels in the bizarre and grotesque, but the real interest here is in the twisting plot of her idiosyncratic imagination, and the constant tension between the reader's knowledge of the future and novel's teasing ironies. 'Such a strong willed young man,' says one of the little group who see him off to Linz. 'What a pity he will never amount to anything!'

webTitle: Sylvia's mother said...

fields.headline: Sylvia's mother said...
fields.standfirst: Sylvia Smith is 56, unknown, unmarried, unemployed and has just published the story of her uneventful life.  Kate Kellaway  meets the unlikely author tipped to be one of this year's bestsellers
fields.trailText: Sylvia Smith is 56, unknown, unmarried, unemployed and has just published the story of her uneventful life. Kate Kellaway meets the unlikely author tipped to be one of this year's bestsellers
fields.body:
Stevie Smith, spinster of the suburbs, preferred not to stir from Palmer's Green. But she turned her uneventful life into wonderful, eccentric copy. Sylvia Smith may not be a great writer but she and Stevie share more than their surname. Sylvia could be Stevie's working-class sister: unmarried, childless, a retired secretary with a similarly deadpan sense of humour who has never moved from London's East End.

At 40, Sylvia took a hard look at her life and concluded she 'hadn't done much with it'. Now at 56, she has written a book about everything that has (and has not) happened to her: Misadventures. There is nothing more cheering than reading about other people's lack of success and I could not put down her unusual, deflated, hilarious book. It deserves to be a best-seller. But, if the rest of her life is anything to go by, it will be a flop.

The book emphasises comic anonymity. This is the story of Anywoman. Jeremy Lewis, a shrewd former publisher, suggests that Sylvia is a mature Helen Fielding, a 'champion of those who seem on the surface at least embattled, defeated and horribly unsuccessful'. But this is missing the point. Sylvia Smith isn't making anything up. She is no Bridget Jones: she is the real thing. Even her goldfish are unlucky. Disliking their boring environs, they leap out of their bowl and stun themselves on the lino. Sylvia is doing the same thing: leaping out of her life and into print.

She shies away from self-description, preferring incident to emotion. Her flat style is catching. Some chapters (each with its own title) are only a paragraph long; they are like matches that refuse to light. She finishes chapters with lines such as: 'Frank married someone else a few years later.' Or: 'Personnel think it would be nicer if they had a younger temp.' I note, too, that Sylvia always gives the exact age of those appearing in each brief instalment, as if age were the key to everything, including disappointment.

The phone call

I am 43. Sylvia is 56.

I tell Sylvia I loved the book. 'Have you read it? she exclaims, astounded. 'I thought it was very funny.' 'Oh good, you're meant to find it funny.' I am surprised by her voice. I had expected a prudish voice to match her behaviour. (She went out with 100 men before she was 25 but all relationships were platonic. She dislikes it when men are too forward. But she talks as if each word might contain a triple entendre. How long would it take to walk to her flat from Leyton tube? 'I don't know. I never use the tube.' She thought the walk might take 'about seven minutes'. I said that would be fine. She said 'Oooh... it wouldn't suit me, it's raining.' I tell her I don't mind a walk. She says 'I've got a hairdryer...'

I go at a brisk pace down Leyton High Road and finally reach Sylvia's front door. I am out of breath but not wet. The walk takes 25 minutes.

The meeting

I am (still) 43. Sylvia is 56.

Sylvia comes to the door in a saffron yellow T-shirt in shiny material. Her trousers are black. 'I made them myself,' she tells me. She is thin and bold with a naughty laugh, like someone gargling down an illicit drink. She could be a 'resting' actress. Her eyes are kohled, her hair quite long. 'Do you want the hairdryer?'

I decline. Sylvia trained as a hairdresser but gave up before completing her apprenticeship. She subsequently attempted to cut a friend's hair but could not get it even and eventually cut almost all of it off.

When did she start writing? 'The idea came into my head when I was 43. I am 56 now. You can make a note I don't look it, if you like.' (She gives one of her incredible laughs at this). Rain is hammering down on the plastic roof of the kitchen and she introduces me to the flat as if it were a close friend. We sit down on her sofa. 'It folds out into a double bed,' she remarks. I look around. It is like being inside a toy box full of pretty trinkets and buffeted toys. 'There are eight bedsits here. I've been in my little studio two and a half years. Do you want some biscuits?'

There was almost no editorial interference with the book. 'I worked very hard, sometimes three hours on one page.' The title is her own. What do her friends think of it? 'I asked this married girlfriend whether she liked it. She said, "Not particularly." Then I asked her if she had found it funny. She said, "No. Not at all." '

Three photographs

There are three framed photographs on a coffee table. The first is of Sylvia as a little girl in a white frock with a forest behind her. 'It is my back garden in Walthamstow,' she explains. She is wearing a huge hat and frowning. 'You look cross,' I say. She puts her glasses on, and stares at the picture: 'No. It's total innocence, isn't it? Look at my big, fat face.' She is critical of her dress, too. 'Look how my dress goes up at the front.'

Second: Gertrude Elizabeth and Walter Smith, her paternal grandparents. They appear miserably awed by the camera. Walter longs to get away. Gertrude wears a black belt that looks uncomfortable. Gertrude's maiden name was Smith, then she married a Smith: 'Miss Smith became Mrs Smith.'

Third: Reginald John Smith, Sylvia's father. She praises his smile (as if it were an achievement at his age). He died a few years ago, at 92, of a 'massive heart attack'. She was recalled from a 'four-day holiday at Ramsgate.' She had to arrange the funeral which was 'awful'. 'But I've spent my life sorting out things.' She says: 'My parents were funny in a way.' One hand flickers like a bird scarer. Had her mother read the book? 'With difficulty, through a magnifying glass. She thinks it is fabulous. She thinks everything I do is fabulous.'

Husbands and other 'h' words

I ask her if she could live her life again, what she would do differently? 'I don't go around thinking of my life,' she says (as if the idea were indecent). Would she describe it as very disappointing? 'No. A bit disappointing.' The love of her life was a Greek boyfriend, Heracles, whom she met in the Café de Paris, off Leicester Square when he was 27 and she was 25. She tells us how to pronounce his name: 'The H is silent. You then say 'error' and join it to the surname of John Cleese the actor and you have the name "Heracles".'Heracles does seem to have been an error. Twenty years after they parted, she found a Christmas card from him on which he had written: 'I remember you and every moment of the quite long time we spent together... ' She realised how much he must have loved her. 'I sat and cried.'

In the book, Sylvia explains she is bad at judging when a melon is ripe. I suggest she may be bad at judging when her romances are ripe too. Did she regret not marrying Heracles? 'No. I had such a traumatic time with him; he had a bad time with me.' Does she wish she had married someone else? 'No. I don't go around looking for a husband.' (This is in the same fastidious tone in which she explained she does not go around thinking about her life.) 'If I meet someone nice I go out with him.' So she would not like a husband? 'No. I don't want one particularly.'

The other boyfriend who lasted was Ali, a Turk. 'I still see Ali but only on a friendly basis.' Her most successful relationships were not with Englishmen. Does she find them boring? 'Yes. It might be because I know them. I've fallen in love with all the foreigners - or most of them... '

Sylvia's grandmother, wearer of the uncomfortable belt, had nine children. She complained to her husband about his attentions and 'would jump down the entire staircase in her house in the early stages of pregnancy in the hope of losing her unborn child'. Sylvia is not sure why anyone wants children. 'One fella I know says he loves his children but they drive him mad. Children can give you a whole lot of grief. The children I see with my friends are so badly behaved, I don't know how they put up with them. I am delighted I haven't got any. Do you have children? You do? Oh well you probably know what that fella was talking about.'

Other lives

If she could choose to be someone else, who would it be? 'Elizabeth Taylor without the illnesses. If it is with the illnesses, forget it. She swelled up with about six double chins. But she certainly lived her life.' What if she could come back as a man? 'Prince Charles without the sadness. He is lovely. He doesn't show his personality but he has a fantastic sense of humour inside there. I saw him on television at a kids' party; he was blowing on makebelieve cups of tea. Just don't ask me about Camilla.'

The Car

Curiously, Sylvia will talk about men but not about her car. It is off the record. Not that anyone should drive off with the wrong idea about it. It is nothing fancy. But she told me where she likes to go in it: 'Usually, at about noon I take myself to Epping market and have a cheap lunch. I thoroughly enjoy a nice little drive. One of my hobbies is shopping. And I like to have a big breakfast in Tescos. And I like to go to charity shops.' She has been unemployed for years. 'I've had nine years off. It has been absolutely lovely. Why would I want to go to work?'

Sylvia's most recent misadventure

'Me and my neighbour kept getting mice. So I bought a kitten called Tommy. He was a beautiful little thing. He was all right for about four days. But he started to put up a fight about everything. And he kept going for my mother's legs. I disposed of him. He was far worse than I had anticipated.

A wave of the handkerchief...

She hopes 'everyone who ever knew me will go out and buy the book and read about themselves'. Would she like to see people she has lost touch with? 'I'd love to see my old friends regardless of whether we fell out. It was probably 50/50...' Has she ever felt self-pity? 'I am not going to answer your question. It is too long a story to go into it. But I am not bitter.' She isn't. Earlier, she caught me sniffing and jumped up to open a glass closet inside which there was a bulk supply of travel-sized paper handkerchiefs. 'Take the packet,' she said. Just now, she is giving them away.

Sylvia's Stories: Two Chapters from 'Misadventures'

1969

Bob

Bob was 30. I was 24. We met at a dance at the Empire ballroom in Leicester Square. We had one date.

Bob invited me to dinner at his flat one Thursday evening and we made arrangements that he would meet me by car at his local underground station.

He cooked an excellent medium rare steak and French fries, served with a dressed salad and a glass of claret.

After our meal we settled in his lounge with the remainder of the wine. I found him to be far too amorous. I turned down his advances and would do no more than kiss him.

At the end of the evening he drove me back to the Tube and suggested I meet him there the following Thursday, but this time with a pound of sausages as he would have no time for shopping.

The next Thursday I arrived at the underground station at the appointed hour but there was no Bob. After waiting 40 minutes and not knowing exactly where he lived and still there was no Bob, I went home, taking my sausages with me.

1981

The Indian Shopkeeper

He was short and middle-aged. I was 36

I saw a beautiful green handbag in the window of an east London leatherware shop. But without its price tag. I entered the shop and asked the Indian shopkeeper how much it cost. He reached for the bag and passed it to me, saying: 'This is an excellent handbag in a very soft leather that I imported from France and I want £75 for it.' It was much more than I had expected and I told him so. He showed me various cheaper bags but I didn't like any and left the shop.

I walked along the High Road and the Indian shopkeeper caught up with me. He fell into step beside me and we strode along the main road together. He asked: 'Can I take you for a coffee?' I replied:'No thank you.' Undaunted he asked: 'Can I take you for a drink?' Again I replied: 'No thank you.' He then asked: 'Would you like to be my wife?' I was very surprised but once again I replied: 'No thank you.' He returned to his shop as I continued on my way.

Jeff Bezos is the king of the New Economy. His online company turned the $300,000 he borrowed from his parents into $79,800,000 in five years. But Amazon.com last week announced a dramatic cut in staff and if it folds e-commerce could be a thing of the past. Andrew Smith meets the man who's laughing off a personal loss of $7bn
