fields.trailText: Jeff Bezos is the king of the New Economy. His online company turned the $300,000 he borrowed from his parents into $79,800,000 in five years. But Amazon.com last week announced a dramatic cut in staff and if it folds e-commerce could be a thing of the past. Andrew Smith meets the man who's laughing off a personal loss of $7bn.
fields.body:
It's the tail end of 1999 and a dusty road in Coffeytown, Kansas leads to the largest warehouse anyone round these parts has ever thought to conceive of. Inside, 300 residents sit rapt before a makeshift podium as the voice of America's most controversial businessman reverberates through a million square feet of near-empty space. He gives them a well-practised spiel about their company's mission, about the sanctity of the customer and misguidedness of critics who have been lining up to trash the vision he is inviting them to share. He is their boss, but he's so much more than that. This edifice is one of five state-of-the-art distribution facilities scattered across the US like New Economy fairy dust. To some, Jeff Bezos represents, even embodies, the future. To others, he is a self-deluding billionaire conman. His online trading company, amazon.com, has never made a profit. Time magazine crowned him its Man of the Year anyway.

But here comes the strange part. At the end of Bezos's talk, there is a brief question-and-answer session. He is asked what his new house - a $10m mansion, not far from Bill Gates's on the 'gold coast' of Lake Washington in Seattle - looks like. He is asked how many items Amazon sells and where he got the name from: his first choice had been abracadabra.com, but his lawyer had heard this over the phone as 'cadaver.com', after which it didn't seem such a good idea. Then, finally, a woman in the front row gets up and asks a question the outwardly modest and self-effacing Bezos wasn't expecting.

'Can I have your autograph?'

He smiles and nods and she approaches, closely followed by the first four rows, and the ones behind, before virtually everyone in the room is crowded round, handing over dollar bills, scraps of paper, the hard hats they wear, to be anointed by the chairman.

All of which is by way of saying that, at the end of 1999, Chief Executive Officers of new technology firms have fans and groupies and stalkers, like pop stars or matinée idols. The world seems to be turning upside down. And though neither Bezos nor his purring shareholders and staff knows it, before the next year is out, it'll turn again.

And if thrusting techie CEOs are the film stars of the modern age, Jeff Bezos, in his plain button-down shirts and chinos, cuts an unlikely but indisputable Errol Flynn. Few people on earth would have the stomach for the ride he's had over the past five years since he borrowed his parents' $300,000 retirement money and began selling books over the internet from his garage. The first tranche of staff he recruited all became millionaires. When it was floated on the stock market on 15 May 1997, Amazon shares were valued at $1.50. Precisely 19 months later, they stood at $242.75. Three weeks after that, they shot past $400. $400! The $300,000 his mother had lent him with a concerned 'Can't you just keep your day job, dear, and do this part time?' was now worth $79,800,000 and while the stock was 'split' three times and had levelled out at a saner-looking figure of $107 by the end of 1999, this still represented a staggering return in real terms.

At this time, Fortune magazine was estimating Bezos's personal paper wealth at close to $10bn, more than the GDP of Iceland. Venture capitalists were still lining up to bankroll anyone with an idea for an internet-based enterprise and Amazon's founder had emerged as the standard bearer, the brilliant king of cybercommerce whose daring business plan involved spending heavily on infrastructure and buy-outs of smaller players while such opportunities existed, on the grounds that the thrilling chaos of this frontier economy wouldn't last forever. He had begun with books, then decided to sell everything, taking on Barnes & Noble, Borders and Wal-Mart, and was losing money hand over fist: $390m in 1999 alone, on revenues of $1.6bn. Sceptics were beginning to wonder how long it would be before Amazon simply ran out of cash. They provided nicknames like 'amazon.con', 'amazon.toast', 'amazon.bomb' and, Bezos's avowed personal favourite, 'amazon.org' (the 'org' handle usually being used to denote a non-profit organisation).

Bezos looked to be playing a dangerous game, raising the stakes higher and higher still with each passing month, moving expensively into the UK, France and Germany. Nevertheless, things still looked good when, on 10 March 2000, the Nasdaq hi-tech share index rose to an all-time high of 5,132. Bullish commentators were speculating that this boom, unlike those of the past, could go on forever. Then, the very next week, the bottom dropped out of the dotcom market, as investors finally realised that they'd been sold a pup; that the same rules concerning visibility and service and cash flow attached to e-commerce as to any other kind of business. In the UK, the Techmark index fell from a high of 5,743 to 2,864. Since then, another dotcom start-up has crashed, on average, every day. The worldwide web is becoming littered with lonely 'ghost sites', each a testament to the broken dreams of another would-be Bezos. You can find a long list of them on the net at the e-museum.

Suddenly Amazon, whose business plan had been so widely emulated, became the subject of intense scrutiny. Shares temporarily stabilised at around $30, but at the time of writing stand at less than $19. Bezos made a show of unflappability, painting the crash as a return to normalcy, to rationality on the part of investors, but the anxiety surrounding him was palpable. If Amazon went down, it was whispered, the whole 'New Economy' would be revealed as a chimera. Furthermore, Amazon staff were paid partly with shares in the company and had been forced to stand by helplessly and watch their wealth collapse. Last July, a report from market analysts at Lehman Brothers predicted that the organisation would run out of cash early this year. An accountancy professor at the London Business School is notorious for having bet his students that the crunch would come in the second quarter.

Ten days ago, Amazon announced that it would be ditching 15 per cent of its 8,000-strong workforce and closing one of its distribution centres. The buffeted workers in Coffeytown must have breathed a sigh of relief when they heard that the loser was to be Georgia, not Kansas. At the same time, the figures for the fourth quarter of 2000, which included Christmas and was thought to be crucial to the company's survival, were inconclusive. Nevertheless, Bezos was upbeat and brazenly optimistic as ever. If he's not just another Wall Street morality tale at the end of all this, he could be the last man standing. And if that happens, Bill Gates's success at Microsoft will look like a drop in the cyber ocean by comparison. As one acquaintance says, 'Jeff, he's a sweet guy. But he's so tough.'

Amazon's Pac Med building stands imperiously on a hill overlooking the twinkling business district of Seattle. It is beautiful: a former state hospital built in a Deco style in 1928, from red brick and glass, on a site donated to the government by Seattle's elders. An ornate marble and brass reception area opens into a network of open-plan communal spaces, mazes of the tiny, dour grey cubbyholes tech firms seem to favour for their junior staff, and austere offices, each sporting one of Bezos's trademark homemade desks, which are fashioned out of DIY store-bought doors. Boxes of extraneous items - big stuffed toys, vintage model cars, novelty clocks - spill from boxes, waiting to be auctioned or swapped through the website. The canteen looks and feels like a gastro pub.

It's hardly an exaggeration to say that you can hear Jeff Bezos coming from two floors away. Anyone will tell you that the most distinctive thing about him is his laugh. Sometimes it is a mere roar - huuaaaarrrhhahahaha! - at others, mostly in moments of stress or discomfort, what you get is a full-scale explosion... ahhahrhaHAHRHAHRHAHR AAAHHHHHRRRR!!! Often you can spot one of these coming and have to struggle to stop yourself from diving under the table for shelter... duck for cover. Blaawwwwww!! It's an endearing and, perhaps more to the point, disarming trait in someone whose whole life depends on the whims of a bunch of jumpy gamblers (ie 'investors'), and may help to explain why almost no one has a bad word to say about Jeff Bezos once they've met him. When I comment on the laugh later, he chuckles and offers, 'Well, I come from a long line of goofy people.' You find yourself thinking that such outsize bonhomie must be a defence mechanism of some kind, but if so, it runs deep.

'My wife always says, "If Jeff's in a bad mood, just leave him for three minutes, then he'll be OK,"' he tells me when I question his evident lack of angst.

Either way, Jeff Bezos is not what you were expecting.

In fact, if Bezos was the only factor in all of this, no one would bet against him. The words which feature most prominently in any telling of his story are 'first' and 'youngest'. His father, Mike Bezos, left Cuba, alone, at the age of 15, shortly after Castro's revolution. At that time, the US was accepting refugees with open arms and the young Bezos was taken to Delaware by Catholic missionaries, who fed, clothed, educated him and ultimately sent him to college. When he met his future wife in Albuquerque, New Mexico, she already had Jeff, whom she'd given birth to at the age of 17 while involved in a turbulent marriage which only lasted a year. Her son didn't learn until he was eight that Mike Bezos was not his biological father, and if he has had any inclination to track the other man down, he admits it to no one.

'As far as I'm concerned, I only have one dad and he's my real dad,' he states bluntly.

Did his parents face any prejudice over their mixed marriage in the South of the early 60s?

'If they did, I never recognised it. You're right, of course, that's a possibility, there's a lot of prejudice in the world. But he's an incredibly funny and charming person. I can't imagine anyone taking against him. Arharharharhhar!'

The childhood he describes is idyllic, defined by loving parents and doting grandparents, particularly his maternal grandfather, after whom Bezos named his 11-month-old son, Preston. He was recognised as bright early on and went to a school for gifted children. Geeky and awkward, he got picked on, but not so badly as he might have done elsewhere. In the first grade (at the age of six), he wanted to be an archaeologist, he thinks, because someone taught him how to spell the word and he was proud of it. After the moon landing in 1969, he wanted to be an astronaut and admits with boyish enthusiasm that 'that's still on my list of things to do, if it ever becomes practical'. Eventually, he would go to Princeton with the aim of becoming a theoretical physicist. He was always top of his class - though even now, he doesn't parade his intellect, hoving it into view only when absolutely necessary. All his energies seem focused on making everyone in his immediate orbit feel comfortable. To be so relentlessly, unfeasibly nice must be draining and I find a kind of heroism in it, whether it's a true reflection of what's going on inside or not. Perhaps even more if it's not.

At Princeton, something unexpected happened. He met people who were as smart as him. In fact, some who were smarter.

'I went to Princeton specifically to study physics,' he says evenly, 'and found out, by the time I got to quantum mechanics... I was doing well, but it was so much work for me, it was hard - and there were half a dozen people in my class who were so gifted, and their brains were just wired in a different way, and the things that I worked so hard to do came so effortlessly to them... and it was...'

Brace yourself.

'Eerharhahrhahrhahrhar!!'

You mean it was disappointing.

'Well, it was certainly... I would say it was a combination of shocking and awe inspiring. It was sort of, "Wow, this is incredible that some people can process these incredibly abstract concepts so gracefully"... So anyway, I realised that I was going to be a mediocre theoretical physicist - herhehrhehrher!'

And there's probably not a lot of call for that?

'Exactly, you just hit the nail on the head. Mediocre theoretical physicists make no progress. They spend all their time understanding other people's progress. Aarharhaherhahtrerh! So once I got over the pain, huhuhuhuhuhuhh...'

So it was painful?

'Actually, not as painful as awe-inspiring.'

OK. Fortunately, Bezos had also been conducting a love affair with early computers since his days at school, so he refocused on that, 'as a space that I could swim through'. He left Princeton and, by the age of 26, had become the youngest-ever vice-president of the Bankers Trust Company. In December 1990, he moved to DE Shaw & Co, a high-end company specialising in arcane financial transactions, where he specialised in spotting new business opportunities and became the youngest-ever senior vice-president at age 28. It was here that the idea of Amazon was born, but first there was another deal to be brokered. At 27, Bezos decided it was time to find a wife. Adapting the business term 'deal flow' to his purposes, he decided that what he needed in his life was more 'women flow'. So he instructed his friends to start arranging blind dates. His only hope for his future wife was that she should be 'someone resourceful enough to get me out of a Third-World prison'. That was all. It didn't work.

But he was extremely wealthy at that point. And, as we've established, a winning personality. He must have been a catch.

'Oh, they certainly didn't see it that way!!!' The ensuing convulsion seems to last for about a minute and a half. 'Ah. Hmmm. I should have had you as my PR person. Ah. No. I think that, ah, I'm a very goofy sort of person in many ways. I tell duff jokes. I kind of have to grow on somebody. Huge laugh. 'Yeah, ub, ah, indeed . It was exactly like that.'

He smiles.

But when I ask him if the burden of leadership ever feels onerous, his blunt reply, which shoots back way too quickly to be real, is: 'No. No .'

Still, this man could end up as the most powerful magnate on the planet, and we want to know how, if at all, his corporation and its methods are going to differ from those of the past. When it was just books, Amazon seemed like such a charming idea. Now that they're moving into every area of our lives, what's to stop them from becoming little more than an online alternative to Wal-Mart, the US retailing behemoth that piles 'em high and keeps wages down? The briefest flicker of anger flashes across Bezos's face. It's so out of character as to be startling.

'No, definitely not.'

Why?

'Because we're building something completely new. Online retailing won't replace in-store retailing. I've never said that. But I do think that it can be a different, enriching experience. But even there, the store doesn't instantly customise itself to suit your interests the way ours does and no one can tell you what other people who buy the books you're buying also bought. And you can't read your neighbours' reviews the way we allow you to. Those kind of community features can only be done online. And you can't have universal selection in a store, however big it is.'

And I can vouch for their reputation for finding anything: they once secured an obscure book of poetry - secondhand, in Australia - for a friend of mine who had tried every other means of locating one, and charged her $5.99 for it. Which brings us back to where we began. You would have to be a freak to dislike Jeff Bezos. Up to now, you'd have to be pretty screwy not to admire Amazon. But this won't ensure its survival. Everywhere you go, you find doubters.

And I wonder if they'll make more, or less, difference than their predecessors.


How dotcoms drowned in a tide of hope and hype


New economy tycoons who flew too close to the sun

Inside, 300 residents sit rapt before a makeshift podium as the voice of America's most controversial businessman reverberates through a million square feet of near-empty space. He gives them a well-practised spiel about their company's mission, about the sanctity of the customer and misguidedness of critics who have been lining up to trash the vision he is inviting them to share. He is their boss, but he's so much more than that. This edifice is one of five state-of-the-art distribution facilities scattered across the US like New Economy fairy dust. To some, Jeff Bezos represents, even embodies, the future. To others, he is a self-deluding billionaire conman. His online trading company, amazon.com, has never made a profit. Time magazine crowned him its Man of the Year anyway. But here comes the strange part. At the end of Bezos's talk, there is a brief question-and-answer session. He is asked what his new house - a $10m mansion, not far from Bill Gates's on the 'gold coast' of Lake Washington in Seattle - looks like. He is asked how many items Amazon sells and where he got the name from: his first choice had been abracadabra.com, but his lawyer had heard this over the phone as 'cadaver.com', after which it didn't seem such a good idea. Then, finally, a woman in the front row gets up and asks a question the outwardly modest and self-effacing Bezos wasn't expecting. 'Can I have your autograph?' He smiles and nods and she approaches, closely followed by the first four rows, and the ones behind, before virtually everyone in the room is crowded round, handing over dollar bills, scraps of paper, the hard hats they wear, to be anointed by the chairman. All of which is by way of saying that, at the end of 1999, Chief Executive Officers of new technology firms have fans and groupies and stalkers, like pop stars or matinée idols. The world seems to be turning upside down. And though neither Bezos nor his purring shareholders and staff knows it, before the next year is out, it'll turn again. And if thrusting techie CEOs are the film stars of the modern age, Jeff Bezos, in his plain button-down shirts and chinos, cuts an unlikely but indisputable Errol Flynn. Few people on earth would have the stomach for the ride he's had over the past five years since he borrowed his parents' $300,000 retirement money and began selling books over the internet from his garage. The first tranche of staff he recruited all became millionaires. When it was floated on the stock market on 15 May 1997, Amazon shares were valued at $1.50. Precisely 19 months later, they stood at $242.75. Three weeks after that, they shot past $400. $400! The $300,000 his mother had lent him with a concerned 'Can't you just keep your day job, dear, and do this part time?' was now worth $79,800,000 and while the stock was 'split' three times and had levelled out at a saner-looking figure of $107 by the end of 1999, this still represented a staggering return in real terms. At this time, Fortune magazine was estimating Bezos's personal paper wealth at close to $10bn, more than the GDP of Iceland. Venture capitalists were still lining up to bankroll anyone with an idea for an internet-based enterprise and Amazon's founder had emerged as the standard bearer, the brilliant king of cybercommerce whose daring business plan involved spending heavily on infrastructure and buy-outs of smaller players while such opportunities existed, on the grounds that the thrilling chaos of this frontier economy wouldn't last forever. He had begun with books, then decided to sell everything, taking on Barnes & Noble, Borders and Wal-Mart, and was losing money hand over fist: $390m in 1999 alone, on revenues of $1.6bn. Sceptics were beginning to wonder how long it would be before Amazon simply ran out of cash. They provided nicknames like 'amazon.con', 'amazon.toast', 'amazon.bomb' and, Bezos's avowed personal favourite, 'amazon.org' (the 'org' handle usually being used to denote a non-profit organisation). fields.headline: Nigeria's nightmares
fields.standfirst: Karl Maier paints a bleak picture of contemporary Nigeria in This House has Fallen
fields.trailText: Karl Maier paints a bleak picture of contemporary Nigeria in This House has Fallen
fields.body:
This House has Fallen
Karl Maier
Allen Lane/Penguin £20, pp368
Buy it at a discount at BOL

'The trouble with Nigeria is simply and squarely a failure of leadership,' wrote Chinua Achebe almost 20 years ago, referring to the endemic corruption that had afflicted every government, civilian and military, since the country gained independence in 1960. The litany of the country's woes makes for depressing reading. Blessed with abundant oil resources, the world's tenth most populous country is shamefully underdeveloped and in constant crisis. Since 1960, Nigeria has endured the Biafran civil war, which has led to over a million deaths, the assassination of two government leaders, six successful coups and three decades of military rule.

In This House Has Fallen Karl Maier argues that Nigeria is driven by religious, ethnic and regional disputes. Post-colonial Nigeria, says one observer, is a 'mere geographical expression' created by the British as an administrative solution. Maier, former Africa correspondent for the Independent, has travelled extensively throughout the country over the last decade, returning after the landmark 1999 elections, and his book features some memorable reportage. His evocative descriptions, ranging from an audience with former military dictator General Ibrahim Babangida to a fervent Pentecostal church minister, prove more compelling than his thesis. He describes a country on the brink of a nervous breakdown but, disappointingly, offers little vision of Nigeria's future.

The real problem, suggests Maier, is an overwhelming sense of discontent, often exploited by politicians unwilling, or unable, to grapple with the social and economic issues. Half the country's inhabitants live in poverty and the university-educated middle classes struggle to find commensurate employment in the sick economy. Nigeria's petro-dollars haven't trickled down. Instead the military and bureaucrats collect the contract sweeteners and siphon off the oil revenues.

Yet Nigeria is also a country rich in human resources and potential. The populace is resourceful, stoic and passionate but, according to President Obasanjo, obsessed with success and status. He says: 'What matters to most Nigerians are the six Ps which are pursued at all cost - position, power, possession, plaudit, popularity and pleasure. With the six Ps he can buy anything and buy himself into anything. Honesty is disregarded, indolence is extolled, probity is derided, and waste and ostentation are paraded.'

Obasanjo's controversial election victory in 1999 marked a final break from the reviled despotism of former leader General Sani Abacha. The dark days of Abacha's deserve more space than is merited here since they had enormous effect on the nation. Anecdotal evidence suggests not much has changed since.

This House Has Fallen concludes on a cautiously optimistic note. Pro-democracy movements, grass roots activism and a large dose of altruism could save the day, a message that is noticeably at odds with much of the preceding text.

webTitle: Size matters

fields.headline: Size matters
fields.trailText: The idea that a little book can be important is shocking to some people...
fields.body:
This new year has seen the publication of two good new books, Edmund White's The Flâneur: A Stroll Through the Paradoxes of Paris (Bloomsbury £9.99) and Carol Shields's biography of Jane Austen (Weidenfeld £12.99) each of which, at about 150 pages, suggest that the shorter book is making a comeback. In the world of books, two almost makes a trend, and if this turns out to be the case, it's quite a startling development.

The idea that a little book can be important is shocking to some people. Brevity rhymes with levity. Little books are seen as somehow not serious. Literature, on the other hand, reaches us in long books. And length implies gravity, as William Henry, first Duke of Gloucester, acknowledged when, upon receiving Edward Gibbon's latest, he notoriously exclaimed 'Another damned, thick, square book! Always scribble, scribble, scribble! Eh, Mr Gibbon?' (This remark is also attributed to George III.)

Pace the Hanoverians, we are brought up to believe that reading should be a wholly absorbing process of intellectual engagement with a complex and substantial text - War and Peace, for example, or Bleak House. Both of these titles fall within the realist tradition whose shadow still falls over many of the books released today. Realism and length go hand in hand. 'Realism,' wrote Albert Camus in The Rebel, 'is indefinite enumeration.'

Actually, when you come to think about it, English literature is full of some marvellous short books: Thomas More's Utopia, Dickens's A Christmas Carol, Sterne's Sentimental Journey, Orwell's Animal Farm and Johnson's Rasselas (composed in the evenings of a single week to defray the cost of his mother's funeral). Many other great writers have not scorned to be brief when it suited them.

Your shorter book may be a breeze for the reader. To the author, it's a demanding genre. Every writer knows that it's harder to write three pages than 30. One of my favourites, Robert Louis Stevenson, who rather cornered the market with Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, Treasure Island and Travels With a Donkey, once observed that 'the only art is to omit'. He enlarged on this thought in a letter to a friend: 'If there is anywhere a thing said in two sentences that could have been as clearly and as engagingly said in one, then it's amateur work.'

In the history of English-language publishing, the size of books has generally related to the temper and economic circumstances of the times. The Victorians, famously, wrote, published and finally read that stalwart of the circulating library, the three-decker novel. Later, in the leaner circumstances of the Thirties, and again during the Second World War, books (often in paperback) were commonly less than 300 pages, and often susceptible to a reading in a single sitting. Is there, indeed, for the book lover any more satisfying literary experience?

The long boom of the Eighties and Nineties sponsored shelfloads of fat books, many of them American volumes, written and manufactured to suit the Pile 'Em High traditions of the American book trade. It's no accident that the world champion in this genre, Tom Wolfe's Bonfire of the Vanities weighs in at 752 pages.

Recently, however, there has begun to be a reaction to the tyranny of length. Two years ago, a New York man of letters, James Atlas, and his business partner Ken Lipper dreamed up, and then sold, the idea of short biographies. Not everyone thought this was a good wheeze, but after a slow start, they clicked. Interestingly, Mr Atlas does not practise what he preaches. His recent biography of Saul Bellow is a monster of some 704 pages.

Anyway, the Atlas-Lipper series, Lives, is generally first class (and includes the Shields biography of Austen). It is published in America by Viking, and over here by Weidenfeld. Perhaps it was this example that gave Bloomsbury's Liz Calder the idea for a series of short books about cities. And - who knows? - perhaps it was Edmund White's brilliant short life of Marcel Proust that secured him the commission to write another short book, this time about Paris.

It would be nice to think that the success of these books will encourage publishers to look again at their commissioning habits and practises. It would be nice to imagine this, but it probably won't happen. The British book trade is as temperamentally conservative as a Bexhill whist drive. And as cautious, too. It will follow where others lead. So it's a fair bet that just now many of the cannier operators are keeping a sharp eye on another brave new publishing venture that will launch later in the spring, the brain-child of two former journalists, Rebecca Nicolson and Aurea Carpenter. It's called Short Books. Maybe there is a trend here, after all.

webTitle: Observer review: Titan by Filippo Pedocco and MA Chiara Moretto Wiel

fields.headline: Box of fireworks
fields.standfirst: Filippo Pedocco and MA Chiara Moretto Wiel's long-awaited catalogue reveals Titian's genius in all its splendour
fields.trailText: Filippo Pedocco and MA Chiara Moretto Wiel's long-awaited catalogue reveals Titian's genius in all its splendour
fields.body:
Titan: the Complete Paintings
Filippo Pedrocco and MA Chiara Moretto Wiel
Thames and Hudson £50, pp336

Titian was famous from the start, when he burst on Venice as the greatest of prodigies; he remained at the pinnacle of his profession until his death in advanced old age, 70 years later, somewhere between the ages of 86 and 103. He has left us a body of work that in its freedom, daring and unflagging excitement has no parallel. He is the peak of the Venetian renaissance, the greatest colourist in the history of Western art. Even a formal catalogue of his complete paintings like this can hardly fail to give the dangerous thrilling promise of a box of fireworks.

The magic of Titian is in his marriage of rich sensuous appeal with the most elevated philosophical symbolism. The observer can immediately fall in love with the characteristic velvety surface, the astonishing absorption in the effects of colour. Close your eyes and think of the National Gallery's Bacchus and Ariadne, and what comes to mind is the unforgettable leaping God and the most intense blue sky a painter ever imagined; the late mythologies leave an enduring impression of russety browns and greens, as clear as Rothko.

But Titian's painterly genius is only the half of it, and a slower examination of the paintings will reveal a man who talked with the poets and the philosophers of his age on an equal footing. Often, a mythology or a portrait will reveal a deep interest in neo-Platonic imagery. The late Venus Blindfolding Cupid in the Galleria Borghese, for instance, may be an allegory of the neo-Platonic idea of earthly and divine love, and certainly a subject that was devised by the painter for the benefit of a learned patron. Some of these subjects have now become obscure, and scholars are always arguing about the exact meaning of the Flaying of Marsyas; but they were never meant to be clear, and were always painted for the benefit of a rarefied and scholarly group of philosopher-kings.

What the paintings reveal is a painter of the utmost originality and curiosity. Most painters, even the greatest such as Raphael, are content to work within the subjects and manner of their predecessors. Titian was not, and his subjects, such as the mythologies on Ovid, are as likely to be inspired by his reading and thought; his practice in painting derives from experimentation in the studio and is without precedent. He transformed the art and is always looking forward rather than backwards; the Interrupted Concert is startlingly reminiscent of a Caravaggio, and Velazquez became what he was by long thought about the sublime Titians of Philip II.

Of course there are things which Titian took from his contemporaries; the impact on him of Roman mannerism in the 1540s has been much examined, and perhaps overstated. But he showed a marvellous ability to take without direct imitation, and when the posture of a Titian Venus may be demonstrated to derive from one of Michelangelo's figures of Day and Night, it strikes one as a shock, so completely has Titian succeeded in making it his own. Perhaps the greatest tribute to the riches of Titian's art is that he proved, for Veronese or Tintoretto, one of those models in which quite unsuspected qualities, the opposite of what we normally mean by Titianesque, may be found. Like Rembrandt, he encouraged greatness and not just imitation.

The characteristic texture of a mature Titian - what Filippo Pedrocco aptly calls a 'smoky, magma-like impasto' - was produced by an extraordinarily intricate technique. We have a thorough account of his working methods from Palma Giovane, as recorded by Marco Boschini; a broad sketching of the principal figures in raw colours, and then the canvas was abandoned for a few months for consideration, before reshaping in solid layers of paint.

The final surface was produced, according to Palma, 'more with his fingers than with his brush'. What remains reveals, as well as conceals, its rich depths; the characteristic texture of a Titian, particularly in his later phase, is of highlights scudding over a deep, complex series of layers, shadows and light. He worked quickly when it was necessary - the great frescoes for the Scuola del Santo in Padua were done in just 23 days - but for the most part his paintings were the product of deep thought and contemplation.

It is surprising, given Titian's place in European art, that no proper catalogue has recently been produced of his paintings, and this is something anyone with an interest in painting will want to have. A slightly dry, but accurate and informative essay is followed by the paintings, and each is given an admirable and enlightening commentary. Titian's masterpieces are the mythologies, and particularly the mythological subjects he produced late in life for Philip II of Spain, from which all great Spanish painting stems.

What is particularly pleasing is the serious consideration of the marvellous series of portraits, which are viewed in exactly the same way, as symbolic statements; there are always fewer props, but Pedroccio confirms what one always instinctively felt, that in the Man with a Glove there is a philosophical statement to match anything in Titian's more crowded and elaborate works. Admirable, too, is the patient explanation of why Titian's religious paintings and altarpieces represent so very radical a break with the past, and it is important to be taken through their innovations in space, colour and design by a scrupulous guide.

Titian is always beautiful and perhaps the great benefit of this solid guide through his work is that it takes that largely for granted and reminds us that he is also difficult and was utterly revolutionary.

webTitle: Observer review: Late Victorian Holocausts by Mike Davis

fields.headline: From mud to pebbles
fields.standfirst: Mike Davis tells how western empires wrought destruction in Late Victorian Holocausts
fields.trailText: Mike Davis tells how western empires wrought destruction in Late Victorian Holocausts
fields.body:
Late Victorian Holocausts: El Niño, Famines and the Making of the Third World
Mike Davis
Verso £20, pp464
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Driven to insurrection by the drought of 1877, the native Kanak people of New Caledonia rose against their French colonists in a desperate and ultimately tragic revolution. In a meeting with the Governor, Olry, the rebel leader Atai acted out a graphic explanation of his people's grievances. He carried with him two sacks, the contents of which he emptied at the Frenchman's feet. The first contained soil. 'This,' said Atai, 'is what we had before you came.' The second contained pebbles. 'And this is what we have now.' By June of 1878 Atai's rebellion was over after a slash and burn policy had reduced hundreds of Kanak villages to ash. Atai himself was captured and decapitated by the French, his head sent back to Paris as a trophy of war.

It is a grim irony that many of those who fought in the war of extermination against the Kanaks were themselves exiles from the revolutionary Paris Commune of 1871. But Louise Michel, The Red Virgin of Paris, took the Kanak side and even gave half her famous red scarf to two rebel friends.

In her memoirs Michel wrote movingly of the failed rebellion: 'The strength and longing of human hearts was shown once again, but the whites shot down the rebels as we were mowed down in front of Bastion 37 and on the plains of Satory. When they sent the head of Atai, I wondered who the real headhunters were; as Henri Rochefort had once written to me, "the Versailles government could give the natives lessons in cannibalism".'

Atai's simple but dramatic demonstration before the French governor and Michel's more conventional colonial narrative both express the central argument of Mike Davis's book.

He maintains that the droughts that struck across Asia, Africa, South America and the Pacific at the end of the nineteenth century were at best exacerbated by the colonial powers and at worst turned into vehicles of extermination by European governments blinded by the yoked ideologies of neo-Darwinism and free-market capitalism.

Since the French invasion of 1853 the indigenous Melanesians of the Pacific island of New Caledonia had been driven off the fertile land on the west coast into reserves in the mountainous interior. In a policy developed first in Algeria, the French replaced potentially troublesome local chiefs with pliant placemen loyal to the new regime. Within two years the French had thrown the Kanaks off 90 per cent of the best land and destroyed the tribal culture. The famine and its aftermath did the rest.

Late Victorian Holocausts is two great books in one. The first is a political history of the droughts and famine that killed millions in the colonial world just as it was being wiped out in western Europe. The second is the scientific history of the phenomenon that became known as the El Niño Southern Oscillation (Enso): the cyclical pattern of extreme weather conditions that created the droughts in the first place. This part of the book celebrates the work of scientists, culminating in that of Jacob Bjerknes of University of California, Los Angeles, in the 1960s who studied the inner workings of El Niño, the rapid warming of the tropical Pacific that leads to drought, and its equally deadly twin La Niña, which causes torrential rain and flooding

Davis draws together these meteorological and social phenomena to produce a picture of what he calls 'the malign interaction between climactic and economic processes'.

Between 1876 and 1902 as many as 60 million people died as a result of famines in India, China and Brazil. The earliest official examination of the causes of mass death in India by the Famine Commission of 1899-1902 found that it had been caused by high prices and not a shortage of food. In fact 1877, when millions died as a result of famine, was also a record year for Indian grain exports to Britain.

According to Davis, the Third World was created at this moment. Late Victorian Holocausts will redefine the way we think about the European colonial project. After reading this, I defy even the most ardent nationalist to feel proud of the so-called 'achievements' of empire.

This part of the book celebrates the work of scientists, culminating in that of Jacob Bjerknes of University of California, Los Angeles, in the 1960s who studied the inner workings of El Niño, the rapid warming of the tropical Pacific that leads to drought, and its equally deadly twin La Niña, which causes torrential rain and flooding Davis draws together these meteorological and social phenomena to produce a picture of what he calls 'the malign interaction between climactic and economic processes'. Between 1876 and 1902 as many as 60 million people died as a result of famines in India, China and Brazil. The earliest official examination of the causes of mass death in India by the Famine Commission of 1899-1902 found that it had been caused by high prices and not a shortage of food. In fact 1877, when millions died as a result of famine, was also a record year for Indian grain exports to Britain. According to Davis, the Third World was created at this moment. Late Victorian Holocausts will redefine the way we think about the European colonial project. After reading this, I defy even the most ardent nationalist to feel proud of the so-called 'achievements' of empire.

webTitle: Observer review: The Mind Game by Hector Macdonald

fields.headline: Something on his mind...
fields.standfirst: Hector Macdonald's first novel, The Mind Game, is an engaging thriller, but is it anything more?
fields.trailText: Hector Macdonald's first novel, The Mind Game, is an engaging thriller, but is it anything more?
fields.body:
The Mind Game
Hector Macdonald
Michael Joseph £9.99, pp329
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Hector Macdonald's first novel, The Mind Game, opens with a splendid mise-en-scène of social embarrassment and cruelty in the house of the obnoxious Piers, the worst sort of Oxbridge student - spoilt, arrogant, vicious. Among the guests is the social-climbing Dorset-born boy Ben Ashurst, too nice to be there, but too needy not to play along with the fast set.

Ben has foolishly invited an innocent and vulnerable freshwoman, out of her depth and in love with Ben. Also at the party is another newcomer, Cara, a drop-dead gorgeous femme fatale and consummate games player. And games there are: emotionally charged, stylised and sadistic versions of 'truth and dare'. It makes for an exciting and upsetting entrée into a thriller whose games are no less cruel and considerably more complex.

Ben's tutor, James Fieldhead - a sexy media don with the world at his feet - asks him to act as a human guinea-pig in a pioneering experiment in the measurement of emotion as electrical impulses in the brain, starting with pleasurable feelings. Ben eventually concurs, after events in his personal life give him good reason to; and besides, a three-week luxury holiday in Kenya, with pneumatic love interest, seems a small price to pay for having a sensor sewn into the back of his head. It isn't, of course. The holiday in paradise is the start of a trip through personal hell.

To set out any more of the plot would be to spoil the novel's main pleasures; a rapid succession of paranoia-inducing events, requiring guessing and second-guessing, where every revelation might be exposed later as mere puppeteering. Macdonald does a fine job with his plot, though it occasionally flirts with over-contrivance and the characters are developed no further than is necessary for their functions. The shocks he establishes, and the gradual harrowing of his protagonist, do make for a genuinely compulsive read. As a thriller, The Mind Game should more than satisfy fans of the genre.

Whether greater claims can be made for The Mind Game, as its publicists maintain, is less certain. The book, and the marketing surrounding it, inevitably makes much of the fact that its author is a former student of Richard Dawkins - to whom he gives credit within the story. Macdonald explains that 'to keep the book entertaining to non-scientific readers, I have simplified, omitted and selectively amplified', and there's nothing wrong with that, but there is nothing here that would require a university degree from either author or reader.

Neurophysiology and genetic research are two of the most exciting fields in science, and will have profound social impacts. Macdonald's larger concerns are offered mostly as stylised humanist outrage in the face of scientific and corporate evil.

I was, at times, reminded of John Fowles's The Magus, which is a more haunting investigation of human emotion, guilt, paranoia and manipulation, because its protagonist is more vividly realised, and the work more finely wrought, fruitfully enigmatic and philosophical. But Macdonald has produced a decently written, engaging and enjoyable thriller, which should be enough for most readers.

webTitle: The book I'd give...

fields.headline: The book I'd give...
fields.trailText: It is a story of love and loyalty, pain and devotion and loss, and the price a famous singer, La Perichole, pays for her art.
fields.body:
The Bridge of San Luís Rey
Thornton Wilder
Penguin Classics £6.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This book, first published in 1927, is about the lives and deaths of five people who perish when the suspension bridge between Cuzco and Lima gives way. Brother Juniper, a Franciscan monk, undertakes an examination of these five lives, hoping to discover God's intentions - unwisely, as it turns out. It is a story of love and loyalty, pain and devotion and loss, and the price a famous singer, La Perichole, pays for her art. The Bridge of San Luís Rey is full of clear air and high sunlight and an atmosphere that has made it part of my life since the time I first read it.

webTitle: Observer review: The Body Artist by Don DeLillo

fields.headline: The library in the body
fields.standfirst: Don DeLillo's intriguing new novel, The Body Artist, wrestles with syntax and the self
fields.trailText: Don DeLillo's intriguing new novel, The Body Artist, wrestles with syntax and the self
fields.body:
The Body Artist
Don DeLillo
Picador £13.99, pp124
Buy it at a discount at BOL

After the revolution comes... well, what, exactly? Three years ago, with Underworld, Don DeLillo exploded the scope of the contemporary novel. He proved that it could fuse historical stringency with Cold War paranoia; could provide an arena for our techno-dreams and urban myths. His book was an 827-page manifesto for the connexity and sweep of the late twentieth-century imagination, and, as Martin Amis observed in the New York Times, his voice 'suddenly filled the sky'.

He has followed that mushroom cloud of literary energy with something small and, by comparison, very nearly mute. The Body Artist feels like a wilful contraction of DeLillo's powers, a self-conscious rebooting of his sensory memory, almost an aftershock of humility. It returns this most daring of writers to first principles: how to construct sentences that properly describe the world; how to build a syntax adequate to extremes of emotion. If Underworld required the reader to think of Joyce, The Body Artist brings to mind, in the wariness of its prose, Beckett. Having spent most of his writing life revealing what of the present moment language might nail down, DeLillo here examines the substance of experience it can only grope towards.

He achieves this through the semi-detached voice of Lauren Hartke, a performance artist. The book opens with her making breakfast for her husband, a film director. The couple have rented an old house near the coast for six months, and everything has a new-lit, scoured quality. Lauren watches birds on the bird table, tries to get her mind to articulate their movements, and fails: '[they] broke off the feeder in a wing-whirr that was all b's and r's, the letter b followed by a series of vibrato r's. But that wasn't it at all. That wasn't anything like it...'

She finds unlikely intensity in simple domestic ritual: little haiku in the rinsing of blueberries under the cold tap or in watching her husband light his morning cigarette. She feels herself 'hyper-prepared, or haywire, or hair-trigger' as the detail of her life crowds in, threatens to overwhelm her. Instinct suddenly requires prompts: 'she took a bite of cereal and forgot to taste it', she observes of herself, third person; or, 'she remembered to smile'. As she reads the newspaper she drifts in and out of the distant lives it reports.

In some senses, all of this is by way of preparation. Though she does not know it as they routinely bicker over news and cereals, this will be the last morning Lauren will spend with her husband. After breakfast he drives to his ex-wife's apartment in Manhattan and shoots himself in the head. The remainder of the novel is concerned with Lauren's attempts to inhabit her sense of being 'sexually and abysmally alone'.

DeLillo's characters have often been super-sensitive to the aura and nuance of everyday objects, the strangeness of them. Here, he rounds on that quality, makes it his subject. After her husband's death Lauren needs to reconstruct her life into a narrative, but it refuses cause and effect. Driving, she finds herself in that state where 'all the cars including yours seem to flow in dissociated motion... and the highway runs in a white hum'. For her art and for her sanity she commits herself to the 'gyrate exaggerations, the snake shapes and flower bends' of yoga; she relearns how to breathe; she cuts her hair and sheds her skin, obsessively exfoliating and scraping and pumicing, making herself raw to the world.

The author returns - a persistent theme - to the dehumanising effects of technology, the ways in which reality is diminished by electronic mediation. Lauren, clinging to a sense of what is human, becomes intrigued, here, for example, by the automated voice on an answering machine message 'one male voice in seven different time cycles. But not male exactly either...' She finds a metaphor for her loneliness on the internet, a fixed camera on a Finnish street in the middle of the night and watches 'cars entering and leaving Kotka, or just the empty road in the dead times.' She imagines - pure DeLillo - 'that someone might masturbate to this'.

In this state, ascetic and delusional, she becomes fascinated with, and unsure of, the boundaries of the self. The author has been criticised in the past for not creating 'rounded' characters though the precise point of his characterisation has often been to show an individual - Lee Harvey Oswald in Libra is the prime example - not as a fixed point but a series of desperate and dissolving gestures. The Body Artist takes that idea to its logical extreme: by the end of the book, in performance, Lauren achieves literal shape-shifting, becoming, briefly on stage, someone entirely other.

This process begins in earnest when, convinced that there is someone else in the old house, she walks into a little-used room one day to find a boy seated on the bed. She is unsure if he is a ghost, or a 'foundling', or an externalised embodiment of her loss, but he speaks in a voice uncannily like that of her late husband. At the heart of the novel are Lauren's conversations with the boy, which she tapes, and interrogates, a kind of fragmentary pillow talk from beyond the grave, or from back in time, or an inspired act of mimicry. The boy, is an 'as if', he exists only in relation to other references, and in him time has slowed to a full stop.

DeLillo enjoys the possibilities of this suspension of reality. 'The world is full of abandoned meanings,' he wrote in White Noise; 'Believe everything,' says a a character in Underworld, 'Everything is true.' Here he focuses that sense on the personal and the intimate, brings it to bear on the strained moments in which selfhood might slip through our fingers. In doing so, he fumbles for something archetypal - Cathy Earnshaw or Tennyson's Mariana in her moated grange are not far from Lauren as she listens to her unreachable house guest 'shadow-inching through a sentence, showing a word in its facets and aspects, words like moons in particular phases'.

'I write to find out how much I know,' DeLillo is fond of saying, in his rare interviews. 'The act of writing for me is a concentrated form of thought.' This is a book, more than any of his previous work, that confronts how much he doesn't know, and the ways in which concentrated forms of thought might let you down. The result is a novel that is both slight and profound, a distilled meditation on perception and loss, and a poised, individual ghost story for the twenty-first century.

DeLillo: the facts

Born 20 November 1936, New York

Novels Americana (1971) The Names (1982) White Noise (1985) Libra (1988) Mao II (1991) Underworld (1997)

DeLillo on his work 'Silence, exile, cunning... I've always liked being relatively obscure. I feel that's where I belong, that's where my work belongs'

On writing '[It] is a concentrated form of thinking'

On publishing 'The more books they publish, the weaker we become. The secret force that drives the industry is the compulsion to make writers harmless'

 Kim Bunce

webTitle: Observer review: The Right Hand of Sleep, Homestead, The Family Orchard

fields.headline: Everyday stories of Austrian folk
fields.trailText: In some strange convergence of fate or Zeitgeist, two of the most readable and moving novels by new fiction writers this month are set in rural Austria. As if in comment, the third novel here is a lyrical multi-generational saga of European settlers in Israel.
fields.body:
The Right Hand of Sleep
John Wray
Chatto & Windus £10, pp352

Homestead
Rosina Lippi
Flamingo £12.99/6.99pb pp207
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Family Orchard
Nomi Eve
Little, Brown £12.99, pp316
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In some strange convergence of fate or Zeitgeist, two of the most readable and moving novels by new fiction writers this month are set in rural Austria. As if in comment, the third novel here is a lyrical multi-generational saga of European settlers in Israel.

The title of John Wray's The Right Hand of Sleep comes from a poem whose last lines are 'Coming home to you fills me/ With a vast sickness', and this is pretty much what the hero, Voxlauer, feels on coming back to his homeland, as the townspeople he grew up with begin to heil Hitler and desecrate the property of the Jewish family in town - the Ryslavys - one of whom happens to be his best friend.

The opening chapters have the excitement of discovering that Voxlauer is an emblem of twentieth-century history: he deserted from the First World War after being forced to shoot an Awol soldier, and made his way to Russia. A traumatised teenager, he was taken in by a woman relieved to be rid of her battering husband; after she and Voxlauer become lovers, she tells him they are married, and they develop a playful, happy partnership.

They believe in the socialist ideal but, like so many, they are destroyed by Stalinism. Voxlauer spends years in a labour camp. When his partner dies, broken by collective farming, he returns to Austria. He takes a job as gamekeeper on the Ryslavys' land, and despite the isolation of the property, meets a beautiful, sensitive, highly intelligent woman with a mysterious past; this makes for a more conventionally suspenseful plot when her cousin, a Nazi officer, arrives to run the town.

Like Ian McEwan's Black Dogs, The Right Hand of Sleep lays out the past century's dilemma in terms of politics versus the personal, but ultimately as a matter of happenstance rather than choice. The characters do not divide over whether the interior or exterior is the way to a better life, but, more prosaically, over whether it's OK to destroy people for a cause. Politics, in other words, is what gets in the way of our personal lives.

The book always suggests more than it states, and is at its best in the friendly insults that Ryslavy and Voxlauer exchange, in the feeling for countryside and homegrown food, and in the delicately calibrated emotional temperature of the relationships. Most of all, there is the tone, which hums along somewhere between resignation and resolution; Wray is also a poet, and it shows.

Like Wray, Rosina Lippi is an American who has spent time in rural Austria; she gives us the local, untravelled, minimally educated farm folk unsymbolically, for themselves. The 12 linked stories of Homestead, set in the fictional village of Rosenau, get immediately under the skin and pack as much punch as 12 novels, diving into the characters' most wrenching moments between 1909 and 1977.

The villagers are not untouched by two world wars, even though they still take their cows to upland meadows for the summer, make cheese, and know everyone's business and little of the outside world. Another First World War deserter comes into it: an Italian soldier who takes refuge with a hardworking farm woman. She has been spurned by all the local men because of her limp; he sees her value. Of course it is too dangerous, after they become lovers, for him to stay.

Lippi's language is as direct and elemental as the world it describes. What is extraordinary is the way it so factually evokes the wistfulness, inner corrosion, or immense tenderness of lives that are both circumscribed and rich, mundane but, over the long haul, deep in drama. You get the anthropological pleasures of literary tourism, from a sense of the high mountains in a town that is like 'living at the bottom of a bowl' to the details of how to make rennet (this involves vinegar, calves' stomachs and praying to saints). You begin to feel that you yourself are one of the people of Rosenau.

I expected to feel like one of the people in Nomi Eve's The Family Orchid - descendants of Russian Jews who have emigrated to Israel and, in the last generation, America; real people based on the author's family. Realism, however, is not her thing; this is a work of magic realism, the mysticism of nineteenth-century Hassidic tales wed to 1970s García Márquez and set in Israel. The book goes from Jerusalem in 1837 - where the happily married Esther carries on a lifelong affair with a baker which, to her husband's consternation, both pleases and excites him - to the present, including the author's own idealised courtship by her eventual husband.

In The Family Orchard, tree-grafting, sewing and local legends all have the power of spells. This makes courtly fairytales out of lives that, viewed more objectively, might be hard or prosaic. This could not be more of a contrast with Linda Grant's sober, Orange Prize-winning When I Lived in Modern Times. Eve shows us mainly the joyous side of Jewish life, its sensual acceptance and earthiness. Like the villagers of Rosenau, and unlike Voxlauer and company, these Israelis are neither alienated nor ironic. It is good to encounter this American view, but in The Family Orchard, it is wedded to a sensibility that some may find a little too whimsical and self-loving.

You begin to feel that you yourself are one of the people of Rosenau. I expected to feel like one of the people in Nomi Eve's The Family Orchid - descendants of Russian Jews who have emigrated to Israel and, in the last generation, America; real people based on the author's family. Realism, however, is not her thing; this is a work of magic realism, the mysticism of nineteenth-century Hassidic tales wed to 1970s García Márquez and set in Israel. The book goes from Jerusalem in 1837 - where the happily married Esther carries on a lifelong affair with a baker which, to her husband's consternation, both pleases and excites him - to the present, including the author's own idealised courtship by her eventual husband. In The Family Orchard, tree-grafting, sewing and local legends all have the power of spells. This makes courtly fairytales out of lives that, viewed more objectively, might be hard or prosaic. This could not be more of a contrast with Linda Grant's sober, Orange Prize-winning When I Lived in Modern Times. Eve shows us mainly the joyous side of Jewish life, its sensual acceptance and earthiness. Like the villagers of Rosenau, and unlike Voxlauer and company, these Israelis are neither alienated nor ironic. It is good to encounter this American view, but in The Family Orchard, it is wedded to a sensibility that some may find a little too whimsical and self-loving.

webTitle: Observer review: Disobedience by Jane Hamilton

fields.headline: Truth and deception
fields.standfirst: Jane Hamilton refracts an old story of betrayal through the lens of an unexpected third party in Disobedience
fields.trailText: Jane Hamilton refracts an old story of betrayal through the lens of an unexpected third party in Disobedience
fields.body:
Disobedience
Jane Hamilton
Doubleday £12.99, pp273
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Jane Hamilton is the chronicler of family relationships; the cartographer of the human heart. Everyday catastrophe blows apart the lives of her characters, so that pain, guilt and all the tensions and terrors of intimacy are exposed. In all her books the domestic is turned into the epic. Sorrow is a human condition. Betrayal becomes an earthquake rumbling along the fault lines of love. A depiction of one quiet tragedy becomes the map of the world. Her novels are lush, long-winded, easy to read, intense and brimming with dangerous emotions. They are melancholy blockbusters.

Disobedience tells an old story: the adulterous relationship between a woman and a man. The woman is a musician, a wife and a mother of two: Mrs Beth Shaw. The man, Richard Polloco, is a violin player who lives in a wooden cabin, wears shabby clothes and is a seductively two-dimensional cliché, like a pen-and-ink drawing of a romantic lover.

The daughter, Elvira, is beautiful and stubborn and strange; all her adolescent passions channelled into Civil War reconstructions. She dreams not of boys but of glorious slaughter. Henry, the quieter oldest child, narrates the story of his mother's long betrayal, looking back in his late twenties, on his 17-year-old self. He discovered his mother's secret, through (a postmodern touch) her emails. He's a computer buff, amiable, shy.

On the brink of troubled adulthood, he discovers his mother isn't just Mrs Shaw. She's someone else as well, someone lyrical, rapturous and besotted: she's Liza38 (the computer name Henry gave her), sneaking off to see her lover each week, deceiving her family.

The affair is imagined by the son, who constructs it from the messages he reads. He evokes for himself his mother naked, his mother joyful. The clothes she wore, the looks she threw, the way she would have smiled, the way she must have felt. The fact that the ostensible subject of the novel - a love affair - becomes refracted in this way does not matter. The real subject of Disobedience is apparently obedient Henry's relationship to his mother. He looks at her, voyeuristic, when she is unaware of his gaze. He tracks her life. He follows clues she doesn't know she is leaving. He torments himself.

The shadow subject of Disobedience is the tricky nature of truth and knowledge. We think we know a person but we know only the face we see. Like Henry's mother, we are the objects of other people's narcissistic inventions.

Hamilton is an emotional, full-throttle writer. Not for her understatement, reticence, simple lucidity. She describes and re-describes events. She seems more interested in emotions than creatures. She loves to dwell on the meaning of betrayal, or grief - on all the psychodramas of the human soul.

webTitle: Nick Cohen: the big lie about 'genuine refugees'

fields.headline: Lies for lives
fields.standfirst:
Forget about principles, asylum seekers are only welcome if they guarantee our future prosperity

Asylum myths and reality - Observer special

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Forget about principles, asylum seekers are only welcome if they guarantee our future prosperity.
fields.body:
I lay myself open to two charges when I say that the asylum 'debate' is the most shameful example of political and journalistic lying I have heard in 20 years as a reporter. The first, that I sound like a sententious saloon-bar berk, is unduckable and must be taken on the chin. The second is encapsulated by the rejoinder: what about the competition? It's ferocious, I grant you. But the merits of rival claimants cannot trump the pretence that we treat refugees decently. Since the early Nineties, grateful New Labour and Conservative politicians have been allowed to - encouraged to, in fact - get away with transparent falsehoods by media inspired by hatred of strangers (the far-Right press) and a credulous trust in authority (the BBC and ITN).

Last Sunday, Tony Blair and Giuliano Amato wrote in these pages of their detestation of 'the horrors illegal immigrants endure at the hands of the people traffickers' and promised, 'in all that we do, we will honour our obligation to provide protection to those fleeing persecution'.

It was an old, big lie, which was polished by Jack Straw at the European Union justice ministers conference in Stockholm on Thursday when he posed as a tough yet tender statesperson who wanted to be 'generous toward genuine refugees' while taking a 'tougher line' against economic migrants.

In a Westminster world where words have been yanked from their moorings to meaning, comprehension comes when you grasp that the truth is invariably the exact opposite of what is said. The leaders of the European Union have created people-trafficking gangs as surely as prohibition created bootleggers. Blair and Straw are doing everything they can to stop 'genuine refugees' finding sanctuary. As for economic migrants, we love them for their labour and taxes.

The 1951 United Nations Convention on Refugees allows the victims of political oppression to claim shelter in safe countries. Britain has been subverting its enlightened principles for years. Whenever conflicts begin, the Home Office imposes visa restrictions on the suffering countries. The persecuted who are running from Saddam Hussein or the Taliban cannot travel to Britain legally unless they have a visa.

But, and here is where the Home Office shows its slyness, we don't give visas to those who say they want asylum or are suspected by embassies of thinking of claiming asylum. As a result, authentic refugees can be slandered as 'illegal immigrants' when they arrive at Dover.

To make sure they get the message, Britain and her European allies fine the owners of planes, trains, ships, cars and lorries if they carry passengers who don't have visas. Last week the last breach in the walls was plugged when France agreed to allow British immigration officers on to the Eurostar. The various News at Tens reported the restrictions as a blow against illegal immigrants without explaining why the aliens were illegal or noting that genuine victims of persecution were among their number. I suppose I've no right to be shocked after all these years.

Desperate people take desperate measures. For want of legal means of travel, refugees have turned to smugglers and visa forgers whose businesses have been boosted by Blair and his colleagues. Not everything is going the gangsters' way. Britain now receives the greatest number of asylum applications in Europe because the far greater flow of millions from the former Yugoslavia, most of whom went to Germany, has been stemmed by the Kosovo campaign (for which the PM can take credit) and the fall of Milosevic.

The keepers of Fortress Europe remain frustrated, however, and plan to get rougher still. The French are proposing that carriers who allow undocumented refugees to travel should be fined and then made to return them to the point of embarkation. Straw, meanwhile, is demanding mass expulsions.

His hope that refugees seeking a home in Europe could be forced to live in camps in the Third World, while interior ministries decide whether they would accept them, puzzled observers. Why on earth would dirt-poor countries, which already have to look after the majority of the world's refugees, cooperate?

The short answer is that they will be bullied and bribed into compliance. Last year the European Union signed a new Lomé convention with the nations of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. They were compelled to accept the repatriation of people 'illegally present' in Europe - as asylum seekers tend to be - or lose £8.5 billion in aid and trade. The victims of the world's greatest crimes will either be sent back to face their local police chiefs or confined behind wire in neighbouring states. (The EU has told the Turks that it will finance the building of internment camps for refugees who come into their territory and promised the persecutors of the Kurds that the jails would not be troubled by UN inspectors.)

Straw will soon be free to engage in gesture politics. If a celebrity reporter finds a wounded girl with a cute face in the next Sarajevo, I'm sure she will be rushed to Great Ormond Street Hospital. If the cameras aren't there, I suspect compassion will evaporate. When you put their cruelties to the political class, you are often treated to a bluff lecture on pragmatism. We agree with much of what you say, you're told, but live in the real world, son. There's only so much immigration society can take. We're civilised people, but you should see our swinish voters. If we aren't mean, there will be a racist backlash.

The force of this argument is blunted by the generally tolerant welcome asylum seekers receive in British cities - despite the hard work of the Daily Mail, there's been nothing to compare with the fire-bombings of hostels in Germany. It is refuted by the desire of European Union governments to allow mass immigration.

The baby-boomers who are now in power have, somewhat carelessly, failed to produce enough sprogs to generate the wealth which might pay for their pensions. As this is a generation unused to privation, something must be done. Barbara Roche, the immigration Minister, who rants at gypsy mothers and presides over a system of relief which has brought asylum seekers to the edge of starvation, is therefore singing the positive virtues of economic migration.

With an ageing and declining population, Britain requires doctors, computer programmers and engineers as well as skivvies and navvies to do the dirty work. A Home Office report released last month said that about 150,000 immigrants from outside the EU will be needed every year for 20 years if the economic show is to be kept on the road. Roche was not reviled by the press. Even the Mail praised her. Prejudice must never threaten profits.

Everyone in power can empathise with people who move to make money. What they find intolerable and incomprehensible are those who run for their lives because they have made a stand on -- of all things! - political principle.

Livin' La Vida Loca with Big Willie Hague

Men don't come harder than Big Willie Hague. He's a fighting, drinking Cock of the North who can have you any day, with one hand behind his back.

But you must not go thinking that he doesn't experience spiritual moments. When he contemplates the big questions - What are we here for? Where is God? Why Archie Norman? - he turns to his pastor, Tim Montgomerie, the director of the Conservative Christian Fellowship.

Montgomerie's place at the right hand of Willie surprised many Tories. When he was elected leader, Hague had no noticeable religious convictions and boasted of his support for gay marriages, Notting Hill Carnivals, single mothers and sex before wedlock. Then he had a cool look at his activists and realised that many were in danger of being carted off to the nursing home after the next hard winter. The able-bodied minority he needed to enthuse contained a large number of God-botherers inspired by the ignorant and vicious Christian Coalition of the United States.

Montgomerie was quickly moved into Tory Central Office from where he has been correcting heretics who misinterpret 'compassionate conservatism'. Many in Britain 'heard the Ricky Martin songs and observed the multitude of ethnic faces at last year's Republican Convention' and thought that Bush and his British disciple were 'friendly to alternative lifestyles'.

'Compassionate conservatism,' he sternly reminds readers of the Renewing One Nation website, 'is actually the philosophical opposite of the social liberalism that attempts to enshrine indifference in legislation to forms of anti-social behaviour - eg, infidelity, minor crimes or drug abuse.'

If liberals are indifferent to these vices, should Conservatives enshrine their detestation of anti-social behaviour in legislation? If so, is Montgomerie sure that infidelity should be included in the list of sins? Is there not a danger that Conservative MPs - God and the News of the World alone know how many - could end up in the dock?

webTitle: Some still more equal than others

fields.headline: Some still more equal than others
fields.standfirst: Despite victories, the discrimination battle continues on all fronts, says Caroline Palmer
fields.trailText: Despite victories, the discrimination battle continues on all fronts, says Caroline Palmer
fields.body:
Twenty-five years ago a tailor called Mrs Kersten had her brief moment in the limelight when she won a landmark case and was awarded equal pay with a male colleague who had been getting more for doing a similar job.

Eleven years on, in 1987, a certain Ms White, a machinist, and several female colleagues were also involved in a key case, again supported by the Equal Opportunities Commission. They too were awarded a pay rise in line with the pay of male upholsterers they worked with. The progress of equal opportunities is slow and painful.

As the EOC celebrates the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Sex Discrimination Act, it can look back on some important achievements. But it is also positioning itself for more fights. The EOC points out that in the past 25 years the gap between the proportion of women and men in the labour market has fallen from 30 to 11 per cent. The percentage of directors and managers who are women has increased from 2 per cent in 1974 to 22 per cent in 2000.

In 1976, the needs of working parents and carers were low on the public policy agenda. Now employment law includes the right for parents to take time off after the birth of a child or if their child is unwell, and improvements have been made to maternity rights and rights for part-timers. Paternity leave and extended maternity rights are under discussion.

But there is a long way to go. More women than men are in low-skilled, low-paid jobs with little access to vocational training and education - 83 per cent of part-time workers are women, the same proportion as in 1975. At the same time, women receive only 82 per cent of men's hourly wages, a situation exacerbated for part-time women workers, who earn 61 per cent of the average hourly earnings of full-time male counterparts. In a recent European survey on equal pay, Britain came tenth out of 15 countries.

Julie Mellor, chair of the EOC, says: 'Most women are still trapped in a lifecycle of inequality: working in low-paid, low-status jobs and struggling to combine work and family responsibilities - caring for children and older relatives. British fathers work the longest hours in Europe, and many are prevented from spending time with their children. We must not think we've made it just because a few women have reached the top of their field and a few employers now offer paternity leave. The reality of most people's every-day lives is still determined by their sex.'

Baroness Helena Kennedy, chair of the British Council, says: 'The reform of working practices - for men as well as for women - is at the heart of promoting sex equality in the UK.'

Over at the Commission for Racial Equality there is a firm belief in the importance of reform in this area. The CRE is getting ready to put flesh on the bones of a new piece of legislation it is hailing as 'the biggest shift in employment practice on the race equality front for almost two decades'.

The Race Relations (Amendment) Act alters the 1976 Act in a way that will, it is hoped, turn the public sector into a model equal opportunities employer. Said a CRE spokesman: 'The 1976 Act said thou shalt not discriminate or you may be prosecuted; the amended legislation says if you are a public sector employer you must deliver equality of opportunities and here is a code of practice that you must follow.' Home Secretary Jack Straw will be publishing draft regulations for consultation this month; the CRE plans to publish the draft codes of practice in June or July.

The CRE spokesman said: 'Instead of knocking on doors and saying "could you ever so kindly work for racial equality?", we will have a code of practice that the public sector must abide by. For instance, the police will have a requirement to show that they have fully implemented equal opportunity employment practices, as well as showing an equal opportunities commitment in the way they treat the public.'

The NHS, too, will be among the public sector bodies taking a long hard look at its employment practices. Last week, the CRE revealed the details of a survey it carried out into working practices in NHS trusts in the south of England. 'The usual picture emerged,' the spokesman said. 'People say they are against discrimination, but only 10 per cent of the trusts were able to demonstrate good equality programmes. This is the NHS, which has depended on ethnic minorities to carry the service.'

The newly formed Disability Rights Commission is young enough still to be bright-eyed and bushy tailed in its approach to pushing through reforms in the workplace. Against the background of the Disability Discrimination Act, the DRC has launched its first major initiative, 'Actions Speak Louder Than Words', part of which involves approaching companies and asking them to make a commitment to promoting equality of opportunity for the disabled over and above the requirements of the Act.

The argument the DRC is presenting to business is that there are 8.5 million disabled people in the UK with a combined income of £40 billion a year. So it makes good business sense to be seen as disabled-friendly, as well as demonstrating admirable social responsibility.

Organisations backing the campaign include Microsoft, Lloyds TSB, the Halifax, transport company Arriva and the TUC. Microsoft's commitment involves links with online recruitment company Totaljobs.com and disability charity Leonard Cheshire to launch a web-based service for disabled people seeking a new career. The site is expected to open in early summer. The Halifax has committed itself to increasing the number of people with learning disabilities it employs, initially at its head office.

The initiative underlines the DRC's emphasis on communication as well as litigation. DRC chairman Bert Massie says: 'We have learned a lot from the EOC experience. We have not had to be so litigious: we started out with statutory codes of practice, so have not had to rely so much on case law.'

But there is nothing quite like statutory clout to improve an organisation's powers of persuasion. Massie gives an example of a restaurant that refused entry to a blind person because of their guide dog. Instead of taking the restaurant to court, the DRC persuaded it to pay £500 and also allow a DRC team to come in and talk to their staff. This duly happened; the staff were shown the error of their ways; and now the restaurant happily welcomes blind people.

DRC helpline: 08457 622633; EOC helpline: 0161 833 9244; CRE helpline: 0207 932 5437

Opportunities galore

A free service aimed at small businesses, offering information and advice on what the law says about equality in the workplace and how to implement equality policies has just been launched. Called Equality Direct, it is confidential and comprises a telephone advice line and a supporting website.

The service is provided by a consortium experienced in giving advice on equality issues and managing advice centres. It includes DLA, an international law firm, and BSS, a telecommunications provider. The service has been designed in partnership with the Small Business Service, Acas, the Federation of Small Businesses, the CRE, the EOC, the DRC and the Department for Education and Employment.

The telephone advice line is open Monday to Saturday, 8am-8pm, Sunday, 10am-4pm. Call: 0845 600 3444; or visit www.equalitydirect.org.uk
