More women than men are in low-skilled, low-paid jobs with little access to vocational training and education - 83 per cent of part-time workers are women, the same proportion as in 1975. At the same time, women receive only 82 per cent of men's hourly wages, a situation exacerbated for part-time women workers, who earn 61 per cent of the average hourly earnings of full-time male counterparts. In a recent European survey on equal pay, Britain came tenth out of 15 countries. Julie Mellor, chair of the EOC, says: 'Most women are still trapped in a lifecycle of inequality: working in low-paid, low-status jobs and struggling to combine work and family responsibilities - caring for children and older relatives. British fathers work the longest hours in Europe, and many are prevented from spending time with their children. We must not think we've made it just because a few women have reached the top of their field and a few employers now offer paternity leave. The reality of most people's every-day lives is still determined by their sex.' Baroness Helena Kennedy, chair of the British Council, says: 'The reform of working practices - for men as well as for women - is at the heart of promoting sex equality in the UK.' Over at the Commission for Racial Equality there is a firm belief in the importance of reform in this area. The CRE is getting ready to put flesh on the bones of a new piece of legislation it is hailing as 'the biggest shift in employment practice on the race equality front for almost two decades'. The Race Relations (Amendment) Act alters the 1976 Act in a way that will, it is hoped, turn the public sector into a model equal opportunities employer. Said a CRE spokesman: 'The 1976 Act said thou shalt not discriminate or you may be prosecuted; the amended legislation says if you are a public sector employer you must deliver equality of opportunities and here is a code of practice that you must follow.' Home Secretary Jack Straw will be publishing draft regulations for consultation this month; the CRE plans to publish the draft codes of practice in June or July. The CRE spokesman said: 'Instead of knocking on doors and saying "could you ever so kindly work for racial equality?", we will have a code of practice that the public sector must abide by. For instance, the police will have a requirement to show that they have fully implemented equal opportunity employment practices, as well as showing an equal opportunities commitment in the way they treat the public.' The NHS, too, will be among the public sector bodies taking a long hard look at its employment practices. Last week, the CRE revealed the details of a survey it carried out into working practices in NHS trusts in the south of England. 'The usual picture emerged,' the spokesman said. 'People say they are against discrimination, but only 10 per cent of the trusts were able to demonstrate good equality programmes. This is the NHS, which has depended on ethnic minorities to carry the service.' The newly formed Disability Rights Commission is young enough still to be bright-eyed and bushy tailed in its approach to pushing through reforms in the workplace. Against the background of the Disability Discrimination Act, the DRC has launched its first major initiative, 'Actions Speak Louder Than Words', part of which involves approaching companies and asking them to make a commitment to promoting equality of opportunity for the disabled over and above the requirements of the Act. The argument the DRC is presenting to business is that there are 8.5 million disabled people in the UK with a combined income of £40 billion a year. So it makes good business sense to be seen as disabled-friendly, as well as demonstrating admirable social responsibility. Organisations backing the campaign include Microsoft, Lloyds TSB, the Halifax, transport company Arriva and the TUC. Microsoft's commitment involves links with online recruitment company Totaljobs.com and disability charity Leonard Cheshire to launch a web-based service for disabled people seeking a new career. The site is expected to open in early summer. The Halifax has committed itself to increasing the number of people with learning disabilities it employs, initially at its head office. The initiative underlines the DRC's emphasis on communication as well as litigation. DRC chairman Bert Massie says: 'We have learned a lot from the EOC experience. We have not had to be so litigious: we started out with statutory codes of practice, so have not had to rely so much on case law.' But there is nothing quite like statutory clout to improve an organisation's powers of persuasion. Massie gives an example of a restaurant that refused entry to a blind person because of their guide dog. Instead of taking the restaurant to court, the DRC persuaded it to pay £500 and also allow a DRC team to come in and talk to their staff. This duly happened; the staff were shown the error of their ways; and now the restaurant happily welcomes blind people. DRC helpline: 08457 622633; EOC helpline: 0161 833 9244; CRE helpline: 0207 932 5437 Opportunities galore A free service aimed at small businesses, offering information and advice on what the law says about equality in the workplace and how to implement equality policies has just been launched. Called Equality Direct, it is confidential and comprises a telephone advice line and a supporting website. The service is provided by a consortium experienced in giving advice on equality issues and managing advice centres. It includes DLA, an international law firm, and BSS, a telecommunications provider. The service has been designed in partnership with the Small Business Service, Acas, the Federation of Small Businesses, the CRE, the EOC, the DRC and the Department for Education and Employment. The telephone advice line is open Monday to Saturday, 8am-8pm, Sunday, 10am-4pm. Call: 0845 600 3444; or visit www.equalitydirect.org.uk

webTitle: How to tell if you are a bully

fields.headline: How to tell if you are a bully
fields.trailText: 1 Don't believe your own propaganda. Few people seen by colleagues as bullies recognise themselves as such . But someone must be doing the bullying: 47 per cent of workers questioned by the TUC say they have witnessed it. 'Most perpetrators are managers,' concludes the TUC research. Victims were likely to experience autocratic, divisive management.
fields.body:
1 Don't believe your own propaganda. Few people seen by colleagues as bullies recognise themselves as such . But someone must be doing the bullying: 47 per cent of workers questioned by the TUC say they have witnessed it. 'Most perpetrators are managers,' concludes the TUC research. Victims were likely to experience autocratic, divisive management.

2 Look out for a psychological trait in you which creates the right environment for bullying: a feeling that someone else is responsible for your difficulties. 'The one consistent theme of most power games is blame,' write Kay Douglas and Kim McGregor in their book Power Games (Women's Press, £8.99). 'Blaming other people locks us into a place of powerlessness.' Once you perceive yourself as a victim, you can feel justified in giving other people a hard time. Most bullies will believe they have strong moral defences for their behaviour, perhaps viewing themselves as perfectionists who are right to shout at subordinates.

3 Understand that bullying is the emotional equivalent of physical violence. Rather than letting other people develop naturally and make their own decisions, bullies will use emotional techniques to set up their own control system over others. To justify such invasions, bullies develop a moral code in which they say things to themselves such as 'X deserves to get the cold shoulder' or 'Y ought to understand that she cannot make mistakes.' The result reduces someone's confidence by making them feel ashamed.

4 Don't assume that all bullying takes the form of public humiliation. Sulking, sarcasm and ignoring people also undermines them. Former Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson was famed for his icy expressions of contempt - behaviour which seems to have left him virtually friendless in his time of crisis. Read up about being assertive and co-operative if you want to reduce the chances of your bullying others: you will gradually become more direct, diplomatic and non-judgmental. A tendency to bully is exaggerated under pressure.

5 Ask yourself if you feel unhappy about major aspects of your life. Douglas and McGregor say bullies 'often feel out of control... victim to outside forces such as other people's "bad" behaviour'.

6 Make sure you know what matters in your workplace if you are a boss. Bullies are usually surrounded by sycophants too frightened to tell them the truth.

webTitle: Sharp suit at the sharp end

fields.headline: Sharp suit at the sharp end
fields.standfirst: Going back to the floor was not light entertainment for Safeway boss, says  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: Going back to the floor was not light entertainment for Safeway boss, says Heather Connon
fields.body:
Simon Laffin is finance director of the Safeway supermarket group. You might expect him to start his day by leaving his executive saloon in his company parking space and walking along a carpeted corridor to his spacious, private office.

But for three months at the end of last year it was nothing like that. On a bad day, it took Laffin half an-hour to walk the 60ft to his desk. By the time he got there, he could have sorted out everything from finding a replacement for a member of staff who had gone off sick, a repair to a key piece of equipment, or dealt with a couple of customer complaints.This was because Laffin had gone 'back to the floor' for real, running one of the group's stores.

As finance director, the issues he has to deal with are crucial to the company - how should its borrowings be structured, what impact will its promotional campaign have on profits. But they are problems that are soluble and Laffin had the time to solve them.

In store, it was different. A woman who could spend more than £5,000 a year at the store had hit her car on a kerb in the car park and wanted Laffin to foot the bill for repairs; a bomb scare at a neighbouring premises meant stock could not be delivered; the in-store bakery could not make bread because a huge delivery of promotional goods was blocking the path to supplies. All those issues had to be dealt with immediately but there was no easy solution.

'Everyone at the top thinks they know how their business works, but 99 per cent of them are kidding themselves,' says Laffin.

Other British bosses, including Sir Neville Sims of the Carillion construction company, John Coleman of House of Fraser and Bob Baty of South West Water, have also been going back to the floor, courtesy of a BBC television series by the same name.

In that programme, the bosses spend a week at the sharp end of their business, accompanied by cameras. Some have found it a salutary experience - Luke Johnson of the Belgo chain stormed out, telling the camera man to 'stick your programme'; Dino Adriano made major changes to the Sainsbury check-out system after he spent a stint on the tills. The producers usually also tried to throw at least one spanner in the works for the boss to deal with, their response caught by the unforgiving eye of the camera.

But they were only there for a week. Laffin's experience was different and not just because it is longer: his performance would affect the company's profits. His sales were monitored daily, his profits weekly; if he fouled up it would have been spotted quickly, and that would hardly be good for the reputation of a main board director.

However, back to the floor is the wrong phrase. Laffin had never worked in a supermarket before and neither had most of the group's senior managers. The exception is Carlos Criado-Perez, Safeway's chief executive, who worked his way through a number of European food retailers, ending up at US giant Wal-Mart before taking on the Safeway job in 1999. The lack of hand's-on experience of other senior managers prompted him to start the programme of sending executives out to run stores. Laffin was the second to go and it is likely that others will follow.

Laffin has found the experience invaluable. He sums up the key benefit as altering his perception. 'When you watch the Back To The Floor programmes they always learn a lot. But some also begin to see the world through different eyes. I do now have a completely different perception of the business. The world really does look different in a store than it does in a boardroom.'

For a start, there is the communication problem. The board may decide what it wants to tell staff in the stores, but what is actually communicated to them may lose a lot in the translation. 'What matters is not what you say, but what people hear you say.'

At head office, Laffin thinks he suffers from constant interruptions. In store, however, he said ' I never had 10 minutes uninterrupted'. He may tell his office staff that he does not want any interruptions but, in a store, that was impossible. 'I could be dealing with some delicate problem and someone would burst into my office and say "Bloggs has been rude to me, what are you going to do about it?".'

Laffin was give six weeks of training - three weeks shadowing the manager in another store, two accompanying an area manager on his visits to his stores and a further week back in the store. Safeway's real store managers, by contrast, are likely to have spent their careers in a store, doing all the different jobs.

Laffin admits that his store staff probably knew a lot more than him about how it operates.

The store, in Wokingham, Berkshire, is not one of the largest in the group. 'It is not a flagship,' said Laffin. 'If you wanted someone to drive your car, what would you give him - a Ferrari or a Ford Mondeo? I know my limitations. It was more important that I do we.'

Nevertheless, he managed to improve its performance: sales growth is 3 per cent higher than it was and profits increased by more than that. Laffin admits he was lucky: the store he was running was his local, which he had been using for 16 years before he started at Safeway, so he knew the changes he would like to see as a customer. They were pretty simple.

He increased the number of promotions in the store. Safeway's strategy, since Criado-Perez took over, has been to make big cuts in the price of around 20 basic items, changing every week and varying from store to store. Research has shown that Safeway's customers love them and are irritated when the store runs out of stock. So Laffin increased the number of items on offer each week, and gave them greater prominence in the store.

Laffin's key lesson for the future is that, before any changes to the way stores operate is imposed by the centre, a serving store manager must be involved in the decision. Only he or she will be able to assess the impact the changes will have on them and their time.

And he would recommend that other companies do similar exercises - except for his rivals. He would not want them to benefit from the lessons he has learned.

webTitle: I'm scared about blowing the whistle

fields.headline: I'm scared about blowing the whistle
fields.trailText: I want to blow the whistle at work because I am suspicious about some of the things going on in our office. But I am worried that I could get into trouble with my bosses. Can we get help somewhere?
fields.body:
I want to blow the whistle at work because I am suspicious about some of the things going on in our office. But I am worried that I could get into trouble with my bosses. Can we get help somewhere?

The obvious place is Public Concern at Work (020 7404 6609), the organisation behind the Public Interest Disclosure Act. This Act came into force in 1999, giving protection to people who tried to highlight wrongdoing at work and were threatened with losing their job as a result.

Under the Act, staff are expected to raise their concerns internally first - or to go to a body such as a regulator if this is not appropriate. For example, if you worked for a law firm and suspected the senior partner of embezzling funds, you might consider approaching the Law Society. But to be absolutely sure of proceeding correctly you may want to contact Public Concern at Work first. About 300 people have made claims under the Act.

An important aim of Public Concern at Work is to help prevent problems before they arise by encouraging organisations to set up procedures for whistleblowers to talk confidentially if they are concerned about something. But blowing the whistle is still difficult in most businesses.

Legal advice from Public Concern at Work and Hammond Suddards Edge.

webTitle: Style is the key in Britain's new labour market

fields.headline: Style is the key in Britain's new labour market
fields.standfirst: Work site
fields.trailText: Young people may be wasting their time winning degrees and burdening themselves with massive debt in the process. New research has found that more firms than ever before are recruiting on the basis of an employee's 'aesthetic appeal'. Qualifications come a poor second.
fields.body:
Young people may be wasting their time winning degrees and burdening themselves with massive debt in the process. New research has found that more firms than ever before are recruiting on the basis of an employee's 'aesthetic appeal'. Qualifications come a poor second.

Many employers now expect you to have the right hairstyle and the right clothes, as well as the right accent.

'We are seeing the development of a style labour market in many growing industries,' says Chris Warhurst, who carried out the research for the Industrial Society. 'It's not just a suit that matters. It's the sort of suit you're wearing, how you wear it and how you stand, that can determine your job prospects.'

Although 'new technology', with its dotcom start-ups, has been heralded as the growth sector to replace manufacturing, the research confirms that most new jobs are still in service industries, ranging from hospitality to education. In 'post-industrial' cities such as Glasgow, 84 per cent of jobs are now in services, up from 68 per cent 20 years ago.

Among employers of new staff in growth sectors, technical skills now rank 23 out of 24 as a criteria for recruitment. 'Within significant sectors of the new economy, employers are using people who have not, in the first instance, acquired technical skills,' said Warhurst. 'Good companies will provide training to shape employees as they wish. Many more employers, however, are weeding people out at recruitment level.'

The Elba Hotel chain recruits only staff who are 'passionate, stylish, confident, tasty, clever, successful and well-travelled'. A spokeswoman for the group says: 'We haven't actually looked for people with experience, because we felt that wasn't particularly important. We wanted people who had a personality more than the skills.' All staff must have 'nice smile, nice teeth, neat hair and be in decent proportion'. Above all they must fit an 'Elba look, quite plain but neat and stylish'.

In America, firms often include reception staff in the recruitment process. If interviewees are polite to a receptionist, it is thought they will be polite to customers. The Industrial Society has found companies in Britain ringing job candidates at home to establish if they answer the phone courteously.

A Glasgow-based financial services company offers staff elocution lessons to soften their voices. Coaching for those who do not speak in a gentle 'non- threatening' accent is compulsory. Another company has prescribed vocabulary. 'Lovely' is forbidden, 'exquisite' is approved.

Discrimination on the basis of looks is not new: 500 years ago, the Jesuits declined to recruit members who had 'any notable ugliness, disfigurement or deformity'.

The Commission for Racial Equality cautions against the trend towards recruiting staff for 'style appeal'. 'There is a danger,' said a spokeswoman, 'that if employers don't use transparent criteria such as qualifications or specific skills they will not treat all applicants fairly.'

'British companies are simply prescribing how employees use their bodies to represent the company,' said Warhurst, whose report, Looking Good, Sounding Right, is published this month. 'You could argue that some professions such as solicitors have done this for a long time.'

webTitle: Style counsel: How to succeed in twenty-first century Britain

fields.headline: Style counsel: How to succeed in twenty-first century Britain
fields.standfirst: Work site
fields.trailText: 1 Have your hair styled, not cut.
fields.body:
1 Have your hair styled, not cut.

2 Wear designer, not high street clothes. It's what you wear - and how you wear it.

3 Feel comfortable eating out in a restaurant.

4 Demonstrate 'emotion management' skills.

5 Have a healthy eating plan.

6 Talk in a low-pitched voice (high-pitched voices are offputting).

7 Be well poised. Have 'open' body language.

8 Upgrade your accent, but don't speak 'posh'. The 'voice of the moment' is Zoë Ball.

9 Above all, don't have a strong Glasgow, Liverpool, or Birmingham accent. It spells career death.
